column2: PARIS, Feb. 28--A band of nine right-wing terrorists, whose reported aim was to kill Premier Georges Pompidous, has been rounded up by the police.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands (Feb. 28--The French Ambassador was called to the Foreign Office today to explain a lecture to students of the Technical High School in Delft in which he was reported to have criticized the Dutch resistance to President de Gaulle's European policies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The following are excerpts from President Kennedy's special message to Congress today on Civil Rights:

NEW YORK. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., the motion picture company, continued to operate at a loss in the second quarter of the fiscal year that will end Aug. 1, 1963, Robert H. O'Brien, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday.
PARIS, Feb. 28--France is considering a loan in francs to the United States of $100,000,000 or more as part of the developing system of monetary cooperation among the Atlantic nations.

NEW YORK. The United States lost $50, 000,000 in gold during the week ended Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This withdrawal of gold, the second $50,000,000 drain this year, dropped the nation's gold stock to $15,878,000,-I 000, the lowest level since 1939.

NEW YORK. A few weeks ago President Kennedy called attention to a directive issued by President Theodore Roosevelt that Marines should be able to march 50 miles in three days, spending no more than 20 hours on their feet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)--The President of the American Farm Bureau Federation urged Congress today to delay action on new feed-grain legislation. He charged that the Government's 1961-62 feedgrain program was partly responsible for a prospective substantial drop in farm income.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28--Alderman Benjamin F. Lewis, one of the leading Negro politicians in Chicago was found handcuffed and shot to death in his office this morning.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 28-- Commanders of South Vietnam's military forces in the Mekong River delta have developed a tendency to avoid contact with large concentrations of Vietcong guerrillas.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- A Pennsylvania law requiring 10 verses of the Bible to be read daily in public schools came under intense scrutiny in the Supreme Court today.

The late Commodore Vanderbilt, whose contempt for the public that rode his railroads helped ensure regulation of transportation, set a sour precedent for railway labor. But the latter appears determined to follow in his footsteps.

NEW YORK. The stock market extended its decline further yesterday in lively trading. Closing prices on the New York Stock Exchange were near their lows for the session, and losses of 2 or more points were pretty general.
SAGINAW, Mich., Feb. 28 (AP)--United States Dis trict Judge Frank A. Pickard, 73, whose portal-to-portal pay decision once ended a $5,000,000,000 controversy, died of cancer today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--President Kennedy, in a civil rights message of unexpected sweep, called today for new measures to protect Negro rights in voting, schools and jobs.

NEW YORK. Manipulating the hard rubber and resins used for shoe heels and soles with pigments, fillers and other chemicals, Goodyear Rubber Company scientists at Akron, Ohio, have come up with a "wood" that they predict will have a variety of uses in typical hardwood products.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The latest round of polemics between Moscow and Peking has buttressed the views of experts here that the risk between the two giant Communist nations is not likely to subside in the foreseeable future.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Dorothy Schiff, president and publisher of The New York Post, announced yesterday that The Post would resume publication on Monday.
SALEM, Ore., Feb. 28--Six weeks of hearings in the Legislature to review the proposed new state Constitution have resulted in only one point on which agreement has been reached.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28--Mickey Vernon who, like Casey Stengel with the National League Mets, is tackling the intricate job of extricating his Washington Senators from the basement in their second year in the American League, has one thing going for him.

NEW YORK. Players of the highest ex pert rank admire a good deceptive play more than any other kind; most other players consider any kind of irregular play to be an intrusion on the integrity of the game, for which reason such...
EL ESCORIAL, Spain, Feb. 28--Generalissimo Francisco Franco received quasi-royal honors today at a solemn commemoration of all the kings of Spanish history.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- A challenge to the executive powers of the President set up a clear battle line over the Wilderness Bill today.
NEW YORK. For those who admire Jack Benny, a king-sized portion of him is on display at the Ziegfield Theater.

The Caribbean Sea is a little world all its own. Once upon a time, the Caribbean was to us what the Mediterranean was to Rome--Mare Nostrum, (Our Sea). That was in the days when the Monroe Doctrine had literal meaning; when Teddy Roosevelt wielded a "big stick," and President Taft made "dollar diplomacy" with the aid of American Marines.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 --A steamship company and an airline have started a joint sea-air express freight service between the Orient and the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 28-- Olivia de Havilland stood in a cage at the Paramount Studio. Leaning on a cane, she mused contentedly over a book in her other hand. Suddenly the cage began to rock. Then the light went out. She was alone in her
STOCKHOLM. Since the Royal Dramatic Theatre of Stockholm is a grave institution, many people have been astonished by the appointment of Ingmar Bergman as executive director.

NEW YORK. The years 1910-20 are of sig nal importance in American art, marking definitely the initiation of the modern movement in painting and sculpture. This heroic period is well commemorated in a loan exhibi-...
NEW YORK. A list of 54 notable books of 1962 was made public yesterday by the American Library Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28,-- (AP)--Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee introduced a bill today proposing a limited moratorium on major rail merger decisions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Republicans sharply questioned today the motive and integrity of Howard Morgan, a Federal Power Commissioner. They accused him of "McCarthyism" in his criticism that the F.P.C. had failed to protect the public or the public utilities it is charged with regulating.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)--There are 46,000,000 school-age children in the United States, nearly 10 per cent of them in California.

NEW YORK. The National Tea Company has reported net income of $9,118,011, or $1.28 a share, for the fiscal year ended Dec. 29 1962, compared with $9,314,514 or $1.31 a share, earned in fiscal 1961, despite a gain in sales.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) Organized labor endorsed President Kennedy's Youth employment program today but called for assurance that no jobs would be taken away from adult workers.

HONG KONG, Feb. 28--Communist China's climactic outburst against the Soviet Union yesterday confirmed that the ideological break between Peking and Moscow has been the outgrowth of a serious conflict in the national aims of the two countries.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 28--India will raise taxes and customs duties and impose compulsory savings in the next fiscal year to increase the revenues of Federal Government by 2,963,000,000 rupees ($622,230,000).

WASHINGTON, Feb 28 (AP) --A Government trial examiner proposed drastic remedies today to end what he called a 35-year pattern of racial discrimination against employes of the Hughes Tool Company in Houston, Tex.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)--Antonio Carrillo Flores, the Ambassador from Mexico, visited President Kennedy today to discuss the problem of salinity in the Colorado River.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28-- A monorail syndicate offered Los Angeles County today a 49mile, $123,000,000 rapid-transit system that nominally would not cost taxpayers anything.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara indicated today that the United States would not tolerate the use of Soviet troops to put down a popular uprising in Cuba if one occurred.
NEW YORK. Politics in the Pentagon and "brochuremanship" in winning contracts are two of the issues involved in a Senate subcommittee's investigation of the socalled TFX contract.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--The Pentagon's manpower chief today labeled the draft "one of the most vital elements in our defense" and asked Congress to extend it for four years from July 1.
ATLANTA, March 1--Four major civil rights organizations announced today that they were joining forces immediately in a saturation campaign to register Negro voters in Leflore County, Miss.
NEW YORK. The New Haven Railroad wants $5,500,000 a year in public subsidies to apply against its chronic deficit from commuter operations in New York and Connecticut.
NEW YORK. The Kellogg Company reported yesterday that net income for 1962 reached $24,615,737, equal after preferred dividends to $2.71 a common share, up from $22,287,039 or $2.45 a share in 1961.
CORTINA, Italy, March 1 (AP)--Donald McPherson of Canada, with a brilliant freeskating exhibition, won the men's single championship tonight in the world figure skating championships.
The visit to this country of King Savang Vatthana and members of his Government serves to remind us of the uncertain outlook for the kingdom of Laos.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- The medical charities are comng around again for money and scaring everybody half-witted to get it. Nobody is against charity, of course, but the fact remains that the most prevalent disease in America today is not heart trouble, as so often asserted, but hypochondria.
BALTIMORE, March 1 (AP) --Archbishop Lawrence J. Shehan, spiritual ahead of Maryland's 430,000 Roman Catholics, condemned today all racial segregation and prejudice in his archdiocese.

NEW YORK. The "turn around in opera tion" of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer that Robert H. O'Brien, the company's president, forecast at a stormy stockholder's meeting on Thursday will likely include the production of more moderate-budget "specialized" films of a sort that has been scarce on the company's schedules in the last several years.

Congress has lost none of its zest for the traditional sport of baiting the Treasury whenever the latter requests an increase in the ceiling on the public debt. But it is no longer a harmless pastime for letting off steam. Now some members seem to be serious about denying the Treasury the leeway required during the remaining months of the current fiscal year.

PARIS, March 1--One old rule of civilization is that concentrations of wealth and power are, if not preceded, inevitably followed by concentrations of brains. Rome and Athens attracted artists and intellectuals. Florence and Venice saw bankers and merchants inviting painters, poets, architects and engineers. Renaissance England...

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--The Senate manpower subcommittee completed a week of hearings on President Kennedy's youth employment bill today with the measure winning almost unanimous support from witnesses.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13--As Roger Maris sees it, a mere matter of an eighth to a quarter of an inch is all that stands between him and a comeback to another big season.
LONDON, March 1--British newspapers spoke out sharply today against the veto yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Board of the purchase of three short-range British planes by Bonanza Airlines.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Senate investigators said today that Eugene M. Zuckert, Secretary of the Air Force, had used a wrong set of figures in justifying the award of the big TFX fighter-plane contract to General Dynamics Corporation.
NEW YORK. Television viewers and the National Broadcasting Company were poorly served by those who prepared last night's "NBC White Paper on Communism."

WARSAW, March 1--Poland's ruling Communist party has called for the strengthening of the nation's state-owned farms as a means of speeding modernization and increasing production of Polish agriculture.
PARIS, March 1--A mining strike halted almost all coal production in France today, in the year's first big clash between the Government and French labor.

MOSCOW, March 1--Members of the audience in the Kremlin Palace of Congresses surreptitiously glanced at each other when Premier Khrushchev mused aloud: "Soon I'll be . . . you know yourselves how old I'll be."
CINCINNATI, Feb. 28 (AP) --Eppa (Jeptha) Rixey, a lefthanded pitcher who was voted into baseball's Hall of Fame only last month, died yesterday. He was 72 years old.

NEW YORK. A "last ditch" effort to end the 84-day-old. New York newspaper strike, got underway yesterday as, representatives of the sprinters' union and eight of the city's nine major dailies met face to face.

NEW DELHI, March 1--A team of United States production experts has advised Indian producers of rifles, ammunition and other military equipment to eliminate goldplating from manufacture and to cut corners without reducing quality.

HONG KONG, March. 1--Communist China accused the Soviet Union today of jamming Peking radio to prevent the Soviet people from hearing the Chinese side in the ideological warfare between the two powers.
GENEVA March 1--The Soviet Union bluntly refused today to engage in any form of detailed negotiation on a treaty for the cessation of nuclear weapons tests.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 1 --Top executives of the Shell, Esso and Caltex oil companies met with the Prime Minister, Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, today to discuss the Government's decision to fix ceiling prices at which oil may be imported.

MADRID, March 1--A series of law decrees went into effect today aimed at welding metropolitan Portugal and Portuguese overseas possessions in African and Asia into an economically integrated monetary area of some 25,000,000 inhabitants. The first step in what is designed to be a gradual process was the introduction of a common currency throughout the Portuguese empire.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- The Administration hopes that a dozen nations will help it supply the Congo with $175,000,000 in military, technical and development aid next year to begin the conversion of the former Belgian colony into a viable nation.

NEW YORK. If one is seeking morals, there is one to be found hiding behind the displays of Meteor Aims Company of the National Sports, Vacation and Travel Show that will end on Sunday at the Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- So far, the Peace Corps has been mainly interested in its impact on developing societies around the world. But with the corps two years old today, officials are interested in what will happen on the rebound.
JERUSALEM, March 1--The touching question of Israel's relations with West Germany disrupted the annual conference last night of the National Union of Israeli Students in Tel Aviv.

TUCSON, Ariz. The economy of this state is based on the four C's, cattle, cotton, copper and climate. The climate brings people and industry into the state. As a result there is a little-heralded race among bankers for new business created by the burgeoning population. And among the pacesetters is Lewis W. Douglas.
WARSAW, March 1--A Polish-East German trade agreement calling for an 11 per cent increase in trade this year was announced today.

The United States has acceded to a Soviet request to resume the talks on Berlin. Washington emphasizes that these talks will continue to be purely "exploratory." Two years of previous talks, as President Kennedy said recently, have not been promising enough to lead to negotiations and there is no cause for optimism now.

PARIS, March 1--Political developments in three interested European countries may complicate and perhaps delay their decisions on participation in a North Atlantic Alliance Polaris fleet, diplomatic sources said today.

NEW YORK. Oliver Hailey is a young playwright with a future. In "Hey You, Light Man!" which opened last night at the Mayfair Theater, he discloses an imaginative gift expressed felicitously in terms of theater.

PARIS, March 1--Slower economic expansion in the United States this year than last year and a generally steady rate of expansion in Western Europe was predicted this week by the top economic officials of the 20 member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

NEW YORK. A newly formulated code of advertising standards was adopted this week by the Canadian advertising industry. Some Canadian adman believe the code will prove a major aid in eliminating faults and "vulgar" advertising.
PARIS, March 1--A bomb scare caused a hurried evacuation today of the military courtroom in Vincennes where nine men are on trial on a charge of trying to assassinate President de Gaulle.
LONG BEACH, Calif., March 1 (UPI)--Irish Meusel, outfielder with the New York Giants in the early nineteen twenties, died today in a Long Beach hospital. He was 69 years old.
WARSAW, March 1--Poland has settled down to work after the last good spree of the winter.
BERLIN, March 1--Rudi Heidemann, a 31-year-old Berlin businessman, found his name today in bold print on posters at public notice boards all over Schoeneberg, the West Berlin borough where he lives.
San Francisco March 1--The Brotherhood of Railway Clerks moved late today to attack the injunction that impedes its strike against the Southern Pacific Company.

WASHINGTON, March 1--The United States launched today a balloon-borne telescope to look for evidence of life on Mars from the top of the earth's atmosphere. The balloon was launched at 3:41 P.M. Pacific standard time.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) --Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy whipped out an "emphatically not" when asked today if he were planning to run for President in 1968.

NEW YORK. It begins with a walk, and ends with a walk. In between the strolls by Gerald Weems, the past rears its sordid head to menace the comfortable future he has planned for himself. Though the future survives the menace, it does not bring with it the happiness Weems had sought.

NEW YORK. "Ballet is a woman." Thus George Balanchine epitomized the art he serves in a symposium held recently at the Fashion Institute of Technology. The sympasium was one of a series of three being sponsored by the Fashion Institute and the Brooklyn Museum of Art to acquaint their students with some of the concepts, problems and personalities of the dance art.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--A tiny super-powered invader from distant space penetrated the solar system last month and crashed into the earth's atmosphere, setting off a cosmic ray shower over New Mexico.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- At least 1,000 to 1,500 persons from Latin American countries went to Cuba in 1962 to receive training in guerrilla warfare and subversion, and more are in training this year, according to United States intelligence information.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, told Congressional investigators today that the White House had never attempted to influence him.

MOSCOW, March 1--A Cabinet minister put the United States--and the Soviet people-- on notice today that the Soviet Union would buy no more United States films until American distributors accepted Russian motion pictures under the exchange program.

NEW YORK. The stock market changed its trend several times during yesterday's session, but closing prices on the New York Stock Exchange were generally lower. Price changes were mostly narrow, although a few of the more volatile issues showed losses of a point or more.
CHICAGO, March 1 (UPI)-- Old crop wheat futures rebounded from an early setback and closed firm today on the Chicago Board of Trade.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 1--The United States has been telling other delegations that it fears the Soviet Union is out to wreck the work of the United Nations 28-member Outer Space Committee.
BONN, March 1--Chancellor Adenauer's controversial Treaty of Cooperation with France cleared its first parliamentary hurdle today.

WASHINGTON, March 1--An invention of great importance to the astronaut--the parachute that brings his Mercury capsule safely back to earth--was patented this week. It will be used in May on America's fourth orbital flight.

KALA DIZA, Iraq, Feb. 28-- Mullah Mustafa al-Barzani said today that he had ordered his men to "return to their positions" to be ready to fight again if the Iraqi Government does not soon recognize the Kurds' right to autonomy.
PARIS, Feb. 28--The direction that life in France is taking is demonstrated strikingly at the 32d annual Salon of Household Arts which opened today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 --The State Department system of overseas assignment "has tended to squeeze the juices out of a man so that he could be packed, preserved and shipped about like a dried apricot," the Associate Director of the Peace Corps said here today.
NEW YORK. Mutual of New York has re ported a net gain of $60,300,000 from all operations for 1962, compared with $59,900,000 in 1961.

There are crises in a chess player's career that ,if "taken at the flood lead on to fortune." In the game below, from the interzonal playoff series now in progress at the Herman Steiner Club in Los Angeles, Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., beats back a nerve-wracking counterattack evolved by William Addison of Los Angeles.

WINNIPEG, March 1--Duff Roblin, the Conservative Premier of Manitoba who aided his party substantially in the last national election, greeted the embattled Conservative Prime Minister of Canada at the railroad station here today.
NEW YORK. Anthony Anastasio, labor boss of the Brooklyn waterfront, died early yesterday at Long Island Hospital, Brooklyn, of complications following a recent heart attack. He was 57 years old.
NEW YORK. Stockholders of the Radio Corporation of America have been receiving quarterly cash dividends of 25 cents a common share since January, 1954, when the rate moved up from 20 cents.
HOLLYWOOD, March 1-- Vote-swapping deals of outrageous proportions are indicated by this year's Oscar nominations for the best picture of 1962.

Those who dismiss as a capricious and meaningless waste of time the losing fight by Senator Joseph S. Clark of Pennsylvania to alter the size of and representation on committees of the Senate miss the point of a profoundly serious conflict.
MOSCOW, March 1--The United States has rejected a Soviet complaint against the Western ban on the shipment of "big inch" oil pipe to the Soviet Union.

The demise of the Central African Federation has long and often been predicted. It has now become a certainty. Nyasaland became a self-governing country on Feb. 1. Last week, the Northern Rhodesia Parliament asked for secession from the federation and for a new constitution.

The bombshell that de Gaulle dropped on the Common Market (the "Inner Six") by vetoing Brit ish membership caused deep re sentment among the other mem bers. All five strongly supported Britain. There was speculation that they might retaliate against France for having overridden their wishes.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 3 --Iraq's revolutionary council has guaranteed "the rights of Kurds" but a broadcast did not mention the particular right demanded by the Kurds--autonomy.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- This country's tradition of putting to the Supreme Court for decision the most fundamental and divisive policy questions is nowhere better illustrated than on the issue of church and state.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- The first big postwar tax cut, in 1948, was enacted by Congress over President Truman's veto. The second big tax cut took effect in 1954--when some of the special Korean War tax rates were allowed to expire-- contrary to President Eisenhower's budget-balancing instincts.
LIMA, Peru, March 3--Gen. Ricardo Perez Godoy, senior member of Peru's ruling junta, was ousted today in a bloodless squabble among the nation's military chiefs.
MADRID, March 3--Fourteen civilians were sentenced yesterday to prison terms of one to six years for "military rebellion" by nonviolent activities against the regime of Generalissmo Francisco Franco.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 --The bones of the man who picked the site for San Francisco and led the first Spanish colonists into northern California have been identified in an unmarked grave beneath the floor of a 315-year-old church in Mexico.

"Lost soldiers" is a term applied to scores of former French army officers who fought France's losing fight in Indochina and then sought vainly to create a French Algeria, disagreeing so violently with President de Gaulle's policy of independence that they rebelled against him under the name of the Secret Army Organization.
PRINCE ALBERT Sask., March 3--Prime Minister John Diefenbaker said today that the United States was a fickle and unreliable partner in its alliances where weapons were concerned.

Candidate Nikita Khrushchev, standing for re-election as a delegate to the Supreme Soviet (the parliament) of the Russian republic from the Kalinin electorial district of Moscow, made a speech last week to 6,000 voters in the Palace of the Soviets in the Kremlin.
WURZBURG, Germany, March 1--Of the more than 800,000 West Germans who decided to leave their country after World War II as emigrants, none has received as much attention as Dr. Elmar Herterich.

A century after the Emancipation Proclamation, President Kennedy observed last week in a special message to Congress on civil rights, "The--harmful, wasteful and wrongful results of racial discrimination and segregation still appear in virtually every aspect of national life, in virtually every part of the nation."

WASHINGTON, March 3-- The United States Department of Labor will be 50 years old tomorrow. It will celebrate here with a day-long series of events and a dinner at which President Kennedy will speak. Regional conferences and dinners will also be held in 16 other cities across the nation.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 3 --Young American officers who came to Vietnam a year ago during the first wave of the American buildup here are proud of what they have done, but they note that it has been generally far less than what they hoped to achieve.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3--Although scattered fighting continues in Katanga, this phase of the Congo problem appears to be settled as a result of the military action undertaken by the United Nations Congo force last January.
PALO ALTO, Calif., March 3 --Shipowners and union leaders ended two days of talks on automation problems here last night with the significant announcement that further talks will be held.
PARIS, March 3--The shrewdest Soviet confidence trick now being played on the free world comes in Khrushchev's skillfully conducted oil trade.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- The Government announced today it had negotiated a settlement in its long, complicated dispute with a Swiss holding company over the ownership of General Aniline and Film Corporation.
BAKWANGA, The Congo, March 1--The Congolese Army has temporarily beaten down a revolt against the Central Government's authority in formerly secessionist South Kasai province.

NEW YORK. Alwin Nikolais, a man whose imagination seems almost inexhaustible, introduced his latest dance-theater production at the Henry Street Playhouse on Friday night and proved once more that he is one of the creative talents working in the theater today.
DETROIT, March 3--One of the nation's prominent conservationists warned here that the nation was "at the crossroads" where vital decisions must be made about the future use of toxic pesticides.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- The United States may be a convenient target for working out the frustrations and disenchantments of a Latin America at the crossroads of history, but the much-maligned "Colossus of the North" remains basically the key fact in a life that the hemisphere intends to go on living.

WASHINGTON, March 3, (AP)--The Federal Trade Commission announced today an order that would stop members of the National Macaroni Association from agreeing to fix prices for ingredients of their products. The manufacturers immediately challenged the findings, calling them erroneous.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- The title of Dr.--the Ph.D. type--was once the standard handle for top brass in the Office of Education. It is no longer so.

PALO ALTO, Calif., March 3 --Scholarly analysts of Civil War political history "wrote a book" here on the Stanford University campus this weekend with the help of an audience of 500 faculty members of secondary schools, junior colleges, state colleges and universities.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- Stung by allegations at Congressional hearings, the Pentagon released today an official explanation of its award of a contract to produce the daringly designed TFX fighter plane.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- A balloon-born telescope returned to the earth's surface on Saturday after looking for evidence of life on Mars from the top of the earth's atmosphere.

NEW YORK. Four more berths in the Na tional Collegiate championship basketball tournament were fill Saturday night. Duke and West Virginia made the grade by winning the Atlantic Coast Conference and Southern Conference tournaments, respectively. Connecticut earned a place by defeating Rhode Island to capture the Yankee Conference title.

Evidently a number of people who bought securities at the end of last summer went to the recent revival of "Oklahoma" and thought of the stock market when they heard a line from one of the songs: "They've gone just about as far as they can go." NEW YORK. A report about mint produc tion in last week's column was incorrect. This was the statement that "as a result of plant expansion and improved production methods, the Philadelphia and Denver mints are now well able to take care of the ever-growing demand for coins."

PARIS, March 3--France's five partners in the European Common Market face a deep political dilemma. How they resolve it will determine the Market's future in the view of diplomatic observers closely involved.
NEW YORK. Premier Khrushchev excised from the record his 1957 promise to give the Soviet people as much meat per capita as Americans consume.
LOS ANGELES, March 3-- The Bendix Corporation is planning to sell its computer division, located in Los Angeles, to the Control Data Corporation of Minneapolis.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 (AP)-- The New York Mets decided today to dispense with the services of Gene Woodling.

NEW YORK. President Kennedy has pledged to preserve the value of the dollar in terms reminiscent of Winston Churchill's vow that he would not preside over the dissolution of the British Empire. But one of the White House's principal economic advisers has apparently decided that devaluation of the dollar should not be rejected out of hand.

NEW YORK. A plan to improve legal de fense services for indigent persons will be financed by a $2,300,000 grant from the Ford Foundation. Legal defenders may be either public employes or representatives of legal aid societies.

MOSCOW, March 3--Premier Khrushchev arrived later than expected at a polling station near the Kremlin to vote in today's local elections.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 3--A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that Communist China had conceded 750 square miles of territory under its control and had not gained any territory hitherto controlled by Pakistan under a border agreement signed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- The steady increase in the number of units of the Executive Department that have an operational function in foreign policy is a natural result of the ever-widening scope of the international problems imposed on this Government by the Cold War.
LIMA, Peru, March 3--Several hundred persons were reported today to have been killed in a landslide yesterday at Pampayacta, in the rain-swept highlands of southern Peru.
DETROIT, March 3--The Ford Motor Company announced today the development of a 600horsepower, supercharged gas turbine engine for use by the United States Army and Navy.

The Republican party is picking up recruits in the South, but in the case of some of them it ought to charge admission.

CHICAGO, March 29 (UPI) --News of a Cuban apology for firing on a United States ship brought selling into the futures market late today on the Chicago Board of Trade, carrying most grains into the loss column from stronger levels.

NEW YORK. Carnegie Hall and the inter national music organization known as Jeunesses Musicales have completed their first season of cooperation. Having presented the foreign team on Feb. 15, they brought in the American team on Thursday night.

SEOUL, Korea, March 29-- Seoul's university students, fiercely proud of their revolutionary traditions, broke almost two years of enforced silence today with a stinging public denunciation of South Korea's military Government.
NEW YORK. As the spring flood of annual corporate reports rolled in, the Oak Manufacturing Company managed to achieve a shade of difference with a five-in one format for its report.

For a few generations it aspired to the leadership of South America, and in that great continent acted as the rival to the "colossus of the north."

EDMONDTON, Alberta, Mar. 29--Speaking before huge audiences in this normally Conservative community, Lester B. Pearson, Liberal party leader, made two new campaign promises before flying west today to try to wrest votes from the new Democratic party in British Columbia.

LOS ANGELES, March 29--The Rockefeller-for-President campaign that Goodwin Knight opened here Wednesday over the objections of Governor Rockefeller was closed today, following three lengthy long-distance telephone conversations between Mr. Knight and the New Yorker.
NITEROI, Brazil, March 29 --Latin American supporters of Premier Fidel Castro debated here today a continental program of support for Cuba and the "socialist revolution in the Americas."

In this era of mass markets, it is said, manufacturers can no longer afford to send a salesman to see every prospective customer. Instead, they rely on advertising.

PALO ALTO, Calif., March 29--Harlan Cleveland, Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, said tonight that the United States had been neglecting the people under its care in the Pacific trust territory.
NEW YORK. As there will always be an England there will always be a manual typewriter, says the head of the nation's biggest typewriter manufacturer.
BOSTON, March 29 (AP) --A fire swept the Sherry Biltmore Hotel on Massachusetts Avenue, killing four persons today, and injuring at least 26. Firemen rescued nearly 100 guests.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- The scientific community was thrown into uproar this week when Congressional leaders ap-- peared at the White House and told the President that Congress might pass a bill or two by Easter.
WARSAW, March 29--Polish newspapermen welcomed today a new Government order exempting them from recent regulations for the release of information by officials.

LOS ANGELES, March 29-- A streetcar emblazoned "So Long Forever, Old Pals and Sweethearts" has been forlornly coursing Los Angeles' remaining trolley routes for several weeks, presaging a milestone in the city's checkered transit history.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--A $2,700,000,000 college aid bill was shunted aside today as President Kennedy stepped in and halted a jurisdictional battle between two House committees.
NEW YORK. A 43-minute meeting between representatives of the striking photo-engravers and the publishers made no progress yesterday toward ending the New York's 112-day-old newspaper strike.

LONDON March 29--When Harold Wilson flew to the United States today for talks with President Kennedy, he was in a far stronger position as leader of the Labor Opposition than anyone could have expected when he was elected just six weeks ago.
BAKERSIFLED, Calif., March 29--Is the politics of the nation's most populous state --as a sage once has said of another field--"too important to be entrusted to professionals?"

BALTIMORE, March 29 (AP) --A group of researchers at the Johns Hopkins University said today that they had captured on film the formation and removal of free-floating cancer cells in the blood stream.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has proposed "major surgery" on the Kennedy budget.

In the Counting House (Dec. 13)--Conventional theme, trite treatment. Ran four performances.

William Harvey Allen, 89, founder and director of the Institute for Public Service, Feb. 23 in New York. A political reformer, he publicized waste and frauds in Government operations. He was secretary of the New York City Civil Service Commission from 1934 to 1937 and was the author of "Why Tammanies Revive."

At a meeting of the Common Market's finance ministers a few days ago, Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France confounded the prophets by failing to demand controls over American investment. Instead, he postponed the issue by merely asking for a study of investments by outsiders in the Common Market.
General Andre Puget, chairman and chief executive officer of Sud Aviation, announced over the weekend the start of a campaign to expand production of twin-engine, fan-jetpowered Caravelles.
GUATEMALA, March 31-- Friends of Colonel Enrique Peralta Azurdia, who became Guatemala's chief of state today, look forward to a period of the strictest discipline.

Because of its inexcusable evasion of fiscal responsibility, the Legislature--no matter what else it may do the next few days--cannot claim to have faced up to the needs of the people of New York. But, as it prepares to adjourn, it could still to some degree improve its record if it were to act on a few controversial issues.
WASHINGTON, March 31, Peanuts are political news again, and the Administration wishes they weren't.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, CALIF., March 31 (AP) --Fifteen pilots have been named as candidates for jobs as astronauts. One is a Negro--the first to be chosen as a trainee for the United States manned-space program.
Terence Rattigan has written a new drama, "Man and Boy," to open here Nov. 12 with Charles Boyer starred. It is possible that the star will also act in the screen version.

Investment and business expansion in the European Economic Community will be discussed by European and American legal and financial specialists at a conference in Washington on April 8 and 9. The conference, sponsored by George Washington University and the Commerce Clearing House, will be held in the university's National Law Center.

The number 13 provided a theme Sunday afternoon for the final concert of the Friends of Live Music's first season at Town Hall. Eric Simon conducted a chamber orchestra in two works: Mozart's Serenade in B flat for 13 Winds and Alban Bergs Chamber Concerto for Violin, Piano and 13 Winds.
The strange malady of negativism afflicting Washington these days is jeopardizing a vital project in defense of the Western World--the proposed nuclear force for the North Atlantic alliance.
MADRID, March 31--The entire Spanish press reported without comment today that a hostile group of students had demonstrated before the United States Consulate in Valencia yesterday.

CLEVELAND, March 31 (UPI)--Mayor Ralph Locher's demand for non-stop negotiations to end the 123-day newspaper strike here paid off early today with agreement between the striking printers and the publishers.

The fate of Mayor Wagner's bills to give the city power to increase its retail sales tax to 4 per cent, double its cigarette tax to 4 cents a pack and impose an occupancy tax on commercial tenants remained in doubt at Albany yesterday.

Although all of the relevant statistics are not yet in, there is no doubt that the economy survived the rigors of the winter in pretty good shape. Its performance has... banished most of the recession blues that have been haunting businessmen since the crack in the stock market last year. It may not be long before the prevailing note is one of enthusiasm about the prospects for growth.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 31--Two of Europe's top Alpine racers, Jos Minsch of Klosters, Switzerland, and Barbi Henneberger of Munich, Germany, finally scored in the Harriman Cup races today.
Louis Harris, the public opinion analyst, no longer will do any polling for political candidates or political parties.

A city sales tax increase to 4 per cent, a doubling of the cigarette tax to 4 cents a pack and the imposition of an occupancy tax on commercial tenants was recommended by Mayor Wagner on March 24.

DETROIT, March 31 (UPI)-- Alex Faulkner and Bruce MacGregor tipped in third-period goals in a 41-second span tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 4-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. The Hawks' lead in the four-ofseven-game, Stanley Cup semifinal series was cut to 2--1.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- One has to have a program to understand a show now playing on Capitol Hill.
A far-reaching effort to keep the services of The New York Times flowing to the public was maintained throughout the newspaper blackout in New York.
The shutdown of New York City's major newspapers caused losses ranging from $190,000,000 to $250,000,000 to business, labor and government, depending on varying appraisals.

WASHINGTON, March 31--The Government moved today to enforce its policy of preventing Cuban refugees from using United States territory to organize or launch raids against Cuba. The Justice Department placed restrictions on 18 Cubans in the Miami area.
The 114-day-old New York newspaper strike came to an end shortly after noon yesterday.
In his budget message on Jan. 18, President Kennedy called for a "program carefully designed to provide a major impetus to the solution of a selected number of critical educational problems."
CHICAGO, March 31--Chicagoans will go to the polls on Tuesday for a mayoralty election in a mood of stale fatalism.
The city is getting a $1,000,000 annual windfall from the Coliseum, which the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority built reluctantly to meet the desperate need for a major exhibit hall here.

The Bargain Box annual theater benefit will take place at the Thursday evening performance of "Hot Spot," starring Judy Holliday, at the Majestic Theater. Tickets may be obtained from Mrs. Gillette Boland at 232 East 62d Street.
Chess enthuiasts of California, sparked by the generosty of Mrs. Jacqueline Piatigorsky, have committed themselves to big-time sponsorship.

In some segments of the advertising world Hazel Bishop, Inc., is known simply as "that roving lady." The big cosmetics company has changed agencies four times since the start of 1960. Now it is roving again.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- The United States will have enough natural resources for at least the rest of the century to meet the demands of an increasing population and a rising national economy, it was reported today.

PARIS, March 31--The United States now has probably the biggest Foreign Service in the world--but certainly not the best. In fact, our diplomatic corps is a prime example of Parkinson's Law that bureaucracy breeds more bureaucracy.

The military coup in Guatemala spells danger for all of Central America and will send shock waves deep into South America. Every indication points to this as an example of the sort of reaction by the extreme Right that all authorities on Latin America have been fearing. It is an attempt to answer the Leftism symbolized by Fidelismo but is a swing to the other extreme.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- The Soviet Union's "friendship pipeline" through Eastern Europe is straining friendship in the West.
The New York City Ballet, which has called the City Center its home since 1948, will have a new landlord next year.
WASHINGTON, March 31--It is too early to cheer, but the first omens suggest that the country has finally had enough of the Civil War.

In his third and final concert with the Symphony of the Air, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, Walter Kappesser conducted the New York premiere of Licinio Refice's "Lilium Crucis," a dramatic cantata concerning St. Maria de Gesu.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- The ouster of the Guatemalan Government of President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes, an authoritarian but constitutional ruler with a long record of active anti-Communism, has created a difficult problem for the United States. It faces the question of how to deal with situations where political democracy is being sacrificed in the name of anti-Communism.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)--President Kennedy is expected to step in this week to block for 60 days the threat of a nationwide railroad strike.

With the large-scale western coming back into style (for example, Cinerama's "How the West Was Won"), Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, Warner Brothers and Richard Aldrich have joined forces to produce a high-budget outdoor drama called "Two For Texas." It is from an original story by Mr. Aldrich.
Dr. Robert M. MacIver was appointed acting president of the New School for Social Research yesterday.

The costly, indeterminate antiCommunist war in South Vietnam focused new attention during the last four months on the expense and risks of United States involvement throughout Southeast Asia. The Times characterized a report by a Senate group led by Majority Leader Mansfield as a well-rounded survey.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., March 31--Hearings on three petitions arising from charges of segregation in Lincoln Elementary School here are scheduled to start tomorrow before the State Education Department.
GREENWOOD, Miss., March 31--A Federal court will receive a request tomorrow that could lead to the most serious challenge yet faced by this city in its racial crisis.

President Kennedy visited Strategic Air Command Headquarters at Omaha Dec. 7, then flew on to inspect the Los Alamos weapons laboratory. The next day he saw the Nevada nuclear weapons-testing range.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- Most members of Congress who report their expenditures for overseas travel in "counterpart funds" have actually been spending American tax dollars. The total spend last year was approximately $250,000.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 31 --President Joao Goulart of Brazil and the coordinator of the Argentine Peronist movement, Raul Matera, conferred here last night on Argentina's political problems.
THE N.B.C. Opera Company completed the first half of an interesting and ambitious project yesterday afternoon: it presented Bach's "St. Matthew Passion" as a television show.

Andrew Wyeth, that painstaking microscopist of the familiar, is having a large exhibition of dry brush and pencil drawings at the Morgan Library, Madison Avenue and 36th Street. The drawings show how carefully he carries a precarious insight along with him to encage it in the finished picture.

CAMBRIDGE, MASS.--March 31--The increasing interest in the world-wide movement for Christian unity received fresh impetus last week when a Roman Catholic Cardinal attended interfaith discussions at Harvard University's Divinity School.

President de Gaulle's "grand design" for an independent Europe under French leadership clashed with the will of most of his allies, provoking a crisis in the Atlantic alliance that capped international affairs as 1962 was ending and the new year beginning.
The likelihood of Federal control over boxing was enhanced yesterday after a New York State joint legislative committee recommended that the sport be continued here under more stringent regulations.

The principal event to have shaken the Western Alliance during the past three months was President de Gaulle's open break with the AngloAmerican concept of the Atlantic community. The easing of tension that followed last October's Cuban crisis continued. The Times observed that nothing had really been settled in Soviet-American relations, but we share President Kennedy's hope that wide areas of agreement and cooperation can still be found between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- New drug--resistant strains of malaria have appeared in two areas of the world. They threaten to break the limited control that has been achieved since World War II over this most prevalent infectious disease of man.
New crime prevention techriques that "will surpass the dreams of even a comic strip cartoonist" were promised yesterday by Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy.

With today's issue, The Times is resuming publication in New York after a strike that closed this city's major newspapers for 114 days, the longest and costliest labor-management dispute in the history of the New York press. Throughout this period our most earnest desire has been to obtain a reasonable and speedy settlement so that we could once again carry out our public responsibilities.

The Green Bay Packers retained the National Football League championship by beating the New York Giants, 16-7, on a particularly cold and bitter last Sunday of December. A blankettoting, beflasked crowd of 64,892 that had hoped to see the Giants avenge their humiliation of the previous championship game returned home disappointed.
LONDON, March 31--The basement storerooms of Sotheby's Bond Street auction house, crammed like the closets of an eccentric collector, are taking on a new luster this week.
NEWBURY, England, March 31 (Reuters)--Gen. Sir Harold Edmund Franklyn, who commanded Britain's "underground" force during World War II, died here today. He was 77 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31--India has obtained a credit of $67,500,000 for improvements on her railway system. The money, from the International Development Association, will be used this year for work on India's 35,395-mile rail system.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- Congressional leaders hope to make a little progress this week on President Kennedy's legislative program.
JERUSALEM--(Israeli Sector), March 31--The chief of Israel's security services has resigned in the controversy over the German scientists working for the United Arab Republic.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31--Samuel Paley, retired Philadelphia manufacturer and philanthropist, and a former member of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died here today at his summer home. He was 87 years old and lived in the Philadelphia suburb of Chestnut Hill.

The Metropolitan Golf Association will conduct its first tourney of the 1963 season on May 3. This will be the William D. Richardson Memorial, named in honor of the late sports writer of The New York Times.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 1--South Korea's civilian leaders agreed today to discuss with the country's military rulers a plan for a temporary coalition government.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31--Jay Hook today became the first Met pitcher to go nine innings this spring as he hurled New York to a 6-to-1 victory, over the Kansas City Athletics before 1,304 fans at Al Lang Field. Hook struck out nine and walked one.
ALBANY, March 31--The Legislature has disposed of relatively few major issues in the 11 weeks since it convened Jan. 9.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 31 --Taking full advantage of some fine pitching and even finer hitting, the New York Yankees shed their springtraining wraps today and displayed their habitual world championship form. It was virtually the first time this season that the Yankees looked like the Yankees.
The eighth annual Heart of America Ball, which aids the Heart Fund, will take place in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria on Tuesday, April 30. It is being sponsored by Schenley Industries.

A 114-day New York City newspaper strike began on Dec. 8 when printers walked out at four of the city's nine major dailies. The five other papers shut down voluntarily, although one of these. The Post, resumed publication on March 4. The stoppage ended yesterday.
CLEVELAND, March 31 (UPI)--The Santa Clara Swim Club of California retained the Amateur Athletic Union women's national swimming championship today, scoring 113 points in the four-day meet.

The shipping industry is increasingly concerned over the mounting cost of seaman's illnesses and injuries, and has called on the unions for support of legislation establishing uniform physical fitness standards under United States Coast Guard supervision.

LONDON, March 31-A politically crucial national budget, one that is expected to include generous tax cuts, will be presented to an anxious Parliament on Wednesday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31--Marvin Eugene Throneberry became the symbol of the New York Mets last season. Even his initials spelled out Met. Businessmen who have been worried about a crackdown on expense account living can breathe a bit easier. The Internal Revenue Service issued its new rules on expense account tax deductions over the weekend and they are less drastic than many had expected.
TOKYO, March 31 (AP)-- Indonesia's Charge d'Affaires in Peking charged today that the International Olympic Committee was "imperialist in character," the New China News Agency reported.

The forces arrayed against indefinite continuance in power of the military junta in Korea grow steadily more formidable. Old-line political groups and the United States Government have voiced their opposition; now the students of Seoul University describe South Korea's military government as "corrupt and inefficient" and denounce the junta's efforts to keep office "by unreasonable methods."
WASHINGTON, March 31-- The Secretary of the Interior, Stewart L. Udall, made clear today that he still wanted a national seashore on Fire Island in New York State.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- President Kennedy has established a ten-member commission to encourage more people to vote in national and Congressional elections.

In times many years ago, when the late Ely Culbertson was the most widely followed bridge authority, there were many odd bidding conventions put out as trial balloons in the Culbertson system, and most of these conventions were soon withdrawn because they seemed too difficult or because players of that era disliked all artificial conventions.
A television quiz show entitled "100 Grand," which would offer contestants $100,000 in cash, is listed on the American Broadcasting Company's tentative program schedule for next fall.
Lynn Farnol, a public relations director for motion pictures and other enterprises, died Saturday of chronic nephritis in Presbyterian Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 430 East 57th Street.

Walking was once a pastime for British vegetarians, pickets for peace, political candidates and persons with disabled cars. But for two glorious weeks last month, a sedentary nation took to the open road.

The accelerating and expanding nature of the nation's space program was illustrated in an Administration request to Congress in January to spend some $6,000,000,000 on space activities in the coming fiscal year.
DETROIT, Tuesday, April 2 A proposed new Michigan Constitution, championed by Gov. George Romney, was apparently approved by the voters in yesterday's election.

King Hassan II of Morocco pleased lower Broadway crowds yesterday by walking part of the way in the tradiitional parade to City Hall. Later, at a news conference he promised clemency to members of the Bahai sect condemned for heresy in his country.

WASHINGTON, April 1--Harold Wilson, the new leader of Britain's Labor party, said today that if his party were in power it would be willing "at the right time, and given the right conditions" to renew negotiations for British membership in the European Common Market.
More than 3,000 donors have made possible the success of the Museum of Modern Art's $25,000,000 fund drive.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. went on trial yesterday in a $1,000,000 libel suit.
WASHINGTON, April 1 Collective bargaining in the United States is in a major transition.
Daniel J. Mahoney, publisher of The Miami News, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital while undergoing surgery for lung cancer. He was 75 years old and lived in Miami.
New York's department stores lost heavily in March, a survey by The New York Times indicated yesterday. The drop in sales was put at 10 per cent.
The bribery trial of Joseph McD. Mitchell, self-suspended City Manager of Newburgh, was adjourned yesterday in Supreme Court here when the court was informed that Mr. Mitchell had changed lawyers.

Steel production last week hit its highest level in a year. The new gain marked the ninth consecutive week-to-week advance in production, with inventory-building credited as a powerful element in the current demand.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company expects its earnings for the first quarter of 1963 to show an improvement over 1962 levels, E.J. Thomas, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday in Akron, Ohio.

Concern in this country over the continued presence of Soviet troops and arms in Cuba has tended to obscure the more basic factors making Latin America the politically critical region it is. Even if all Soviet troops were to leave Cuba, there would remain the poverty, rapid population growth and gross economic and political inequality that characterize much of South and Central America and render it so easily subject to Communist and other totalitarian penetration.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 1 Syria declared a state of emergency today and imposed an 18-hour curfew in Damascus after Nasserite riots. The Nasserites were defying the army's "no demonstrations, no pictures, no slogans" order.

A group of Senate Republicans has introduced a sheaf of civil rights bills which top anything we have seen thus far in the new Congress. New York's two Senators, Javits and Keating, are in this group. So are Case of New Jersey, Scott of Pennsylvania, Saltonstall of Massachusetts, Kuchel of California, Beall of Maryland and Fong of Hawaii.

TO most observers in Africa, Joshua Nkomo, South Rho desia's national leader, has long seemed to be a quiet man, a passionless, mellow soul who would never hit a policeman. But he did hit one, and yesterday was sentenced to six months' imprisonment at hard labor.
PARIS, April 1 The French coal strike, now in its fifth week, appears to be drawing to a close. The mine unions and officials of the National Coal Corporation have arranged to meet tomorrow morning.

NEW YORK. Oliver Hailey is a young playwright with a future. In "Hey You, Light Man!" which opened last night at the Mayfair Theater, he discloses an imaginative gift expressed felicitously in terms of theater.
BUFFALO, April 1 State Supreme Court Justice Harry J. Forhead, who was chairman of the Erie County Republican Committee from 1948 to 1956, died today in his home. He was 57 years old.
WESTPORT, Conn., April 1 This town has begun legal action to oust a group of reformed narcotic addicts from a 20-room mansion in the exclusive Greens Farms section.

BOCA GRANDE, Fla., April 1 The problem of reapportioning the legislative districts of Florida in volves a special factor to a degree reached in only one other state, California. This condition arises from the high tide of immigration, of elderly retired citizens and small business operators from other states, that for years has flowed into Florida and California.

PARIS, April 1 The Paris couture is in the throes of spring housecleaning, hiring new designers left and right. According to Robert Ricci, head of the house of Nina Ricci and president of the Chambre Syndicale de la Couture Parisienne, fashion always has to change.
There is absolutely no doubt that Shea Stadium in Flushing Meadow, Queens, will be completed before the New York Mets win their first National League pennant.
A Government-level showdown on international air fares was developing yesterday as a result of Civil Aeronautics Board action.
LAKELAND, Fla., April 1 It blew hot and cold in a matter of minutes for the Yankees today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 The Duke is coming home. The Mets announced tonight the long-awaited purchase of Duke Snider from the Los Angeles Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, April 1 On his forthcoming 22-orbit flight, Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr., the Mercury astronaut, will trail a multicolored balloon and send back a television view of the earth from more than 100 miles in space.
WASHINGTON, April 1 William L. Batt Jr., head of the Area Redevelopment Administration, was accused by two Republicans today of playing politics with the announcements of his agency's projects.
CHICAGO, April 1--A program of birth control for relief recipients in Illinois went into effect today despite pending legislation to block it.
Union employes of Macy's overwhelmingly approved a new two-year contract yesterday. During their absence for voting, the aisles of the New York store were awash with white carnations plastic ones.

THE last of the season's crop antiques shows, the New York Antiques Fair, opened yesterday with a somewhat marked difference in flavor. A show traditionally characterized by its Early American leanings, the event has gradually assumed a more eclectic character, perhaps as much because of the dearth of the native product as a still growing enthusiasm for the foreign-born.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) April 1 The Israeli political crisis over the German scientists in the United Arab Republic deepened today. Three opposition parties joined in an effort to force the calling of an extraordinary session of the Knesset (Parliament) to debate the issue.
TRENTON, April 1--The Assembly approved overwhelmingly and sent to the Senate today the controversial bond referendums to raise a record total of $750,000,000 in new state revenue.

HOLLYWOOD, April 1--An unparalled agreement between Actors Equity and the movie and television studios here is being worked out that may make Hollywood second only to Broadway as a center for legitimate theater. It will also tighten the present ties between both coasts.

Scott Brady, an actor, was among nine men barred from harness racing yesterday by the State Harness Racing Commission as the result of an investigation of alleged undercover control of horses by gamblers.

The international Cuban "solidarity conference" in Brazil last week should and would have been a fiasco. Unfortunately, it was turned into a propaganda success by the well-intentioned but misguided policies of Gov. Carlos Lacerda of Guanabara Province (city of Rio de Janeiro). The fuss made in Washington over the conference also helped to give it an importance out of all proportion to what it was going to mean.

Jonah J. Goldstein, retired General Sessions judge and onetime Republican candidate for Mayor, confirmed last night that he had resigned from the bar rather than fight disciplinary action for his role in a will case.
ALL that the conservationists want is that chemical sprays be used with knowledge of their dangerous potentials.
ST. PAUL, April 1 Karl F. Rolvaag, who has been waiting in the wings for months, took the center of the stage as Minnesota's new governor today with a conciliatory inaugural.

BRIDGEVILLE, Pa. April 1 (AP)--The Universal-Cyclops Steel Corporation announced today the purchase, for an undisclosed sum, of three steel fabricating companiies with combined net assets of $4,000,000.
WINTER PARK, Fla., April 1 Miss Lucy Baker Hufstader and George Baldwin Sharp plan to be married in June, when she will graduate from Rollins College and he from Yale.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The United States expects to go ahead with plans for economic and anti-subversive conferences with Central American governments this week ... despite yesterday's military take-over in Guatemala.
CHICAGO, April 1 (UPI) Most grain futures declined today on the Board of Trade.
THE Metropolitan Opera is not resting on its laurels in its closing weeks. Last night, for instance, it opened its next-to-final week with a stunning "Pagliacci."
A special phase of Spring lumbered into town yesterday on big elephants' feet. The circus was back.
STOCKHOLM, April 1 (AP) August Rei, exiled former Chief of State of Estonia, has died in Stockholm, where he had resided since 1940 when the Soviet Union absorbed his country. He was 77 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 1 The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee approved today two programs to provide work and training for unemployed youths 16 through 21 years of age.
Three weeks ago, 40,000,000 Nigerians were ready to do battle with Willis N. (Jersey) Jones. Today, in the 400 languages and dialects of the West African nation, the name of Jones no longer is mud.
More than 500 persons attended a funeral service yesterday for Lynn Farnol, publicrelations director who died Sat urday of chronic nephritis in Presbyterian Hospital. He was 63 years old.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 1 Representative Otis G. Pike, Democrat of Suffolk County, declared today that Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall's statement yesterday favoring a national seashore on Fire Island was a "change of position."
SAN FRANCISCO, April 1--Vigorous drives by the entire labor movement for larger wage increases and a shorter work week to help cope with unemployment were urged today.

The simmering controversy between the supervisors of state banks and the supervisor of national banks, Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon, is expected to boil over during hearings before the House Banking and Currency Committee beginning on April 30.

It is always gratifying to hear an opera singer who is as good in an intimate art song as she is in a big aria. So the recital given by Helen Vanni at Judson Hall last night was quite pleasurable, for she demonstrated equal skill in both vocal species.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, April 1 Joshua Nkomo, Southern Rhodesian African nationalist leader, was sentenced to prison today for having assaulted a policeman.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI)--Representative Otto E. Passman charged today that the United States foreign aid agency had $7,000,000,000 in unspent aid funds while asking Congress for billions more.

For some time the two major stock exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealers have gone separate ways in testing registered representatives. The hardest and most comprehensive test has been the New York Stock Exchange examination. But lately all three have been tightening their requirements in the wake of the Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into the securities business.
Cotton futures fell $1.05 to to $2.60 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Mayor Wagner opened a drive yesterday to win the Legislature's authorization for the city to enact a $1.25-$1.50 minimum hourly wage.

Augustin Cardinal Bea, one of Pope John XXIII's closest advisers and the chief Vatican spokesman on Christian unity, described the Roman Catholic Church yesterday as a centuries-old exponent of religious liberty.
A 90-cent Broadway ticket, offered as an attendance stimulant, has become a sellout item at Henry Miller's Theater.

PARIS, April 1 A wave of protest resignations closed virtually every ski resort in the Savoie Department of France today. Signs went up in hotels warning guests that the tracks were closed and that they could ski only at their "risk and peril." The resignations of Mayors, Assistant ...

In a number of editorials The Times strongly supported the efforts of the United Nations to end the secession of Katanga and to restore the unity of the Congo. We held the only alternative to be "new chaos in the Congo that could lead to a Communist take-over and even a new East-West confrontation."
The British pound firmed slightly in foreign exchange dealings here yesterday, but the market apepared to be waiting for the announcement of the British budget on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 Members of the House and Senate space committees are casting a skeptical look at an Administration proposal to establish a large electronics research center in Boston.
SEOUL, Korea, April 1 Two calm old politicians and a tense middle-aged general met in Seoul's Presidential Palace today to play an icy game of political poker for South Korea's future.

The Times recognized that President Nasser's drive for the creation of an Arab empire reaching from the Atlantic to the Persian Gulf gained new momentum from the revolutions in Yemen, Iraq and Syria. These revolutions are outspokenly anti-Communist and have brought to power, especially in Yemen and Iraq, liberal and progressive forces meriting American recognition. Nevertheless, a new Arab empire does not seem close at hand.

CARMEL, N.Y., April 1 A state "fishing for fun" experiment turned out to be all fishing and little fun for the anglers who tested it on opening day of the trout sea son today. Under pressure from sportsman's groups in Westchester and Putnam Counties, the State Conservation Department had designated the 2.8 miles of the Amawalk outlet of the Croton Reservoir an "experimental recreational stream."

With pride and some justification, New York claims to be the postwar capital of the art world. But while we add up the profits in cash and culture from the booming art business, we make it increasingly hard for the artist to exist here.

A development in Whitestone, Queens, known as the Le Havre community, has been purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation for about $15,000,000. Realty Equities is a realty development and construction company headed by Morris Karp.

MIAMI, April 1 (AP) Walter Blum, who started the afternoon with the news that he had been suspended 10 days for careless riding, won four straight races at Gulfstream Park today to increase his lead in the riding standings. It was the sixth time Blum has won three or more races at the meeting.

Mayor Wagner's $224,000,000 package of tax bills appeared yesterday to be on the way to passage by the Legislature. The bills would give the city power to increase its sales and cigarette taxes and impose an occupancy tax on commercial tenants.
Philip H. Gilsten, who was ousted as Deputy City Treasurer in 1961 by Mayor Wagnor, was disclosed yesterday to have resigned from a clerk's job that would have qualified him for a city pension.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 1 (UPI) The Government permitted today the return to Santo Domingo of Maximo Lopez Molina, who was deported last year after forming the pro-Castro, Left-wing Dominican People's party.
The Board of Education, in a new appeal for more state aid, asserted yesterday that the city school system's financial predicament was worse than had been anticipated.
BUENOS AIRES, April 1 Argentina has reached the stage of a full political crisis once more.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez will again serve as coach of the United States Davis Cup team. The winner of the world professional tennis championship in 1961, who has had virtually no tournament competition since, ...

GUATEMALA, April 1 Former President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes has been offered asylum in the United States, it was announced here today. The announcement followed the installation of a new Cabinet by the military regime that seized control late Saturday.

BALTIMORE, April 1 (AP) The Government said today it would "show influence peddling" by two former Democratic Representatives in Congress charged with conspiring with two other men to defraud the Government.
DETROIT, April 1 (AP) The auto industry started work today on the job of building nearly 2,000,000 cars in the next three months.

Record net earnings of $20,860,000 were attained last year by the Babcock Wilcox Company, according to the annual report to be released today. This is equal to $3.37 a share, and compares with $20,241,000, or $3.27 a share, cleared in 1961. Shipments rose to $330,574,000 from $319,353,000 the year before.

WHITE PLAINS, April 1--Tax abatements for the New Haven Railroad should be canceled if the line cuts commutation service further, the Westchester Board of Supervisors was told today by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian.
BRIDGE players who use artificial bids become accustomed to some process of forgetting that the artificial bid was ever made.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 1 Bolero and Escapade appeared to be playing the catand-mouse game today as they led the fleet through the Windward Passage into the final leg of the 844-mile Miami to Montego Bay yacht race.
WASHINGTON, April 1--The economy drive slackened today as the House Appropriations Committee approved the second regular money bill of the session.
The giant Bell System reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the three-month and 12-month periods ended Feb. 28.

SOME ball players were going about their chores the other day at St. Petersburg with their usual quiet efficiency. Zack Taylor permitted himself a gentle sigh. The grizzled Zack is scouting the various spring training camps for the Milwaukee Braves but he was a Dodger catcher during those glory days when they were known as the Daffiness Boys in the carefree reign of Uncle Wilbert Robinson.

In spite of Mayor Wagner's warnings for the past year, many New Yorkers were caught unprepared for his tax increase program or at least for the magnitude of it. Just ten days ago he disclosed that there would be a $235 million shortage in revenue needed to balance the executive budget he is now preparing. But because of the newspaper strike relatively few people became immediately aware of what this would mean in new taxes.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 1 Joao Neves da Fontoura, twice Foreign Minister of Brazil, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

IN a single year, The New York Times publishes more than 1,000 recipes. They run the gamut from soup to nuts or, more accurately, from first course to sweets. An effort is made on occasion to reprint the recipes that have apparently achieved the greatest favor with readers.
MIAMI BEACH, April 1 (UPI) Chris Dundee, a promoter, has come up with something he thinks will help make boxing safer 12 rounds of two minutes each.

OTTAWA, April 1 The Canadian election campaign has been remarkable for the size of the crowds that have turned out to hear the speakers and for the large numbers of undecided voters. This is ascribed to the importance of the April 8 election and the complexity of the issues that must be decided by the voters.

With the annual battle over foreign aid shaping up in Congress, The Times approved President Kennedy's action in appointing the Clay committee to take a new look at the program. But we found the Clay report disappointing. While we agreed that a tougher and more realistic foreign aid policy is desirable, we pointed out that the report's ...

We are compelled to greet with skepticism the call of the President of Indonesia for a big new national effort to rebuild his country's foundering economy. Mr. Sukarno has made similar calls in the past, and little has come of them. Economic gains that might have been attained have been nullified by government extravagance and mismanagement and by Mr. Sukarno's wild and militaristic foreign adventures.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) A "fourth branch" of the Federal Government is reported to be spending from $11 billion to $14 billion a year without any central direction of its "crazy quilt of relationships" with the states.

ABERDEEN, Miss., April 1 A Federal judge turned down today the Justice Department's request for an immediate court order prohibiting interference with Negro voter registration efforts in Greenwood, Miss.

The city is seeking an extensive revision of its leases with the Port of New York Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. It wants to 8ncrease its tax revenues from the tenants by at least $31,000,000 a year.
ALBANY, April 1 The Senate completed action tonight on a bill to eliminate the automatic death sentence for persons found guilty of premeditated murder.
L. Judson Morhouse, former Republican state chairman involved in a grand jury investigation of the State Liquor Authority, received $18,000 in fees from the owners of the Playboy Club.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 1 Wallace C. Speers, former vice president of James McCutcheon Co. and founder of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World, died here yesterday in his home at 69 Sunset Avenue. His age was 66.

BRUSSELS, April 1 Ministers of the six member countries of the European Common Market gathered tonight for their first high-level discussion of the market's future since negotiations for British entry broke down two months ago.
The Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition entered its second round yesterday with one contestant missing from the race.

THE Bharatiya Kala Kendra, a company of Kathak dancers and musicians from North India, ended its first tour of the United States last night with a performance in Kaufmann Concert Hall of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

The owner-trainer-rider combination of Jack Dreyfus, Hal Jerkens and Bill Boland, one of the more successful partnerships on the racing scene last season, had the winner of the $21,400 Correction Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

New Yorkers welcomed their regular newspapers yesterday, the first day of publication after the 114-day shutdown. A holiday atmosphere reigned among readers, workers and publishers.

THE "hire-them-young" policy that once automatically re jected older women job applicants has been losing ground throughout the nation. According to figures for 1962 just issued by the United States Department of Labor, the average age of the American working woman is 41.

The unilateral Chinese withdrawal eased tensions on the Sino-Indian border, but The Times noted as the pullback was made that a formal, permanent settlement could not yet be foreseen.
