The Royal Ballet of England will play a five-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House beginning April 17. The engagement will mark the beginning of the company's seventh tour of the United States.

CEZANNAH!" once reputedly an exclusive, highbrow Bloomsbury cry of supreme approbation, has since been taken up the world over. It can confidently be voiced at the superb loan exhibition of Cezanne watercolors opening tomorrow at Knoedler's, 14 East 57th Street, in aid of Columbia University's Scholarship Fund for the department of art history and archeology.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 1 A special General Assembly committee reported today that it had been unable to agree on how to finance the United Nations Congo force and other policing operations.
WASHINGTON, April 1--The Government is compiling a "gold budget" designed to help reduce the balance-of-payments deficit.
A new home for the New York Stock Exchange near Battery Park moved closer to reality yesterday.
Manhattan and Columbia opened their baseball campaigns yesterday at Baker Field in a fashion and a setting typical of early-season college baseball in this area.

ROME, April 1 Giuseppe Saragat, leader of the small but influential Democratic Socialist party, which takes part in the Italian coalition Government, said today that the leftwing Socialists could not formally join the Government until ...
Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter said yesterday he was "dismayed" to observe the same lawyers appearing repeatedly in behalf of defendants charged with gambling and related crimes.
ADEN, April 1 A South Arabian common market the Arab world's first became operative today in the Britishprotected Federation of South Arabia.
THE emergency measures radio and television sta tions during the newspaper blackout afforded several lessons that a viewer might hope would commend themselves to regular continuation.

Harold Wilson, Labor party pretender to the Prime Ministership of Great Britain, is of an age with John F. Kennedy, on whom he is calling today. They live though so differently in the same world. Their psychological approach is similar. They will understand each other and feel alike on basic issues, even when disagreeing on details or minor problems. Both men are superb politicians in the professional sense of that word.

The Neptune City Shopping Center, a 20-acre property on Route 35 in Neptune City, Monmouth County, New Jersey, has been sold by James D'Agostino and George Rothman. Office Buildings of America, the buyer, acquired the tract subject to a mortgage of $1,435,000. The holding price was $2,500,000.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Tuesday, April 2 Foreign Minister Quinim Pholsena was assassinated last night, official Government sources said today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 A 40-year-old man from Berkeley, Calif., vacationed at Zermatt, Switzerland, for a week in February. He flew home, passing through quarantine without incident. On March 1, three days after leaving, he came down with typhoid fever.
WASHINGTON, April 1 Seventeen heavily armed Cuban exiles planning to attack a Soviet tanker off Cuba were seized yesterday by a British force on a solitary islet in the Bahamas chain.
What in the world is the odd-lotter up to these days? He has been selling stock on balance for eight straight months a remarkably long stretch that encompasses a dynamic winter recovery.
Stock prices rose moderately in active trading yesterday. They were led by a strong automotive group.

IN some thirty years of trout fishing I've never met a fisherman who had a good word for an April 1 opening day. But no real trout fisherman is able to pass it up, and all of them have foolproof excuses for not hooking a fish.

The election of Howard J. Morgens of Cincinnati as a member of the board of the General Motors Corporation, effective May 1, was announced yesterday. Mr. Morgens is president of the Procter Gamble Company and has been a director of that company since 1950.

JAMES THURBER (1894-1961) the Thucydides of the War Between the Sexes, left us a magnificent legacy of laughter. We can best appreciate how he created it by reading his "Credos and Curios," a wonderful collection of random pieces "hitherto uncollected" that trace the whole course of his career.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 1 (AP) Lee Roy Jordan, an allAmerica center, and four of his Alabama teammates testified behind closed doors today to a legislative committee investigating charges of a football fix.

An entire performance of "Antony and Cleopatra," to be staged in Central Park by the New York Shakespeare Festival, will be televised over Channel 2 on June 19. The two-and-ahalf-hour telecast, which stars Michael Higgins and Colleen Dewhurst in the title roles, is expected to begin at 7:30 or 8:30 P.M.
LONDON, April 1 The Labor party published today proposals for a "radical reconstruction" of Britain's social security system to give workers a minimum of half pay when retired, ill or unemployed.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 1 (UPI) The Leon County School Board filed in Federal Court today an integration plan calling for the opening of all first grades to Negro and white pupils starting next year.

HACKENSACK, N.J., April 1 Hearings on three petitions arising from charges of segregation in the Lincoln Elemenary School in Englewood began in Bergen County Courthouse today before the State Education Department.
ALBANY, April 1 The State Thruway Authority opened a new attack today on two of its old enemies billboards and flashing signs.
WASHINGTON, April 1--President Kennedy has found another admiral, Jerauld Wright, to replace Adm. Alan G. Kirk in the difficult post of Ambassador to Nationalist China.
PARIS, April 1 The French Government emphatically rejected today Soviet protests over the treaty of cooperation between France and West Germany.

The Department of Agriculture will boycott the shipping line of Manuel E. Kulukundis, which is threatened with bankruptcy, until it demonstrates an ability "to fulfill its obligations," a Department of Justice lawyer disclosed yesterday.

NEW DELHI, April 1 The Indian Government has charged Communist China with making "preposterous and baseless allegations" to justify an "aggressive concentration" of Chinese forces on the Indian border.

MANILA, April 1 Informal discussions on the potentially explosive proposal to unite Malaya, Singapore and three British territories in Borneo in a new state to be called Malaysia are expected to overshadow the regular items on the agenda of the third ministerial meeting of the Association of Southeast Asia beginning tomorrow.
ORANGE, N.J., April 1 Benjamin Fairbanks, who retired in 1960 as president of the United States Savings Bank of Newark, died Saturday in Orange Memorial Hospital.
The over-the-counter market for corporate bonds softened yesterday. Trading in Government securities was almost at a standstill, and municipal issues continued dull.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 1 The first Negro spaceman candidate would like to be one of the first to land on the moon.

Officials of the Bulova Watch Company have been disturbed of late by the "dulling sameness" that has crept into watch advertising. In the watch business, as in many others, they noted, rival companies have tended to adopt a basically similar approach to advertising.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest transportation company, said yesterday in its annual report that the immediate outlook "contains little prospect of any considerable improvement over the disappointing results of last year."
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would hold an election on a plan that could admit as many as 151 of its 391 associate members to regular membership by the end of 1965.

WASHINGTON, April 1 Supporters of President Kennedy's urban mass transportation bill agreed today to accept a number of restrictive amendments in an effort to win Senate approval of the controversial program.
MOSCOW, April 1--The Soviet Union is striving to maintain its position in the Arab World, despite an upsurge of anti-Communist feeling there.

CHICAGO, April 1--The president of the National Association of Broadcasters strongly criticized today any move that would place the length of time of television commercials under the supervision of the Federal Government.

Wall Street is wondering where the public has been hiding. Although stock market volume has averaged a hefty 4,000,000 shares daily since the start of the year, the non-professional investor has only nibbled at stocks.

LIZA MINNELLI made her New York theater debut last night in a revival of the musical "Best Foot Forward" at Stage 73.

NEW DELHI, April 2--A high-powered mission from the white house is seeking an answer here to the delicate question of how the United States can use its influence to prod India and Pakistan toward a settlement of their dispute on Kashmir.
GREAT NECK, N.Y., April 2--The Sperry Gyroscope, Company demonstrated today an anti-collision system for airplanes that it hopes to convince the Government should be flight-tested.

Twelve persons, including a Deputy State Superintendent of Banks and five former Internal Revenue Service employes, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of defrauding the Government of $1,500,000.

IF any citations are handed out to public officials on the basis of their willingness to make hard, unpopular decisions, then Albert M. Day, executive director of the Pennsylvania Fish Commission, wins hands down.
Stanley Broff, who in 1930 built the six-story apartment house at 320 West 90th Street, adjoining the southeast corner of Riverside Drive, has sold it ...

Three warrants for the arrest of Harry Wismer, former president of the New York Titans of the American Football League, were ordered in Criminal Court yesterday after Wismer had failed to appear for trial for nonpayment of city taxes.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 2-- Judge Marcelino Romany, who broke the tension at the 1952 Republican National Convention with his call for a poll of Puerto Rico's three-man delegation, died last night of cancer. His age was 71.

The proposed $550,000,000 Monterey Gas Transmission Company project was abandoned yesterday. The plan aimed at setting up a complicated system of distributing natural gas outside the jurisdiction of the Federal Power Commission.
Oil, which has long been used to supply heat, transportation and light, may one day be used as food.
The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday the start of the initial phase of primary aluminum production by its Australian affiliate.
BRUSSELS, April, 2--The European Economic Community started moving forward again today after two months of stagnation brought on by France's veto of Britain's entry.
New York City's revenue from its retail sales tax was higher during a period that included nearly three months of the news paper shutdown that it was a year earlier.
LONDON, April 2--With the announcement of the new British budget only hours away, buyers became cautious in trading on the stock market here.
CHICAGO, April 2--The nation's railroads announced today that they would make sweeping changes Monday to eliminate "featherbedding."
The Western Electric Company, Inc., reported yesterday that it stepped up 1962 sales to the parent Bell System by 12.3 per cent. At the same time it cut sales to the Government by 14.8 per cent.

A New York man said last night that his 36-foot boat, the Violin III, had been used repeatedly in Cuban exile operations, often with the advance knowledge of the United States Government.
ROGER PENSKE of Gladwyne, Pa., Dan Gurney of Costa Mesa, Calif., and Robert Holbert of Warrington, Pa., were America's outstanding road-racing automobile drivers in 1962.

A LARGE retrospective exhibition by Herbert Fer ber, a leading member of the New York School, opens at the Whitney Museum of American Art today. His latest work is currently at the Emmerich Gallery, 17 East 64th Street.

The margin was small--apparently less than 11,000 votes in a total of more than a million and a half cast--but by that margin the new state Constitution sponsored by Gov. George Romney has won an impressive victory in Michigan.

Trading in Argentine pesos was suspended yesterday in the wake of the revolution in that country. Brokers here said that since trading was suspended and some banks in Buenos Aires were closed, there was no way of knowing what the peso was worth.
CHICAGO, April 2 (UPI)-- Soybean, oats and wheat futures dropped today on the Board of Trade.
The Lincoln Center's longawaited theater repertory company plans to make its debut in October in a 1,200-seat steel tent in Washington Square.
The P. Lorillard Company is expected to report record firstquarter sales and increased earnings. The company also is acquiring a 50-per cent interest in a European cigarette manufacturer in June.

Following are excerpts from a presentment made yesterday by Attorney General Eugene Cook of Georgia to Gov. Carl E. Sanders in the charges involving Wally Butts, the former University of Georgia athletic director.
WASHINGTON, April 2--Congressional investigators and officials of the A.C. Nielsen Company quarreled today over "editing" of data collected from radio surveys.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I. April 2--Dirt carried by the wind from open potato fields here was described today as containing enough arsenic and other insecticide residues to be harmful for human breathing.

WASHINGTON, April 2-- The chairman of the New York Shipping Association predicted today that there would be another longshoremen's strike next year on the East and Gulf Coasts if Congress did not provide for compulsory arbitration of maritime labor disputes.
Columbia Records plans to record the complete works of Eugene O'Neill--44 plays.

In a desperate appeal to the Governor and the members of the Legislature, Board of Education President Max J. Rubin has warned that, unless emergency financial aid is given to the city schools, education services will not only not be improved but instead will deteriorate.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The Air Force is learning that it apparently got a pig in the poke in receiving permission to participate in the civilian space agency's Gemini man-in-space program.

BONN, April 2--Dr. Carlo Schmid, a vice president of the West German Parliament and an authority on the law, declared today that West German scientists helping the United Arab Republic develop armament were violating the West German Constitution.
Bertram Wolff, board chariman of the H. Wolff Book Manufacturing Company, died Sunday in Madrid while on a trip. He would have been 65 years old on Friday.
A high Ford Motor Company spokesman said yesterday that there was a "real possibility" of three consecutive years in which automobile sales would exceed 7,000,000 units a year.

WASHINGTON, April 2-- The United States disclosed today that a Cuban rebel raiding boat was seized in Miami last Sunday just as a British force was capturing another armed vessel belonging to an exile group.

A new proposal put before the Legislature by Governor Rockefeller would "increase taxes for all employers by approximately $75,000,000 a year," according to a statement a state advisory body has sent the legislators.

BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, April 3--An anti-Peronist military uprising against President Jose Maria Guido's Government yesterday brought a fierce twohour battle between rebel navy planes and loyal tank columns before the revolt appeared to fade.
EUGENE ORMANDY and the Philadelphia Orchestra turned back the clock almost 30 years last night by presenting at Carnegie Hall the sort of program that was immensely popular in the nineteen-thirties.

The board named by Mr. Kennedy--an unusually distinguished one--will go over ground already covered exhaustively by the special commission...
WASHINGTON, April 3-- The Administration has drawn some comfort from the kind of event that, in the simpler days of cold warfare, sent shudders through Washington.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., April 3 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Van Orman of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Van Orman, to Robert Frank Brown of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Emmett Brown of Avondale, Pa.

A Federal Bureau of Investigation agent was beaten severely and stripped of his pistol yesterday while observing a funeral gathering outside a Brooklyn church. Four men who attended the funeral were arrested.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3--The major producing and consuming countries are expected to hold a negotiating conference this year for an international agreement on cocoa, similar to those regulating such other important commodities as coffee, sugar and tin.

ALBANY, April 3--The Legislature will complete action tomorrow on a bill that Governor Rockefeller says will give New York the most powerful weapon of any state against racial discrimination in private housing.

TRENTON, N.J., Agril 3--A sweeping revision of New Jersey's program for aid to dependent children was advocated today to end "almost daily reports of flagrant and revolting abuses" by recipients of aid and their landlords.
BUENOS AIRES, April 3-- The Government said today that a two-day navy revolt had been smashed following heavy attacks on rebel-held installations.

CHICAGO, April 3--Gov. George Romney of Michigan made a slashing attack today on increasing encroachments on local responsibility by Federal bureaucracy. He also criticized the attitude of Newton N. Minow, Federal Communications Commission chairman, toward the broadcasting industry.
WASHINGTON, April 3-- The White House hastily rang down the curtain today on what one official described as a Pentagon comic opera.

WASHINGTON, April 3-- The Labor Department has cut back sharply on the job taining allowances it has been paying 19 through 21 year old youths who do not qualify for regular Federal training stipends.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)--The political potential of a bill to authorize compulsory arbitration of maritime labor disputes was noted today at a House Merchant Marine Committee hearing.
A formal hearing to determine which of two wives is the rightful legatee of the late theatrical impresario John Shubert was ordered yesterday by Surrogate S. Samuel DiFalco.
A new term--"commonality"--has been invoked by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara to defend his controversial award of a contract for the TFX (Tactical Fighter, Experimental) aircraft.
LONDON, April 3--Reginald Maudling, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced today tax cuts amounting to 269,000,000 ($753,200,000) in a budget geared to the theme of "expansion without inflation."
ALBANY, April 3 (AP)-- Fewer New York voters enrolled in the major political parties last year, but the Democrats managed to increase slightly their numerical lead over the Republicans.
MANILA, April 3--Three Southeast Asian countries, Malaya, Thailand and the Philippines, laid the foundations for a Fax Eastern counterpart of the European Common Market today.
Lawrence E. Peterson, a consulting engineer, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Idlewild Airport. He was 65 years old and lived at 1060 Park Avenue.
ALGIERS, April 3--Premier Ahmed Ben Bella declared today that "cooperation" with France would not hold back Algeria's march toward "socialism."

WASHINGTON, April 3--An official of the A.C. Nielsen Company said today that if in his company's broadcast rating samples New York's five boroughs were replaced with another area of the same population, the result of the survey would show "not very much" difference.

FORT MYERS, Fla., April 3 --Suddenly plagued by countless Yankee injuries of varying magnitude, Ralph Houk decided to put full pressure on his reserve squad today. He fielded a team that included only two regulars --Joe Pepitone and Elston Howard.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3-- Contrasts were offered in the preliminary to the Masters golf tournament today. George Bayer, 245 pounds, defeated a Formosan, Chen Ching Po, 140 pounds, in a playoff for honors in the competition over a miniature par-3 layout.

CINCINNATI, April 3 (AP) --Bob Cousy, competing in his 100th National Basketball Association playoff game, sparked a late first-quarter surge tonight that gave the Boston Celtics a permanent lead as they defeated the Cincinnati Royals, 128--110.
The Government securities market moved forward in slightly more active trading yesterday, while corporates and municipals appeared to have cast off some of their recent listlessness.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 3 --A mother and her three children died early today when fire destroyed their two-story home on Eastlake Boulevard in Morris Township. Only the father escaped.

SEOUL, Korea, April 3-- The United States has quietly decided to reduce economic grants to South Korea, a country whose economy is heavily based on such assistance.

The United States Lines Company increased operating earnings 23.6 per cent last year on a 12.3 per cent gain in voyage revenues from 1961, John M. Franklin, chairman, reported in the annual statement for release today.
WASHINGTON, April 3-- The House Rules Committee broke a deadlock today and released for floor action a $205,700,000 Administration program to aid medical education.

PARIS, April 3--Plans for shipping four of Europe's fastest trotters to Yonkers Raceway were announced here today by Stanley Tananbaum, the chairman of the raceway's executive committee.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and the police are investigating the possibility that two men arrested Wednesday outside a Manhattan bank intended either to kidnap or kill Sidney Slater or one of Slater's relatives.

PARIS, April 4--Effective progress in defense planning in the last year was reported today by military advisers of they Southeast Asia Treaty Organization. They had been reviewing defense problems in the treaty area.

The Golden Anniversary of America's wedding with modern art, an arranged marriage that has survived some violent ups and downs, will be celebrated tonight with a party at the spot where vows were first exchanged 50 years ago, the Armory of the 69th Regiment, Lexington Avenue and 25th Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4-- Closer cooperation of independent labor groups--"brothers in exile from a once great organization"--was predicted today at a biennial convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

WASHINGTON, April 4-- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz has named a 15-member National Advisory Committee on Equal Opportunity in Apprenticeship and Training.

MELBOURNE--John McEwen is known as the Turbulent Trade Minister From Down Under. After his determined fight against Britain's joining the European Common Market and for compensating trade preferences for Australia, trade officials in London and Washington are likely to shudder at the mention of his name.
Plastic, a "jack of all trades," has found an additional occupation--it is now being used to cover the roots of cotton plants.
LONDON, April 4--Prices declined slightly on the stock market here today in reaction to yesterday's announcement of the new budget.

Mayor Wagner asked Governor Rockefeller yesterday to, veto a bill, pushed through the Legislature this week, that would sharply restrict the use of state park funds for the development of parks in New York City.

IT was the turn of Thomas Schippers to continue the procession of New York Philharmonic guest conductors. He began a two-week stay with a program that contained one world premiere--"Andromache's Farewell," by Samuel Barber.

The first chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission yesterday described a proposal to construct a nuclear power plant in Queens as "a very risky business."

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 4-- Premier Souvanna Phouma announced today that he had acted to halt armed clashes between rival groups of soldiers in northeastern Laos. He said about 20 lives had been lost in skirmishing since last Saturday.

Directors of W.R. Grace Co, increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday with the declaration of 25 cents a share. It is payable June 10 to holders of record of May 14. In preceding quarters, shareholders received 22 cents a share.
The Japanese television industry, one of the liveliest aspects of Japan's phenomenal post-war boom, is planning to use the forthcoming Olympic Games in Tokyo as a show-case for its wares.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the nuclear physicist who was declared a security risk by the Atomic Energy Commission in 1954, has been chosen to receive the highest honor the commission confers.
Roy Wilkins, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has denounced antiSemitism among Negroes as "senseless hatred."

WASHINGTON, April 4--A Presidential advisory group called today for lighter Federal penalties against small peddlers and "victims" of narcotics, coupled with a "massive attack" on importers and large distributors of illegal drugs.

KATMANDU, Nepal--Political peace resulting from the calling off of rebel activity by the exiled Nepali Congress party may mean a stepping up of developmental activity in Nepal this year.

HONG KONG--The largest hotel outside the North American Continent will open here in April, a $14,000,000 wager by two wealthy Texans that Hong Kong will maintain its independence of China for the foreseeable future.

A State Supreme Court jury awarded $211,500 yesterday to a Harlem widow who had charged that Representative Adam Clayton Powell defamed her by calling her "a bag woman for the Police Department."
Japan's sewing-machine industry ranks 14th as an export earner. In 1961 exports totaled $43,602,000, for 1,666,210 units, half of which were shipped to the United States.

The Times' illuminating survey last week of "Asia in Transition" showed that Asia as a whole is still falling behind in the race to increase production in proportion to its rising population. In such a life-or-death commodity as food it produces only a fraction of 1 per cent more a year to feed 2 per cent more people. The result is that its already ill-fed masses are eating even less than before.

VANCOUVER--It's about time for the whaling boats to put out to sea again, but whether they venture into the rough North Pacific is still in doubt. Last year, after a two-year hiatus, whaling out of Coal Harbor, on Vancouver Island, was resumed.
Bertrand Russell's letter on this page reflects an unfortunate and--despite his eminence as a philosopher--an unthinking receptivity to the most transparent Communist propaganda.
The children of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue held another Model Seder yesterday to demonstrate the ritual Passover meal to their non-Jewish friends.
MOSCOW, April 7--Soviet artists and writers are no longer mixing socially with Westerners in Moscow as they did before Premier Khrushchev disciplined the liberal intellectuals last month.

Twelve major American Jewish religious and secular organizations were prepared yesterday to rush 16 tons of matzohs by chartered plane to Moscow because of a Soviet ban on baking them for Passover. The feast begins at sundown today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 7 (UPI)--Carlos Ortiz of New York successfully defended his world lightweight title tonight by scoring a technical knockout aver Doug Vaillant, as exiled Cuban, in the 13th round.
Within the next 60 days, Broadway between Canal and 14th Streets will be converted from two-way traffic to oneway southbound, Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday.

CARACAS--The Latin-American oil picture for 1962 showed marked improvement over the previous year.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) --President Kennedy is ready to throw the traditional first ball tomorrow when the Washington Senators and Baltimore Orioles open the American League baseball season in the nation's capital.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 7--Eight weeks of inten sive training that began with the advance camp on Feb. 11 ended for the Yankees today on a rather dismal note.

NEW DELHI, April 7--Walt W. Rostow, chairman of the State Department's policy planning staff, was on his way to Washington tonight after his visit to India and Pakistan to report to President Kennedy on how the United States can inject new life into the Kashmir negotiations.

WASHINGTON, April 7--Memo to all candidates for Academy Awards tomorrow night:

IN the spring, when shoots start sprouting, nothing sprouts faster than asparagus. It beats the mushroom at overnight appearances, growing as much as 10 inches in a single day. Thousands of children had a glorious time at the Ringling Bros. and Barnum Bailey circus yesterday, spending as much of their parents' money as they could extort in three hours.

Mayor Wagner showed up late for a Liberal party celebration yesterday, but he bore a gift--a Criminal Court judgeship for the party's New York County chairman.

HOLLYWOOD, April 7--Hollywood will hand out its annual Oscars tomorrow night for the 35th year. The gold statuettes, highest artistic awards of the American movie industry, have been voted on by some 2,300 members of the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Cocoa futures soared and world sugar made a solid advance in heavy trading yesterday. Most other commodities traded on exchanges in New York also rose but dealings were quiet.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 8--Five persons were shot to death and two were seriously wounded early this morning by a man who broke into his estranged wife's home here and opened fire with two revolvers.
A bankrupt travel agent whose Passover tour of Israel was described as "nothing more than a pipe dream" has been barred from the travel business in the state for three years.
WASHINGTON, April 8--The profits of manufacturing companies rose sharply in the final months of last year, and set a new record in the year, the Government reported today.
Two more former Internal Revenue Service employes were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in a continuing investigation of a scheme in which the Government was defrauded of $1,500,000.

The release of the preliminary design for the new home of the New York Stock Exchange again raises a question we have raised before: how will the move away from Wall Street affect the tightly knit Wall Street community?

Mrs. Indira Gandhi, daughter of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India, shoveled the first spadeful of earth yesterday for the Pavilion of India at the New York 1964-65 World's Fair.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 8 --Laos teetered today on the brink of a new civil war. Neutralist forces of General Kong Le reeled under assaults by troops of the pro-Communist Pathet Lao army, stiffened by an illegal cadre from Communist North Vietnam.
A late surge by the Canadian dollar marked trading on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday as returns began to trickle in from the national elections in Canada.

LONDON, April 8--Stocks turned slightly dull on the stock market here today. Most leaders declined a few pennies.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, the world's largest producer of sulphur, which occupies the 55th floor of the Pan Am Building at 200 Park Avenue, has taken 15,100 square feet more on the 56th floor. The company now has 51,000 in the new skyscraper.

Bart Starr of the Green Bay Packer's officially won the National Football League's passing title, according to statistics released yesterday.

Rudolf Bing announced the Metropolitan Opera's plans for next season yesterday and disclosed that he had a new contract, which called for his services as general manager of the opera until the end of the 1967 season.

WASHINGTON, April 8-- The United States said today that Communist forces were guilty of "a serious violation of the cease-fire" in Laos. Western diplomacy swung into action to forestall a major crisis in Southeast Asia.

The number of educational television stations rose by 12 to a high of 75 in 1962. It was the biggest annual increase since non-commercial video began more than 10 years ago. Included in the new outlets was New York City's first educational station, WNDT.

AN urban outdoors miscellany: All winter long hundreds of fat canvasback ducks have lived along the edge of the Hudson River betwen 72nd Street and 158th Street. The last of the flocks are still there, diving each day, peacefully housekeeping. Numbering perhaps three dozen, they show no intention of moving north. The drake outnumber the hens four to one. No one seems to know why.

WASHINGTON, April 8--A labor dispute almost kept President Kennedy from celebrating the traditional rites of spring today. But expert pinchhitting by Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz permitted him to open the big-league baseball season as usual.

Passover, the Jewish holiday commemorating the liberation of the ancient Israelites from Egyptian slavery, began yesterday at sundown.

THE bright young designer who usually has more talent than money is finding it easier to survive in the world of fashion. He is, according to Wesley Tann, no longer afraid to march to the sound of his own music.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, after long hesitation, has decided to produce the twin-jet DC-9, a short-haul airliner. The plane will carry 56 to 83 passengers over routes as short as 100 miles. The maximum length of routes will be 1,000 miles.

New first-quarter records in revenues, sales and net income have apparently been set by General Telephone Electronics Corporation, Donald C. Power, chairman and chief executive officer, told an overflow meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

Today is the tenth anniversary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, established by the Eisenhower Administration in furtherance of the constitutional obligation to "promote the general welfare." In that decade total spending of public and private funds for schools, hospitals, relief, social insurance and other welfare functions through Federal, state,...
A demonstration at graduation exercises for 192 probationary firemen here yesterday provided an unrehearsed glimpse into the perils of the real thing.
WASHINGTON, April 10---- The "Peace on Earth" encyclical of Pope John XXIII was greeted with unusual warmth and interest here.

The prosecution's cash in the trial of Joseph McD. Mitchell suspended City Manager of Newburgh, N.Y., on charges of bribery and conspiracy, is expected to be completed in State Supreme Court here early next week. There will be no trial session tomorrow.
Is advertising becoming too arty? Some ad men think so. Only yesterday one agency president charged in a speech that the "Museum of Modern Art" school of advertising was wasting clients' money.
LONDON, April 10 (UPI)--Sir Winston Churchill, smoking a cigar, toasted his honorary United States citizenship with champagne tonight and prepared to depart on a vacation to the Riviera.

The Wheeling Steel Corporation's announcement Tuesday that it was raising its prices by an average of $6 a ton seems to have left most of the country's other major steel producers speechless, at least as far as public statements are concerned.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 11-- Bertin C. Gamble, president, of Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., failed to appear at his company's annual meeting here yesterday, and the officer conducting the session refused to comment on the company's interest in the Alleghany Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- The hectic effort to bind the Western alliance militarily has produced multitudinous proposals for multilateral, multinational and other multifarious projects.
The Board of Higher Education took steps yesterday to prevent a public trial of charges by two associate professors that Queens College indulged in antiCatholic practices.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 11-- James Ward, a naval sonar technician, son-in-law of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lawrence of 29 West End Avenue, escaped sharing the fate of the Thresher's crew because of the timing of his orders.

American Airlines, Inc., and Eastern Air Lines disclosed yesterday they plan to renegotiate the terms of share exchange in their proposed merger if the Civil Aeronautics Board approves the consolidation.

A sane approach to the narcotics problem and to treatment of the addicts has now been urged by two groups working independently of each other--the President's Advisory Commission on Narcotics and Drug Abuse and the New York Academy of Medicine. Both groups have assailed the unintelligent laws and police regulations that have long hampered efforts to develop a humane and realistic solution.
A citywide search was on yesterday for a blood donor with malignant malaria whose blood was given to a hospital patient.

KINGS POINT, L.I., April 11--A capacity gathering of 1,236 at the United States Merchant Marine Academy greeted the touring tennis professionals tonight. It was the 35th stop of the transcontinental series for the visitors and the biggest tennis evening in the history of the academy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11--Secretary General Thant hailed the encyclical of Pope John XXIII today as a "heartening and noble call" to strengthen the United Nations and remove the threat of nuclear war.

FOR millions of people, Park Avenue symbolizes the ele gance and style of Manhattan. For some it is the Rue de la Paix and the Via Veneto rolled into one. And now the street has a hotel with a lobby and dining room decorated with sufficient taste to justify the glamorous address.
LONDON, April 11-- The British Government disclosed today that it had rejected the demand of the all-white Government of Southern Rhodesia for early independence.
A modest and hopeful attempt to encourage private investment in the renovation of slum tenements--without exorbitant profits or rents--is well under way here.
LEWISTON, Idaho, April 11--The electronic computer has invaded the lumber mill.

Borough President Joseph F. Periconi of the Bronx has set an unusual precedent in reducing his $35,000 salary by 25 per cent because of New York City's financial crisis. His example is not likely to be contagious.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 11-- Erik Carlsson of Sweden, driving a white Saab, took an early lead tonight in the East African Safari rally.

Marcel Duchamp, the hero (or villain) of the 1913 Armory Show, looked over the chessboard at his opponent and played pawn to queen four. The 76-year-old artist, with his spare figure and ascetic face, looked like what St. Thomas must have looked like.
A taxpayer, with a blackened right eye, appeared yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to answer a charge of assaulting an Internal Revenue agent.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 11 (UPI)--Paul Bryant, the Alabama football coach, today filed a $5,000,000 libel suit against The Saturday Evening Post, which had published an article saying that Bryant helped rig the 1962 game with Georgia.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 9--A new political movement in troublesome Katanga is causing concern in Government circles here.
Mayor Wagner appeared last night to be headed for a collision with two of his top aides over whether the $100,000,000 Lower Manhattan Expressway should be revived.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- a bill to create a relatively small and inexpensive domestic Peace Corps was sent to Congress today by President Kennedy.
AFTER 120 years in business W J Sloane still has its corporate eye on the floors of American homes. The furniture store is doing its best to boost the use of oriental rugs in decor.

Mayflower Gardens, a group of two-story garden apartment buildings at Long Bill Road and Hillcrest Drive in Little Falls, N.J., has been bought by Mayflower Gardens, Inc., an investing client of the George, J. Wolf Realty Company of Jersey City, the broker in the deal. Little Falls Associates, Inc., was the seler.

CLEVELAND, April 11 (UPI)--Don Mossi pitched a two-hitter, drove in two runs and scored a run as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Cleveland Indians, 6--1, today to spoil the Tribe's home opener before 25,812 fans.
The resignation of Ralph W. Burger, 73 years old, as chairman of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company was announced yesterday following a meeting of directors.
BONE, Algeria, April 9-- "It's something new when you can walk in and 'buy' a $2,000,000 farm property with nothing but a one-page notice with an official seal on it."

NEW LONDON, Conn., April 11--A five-member court of inquiry was convened at the Navy submarine base here today to investigate the loss of the atomic submarine Thresher. Vice Adm. Bernard L. Austin, president of the Naval War College at Newport, R.I., heads the court.
MOSCOW, April 11--Russian Jews, many of them weeping, rendered an emotional ovation to the opening performance here last night of "The Diary of Anne Frank."
NEW HAVEN, April 9-- Scientists reported here today that they were developing a new and safe biological insecticide that "kills such pests as gypsy moths, forest tent caterpillars and inch worms."

WASHINGTON, April 11-- Rail and truck loadings ended April 6, were both slightly below the corresponding week of 1962, Truck loadings, however, were ahead of the preceding week of this year; rail loadings were below the preceding week's total because of the observance of the eight-hour-day holiday in the coal fields.

NEW DELHI, April 11-- Units of the Assam Rifles, the crack military police force of northeastern India, were rushed today to the scene of a new outbreak of Naga rebel violence north of the Manipur Road, near disturbed Nagaland.

MOUNT FERN, N.J., April 11--Brig. Gen. Norman F. Ramsey, U.S.A. Retired, former Commanding Officer of Picatinny Arsenal in Dover, died today at the Veterans Administration Hospital in East Orange. He was 80 years old and lived on Route 10 in Randolph Township.

Chileans have just held an election for municipal councilors that had considerable national significance. The three main political groups and their individual parties set out to make it a test for next year's Presidential elections.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 11-- Scenes of popular and official rejoicing in Damascus and Baghdad marked the preclamation today of a Syrian-IraqiEgyptian union.
Eddie Edwards, a founder and trombonist of the Original Dixieland Jazz Band, died Tuesday in his home at 6 Amsterdam Avenue. His age was 71.

The United States Steel Corporation late yesterday put off until after Easter any statement on the current steel pricing situation and most other major producers declined to comment on the price subject.

A lavish, new movie theater, the Trans-Lux East opened yesterday morning, with the premiere of "The Ugly American," at 969 Third Avenue, on the east side of the street directly between 57th and 58th Street.

MANY an amateur artist will color and decorate egg shells this weekend in an effort to glamorize the Easter Sunday breakfast table. This traditional use of eggs at Easter almost doubles the demand for them.
The American Bankers Association attempted yesterday to avert a clash between the Securities and Exchange Commission and banks that would like to establish two new types of common trust funds.

IN an industry long dominated by lawyers, financial experts and salesmen, William Alexander Steele, president and chairman of the Wheeling Steel Company, stands almost alone. He began his career as a laborer at the mouth of a Pittsburgh blast furnace and moved up...
WASHINGTON, April 11-- The Navy abandoned hope today for the lost nuclear submarine Thresher and the 129 men aboard.
WASHINGTON April 11--A Presidential emergency board begun efforts today to settle the bitter railroad labor dispute over work rules.
The avalanche of objections to Mayor Wagner's tax program grew yesterday at City Hall.

Moscow's decision to hold a Communist party Central Committee meeting devoted to ideological problems will strengthen the widespread Western belief that an ideological crisis exists in the Soviet Union.
The moon is probably covered with a thin layer of openwork fuzz, according to a scientist of the United States Geological Survey.
The United Fruit company suffered a sharp drop in earnings in the first three months this year from the total for the first quarter of 1962.
HOLLYWOOD, April 11--The first steps in a plan for enormous expansion of Cinerama theaters are going into effect in Hollywood, New York, England and Scotland.
The Security National Bank of Long Island announced yesterday that it planned to offer 141,519 new shares of stock to its shareholders.
WASHINGTON, April 11--Nelson Rockefeller was in Washington this week, but his old friends scarcely recognized him. He talked like Harold Stassen and acted like Dick Nixon.
The Government securities market turned upward yesterday following a two-day battering.
A drive to block a privatehousing development already under construction and save the western tip of Rockaway Peninsula for a 1,400-acre public waterfront park was renewed yesterday.
LONDON, April 11 (AP)-- Almost all political factions in Western Europe have united in praise of Pope John XXIII's encyclical on peace.
"The Bedford Incident," by Mark Bascovich, which will come from Atheneum on Monday, has a United States Navy destroyer and a Soviet submarine stalking each other off Denmark. Fiction, fortunately.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- The United States Government warmly praised today Pope John XXIII's "Peace on earth" encyclical as a historic document expressing the "desire of mankind the world over."
ABOARD THE U.S.S. HAZELWOOD, April 11--A team of geophysicists was on the way to the scene of the Thresher disaster tonight.
No dissonant voices were heard here yesterday in the chorus of praise for the new encyclical of Pope John XXIII.
I CLAIM to be the foremost freelance scug trapper in Bergen County, N.J. I've hunted scug since age 9, but so have tens of thousands of others, so I have no special claims there.
Eighty-eight works of art from 15 New York galleries were sent by van yesterday to Winston-Salem, N.C., in an unusual plan to encourage collecting.

WASHINGTON, April 11--A securities firm can be held responsible for improper activities on the part of its salesmen and branch office managers even if the culprits go to some lengths to conceal those activities, the Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today.

CORTLAND, N.Y., April 11 (AP)--The Board of Education voted, 5--2, today to discontinue educational television in the public schools of this city in central New York. Opponents labeled the project as costly and ineffective.

In the oil industry, rumors about takeovers spout forth with all the abandon of a gusher. But yesterday it looked as if one had been capped successfully by the snoopers. Informed sources identified the Sinclair Oil Corporation as the one that has made an offer to buy the Drilling and Exploration Company, Inc.

The Yankees put on quite a pre-game show yesterday at their 41st Stadium opener. They received awards of all sorts before a cheering crowd of 29, 772 chilled fans while the Baltimore Orioles stood on the sidelines in sullen silence.
THIS deal comes from the spring tournament of the New Jersey Bridge League, played at Newark last weekend.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), at a meeting in Cleveland yesterday, declared a 10 per cent stock dividend on the common shares, payable June 24 to stockholders of record of May 17. The company paid no stock dividend last year.
Cowles Magazines and Broadcasting, Inc., added new fuel to the controversy over television ratings yesterday by withdrawing as a subscriber to the research services of the A.C. Nielsen Company.
The Symphony of the Air gave a full-length Mozart program last night at Carnegie Hall with the Liszt E flat Concerto tacked on at the end.
ALBANY, April 11--An appeals court hoisted a "slowdown" signal today for commissions that appraise losses stemming from the development of New York City's water supply system in the Catskills.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 11--Secretary General U Thant said today that it was up to the nations that guaranteed the neutrality of Laos last year to "get together and find a solution" for the renewed fighting there.

ALGIERS, Friday, April 12-- Algeria's youthful Foreign Minister, Mohammed Khemisti, was shot by a Moslem assailant in downtown Algiers at midday yesterday. The bullet pierced the official's skull, and he was near death.
Stock prices rallied strongly yesterday afternoon in response to President Kennedy's relatively mild statement on the possibility of "selective" price increases in the steel industry.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)--Tom Cheney pitched a one-hitter and his batterymate. Don Leppert, slammed three home runs tonight to carry the Washington Senators to an 8-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
Park Lane Hotel (Noon)-- Fashions by Larry Aldrich and furs by Frederica will be shown in the Crystal Room after luncheon. For reservations, call the headwaiter, PLaza 5-4100.

Joseph A. Grazier, president of American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation, struck a happy note for stockholders yesterday at Carnegie Hall. He told the annual meeting of the world's largest plumbing concern that 1963 held prospects for "improved profits.

The humble shoe is very often a source of more pain than pleasure--a fact that is given abundant recognition in a forthcoming advertising campaign for I. Miller Shoe Company. The $350,000 I. Miller account, formerly at Trahey-Cadwell, Inc., has been quietly shifted to Delehanty, Kurnit Geller, Inc.

TORONTO, April 11 (UPI)-- Ed Litzenberger, filling in for the injured Frank Mahovlich, scored one goal and set up two others as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 4--2, tonight. The Leafs thus took a 2-0 lead in their National Hockey League Stanley Cup four-of-seven final playoffs.

LOS ANGELES, April 11 Lakers, back in the comfort of their home court, raced past the St. Louis Hawks tonight 115--100, to win their second straight Western Division crown in the National Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- The State Department suggested today that if West German scientists were withdrawn from rocket projects in the United Arab Republic, they might be replaced by Russians. W. Averell Harriman, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, said also that German assistance to Egyptian aircraft production was helping to reduce Cairo's military reliance on the Soviet bloc.

NEWARK, April 11--Dr. Aaron H. Horland, former president of the New Jersey Academy of General Practice, died today at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 63 years old and lived at 1 Oval Road in Millburn.
The political appeal of glamour was deplored yesterday as a basis for selecting candidates for office in views expressed at a luncheon at the Women's National Republican Club.
HELEN GALLAND has set up her own common mar ket in millinery. The members include France, Italy and, for the first time, Spain.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)--Following is the text of President Kennedy's statement on the steel price situation:

WASHINGTON, April 11-- President Kennedy indicated today that he would not fight increases in the prices of selected steel products, but warned that he was as opposed as ever to across-the-board increases.

The third annual art tour sponsored by the Cornell Women's Club of New York will be held on the afternoon of April 20. The event will benefit the Federation of Cornell Women's Clubs Scholarship Fund and the Georgia L. White Memorial Fund (student emergency aid fund).

SINCE tomorrow is the birthday of Thomas Jefferson (b. April 13, 1743), he can be legitimately discussed in a daily newspaper. By a happy whimsicality of journalism, great men of the past become news on their anniversaries.

Hyman D. Siegel, who was a law associate of Louis J. Lefkowitz for 27 years, declared yesterday that Mr. Lefkowitz, on being elected State Attorney General in 1957, told him: "Don't come near me ever."
The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the city had rightfully denied a cabaret license to the Playboy Club, at 5 West 59th Street.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)--The wife of Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court said today that she planned to divorce the justice, whom she married eight years ago when she was his research assistant.

The Board of Education clarified its policy on school zoning yesterday in an attempt to end a controversy that has embroiled the Brooklyn communities of Brownsville, East Flatbush and Canarsie for more than three months.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- Senator Jacob K. Javits charged today that to transfer the New York regional office of the Internal Revenue Service to Boston "is like asking the camel to swallow the elephant."

IT was cold and windy for the baseball opening at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. But it had been cold and windy there for the football closing less than four months ago, an unforgettable day of paralyzing frigidity as the Packers beat the Giants in the National League championship playoff. It was the memory of that numbing occasion, however, that made yesterday seem bearable.

Friedrich Durrenmatt's "The Physicists" will be put on in November at the ANTA Theater. Mr. Durrenmatt is best known here for his stirring drama, "The Visit," in which the Lunts appeared. "The Physicists" is currently in London under the auspices of the Royal Shakespeare Theater.

United Air Lines announced here yesterday it would file a petition today with the United States Court of Appeals in Washington to restrain the National Mediation Board from holding a representation election among 12,700 United employes.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- Naval officials ruled out today the possibility that the sinking of the nuclear submarine Thresher had been caused by an accident in her atomic power plant.

BALTIMORE, April 11 (AP)--Mrs. Judy Devlin Hashman of England and three other seeded players in the women's singles entered the quarter-finals of the United States open amateur badminton championships today.

A SECRET AGENT, says Christopher Felix in his "A Short Course in the Secret War,"* is "a species of legal criminal." That is, he is authorized by his own government to behave in a manner that another government may regard as totally illegal and punishable with death.
World sugar and cocoa futures rose and potatoes fell in active trading yesterday. Most New York commodities were stronger in heavier dealings.
A little railroad that operates a mere 70 miles of main line, the New York, Susquehanna Western, came under new management yesterday.
TWO viewpoints on the joys of boating in New York Harbor and its tributary waters reached this mooring the other day.
A converted troop transport that served in two wars began life anew yesterday as the world's largest and most sophisticated missile-tracking ship.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 11--Gov. Richard J. Hughes warned today that he would demand the adoption of a statewide sales or personal income tax next January if New Jersey voters rejected his proposed $750,000,000 bond issue.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- The bathyscaph Trieste, long the deep-water stepchild of the Navy, was summoned from the West Coast today to aid in the search for the Thresher.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 11--The man who gave football the three-platoon system and the Chinese Bandits is pondering whether to abandon his creations.
PARIS, April 11--The United States decided today to push ahead in creating a North Atlantic alliance nuclear force, including France, despite French objections.

BIL and Cora Baird, whose attractive marion ettes helped erase the image of the ugly American during a recent cultural tour of India, Afghanistan and Nepal, opened their latest box of holiday bon-bons yesterday at the Biltmore Theater.

ON Wednesday night there was a Poulenc memorial concert in Carnegie Hall. Last night the New York Philharmonic also paid tribute to the composer. One of the Poulenc works had originally been announced. It was the world premiere of the "Sept Repons des Tenebres," which had been commissioned by the Philharmonic in celebration of its opening season in Lincoln Center.

WASHINGTON, April 11--It is too much to hope that, instead of coming to the conference table on the Berlin problem tomorrow with "position papers" re-extracted from the deep freeze, Secretary of State Rusk and Soviet Ambassador Dobrynin will put at the top of the agenda a speech on the subject made in the Senate today by Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., April 11--William H. Crow, senior member of the New York architectural firm of Crow, Lewis Wick, 200 Fifth Avenue, died today at Georgetown Hospital in Washington. He was 59 years old and lived at 297 Glen Avenue here.
A major reorganization at New York's educational television station, WNDT (Channel 13), resulted yesterday in the ouster of Richard D. Heffner, its vice president and general manager.
The Coast Guard is extending its experimental TV "stage" in New York harbor.

Issued statement on steel price situation; issued statement over loss of the nuclear submarine Thresher; sent Congress amendments to his fiscal 1964 budget; sent Congress his proposal for a domestic Peace Corps; flew to Palm Beach for Easter holiday.
Raphael R. Abramovich, a leader of the Russian Democratic Socialists, the Mensheviks, died yesterday in his home at 511 West 113th Street. He was 82 years old.

The six-story apartment building with self-service elevator at 147-05 Sanford Avenue in Flushing, Queens, has been purchased by Sydney M. Siegel for cash over mortgages amounting to $597,000. The building contains 61 apartments. It was sold through the Philip Fogel Company, broker. The seller was a client of Isaac Handler, lawyer.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- The Kennedy Administration's plan for "a tax cut on the installment plan" will prove inadequate to "put new muscle in the economy," the president of the Chamber of Commerce said today.
The Crucifixion of Jesus Christ on Calvary will be solemnly commemorated today-- Good Friday--in the churches and cathedrals of New York.

Television executives at the Columbia Broadcasting System are getting younger all the time. In the matter of age, this youth movement is spearheaded by 25-year-old Fred Silverman, just appointed director of daytime programs for the C.B.S-TV network.

Japan, the strongest industrial power in Asia and the fastest growing country in the world, should have much closer economic ties with the industrialized nations of the West. This is the main point made in a special study by the Committee for Economic Development, which urges that Japan be considered an "equal partner" by the United States and European nations in the development of world trade.
AMID a jungle of apparatus, machinery and human limbs, a white-maned lion of a man roared encouragement or dismay to half a dozen men and women.
The 28th annual Spring Dance for the Boys Club of New York will be held April 25 at the Plaza.

TOKYO, April 12--The loss of the United States submarine Thresher deeply shocked the Japanese Government and may delay its plans to permit docking of United States nuclear submarines in Japanese ports.
Russell A. Kimes, a vice president of the American Machine and Foundry Company, died Wednesday night at the Abraham Jacobi Hospital, the Bronx, at the age of 51.
Harried taxpayers see last minute information in this weekend before the tax return filing deadline can obtain help from Federal and state tax offices by telephone or by visiting the offices.

THE theater is in desperate need of writers with a viewpoint and a gift of eloquence, and Irwin Shaw qualifies on these two points. But being an exigent mistress, the theater also requires writers who can write in terms of the stage, and here Mr. Shaw and his "Children From Their Games" are found wanting.
The lending capacity of the nation's banks expanded in the week ended Wednesday to about the level that prevailed in February and March.

MOSCOW, April 11--The Soviet Communist party announced today that it had revised its May Day greeting to Yugoslavia, which was published Monday. The change implies recognition of President Tito's nation as a member of the Communist bloc.

The Holland-America Line passenger-cargo liner Noordam is about to disappear from the local shipping scene. She is another in the vanishing breed of older medium-sized ships of her type in the North Atlantic.

YONKERS, April 11--Su Mac Lad, the nicest old rich trotter in the world--in fact, the richest--gave way to Orbiter, a nice young--but not so richone in the $45,000 Gotham trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight, With George Sholty whipping furiously through the stretch, the 5-year-old Orbiter overpowered Su Mac Lad and triumphed by a half-length.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- A group of Southern Democrats reacted defiantly today to reports that they were on a "purge" list drawn up by national Democratic leaders.

The Lehman Corporation, a closed-end investment company sponsored by Lehman Brothers, reported total net asset value of $316,571,465, or $26.69 a share, on March 31, compared with $294,923,379, or $25.48 a share, last Dec. 31. March 31, 1962, net assets stood at $351,379,316, or $30.57 a share.
MILWAUKEE, April 11-- Logic indicated that the Mets would get shut out today with six hits. In their first game, they were blanked with two hits; in their second, with four; this was the third.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 11 --The Brazilian press bitterly attacked President Joao Goulart today for what it called "marked" concessions to the demands of imperialism and reaction."
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 11--Negroes defied a County Court injunction and continued demonstrations today against segregation here.
"Reaction mixed" explains the feeling of thoroughbred racing enthusiasts yesterday at the announcement that there would be no racing at Belmont Park in 1963 and 1964.

In the five days following the gala opening of the Armory Show a week ago, 15,535 people have visited the exhibition. The display is a reconstruction of the original Armory Show of 1913, which revolutionized American art. At that time Henri Matisse, Marcel Duchamp and Pablo Picasso were names that provoked laughter and indignation among American critics and public.

ROME, April 11--Pope John XXIII expressed the hope today that "a new energy" might animate the rulers of nations.

CAIRO, April 11--President Gamal Abdel Nasser and his Syrian and Iraqi colleagues labored today over political issues that must be resolved before their proclaimed federal state, the new United Arab Republic, can come into being.

A group of 40 men, women and children marched singlefile onto the traffic island in Times Square yesterday afternoon to start a 42-hour silent vigil for peace.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)--Garland Sevier Ferguson Jr., former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, died today. He was 84 years old.
A conglomeration of cars buffed to an improbable luster will go on display Today when tie International Automobile Show opens a nice-day stand in the Coliseum at Columbus Circle.

Donald A. Campbell, an upstate Assemblyman who is considered acceptable to conservatives in the Republican party, became a candidate for Republican state chairman yesterday.

President Kennedy's cautious statement on Wheeling's steel price increase is a far clearer and more conciliatory expression of his position than was his angry reaction following the attempted price rise a year ago.
Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, the world's most successful 88-yearold trainer of thoroughbreds, today will send the favorites to the post in the feature stakes at both Agueduct and Laurel.
SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, April 12--Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Wright of this community and Cape Haze, Fla., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Wright's daughter, Miss Catherine Frum, to Paul Arthur...

The largest escalator installation in any stadium in the world, a system of 21 local and express color-coded stairways to the stars, will carry New York baseball fans, for better or worse, to their confrontations with the Mets when William A. Shea Stadium opens.
The American Guild of Variety Artists has started a campaign to organize entertainers appearing in Greenwich Village coffee houses.

PARIS, April 12--There is little doubt that Communist leaders, or at least those who follow Khrushchev, will read into the Pope's remarkable encyclical on peace an appeal to coexistence and will see it as primarily a political document.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 12 (Reuters)--Erik Carlsson of Sweden, driving a white Saab, returned at least an hour ahead of the next car tonight in the tough" East African Safari, probably the world's toughest auto rally. Competition was delayed by heavy rain.

OTTAWA, April 12--The United States Ambassador, W. Walton Butterworth, has denied reports that he wrote, a letter to Lester B. Pearson, the Canadian Liberal leader, congratulating him on his defense policy and saying the administration of Prime Minister John Diefenbaker was unfit to govern Canada.
Bob Dylan, a folk musician who breaks all the rules of song writing except those of having something to say and of saying it stunningly, gave a program of his compositions at Town Hall last night.
Easter will be fair, with seasonable temperatures, the Weather Bureau predicted yesterday. True, it may fail to match last year's superlative day, but that was 10 days later in April.

ATHENS, April 12--Dr. John Papadimitriou, a leading Greek archeologist and director general of the Greek Archeological Service since 1958, died after a heart attack here last night. He was 59 years old.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), April 12--Tens of thousands of Christian pilgrims were gathered by the walls of this ancient city tonight to celebrate in sorrow and in joy the crucifixion and resurrection of Christ.

WASHINGTON, April 12-- For the 25th time in 20 months, the United States and the Soviet Union held an informal conference on Berlin today. As always before, the official report was: "No basic change."

Health Department inspectors began a search here last night for 31,200 cans of tuna after tests showed that some cans in the original shipment contained the same type of botulism organisms that killed two women in Detroit last month.

Commissioner John C. Hart, whose term as a member of the State Liquor Authority expired yesterday, will continue in the $20,475 post for an indefinite time, it was learned yesterday.
A light sprinkling of declines in savings and loan dividend rates in recent days may be a harbinger of a midsummer shower.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)--A Civil Aeronautics Board Examiner recommended today denial of the application of Northeast Airlines for a permanent route between New York and Florida.

First-quarter earnings of the Radio Corporation of America were the highest of any three months in its 44year history. Sales set a record for the quarter. for the quarter ended March 31 rose 19 per Cent to $17,300,000 from $14,500,000 in the 1962 period.

Mr. and Mrs. Ewen Cameron MacVeagh of 860 Park Avenue and Dublin, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Moira Cameron MacVeagh, to Daniel McFarlan Burnham, son of Mrs. Kennerly Woody of New York and the late Addison Center Burnham.

HAVANA, April 15 (AP) Prime Minister Fidel Castro says Americans are afraid to have Cuban athletes at the PanAmerican Games in Sao Paulo, Brazil, and are using illegal tricks to keep the Cubans away. The Havana press took up the charge today.

Mayor Wagner's control over how the taxpayer's dollar is spent has increased greatly because of the new budget system set up under the City Charter that went into effect Jan. 1.

DETROIT, April 16 (UPI)-- The Ford Motor Company joined General Motors today in agreeing to set up a joint labormanagement study committee that will meet a year in advance of the 1964 new contract negotiations.
The Yankees' magic spell, which for a time was enabling them to get by quite nicely despite the absence of some of their heaviest armament, is beginning to wear a, bit thin.

The Ballroom of the Plaza had a springtime setting last night for the 11th annual Kips Bay Dinner Dance. The tables in the candle-lit room had centerpieces of fresh anemones in shades of violet, pink, fuchsia and white, a color scheme that was repeated in medallions over the boxes and in the ballroom foyer, where a prefatory reception was held.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 16 --The First Lady's pregnancy has caused President and Mrs. Kennedy to postpone until early 1964 their state visit to Italy.

Educational television station WNDT is not facing a financial crisis that warrants concern over its survival, Dr. Samuel B. Gould, president of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, said yesterday.

The United States Steel Corporation joined smaller steel companies yesterday in raising prices on some of its products. The increases, averaging $4.85 a ton, were less than those announced by other companies.
A secondary distribution of 3,441,880 shares of capital stock of the Gulf Oil Corporation will be made in May through a nationwide group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A total rupture between the Kennedy Administration and the Miami-based Cuban Revolutionary Council was foreseen by some officials today on the second anniversary of the Bay of Pigs invasion.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 16 --Mayor Albert Boutwell and a new City Council organized as a government today and filed suit to oust their predecessors, who refused to surrender their offices.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, April 16--Discussion of a controversial labor bill was postponed twenty-four hours today by the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly.
E. J. Korvette, Inc., discount department store chain, is negotiating to sell its stock holdings in Alexander's Department Store. Inc., back to Alexander's.
Burglar alarms may soon be as common as fire bells in city school buildings, the Board of Education indicated yesterday.
American Metal Climax, Inc., of New York will acquire the Hunter Engineering Company of Riverside, Calif., under an agreement reached by directors of both companies.
LONDON, April 16--Vladimir Ashkenazy, one of the Soviet Union's outstanding young pianists, has decided to live in Britain and not to return to the Soviet Union.

My dear Governor: I represent Judge Melvin H. Osterman of the Court of Claims. In yesterday's newspapers I read a report that you had sent a telegram to Judge Osterman, requesting him to resign the judicial office he now holds, because he had failed to sign a waiver of immunity in the form sought by the District Attorney of New York County.
One hundred and ninety-two persons were treated for smoke inhalation and shock yesterday as a result of a smoky fire that broke out on an empty train in a Brooklyn subway tunnel.
WHITE PLAINS, April 16-- "I was just lucky," William Lalli, 22 years old, of Yonkers, said today in explaining the $63,100 cash that he said he had gained chiefly from recent horse-race betting.
The Ford Foundation is substantially increasing its contribution toward solving the world population problem.
PARIS, April 16--The Lascaux Caves, which contain some of the finest prehistoric paintings in the world, were closed to the public this evening for an indefinite period.
Leases of office and showroom space by three textile companies have been closed in 960 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), a building being renovated at the corner of 35th Street.

CHICAGO, April 16 (UPI)-- Gino Cimoli batted in three runs with a single, a triple and a sacrifice fly as the Kansas City Athletics extended their winning streak to four straight games today, with a 7-4 triumph over the Chicago White Sox. The victory put the Athletics into a three-way tie for the American League lead.

AS anyone who has shopped for furniture and furnish ing ideas over the last few years knows, Bloomingdale's has about the best model rooms in town. The store has just unveiled eight new model rooms, and the design average is as high as ever.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 16 --The old and established cities on San Francisco Bay are in danger of being filled with only the very rich and very poor while the remaining land area will be built up with unplanned and disordered "oneclass" suburbs, a University of California professor warned today.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, will go Moscow late next month to sign a new agreement with the Soviet Union for cooperation in nuclear research.

BALTIMORE, April 16 (AP) --A government witness acknowledged today that he had failed to tell the Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and a Federal grand jury of incidents he testified to yesterday in United States District Court here.

THE first large retrospective of work, 1939-63, by Richard Pousette-Dart opening today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, honors a painter whose accomplishment, individual though it may be, is a characteristic manifestation of abstract expressionism.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 16 (UPI)--A Los Angeles relief pitcher, Eli Grba, walked George Banks with the bases filled in the 13th inning today, giving the Minnesota Twins an 11-10 victory over the Angels.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 16 --Dr. Allen O. Whipple, a surgeon and teacher who led in the development of operations for cancer of the pancreas, died totoday in his home at 31 South Stanworth Lane. He was 82 years old.
Sir Leslie Plummer, a Labor Member of the British Parliament since 1951, died in New York Hospital Monday night, apparently of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 61.
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., April 16--Gov, Edmund G. Brown put California's Democratic-controlled Legislature on the spot tonight.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 16-- Neutralist troops suffered more setbacks today in the struggle with the pro-Communist Pathet Lao forces, increasing fears that Laos might again face an all-out civil war.

DETROIT, April 16 (UPI)-- Dave Keon and Red Kelly scored unassisted third-period goals tonight, and the Toronto Maple Leafs gained a 4-2 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings. The Leafs thus took a 3-1 lead in the Stanley Cup hockey finals.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 16 Miss Mary Anita Hoff and John Hatton Fallon were married here this morning in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. James P. McKelvey, pastor of St. Mary's Church in East Islip, L. I., performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. The Most Rev. Vincent J. Baldwin, Auxiliary Bishop of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, read the papal blessing.
Funds deposited by foreigners in New York banks are subject to state laws and not those of the depositors' home countries, Supreme Court Justice Owen McGivern ruled yesterday.

NEW HAVEN Conn., April 16--Yale will open its rowing season Saturday at Rutgers with largely the same varsity crew that shared the Eastern sprint championship with Pennsylvania last year and defeated Harvard in their four-mile race at New London.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Civil Rights Commission urged President Kennedy today to consider withholding Federal funds from Mississippi until the state ends its "subversion of the Constitution."
BOSTON, April 16--Richard Cardinal Cushing of Boston called upon Roman Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy today to mend the divisions that have kept them apart for nine centuries.

Four bills, passed by the Legislature and now before Governor Rockefeller, threaten sabotage of effective court reform in this state. Herman S. and Richard S. Wolfman, realty investors, have sold a six-story apartment building occupying the blockfront at 135 New York Avenue, between St. Marks Avenue and Bergen Street, in Brooklyn.

William D. Cox, a former baseball man who has worked overtime attempting to establish league soccer in this country, said yesterday that the International Soccer League would have an expanded schedule this season at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. The local season will open May 30.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey endorsed Governor Rockefeller of New York today for the Republican Presidential nomination next year.

Traffic on the Port of New York Authority crossings last year exceeded 100,000,000 vehicles for the first time.
HARTFORD, April 16--Establishment of a pesticide control board and the ending of state subsidies for gypsy-moth spraying were recommended today in a report to Gov. John N. Dempsey of Connecticut.

CAIRO, Wednesday, April 17 --The leaders of Egypt, Syria and Iraq signed early today a communique declaring that their proposal to form a tripartite United Arab Republic would be submitted to a plebiscite on Sept. 27.

WASHINGTON, April 16 The chief judge of the Federal District Court in New York, Sylvester J. Ryan, has issued an extraordinay injunction against the General Services Administration, the housekeeping arm of the Federal Government.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., April 16 --A Nassau County District Court judge said today that suburban youth was suffering from a serious malady called "auto-mania."

State Senator Henry S. Haines, Democrat of Burlington County, was defeated for renomination in yesterday's New Jersey primary election by Edward J. Hulse, brother-inlaw of Gov. Richard J. Hughes. Louis Rodriguez, the welterweight champion, and Emile Griffith, the former titleholder, were matched yesterday for a return 147-pound title fight in Madison Square Garden June 8. BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 19 The second annual Fine Arts Festival is being held this week by the Negro community of Birmingham. Here, the sun shines, ancient bells ring and tourists, as well as the natives, swim and walk or just sit and gaze at the sea.

HARTFORD, April 20--Two investigations by committees of the General Assembly, which under the state constitution must adjourn on June 5, have just about stalled the legislative process in the state.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 --Two beautiful stands of red wood along the Eel River north of here may be sold for logging before money becomes available from the state of California to buy them.

More than 25 million tons of cargo were carried in 1962, a gain of five million over the year before. Prospects in 1963 are even brighter.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.--Thirteen years ago work was started on a mammoth flood-control project in Florida. The project now embraces all or parts of 18 counties, stretching from a point south of Orlando to the Upper Keys. It covers 15,000 square miles, has cost $115,000,000 to date and has created an enormous recreation area that will rival Everglades National. Park in size.

PARIS, April 20--Every few days in the average French household, a fuse blows. It happens when the refrigerator springs into action while the television set is on, or when the iron is plugged in while the vacuum cleaner is whirring way.

COPENHAGEN This capital of Denmark is a wonderful place to visit. Its hospitality and food are proverbial, its ancient and modern features nicely blended, and shopping here has attractions even for habitues of Paris' Place Vendome and Rue St. Honore.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20--The prevention of crime has become a matter of increasing importance to the United Nations.

Six residences and a community center, all restored and remodeled in the last three years, will be seen the afternoon of May 2 on a tour of Brooklyn Heights arranged in behalf of the Willoughby House Settlement.
LONDON, April 20--Britain is intensifying her diplomatic activities in Moscow and Laos this weekend to check the resumption of the Laotian civil war and a new international crisis.

LONDON--The 30-story London Hilton, which opened for business last week, has become something that Londoners cannot ignore not even the Queen.
