HONG KONG, April 20-- President Sukarno of Indonesia endorsed today the major policies of Communist China in Asia. In return, Peking supported the Indonesian Government's opposition to the proposed formation of a Southeast Asian state of Malaysia.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 20 --Yale's varsity heavyweight crew opened its season today with a length-and-a-half victory over Rutgers in their race at a mile and three-quarters on Carnegie Lake.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 20 --Edward Albee, the playwright, and Robert Whitehead, one of the theater's leading producers, did some verbal fencing today on what is wrong with Broadway. They stole the show at Princeton University's symposium, entitled "The Pursuit of Excellence in the Creative Arts."

OTTAWA, April 20--An informal chat at a White House dinner party and the use of a casually chosen word in a working paper for President Kennedy were elements in the straining of relations between the United States and Canada nearly a year before the April 8 general election here.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP)--Roy Sievers, back in the line-up after being sidelined with a rib injury, today batted in three runs with a triple and double as Philadelphia defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-2, and ended a four-game losing streak.

ATHENS, April 14--Fisheries disputes in the Aegean Sea and communal friction on Cyprus have strained relations between Greece and Turkey just as the presence of United States Polaris submarines caused diplomatic attacks by Moscow on the two countries. They are the two easternmost members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

That day will be Open Barn Day at 14 breeding establishments in the Maryland Blue Grass country-yes, Maryland, as well as Kentucky, has blue grass and knows how to use it.

The long-awaited and muchheralded spring recovery definitely seems to be at hand. There has been a steady improvement in the economy and the stock market last week posted new 1963 highs after registering four weeks of almost uninterrupted advances.

CHANTILY, France, April 20--Here and in nearby Maisons-Laffitte, 2,500 race horses dine on oats in perfect contentment, while 500 small boys dream of one day dining on caviar. In the meantime the small boys eat as little as possible and drink almost nothing. Some are pretty hungry.

OVERSEAS travel by Americans in 1963 will exceed any previous year, according to the United States Psssport Office. More than 1,000,000 travelers are expected to go abroad this year, surpassing the record set in 1962, when 906,900 passports and renewals were issued.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- A Senate panel will begin studies next week on how to combat communism in Latin America with housing. In many international programs, housing has proved to be a highly effective cold war weapon.

A LITTLE noticed trend in college admissions is the movement toward the urban school. At one time, such schools merely served their local population. WASHINGTON, April 20-- There is no business like the steel business. Although not the biggest business--the auto, oil and lumber industries sell more--steel is the heart of industrial society. It is the basic material of the machine age. It is, not incidentally, the cheapest industrial metal.

BEFORE painting walls of a room the home handyman should take off all cover plates on light switches and electrical outlets. These should be painted separately and allowed to dry before being replaced. This will not only assure a neater job on both walls and plates, it will also eliminate the danger of paint chipping later on if the plate has to be removed so that electrical repairs can be made.

CONCORD, N.H.--New Hampshire is poised to give the nation its first legal sweepstakes lottery in some 70 years. The State Legislature approved the venture last week, and the bill is scheduled to reach Gov. John W. King's desk soon.
Activity in the over-the-counter market increased somewhat last week, with most issues showing small advances.
The effervescent spirit of spring is bubbling through the retail trade. Easter week brought a surge of purchases in apparel to cap five weeks of continuing gains.
The regional air terminal system run by the Port of New York Authority set records in all categories of air traffic in 1962, the authority said last week in its annual report.
BERLIN, April 19--Nearly 20 years after World War II it is still spine-chilling to read how 17 year-old, German apprentice was executed for listening to a foreign radio broadcast.

WASHINGTON, April 20--The prospect that the problem created by a Communist government in Cuba, allied with international Communism and offensively armed by Soviet Russia, would be a paramount issue between President kennedy and the Republican nominee in 1964 has now attained the temporary status of high probability.

TRENTON, April 20--A bitter struggle for leadership of the powerful Republican organization in Bergen County will highlight the election Tuesday night of major party chairmen in all 21 counties of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- Like the famous question of which came first, the chicken or the egg, a standard baseball question arises when one team beats another by a 7-1 score as the Washington Senators did the New York Yankees tonight.

JACKSONVILLE, Ore.-- This historic Gold Rush town, perhaps the bestpreserved pioneer community in the Pacific Northwest, will offer a double-barreled treat to visitors this summer: the unspoiled setting of a l9thcentury settlement and, for the first time, a music festival.
West Germany is planning a step-up in public aid for university students to enable more low-income families to send their children to college.
HAVANA, April 20 (UPI)-- Premier Fidel Castro said today that the United States had abandoned plans for a second invasion of Cuba in favor of a plot to assassinate Cuban leaders.

Brush fires fanned by gusty winds and a series of multiplealarm blazes destroyed more than 150 homes yesterday in Staten Island, New Jersey and Long Island. More than 100 persons were injured.

City Island, the finger of the Bronx that is the commercial heart of New York, yachting, is buzzing after a drowsy winter. The yacht clubs with boat storage facilities are alive with do-it-yourself fitting-out operations during weekends.

Blake of Medford.

WASHINGTON, April 21Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy urged today that Cuban refugees unify into a single organization that could speak with one voice and have "some relationship" with the United States and other countries.
The large-scale entry of the Soviet Union into an otherwise quiescent world market for secondhand ships was the principal event in the ship sales field during the first quarter of this year.

Africa's musical ambassador to the United States, Miriam Makeba, gave a concert Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. An audience of 2,800, which included the singer's mentor, Harry Belafonte, gave her an enthusiastic reception.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 21-- King Hussein named a new Government, dissolved Parliament and called for a general election today in an attempt to cope with demonstrations in favor of Arab unity under the leadership of the United Arab Republic.

BALTIMORE, April 21 (UPI)--Dick Donovan pitched the Cleveland Indians to a fourhit, 2-0 victory in the second game of a double-header today after the Baltimore Orioles had won the opener, 7--0, on Steve Barber's four-hit performance.
VALLEY COTTAGE, N.Y., April 21--About 250 men, women and children who are the last descendants of an old Russian sect now living in Turkey have been cleared for resettlement in the United States.
William Herbert Eaton, retired owner and publisher of American Home magazine, died yesterday at his residence, 930 Fifth Avenue. He was 81 years old.

MILAN, Italy, Monday, April 22--Premier Khrushchev, in a wide-ranging interview with an Italian editor, declared that the West's position on nuclear inspection was forcing the Soviet Union to consider whether it must withdraw its readiness to allow even two or three inspections a year on its soil.
KANSAS CITY, April 21 (UPI)--Felix Torres and Leon Wagner belted home runs to pace the Los Angeles Angels to a 6-2 victory today over the Knasas City Athletics.
A picture of Beautiful Belmont as a rapidly deteriorating structure on the brink of collapse was painted in two reports released yesterday by the New York Racing Association.

STOCKHOLM, April 21 (AP) --Ingemar Johansson of Sweden, rising groggily from the canvas, was declared the winner on points over Brian London of Britain in a sensational 12-round heavyweight bout tonight.
Controller Abraham D. Beame disclaimed emphatically yesterday any political motivation in opposing a sales tax increase and proposing a fiscal program alternative to that of Mayor Wagner.

Fighting the wave of windfanned fires on southern Staten Island Saturday was "possibly the greatest task in the history of the New York Fire Department," Fire Commissioner Edward Thompson said yesterday.

The future of a movement to unite six Protestant denominations should be evident by the end of this year, the Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, stated clerk of the United Presbyterian Church, said yesterday.

RICHMOND, April 21-- "Painting in England, 1700-1850," which opened at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts last weekend to begin an all-summer run, exemplifies half a dozen requirements for a first-rate exhibition.

THERE are members of a New York bridge club who say that the club secretary last week sent this message to a member in a local hospital, "The card committee has voted 7 to 5 to wish you a speedy recovery."

PHILADELPHIA, April 21-- The St. Louis Cardinals spotted the Philadelphia, Phillies four runs today and then routed Art Mahaffey and won the second game of a double-header, 10-5. The Phillies had won the opener, 4-3, in 10 innings. FIRST GAME
Pension credits that follow workers from job to job were recommended yesterday as the answer to one of the problems created by automation.

VIENNA, April 21--Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty was reported today to be in good health and in no mood to leave Hungary. The Cardinal has been in refuge in the United States legation for the last six and a half years.
WASHINGTON, April 21-- An early reopening of steel labor negotiations appeared likely today.
ALGIERS, April 21--Premier Ahmed Ben Bella announced today that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba would visit here next month.

MOSCOW, April 21--The Communist party's crackdown on intellectuals was reflected today in the annual Lenin Prize announcement. Only five awards were bestowed in arts and literature. Sixty-five works had been submitted for consideration.
No Robbery, the winner of the $90,800 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct Saturday, is preparing to leave town for Louisville and the Kentucky Derby.

Thomas Dunn and his colleagues of Festival Associates apparently believe in doing one composer at a time. Earlier this season they have devoted programs at Philharmonic Hall to Bach, Vivaldi and Handel. Last night they turned to Mozart.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- Americans in Bonn and Washington were set to arguing the other day about when, if ever, President Kennedy decided to visit four instead of two cities in West Germany this summer.
WASHINGTON, April, 21-- One of the less appreciated of the numerous New York Yankee assets--speed and sense afoot--accounted for a 7-6 victory today over the Washington Senators at D.C. Stadium.

Every day that passes--indeed, every second-- makes the problem of the uncontrolled growth of the world's population more acute. At the present rate of increase, the global population will reach six billion by the year 2000, and 25 billion by 2070. What is worse, by far the greatest increase is taking place in the underdeveloped countries of Latin America, Africa and Asia, where the level of subsistence is already much too low.
A bitter struggle is roiling the usually stand banking industry.
WASHINGTON, April 21--The big news in American culture these days is "pop art." Many culture insiders believe it may be a bigger craze than folk-singing before the summer is out, and no wonder.

The most glorious hour in the Mets' short history arrived at 8:14 last night. At that moment, they completed their fourth straight victory by putting away a double-header triumph, 8--5 and 9--2, against the Milwaukee Braves.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 21 --A hard hitting Cuban baseball team defeated the United States 13 to 1, today in the fourth Pan American games.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 22-- The Board of Supervisors voted 5 to 1 today to establish an office of Public Defender for Nassau County under a contract with the County Legal Aid Society.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Atomic Energy Commission approved today the construction of the first nuclear fuel reprocessing plant to be built by private industry.

A VIOLINIST was heard warming up in the wings of Carnegie Hall last night. A moment later, Mischa Elman, 72 years old, chunky, erect and confident, strode to the center of the stage and began one of the best recitals he has given here in recent years.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The National Labor Relations Board upheld an unfair labor practice finding today against the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
In an advertisement of his wares the other day, a local jeweler put forward a nice suggestion. For the sum...
LONDON, April 22--Britain was warming up today to the excitement of a royal wedding --the biggest since that of Princess Margaret nearly three years ago.

Bob Richards, a gold-medal winner for the United States Olympic team in the pole vault at Helsinki in 1952 and at Melbourne in 1956, urged yesterday that this country "provide a true national program" to build future Olympic champions.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth largest steel producer and the first major steel producer to report results for the March quarter, showed sharply lower sales and earnings from those of a year ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22--Adlai E. Stevenson, recently returned from a fiveweek trip abroad, said today that Europe was in the midst of a "new frontier movement all its own."

MIAMI, April 22--Twentyone Americans who had been held prisoner by Fidel Castro's regime in Cuba for two to three and a half years were flown from Havana to the Homestead Air Forces Base this morning by a Pan American World Airways DC-6-D. The base is about 25 miles south of Miami. 25 miles south of Miami.
The bond market was quiet yesterday. Prices tended to move narrowly where changed.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The United States was reported today to be preparing to ask the Organization of American States to declare an economic embargo against Cuba.

Three Cubans and a Cuban-American were released from prisons here yesterday in exchange for the freedom of United States nationals held in Cuba. One of the four was Francisco (the Hook) Molina del Rio, a Fidel Castro supporter who killed a 9-yearold girl during a shooting fray with anti-Castro Cubans in 1959.

LONDON, April 22--In the spring of 1963, with unemployment figures going down and export figures going up, every British politician's fancy seems to have turned to thoughts of an election in the fall.
MOSCOW, April 22--Pravda accused the United States today of having sabotaged the 1962 Geneva agreement that provided for establishment of a neutral and unified Laos.

LONDON, April 22--The Royal Shakespeare Theater will visit New York in June of 1964 during a four-month world tour that is to be part of the theater's commemoration of the 400th anniversary of the poet's birth.

CHILDREN'S parties are not what they used to be. The simple gatherings of the past are giving way to expensive extravaganzas and, although mother still qualifies as social director, an increasing number of parties are being turned over to "experts"--people who specialize in giving children's parties.
The American Broadcasting Company is understood to have selected C.J. LaRoche Co., Inc., to handle advertising for its television network.

The proverb was pronounced yesterday by Gregori Georgevich Khitenkov, the deputy director of the Central Institute of Horse Breeding of the Soviet Union. And the meaning, he said, was: "A child once beaten is better than two children who never have been beaten."
The British pound for immediate delivery eased in trading on the New York foreign exchange market, while discounts tightened on sterling for future delivery.
The average American, surveys tell us, is subjected to 1,600 advertisements a day. That number may become 1,601 this year when machines like the one above are introduced to the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- Young square dancers, as happily relaxed as though they were at a neighborhood houseraising, frolicked around the White House lawn today after a warm welcome from President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- Treasury bill rates declined on today's sale of the regular weekly issues. The average discount on the 91-day bills was the smallest in six weeks. For the fourth consecutive week the Treasury raised $100,000,000 of new cash through the sale.

GEORGE KENNEDY, long associated with Brooklyn bridge teams and clubs, is to teach a series of classes in advanced bidding and play at the Manhattan Beach Hotel in Brooklyn, on Wednesday afternoons beginning tomorrow.
MANASQUAN, N. J., April 22 --George E. Strehan, a civil engineer and an architect, died yesterday in Point Pleasant Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 375 Cedar Avenue.
PHILADELPHIA, April 22-- A management request for removal of restrictions on borrowing by the hard-pressed Curtis Publishing Company was defeated by holders of the company's $4 prior preferred stock.

Attorneys for Nationwide Maritime Leasing Company stepped into a Federal Bankruptcy Court yesterday and offered a $4,000,000 refinancing proposal for the reorganization of the American-flag shipping empire of Manuel E. Kulukundis ...
A huge and weighty bronze sculpture by Auguste Rodin arrived at the Museum of Modern Art yesterday at 8 A. M.

ALONG with the loss of property and life in the Staten Island and New Jersey fires, there was a Heavy toll in wildlife. Only preliminary estimates are available, but there is no doubt that the loss was considerable.

The Saturday Evening Post, commenting editorially on its March 23 story about Wally Butts and Paul Bryant, says in its current issue: "We believe that anyone who rigs a football game should be exposed."
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 22 (AP)--In the Pocket is definitely out of the Kentucky Derby, and Jet Traffic is a doubtful starter, trainers of the two colts said today at Gulfstream Park.
CHICAGO, April 22 (UPI) --Wheat futures advanced today on the Board of Trade. Most soybeans declined and most grains were steady to up slightly.
A new assertive mood, characterized by some Negro leaders as "Black Nationalism," is spreading throughout the United States.

ROME, April 22--The campaign for an Italian election that many people believe will be of comparable importance with that of 1948, when voters decisively rejected Communism, has entered its final week.
The question of the relationship between cigarette smoking and lung cancer has flared up again, with the public once again confused by conflicting statements by principals in the debate.

Alfred Hayes, the president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, asserted last night that neither Federal Reserve nor Treasury officials had "interfered with private decisions to lend abroad nor raised objections as to amounts."
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Supreme Court took the following actions today.

The City University will add doctoral programs in biology and engineering next fall and expand the four doctoral offerings that were begun last September, the Board of Higher Education announced last night.
RYE, N.Y., April 22--Golfers should know all the rules, cautioned an official today, especially if they find a ball nestling against peanuts, fruit or vegetables on the course.

ALBANY, April 22--Governor Rockefeller signed today the bipartisan Metcalf-Baker bill. It bans discrimination in the sale or rental of all housing in the state except for rentals in owner-occupied one-and two-family dwellings.
PHILADELPHIA, April 22-- Our once heroic Mets reverted to type--something less than heroic and a bit inept--as their long victory string of four games was snapped by the Phillies tonight.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 22 (AP)--The defending champion, Billy Joe Patton, opened his bid for a third North and South amateur golf championship today by scoring a 2-up victory over Joe Kind of Anniston, Ala.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The United States Navy was reported today to have engaged in "precautionary" activities in the Gulf of Siam as the international stalemate over Laos seemed to harden.

Mayor Wagner has returned from his brief and deserved vacation apparently unconvinced that any change is necesary or desirable in his large tax-increase program. Lacking any sign of reconsideration by the Mayor, the City Council is presumed ready to follow his leadership and vote the damaging 4 per cent sales tax and application of that tax, for the first time, to goods bought in the city and delivered to New York suburbs within the state.

CHANTILLY, France, April 22--Yves St. Martin is a boy who loves horses, and this is part of the reason why he is the best jockey in France. Yesterday at Longchamp St. Martin won three races, was fourth twice and twice ran out of the money. He won roughtly...
Since our meeting here last April, The Associated Press has had a major change in leadership.
MEXICO CITY, April 22--The responsibilities of private enterprise in world commerce were hammered home today from several angles to 2,000 commercial leaders of the Western world.

DR. JOHN ROBINSON, Bishop of Woolwich, Eng land, upset the gravity of readers of The London Observer last month by advo-- cating a new image of God. He argued that the traditional image of God as the "man up there" no longer accords with knowledge.

BALTIMORE, April 22--The long trial of two former Congressmen, who are accused of selling their influence in Washington to prevent a Federal criminal prosecution, reached the halfway point in United States District Court here today.
More top-level editorial changes at the Curtis Publishing Company were announced yesterday.
A drop in metal and plastics prices and a decline in export shipments adversely affected the first-quarter performance of the Union Carbide Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- Viruses appear to leave chemical fingerprints in the animal cells they make cancerous, even though the live viruses themselves cannot be found there.

A special telecast about the activities of the Lincoln Repertory Company will be presented Sunday, May 5, from 2 to 3 P.M. over the American Broadcasting Company network. The narrators will be Elia Kazan and Robert Whitehead, producers and directors of the group.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 (UPI)--Jerry Lynch, a pinchhitter, and then Frank Robinson took turns belting two-run homers off Jack Sanford in a fiverun eighth inning tonight to lead the Cincinnati Reds past the San Francisco Giants, 7--4. The loss knocked the Giants from first place in the National League.

About 50,000 square feet of space has been leased in the new 18-story Decoration and Design Building being erected at 979 Third Avenue, northeast corner of 58th Street. John Stuart, Inc., and the John Widdiscomb Company, the lessees are two of the country's leading furniture organiations.

NEW HAVEN, April 22--Dr. A. Whitney Griswold was mourned today by the university he had led since 1950. After a funeral service on the Yale University campus, the late president was buried three blocks away, at the Grove Street Cemetery.

Dr. Ray E. Trussell, the Commissioner of Hospitals, challenged last night as "irresponsible" the New York County Medical Society's recent series of articles attacking his findings on medical care. He offered full cooperation, however, for the group's medical audit.
Allie Sherman, the dapper head coach of the New York Giants, was given five years of the National Football League's most precious commodity yesterday--security.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Supreme Court held today that the states, are free to make interstate airlines end racial discrimination in hiring.
Newspaper executives were told yesterday that there was no apparent pattern in the "tragically high" number of strikes in their industry last year.

President Kennedy used a special telephone at the White House yesterday to set in motion a special clock that will record the days, hours, minutes and seconds until the New York World's Fair opens, exactly one year from yesterday.
Eleven roof terrace and backyard gardens of New Yorkers will be on display in two garden tours being arranged by the City Gardens Club of New York. They will take place on May 7 and 14.

Premier Khrushchev's remarks to an Italian journalist about the necessity of preventing thermonuclear war are welcome, but would be more heartening if they were accompanied by constructive action for the cause of peace. Unfortunately, the Premier's long exposition of foreign policy in his interview last weekend sounded like a cracked record repeating what he has said before on the major international issues.
CHESTER, Pa., April 22 (AP) --Jack Nilon, the advisor of Sonny Liston, the heavyweight champion, said today he had agreed to a return title fight with Floyd Patterson in Las Vegas June 27.

A MERMAID clad in sea green silk announces to passers-by the opening of Betty Metcalf's custom dress shop at 779 Madison Avenue (66th Street). The frivolity stops there, however Miss Metcalf has studied the needs of the woman who leads an active life, full of sudden ...
Canada needs and will continue to encourage United States capital, but with new measures to assure an increased Canadian share in resources development, an Ontario official said yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 22--Malcolm Frager, the 28-year-old United States pianist who slipped quietly into Moscow last week, has captivated Soviet music critics with his playing.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- Echoes of the constitutional revolution of the nineteen-thirties were heard in the Supreme Court today.
The city estimates that it will relocate more than 86,000 persons and 2,000 commercial tenants in 1963 and 1964, most of them as a result of urban renewal.

If the forthcoming Off Broadway production of Shelagh Delaney's "Lion in Love" satisifies the 23-year-old English playwright, she may promise her third play, which is almost finished, to a downtown producer.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 22--After a five-year boom, Brazil's automotive industry is going through its first serious crisis.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 22 (UPI)--The United States won gold medals in shooting and weight lifting, broke three more swimming records and lost its best tennis player today in the Pan-American Games.

An apparent victory for the Kennedy Administration, early in the present session of Congress, has turned out thus far to be a snare and a delusion. What looked like a victory was the decision by the House to "liberalize" the all-powerful Rules Committee by adding two progressive Democrats to its membership. But this change has worked no wonders.
New fires, some kindled from the embers of the disastrous weekend blazes, broke out yesterday as officials moved to have Staten Island and New Jersey designated Federal disaster areas.
The State Liquor Authority dismisses yesterday an investigator for the local Alcoholic Beverage Control Board who insisted, however, that he could not be ousted because he had already resigned.
Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, still basking in the heady aura of the $12,500,000 it received from the Ford Foundation last week, announced yesterday new gifts of $10,000,000.

OTTAWA, April 22--Lester B. Pearson became the 14th Prime Minister of Canada today. He immediately buckled down with his new Cabinet to start the "60 days of dynamic action" he promised the country under a Liberal Government.

The companies which compromise the feminine-oriented cosmetic group have been showing plenty of "muscle" in today's stock market. In fact, some of them have been near their highs of last year, and one company's shares have been setting new records.

Kilmoray and Misty Day, the Hobeau Farm-David Shaer entry trained by Allen Jerkens, finished first and third in the 70th edition of the six-furlong Toboggan Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Between the entry performers, and beaten by a head, was Brandywine Stable's For The Road.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 22--The Chief Inspector of the Birmingham Police Department testified today that serious trouble would have developed if recent protest marches and demonstrations by Negroes had not been halted.

The nation's first astronaut to orbit the earth proposed yesterday the creation of a national information center to speed the use of space and other knowledge that is now expanding at the fastest rate in history.

Today's liberal arts colleges have faltered in their responsibility to society by placing too great an emphasis on preparation for specialization, Dr. Rosemary Park declared yesterday in her inaugural address as president of Barnard College.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- Banks and other financial institutions would be made more responsive instruments of overall Government economic policy under recommendations made today.
The attempt to raise prices for steel plate collapsed yesterday and the price increases posted by the United States Steel Corporation on other flatrolled products became standard.

Highways Commissioner John T. Carroll said yesterday that he had called for a crackdown on state highway contractors who failed to repair city streets used as detours around state construction projects.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 22 --An expenditure of $3,255,600 to expand facilities at the Suffolk Community College in Selden was approved today by the Suffolk Board of Supervisors.
LISBON, April 22--A huge Roman Catholic youth rally that was considered to be politically important ended today.

Genesco, Inc., maker and retailer of apparel and footwear, is discussing a major investment in S.H. Kress Co., variety-store chain, with executives of Kress, but the talks have not gone beyond the exploratory stage.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner pursued separate courses today in seeking Federal assistance for fire-ravaged Staten Island.
Shoe retailers are flocking to the National Shoe Fair to purchase fall lines of footwear.
CHICAGO, April 22--James E. Bulger, vice president and director of public relations for the Chicago Motor Club, died yesterday at the age of 75.
Cocoa futures rose sharply in active trading yesterday. Most other New York commodities were irregularly lower in quiet dealings.
An extra judge was called into the housing part of Criminal Court yesterday and an additional courtroom was opened so one landlord could stand trial in 21 cases in which he had pleaded not guilty.
THE titular leader of the troika that nominally gov erns Laos is the Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma. The troika is, so to speak, the three-horse coalition Government of the tiny, turbulent kingdom.

United Press International is experimenting with new techniques in news presentation, but still gives first priority to "swift and accurate coverage of news at home and abroad," its president said yesterday.

KIEL, Germany, April 22 (UPI)--West Germany's sixth submarine since World War II was launched today, with the public excluded. The Howald shipyard announced the launching of the A6, one of a projected series of 12 350-ton craft. The Bonn Defense Ministry disclosed last week that there were "material difficulties" in the submarine series.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that raising the city sales tax to 4 per cent still seemed the best available way to balance the city's $3,093,641,582 budget.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 22--A supervising inspector at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard said today that he thought "a lot better work could be done," in installing flexible hose connections in submarines like the Thresher.
Fred Turk and Ron Griesmer knocked in three runs each yesterday to pace St. John's to a 17-1 baseball victory over Adelphi College at the Redmen's field in Jamaica, Queens.
The proposal to create a "new Jones Beach" on Breezy Point Rockaway Peninsula, Queens, was called "very much alive" yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
BUDAPEST, April 22--From the walls of the old fortress on Gellert Hill, Budapest glittered in the spring sunlight like a huge jewel hung on the silver thread of the Danube.

Crown Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands, carrying a movie camera, toured the city yesterday by convertible, helicopter and tugboat. The unmarried, 24-year-old future queen, spritely and radiant, started her day with a visit to the new Netherland Seamen's House, 145 West 42d Street, where she delighted seamen by trying her hand at billiards.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 22 --The Brazilian Government has approved the nationalization by direct purchase of the properties here of the American and Foreign Power Company.
Construction of a temporary steel tent off Washington Square to house the Lincoln Repertory Company was virtually assured yesterday.
Gary Gubner lacks "harmony." He doesn't have "feel." His "efficiency" has dropped badly.
Mayor Wagner warned yesterday against indiscriminate destruction of the city's dwellings merely because they were not new. But he also cautioned that blight must not be confused with charm.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

WASHINGTON, April 22--The eminent Harvard, gynecologist, Dr. John Rock, has impressively documented the statement in his book released today that religious groups and other "moral" forces are in general agreement that the human species must soon set effective limits on its ratio of reproduction or allow the general welfare to perish in a savage battle for survival.

Three plumbing union officials and the owners of five plumbing contract companies doing business with the city were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges... of violating provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law that prohibit the payment of money to labor officials by management.
The political ferment in Jordan over the weekend was reflected in several European stock exchanges yesterday.

THE bird is here. It flew into New York last night from New Jersey and landed with a terrible thump at the Midway Theater. The bird is "The Purple Canary," and although it is not savage it pecks at the theatergoer's senses until he is almost numb.
DALLAS, April 22--A fullscale model of the Apollo command capsule to be used on the projected manned flight to the moon will be put through a launching-pad escape test early this summer.
Treasury officials are working out the details of President Kennedy's plan to allow American businessmen a 30 per cent credit against taxes for making investments in underdeveloped nations.

The first of rowing's big cup races comes up this week, with Pennsylvania, Princeton and Columbia racing for the Childs Cup at Princeton and facing a formidable added starter in the world-champion Ratzeburg crew from Germany.

The Federal Intermediate Credit Banks will offer today a new issue of approximately $268,000,000 nine-month 3 per cent debentures. Dated May 1, 1963, and maturing Feb. 3, 1964, the debentures are priced at par.

THE true nobility of mankind becomes most evident when anyone is in dis tress. There is an instant and selfless rush to the rescue. Greater love hath no man than he who * * * and all the rest of that jazz. Yea, verily, men have given their lives, their money and their time to help the less fortunate. It's a warming manifestation of humanity's inherent goodness.

THERE'S a pretty counter of fish at Zabar's, a salty array redolent of the fresh tang of the sea and the pungency of the smokehouse. There is salmon and sturgeon, whitefish and butterfish, carp and kipper and herring by the barrel.
CHICAGO, April 22 (UPI)-- United States Steel Corporation announced plans today to fill in 194 acres of Lake Michigan for future expansion of its South Works plant here.
PARIS, April 22--President de Gaulle was greeted by enthusiastic crowds in Northeastern France today at the start of a week's tour of four provincial departments.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- Hidden in the rocks of the earth is an "atomic clock" that can tell when the heavy elements of the human body and the world were first formed.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Supreme Court allowed to stand today an appeals court ruling that a parent union had the right to revoke the charter of a local that had struck in defiance of its orders.
BONN, April 22--Chancellor Adenauer, giving way at last to overwhelming political pressure, accepted Ludwig Erhard tonight as his heir apparent.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., April 22 --Western Governors opened a three-day meeting today with a glowing report on the West's leadership in traffic safety and an appeal to grapple with Army National Guard problems.
Cotton futures fell 40 cents to $2 a bale yesterday on the New Yord Cotton Exchange.
WEST POINT, N. Y., April 22--The New York Yankees paid their annual visit to Doubleday Field today and delighted an overflow crowd of some 6,500 with their batting prowess.

Stock prices pushed forward in active trading yesterday morning and then fell back as volume slackened in the afternoon. Closing prices were mixed with advances outnumbering declines by a small margin.
JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), April 22 (AP)--Jordan's weekend crisis left Jerusalem quiet today, with movement limited to armed soldiers and a few tourists.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the Interstate Commerce Commission lacked a basis for ordering cancellation of freight rate cuts proposed by several railroads for trailer-on-flatcar service--so-called piggyback service.

PURCHASE, N. Y., April 22 --A contemporary chapel with 28 leaded-glass windows of abstract design has risen beside a Victorian mansion here on the campus of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart.

CHICAGO, April 22--a massive statistical study of every common stock listed on the New York Stock Exchange since 1926 will be issued soon. It is expected to revolutionize stock market research, analysis and forecasting.

Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation "hopes" to get an eminent domain bill through Congress in order to pave the way for construction of its proposed coal slurry pipeline from West Virginia to Staten Island, Orville S. Carpenter, president, told the company's annual meeting at Wilmington, Del., yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Kennedy Administration has yielded to Britain and agreed--against its better judgment--to seek a new round of high-level negotiations with the Soviet Union.
VIENTIANE, April 22--The belief grew in diplomatic circles here today that the proCommunist assault against the neutralists in Laos was shift ing from a military to a political phase.

SHORT HILLS N.J. April 22--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William C. Ridgway Jr. of Short Hills and Fishers Island, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Starr Ridgway, to Peter Ottley Crisp. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. VanDevanter Crisp of New York and Glen Head, L.I.
KANSAS CITY, April 22 (AP) --Ed Charles's two-out single in the last of the ninth inning drove in the winning run and gave the Kansas City Athletics a 6-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

With President Nasser's shadow lengthening over the Middle East, the proclamation of a new United Arab Republic to be headed by him and comprising Egypt, Syria and Iraq is producing inevitable repercussions throughout this area.

Customer use of stock market credit, as measured in net debit balances carried by New York Stock. Exchange member concerns, has climbed to the highest level since the Big Board first compiled such figures in November, 1931.

Secretary of State Dean Rusk warned last night that the West could not expect a quick victory in the effort to drive Communist forces from South Vietnam. In a strong defense of the Kennedy Administration's policy in the small Southeast Asian country, Mr. Rusk said: "I cannot ...
Dr. Calvin E. Gross promised yesterday to do everything within his power to give the city "the best school system this country has ever seen."
The United States Plywood Corporation has leased five floors in the 38-story office building under construction at 777 Third Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets.

TEL A VIV, Israel, Tuesday, April 23--President Itzhak BenZvi of Israel died this morning in his residence in Jerusalem. He was 78, years old. The President's health failed after his return from an African tour in August. He entered the hospital April 1 and returned ...
MILAN, Italy, Tuesday, April 23 (AP)--Premier Khrushchev was quoted today as having suggested that West Berlin be given a neutral status like that of Switzerland, Austria or San Marino.
CHICAGO, April 22--Project Stargazer--the Air Force manned balloon program--was discontinued today.

Pan American World Airways called yesterday for a "reasonable reduction" in trans-Atlantic air fares at a time when the fares are disputed by a majority of the world's airlines and the Civil Aeronautics Board.
DETROIT, April 22 (AP)-- Auto production will pass 2,500,000 cars for the calendar year this week.
A Health Department plea for a jail, sentence for a "chronic slumlord" was again rejected yesterday in the housing part of Criminal Court.

An appropriation of $198,610, requested by Newbold Morris, Commissioner of Parks, and approved Feb. 8 by the Board of Estimate, will bring much-needed technical equipment to the free open-air Delacorte Theater, which began its career last summer as the home of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

Mayor Wagner observed yesterday that when he picks up his newspapers nowadays he sometimes wonders whether his efforts to settle the recent strike were not a mistake.

Bedeviled by an extremely severe winter and now by a late spring, the Soviet economy has made a less auspicious beginning this year than the Kremlin had hoped for. The backwardness of spring planting has already brought warning signals in the Soviet press.

ALBANY, April 23--It will be unlawful for motorists to drive cars with treadless tires in New York State after next Jan. 1.

A bus and a truck collided in Times Square yesterday at an intersection where traffic lights were not working, the police reported.

RICO LEBRUN, is so ob viously a major artist that his lack of wider fame seems almost a willful repression on the part of the tastemakers. He has the impoliteness to feel strongly, respect tradition and reject novelty as invention.

MANHASSET, L.I., April 23 --John Bleeck, former, proprietor of the Artist and Writers Restaurant at 213 West 40th Street, New York, died here yesterday in his home at 18 Borglum Road. He was 83 Years old.

Dr. Paul Fejos, president and research director of the WennerGren Foundation for Anthropological Research, died of a heart ailment yesterday at his home, 14 East 71st Street, wheree he also had his office. He was 68 years old.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., April 23 --Fifteen adults tried to register 15 Negro children in the predominantly white Cleveland School here today. After registration forms were filled out, the principal, Thorlief M. Henriksen, said the children did not live in the local district and could not be accepted.
Samuel Golden, president of the Artcraft Lithograph and Printing Company at 106 Seventh Avenue, died Monday in Wickersham Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 140 Riverside Drive.
PARIS, April 23--Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, today offered France a role in the alliance's nuclear force.
The Continental Can Company had a surprise package for its stockholders yesterday in the form of an increased quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)--Senator William Proxmire announced today that he had removed his chief aide, Frank Campenni, from the Senate payroll as of April 1.
WASHINGTON, April 23-- The Senate passed a research bill today aimed at assuring the country an adeduate supply of usable water in the years ahead.
WASHINGTON, April 23-- The steel industry's payroll costs per ton of steel have risen somewhat since the industry last raised its prices in 1958. The increase, however, has been relatively small.
SINGAPORE, April 23-- British officials responsible for the security of Sarawak have begun a series of precautionary moves against that colony's increasingly active Communists.

A New York State court yesterday upheld the right of Brooklyn College to reject the application of an 18-year-old high school graduate who sought admission even though he was seven-tenths of a point short of the required 85 per cent.

ALBANY, April 23--Models of preliminary designs for a 98-acre complex of state buildings were unveiled today by Governor Rockefeller.

THE New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America will run its first New Yorker Rally on Sunday. The start will be at the north end of the Roosevelt Field Shoppin Center in Garden City, L.I., with registration opening there at 10 A.M.

Ten companies will form the core of a reorganized Kulukundis maritime organization if creditors of the financially troubled shipping empire and a Federal Bankruptcy Court referee approve proposals by the debtor companies.
Rail stocks pulled the market to a new recovery high yesterday. The retailing, airline and electronics groups also joined the advance. Steels were the main soft spot on the New York Stock Exchange.
LONDON, April 23--The British and Soviet Governments disclosed tonight their failure to reach agreement on joint action to safeguard the peace in Laos.
The Italian Lnne which has had its North American head quarters for many years at 24 State Street, has leased space in the new 21-story building erected by Samuel Rudin at 1 Whitehall Street.
The Yankees, who still seem to be in business for all the recent furor attending the extraordinary exploits of the Mets, slipped quietly into the Bronx yesterday.
Earnings of the Ford Motor Company fell by 5 per cent in the first quarter despite record sales.

BALTIMORE, April 23 (AP) --The Baltimore Orioles held onto first place in the American League by beating Minnesota, 1--0, tonight. Milt Pappas allowed only five hits and Jerry Adair drove in the only run with a sacrifice fly in the second inning.
WASHINGTON, April 23-- A House subcommittee began an inquiry today into the management of the programs of the Public Health Service.
WASHINGTON, April 23-- George F. Kennan as planning to resign as Ambassador to Yugoslavia by this summer. Ambassador William Attwood is expected to move from Guinea to replace him in Belgrade.

WASHINGTON, April 23-- Two Senate groups gave approval today to legislation to prevent a Washington lobbyist from collecting fees under a Philippine war claims bill.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 23--For a majority of the more important agricultural products, the outlook is for continuing gains in output. Prices wiil be relatively stable and in some cases higher.

Joseph McD. Mitchell was acquitted yesterday in State Supreme Court. The 41-year-old City Manager of Newburgh, charged with having demanded a $20,000 real-estate bribe, had been on trial before a jury of 11 men and one woman for 18 days.

LOS ANGELES, April 24 (UPI) Bob Cousy finished a 13-year pro basketball career tonight by leading the Boston Celtics to a 112-109 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers and a record fifth straight National Basketball Association title.
A blind woman demonstrated yesterday how to solve a Braille crossword puzzle. She fitted plastic tiles embossed with Braille letters into the square recesses of a waffle-like plastic board.

WOODMERE, L.I., April 24 Miss Marianne Smith and Stephen R. Harrison will be married here in June.

The second is Ambassador George F. Kennan's intention to resign his Belgrade post this summer, which will deprive the nation's diplomatic corps of one of its ablest men.
The 34-day waterfront strike that cost the national economy nearly $1,000,000,000 was a result in good part of grave miscalculations by the longshore union, Vincent G. Barnett said yesterday.
The owner of the Tenement, an East Side cafe, said yesterday that he had told a grand jury that he made two $10,000 payoffs in an effort to get a liquor license.

The Pennsylvania Railroad's deficit in the first quarter exceeded by more than $6,000,000 the loss in the first quarter of 1962.

Doubleday Co., the publishing concern, has leased the entire eighth floor, containing 57,000 square feet, in the 50story Chemical Bank New York Trust Building, 277 Park Avenue at 47th Street. The lease is for more than 20 years at an aggregate rental of about $6,500,000.

But Darlene Hard and Carole Caldwell of the United States were beaten in women's tennis.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24 Justin Bomboko, the Congo's Minister of Justice, accused some African countries today of "irresponsibility or deliberate sabotage" in opposing the Congo's plan for reorganizing and retraining her army.

Postmaster General J. Edward Day has ordered an immediate halt of mail deliveries to new buildings in New York that are less than 90 per cent occupied. At the same time he "froze" the hiring of postal employes across the country.
Two detectives were critically wounded last night as they tried to arrest a gunman on the north side of 42d Street just west of Broadway. Hundreds of spectators watched the battle.

WASHINGTON, April 24 Government statisticians said today that the prices of materials used in making steel have declined by about 10 per cent since 1957. The prices of basic steel products rose through 1959 and have declined about 2 per cent since then, according to these tabulations.
LONDON, April 24 (AP)-- Wrangling over the fares to be charged on Atlantic and Pacific air routes began at an international conference in London today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 24 Pakistan's Foreign Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto told an Indian delegation here today that Pakistan had fixed the end of May as the deadline for settling the Kashmir question, according to an authoritative member of the Pakistani negotiating team.

Although newspapers suffered a slight loss of national advertising last year, they maintained their share of the total in over-all advertising, a session of the American Newspaper Publishers Association convention was told here yesterday.

LONDON, April 24 The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, said today that the "next few days" should show whether last year's Geneva agreements on the neutrality and independence of Laos were "to be allowed to survive."

President Kennedy is seeking help from the business community for his stalled tax proposals. A fresh approach is needed, for the brightening business outlook has provided a new excuse for doing nothing. Many Congressmen would prefer to wait until next year, when elections take place, to provide relief for voters; others favor marking time unless they get reductions in suending or can kill off reforms.

The railroad executive who has been in top management longer than any other leading rail official, William White of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, does not expect his carrier to be left out in the cold by mergers. He made this
The threat of a railstrike and political developments in Laos and Jordan restrained prices on the London market yesterday.
Cotton futures were 30 cents a bale up to 10 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

LONDON, April 24 Efforts to give new life to the Europear Free Trade Association are running afoul of the same problem that is increasingly bedeviling the economic relations of the Atlantic nations. The problem is agriculture and curbs on trade in agricultural goods.
MOSCOW, April 24 The Soviet Union's Atomic Energy Committee reported today an important step in the quest for controlled thermonuclear fusion, the harnessing of the power of the hydrogen bomb.

A 21-year-old, baby-faced former convict, who broke into a broad smile when he was asked in Supreme Court what he did for a living, confessed yesterday that he had stolen more than a million dollars worth of jewelry in a hundred burglaries.

PARIS. BRANDO AZARIO is one of the most disarming business women in the fashion world. She is 22 years old, with light brown hair that bobs imperiously as she warms to her sales pitch on couture fabrics.

WHEN Sir Frederick Ashton stepped out before the great gold curtain of the Metropolitan Opera House last night, he acknowledged the applause of a cheering audience and then made shy gestured of friendship to a white pigeon standing nearby.
BALTIMORE, April 24 (UPI) The Kansas City Athletics shut out the Baltimore Orioles, 5-0, tonight behind the 10-hit pitching of Orlando Pena and took over first place in the American League.

JACKSON, Miss., April 24 (UPI) A legislative committee, after investigating the rioting last fall at the University of Mississippi, issued a report today charging that Federal marshals had kept prisoners confined on a "torture slab."

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)-- Congressmen, a Budget Bureau official and a Presidential consultant said today that the Government should pay expenses incurred by a President-elect between Election Day and inauguration.
Dwight Macdonald, author and critic, raised a question yesterday about the salaries paid to key executives of New York's educational television station, WNDT.
Officials of the M. Steinthal Company, a New York concern that makes parachutes, disclosed plans yesterday to conduct a proxy fight at the May 6 annual meeting of the Lionel Corporation.
YONKERS, April 24-- There will be betting on all 10 races tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway, where the $60,000 United Nations Trot will highlight the expanded program.
Tonight, I want to take this first opportunity I've had to talk to you about the topic of the day, the tax program now under consideration by the City Council.
For the next four days the reconstruction of the historic Armory Show of 1913 will morel nearly resemble the original. Some of the paintings, drawings and sculptures will be for sale.
The Canadian dollar continued to maintain its strength in the New York foreign exchange market yesterday, despite a slight dip in the currency for immediate delivery.
The election of Raymond J. Cantwell and Richard H. Harrison as vice presidents of the Babcock Wilcox Company, maker of steam and atomic energy equipment, was announced yesterday.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., April 24 This morning at 8:15 o'clock on the dot, the City Manager of Newburgh, Joseph McD. Mitchell, walked happily into his office, and the townsfolk mostly were pleased.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 (UPI) Curt Simmons pitched the St. Louis Cardinals into sole possession of first place in the National League today with a 4-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
WASHINGTON, April 24 Senate liberals fought confirmation today of the 14 directors of the Communications Satellite Corporation.

Viveca Lindfors is switching from the drama to the songand-dance department. She will make her musical-comedy debut in "Pal Joey," opening May 29 at the City Center. Miss Lindfors will act opposite Bob Fosse, who is better known as a director-choreographer.

CHICAGO, April 24 Beautiful Wrigley Field, the home of the Chicago Cubs, has two distinctions: It's the only major league ball park not equipped for night baseball, and the only one in which the New York Mets have won more games than they have lost.

WASHINGTON, April 24 After more than a year of turmoil and controversy, the banking world and the Government agencies it has to live with may be on their way toward mending their differences both among themselves and with each other.
MANILA, April 24 Presiden Diosdado Macapagal charged to day that two members of the Philippine Congress and two officials of the previous Administration had conspired to assassinate him.

Adlai E. Stevenson, carol Burnett and Walter Cronkite were among the winners of George Foster Peabody awards announced yesterday. The 1962 awards for "distinguished achievement by television and radio" were issued to 18 persons programs or stations.
PINEHITRST, N.C., April 24 (AP) Billy Joe Patton scored a pair of 1-up victories that moved him into the quarterfinals of the North and South amateur golf tournament today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 24 In this region, where thoroughbred horse racing is as much a culture as a sport, the pertinently named Blue Grass Stakes will be contested tomorrow. The race, for 3-year-olds at a mile and an eighth, will be held at the attractive Keeneland course, where it has been run under its present conditions since 1937.

CLEVELAND, April 24 (AP) The Very Rev. Chrysogonos Lavoriotes, pastor emeritus of the American Hellenic Community of Greater Cleveland of the Greek Orthodox Church, died yesterday in Cleveland Clinic Hospital. He was 87 years old.

ROME, April 24 With only two days of campaigning remaining all parties redoubled their efforts today to get a big turnout in the general elections for Parliament Sunday and Monday. All 315 senators and 630 deputies will be chosen.
TEL AVIV, April 24 A tradition that had been all but forgotten during 2,000 years of Jewish statelessness was revived today at the funeral of President Itzhak Ben-Zvi in Jerusalem.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 24 Major obstacles have developed in United States-South Vietnamese negotiations on the program for combating Communist guerrillas in the coming year. A failure to agree, observers believe, could have farreaching effects on the war effort.
PARIS, April 24 A group of leading French citizens political and non political met today in a Paris hotel to see if they could offer France an alternative to Gaullism.

HOLLYWOOD, April 24-- Leslie Epstein, 24-year-old son of an Academy Award-winning writer, today won first prize at the annual U.C.L.A.-Samuel Goldwyn Creative Writing, Competition for a three-act play, "The Speech of Dumb Animals."

MANY department and specialty stores have adopted in recent years the pleasant and courteous custom of saluting a particular country that supplies them with outstanding merchandise. Today, Lord Taylor hangs out the bunting to honor Italy.

WASHINGTON, April 24 The President's Committee on Youth Employment forecast a grim future today for hundreds of thousands of unemployed, poorly trained young people unless immediate steps are taken to aid them.
Governor Rockefeller signed a bill yesterday granting collective bargaining rights to employes of nonprofit hospitals in New York City.
Around the American League the tip, quite pointedly if a trifle inelegantly, is being whispered that "these Yankees ain't what they used to be."
MOSCOW, April 24 The United States and Britain asked the Soviet Union today to join in a new effort to overcome the impasse in the negotiations for a treaty to prohibit nuclear testing.

The Victorian Ball will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Saturday for the benefit of United Cerebral Palsy. Mrs. Raymond Wurtzburger, is chairman for the 12th annual dinner dance, one of the benefits sponsored by the Gotham League for Cerebral Palsy.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)-- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved legislation today to prevent a Washington lawyer from collecting fees under a Philippine claims act that he pushed as a lobbyist.
The city's Health Code will be amended next month in and effort to control the growing, and possibly harmful, practice of glue-sniffing among children.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 24 The International Control Commission for Laos is sending an aircraft to the Plaine des Jarres tomorrow to return 18 or 19 North Vietnamese airport technicians to Hanoi, the North Vietnamesee capital.

The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation gave $5,000,000 to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology yesterday to establish a center where practicing engineers and professors of engineering may catch up with scientific progress.

EVERYTHING has come up roses thus far this season for Senior Alfonso Ramon Lopez. The trade with the Orioles, scathingly criticized as a giveaway, has worked out well for the White Sox. The apparently fatal weakness in catching has been eliminated by rescue from an unexpected quarter. And the confidence of the Gay Caballero has been so restored that he is making bold claims his Chicagoans will be in pennant contention.
THERE is very little new under the kitchen roof. It is therefore refreshing for the mind, as well as the appetite, to discover definitely different and yet delicious culinary formulas.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 24 The deployment of formidable United States military forces in the Southeast Asian region is being used to strengthen the hand of Western negotiators striving for a diplomatic resolution of the current crisis in Laos.

Cesare Valletti, unfortunately, may be lost to the local operatic stages, but his fairly regular recital appearances here are a kind of recompense. Last night in Town Hall, the Italian tenor was in his best form. He wisely avoided any works that might tax his voice, and have a lovely recital, indeed.

PRESIDENT KENNEDY Prime Minister [Lester B.] Pearson of Canada and I have agreed to meet at Hyannis Port, Mass., on May 10 and 11 for a first discussion of the many important questions that are of common interest to the two countries.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

TIMES change. Britain's Lord Chamberlain called Shaw's "Mrs. Warren's Profession" immoral and otherwise improper for the stage in 1894. Shaw was branded as an unscrupulous and blackguardly author. Poor Shaw.

WASHINGTON, April 24 Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry, U.S.A., retired, the World War II commanding general of the Army's Second Service Command comprising New York, New Jersey and Delaware, died yesterday in Walter Reed General Hospital. He was 77 years old.
Trading in Government securities was almost at a standstill yesterday, while new municipal issues were well received and corporate bonds were mixed.

Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night can stay mail deliveries, but Postmaster General J. Edward Day is threatening to try. Although mail service is already far from adequate, he warns that deliveries to new homes, apartment buildings and offices will be cut off and Saturday deliveries for everyone eliminated unless Congress restores the cut of $91,964,000
The companies that make Wheaties, Rice Chex and other breakfast foods eagerly consumed by youngsters are stepping up their efforts to entice more adults to sample their products.
Four children from one family died last night when fire swept a Bronx tenement.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI) Camilo Pascual, beaten in his first three starts hurled the Minnesota Twins to a 6-4 victory over the Washington Senators tonight. Pascual, a 20-game winner last season, struck out 12 and allowed eight hits.
YOKOHAMA, April 24 (UPI) An American freighter whose owner failed to pay $19,610 in wages to the 31 crewmen was auctioned today by the Yokohama District Court.
The Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley announced yesterday that he would step down as president and rector of Fordham University on June 30.

A spark that could kindle an important show-business career is glowing brightly these nights one flight below Eighth Street in the Bon Soir. The source of this spark is Danny Meehan, a slight, bright-eyed young singer who is also an actor and somewhat of a dancer but
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)-- A Negro leader charged today that state and Federal job training programs were helping to promote and extend racial discrimination.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 24 (UPI) A bill to abolish professional boxing today received a "do pass" recommendation by the Illinois House Executive Committee after a sponsor asked the committee, to "stop the traffic of battered human flesh in the state of Illinois."

WASHINGTON, April 24 A bill to enforce stricter rules on Congressmen's trips overseas was backed unanimously today by the House Administrations Committee. Leaders forecast prompt passage by the House of Representatives.
OTTAWA, April 24 (AP) A union battle for supremacy on the Great Lakes raised the threat today of a boycott of United States Ships.

LONDON, April 24-- When Princess Alexandra Helen Elizabeth Olga Christabel, the great-great-grandchild of Queen Victoria, was born on Christmas Day, 1936, the event was marked by gun salutes. She was born to Princess Marina, the youngest daughter of the late Prince...
Springlike Colors Are Worn at Royal Wedding
The women's colleges that make up the Seven College Conference completed mailing notices yesterday to 4,489 candidates accepted for admission next fall.

AS one travels around the country and listens to local orchestras, the high level of accomplishment never ceases to astonish. Even in semiprofessional orchestras there generally are an assurance and a technical proficiency that make the results almost comparable to those achieved in the big cities.
The brush fires that raged on Staten Island and in New Jersey and Virginia recently cost about $3,650,000 in insured losses, the National Board of Fire Underwriters said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 Three agents of the Central Intelligence Agency were among the 21 Americans who returned to the United States last Monday after they were freed from Cuban prisons, authoritative sources said today.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., April 24 The Western Governors Conference declared war today on mail-order promoters of fraudulent or questionable raw land sales in the West.

DARIEN, Conn., April 24-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Hicklin of Darien and Wilson Point, Norwalk, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Wayne Hicklin, to Howell van Gerbig Jr. He is the son of Mr. van Gerbig of Brookville, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. van Gerbig.

WASHINGTON, April 24 President Kennedy is sending a personal representative to Moscow to urge Premier Khrushchev to help restore peace and stability in Laos. The President announced at his news conference today that W. Averell Harriman, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, would leave Lon don for Moscow tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 (UPI) John A.T. Galvin, a former Australian newspaperman, has filed an appeal in United States Tax Court on the largest single assessment for unpaid back taxes ever made against an individual by the United States Government.

SRANTED that the vast majority of,bridge play ers like best the hands from which they can learn something, the top experts become enthusiastic only about hands that have curious facets and unusual results.
Donna Geisler, aged 2, saw her first circus yesterday. She had a bawl from beginning to end.
Cocoa futures rose sharply in active trading yesterday. In other activity, world sugar declined and potato futures were mixed on heavy volume.
Four union officials were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of accepting $4,310 from a plumbing contractor in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act.

The real artist of the high wire at work in New York these days, with apologies to the circus, is Richard Lippold, the sculptor, who is stringing a shimmer of gold in the lobby of the nearly finished Pan Am Building.
The National League's current controversy over the balk rule promises to develop into a king-sized headache for the game.
THE hunting and fishing public for the most part seems unaware of the accelerating trend toward an outdoor way of life historically alien to the American scene.
A new strain of banana known as the "Valery" is being introduced by the United Fruit Company to Jamaica.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 The Standard Oil Company of California had first-quarter net income of $81,901,000, an increase of 7 per cent over the $76,568,000 earned in the period last year, R.G. Follis, chairman, announced today.
CHICAGO, April 24 (UPI) Rye prices plunged today on the Board of Trade and depressed many other grain futures.
The Board of Education said yesterday that teachers would not get salary increases and that many planned school improvements would have to be curtailed or eliminated because of insufficient funds.

Day Care Week will open Monday with a luncheon at the Astor. The annual event is held in behalf of the Day Care Council of New York, which serves 6,221 children in centers supported jointly by public and private welfare in the five boroughs.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 24 (Reuters) Ten thousand Jordanians showed their loyalty to King Hussein today in the wake of weekend demonstrations favoring President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.
BERLIN, April 24 Workers at an East Berlin plant were reported today to have protested against Communist pressure for extra weekend shifts to meet production quotas.

The Cannon Foundation, a charity adjunct of Cannon Mills, Inc., has given a 40-year lease with a purchase option on a plot of 40,000 square feet at 66 to 88 Worth Street to the Katz Parking System, Inc. The Charles F. Noyes Company, represented by William B. Falconer and Jacob Zinovoy, arranged the lease, which involves rental amounting to more than $6,000,000.
ATTALLA, Ala., April 24 (AP) State and county authorities began a massive search today for the slayer of a white Baltimore mailman who was making an integration pilgrimage to Mississippi.
Stock prices continued to rise in active trading yesterday. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was near the highest level of the year.
Mayor Wagner declared last night that those who maintain that the city's first $3,000,000,000 budget would be balanced by economies without new taxes were "mistaken, misled or irresponsible."
LONDON, April 24 The first big sale of the year of 19thcentury and modern paintings was held today by Sotheby Co., the auctioneers and the art dealers breathed easier when it was over.
Directors of the GeorgiaPacific Corporation elected Robert E. Flowerree yesterday as executive vice president in charge of pulp and paper operations. He had been a vice president since June, 1956.
Two major department store chains, Federated Department Stores, Inc., and Interstate Department Stores, Inc., reported record sales and earnings for the year.
WASHINGTON, April 24 President Kennedy expressed support today for any United States effort to provide, information on population control to any nations requesting it.

The president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association called yesterday for "an authoritative and clear-cut assurance" from the Kennedy Administration "that there is no place in its program for the use of the lie as an instrument of national policy."
WASHINGTON, April 24 This is an ugly spring for the Kremlinologists, those hardworking clairvoyants who must keep Americans informed about Russian political developments.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 24 Two members of the Sayreville Board of Education and two former board presidents were convicted of misconduct in office today following a six-day trial in Middlesex County Criminal Court.

The post of state chairman has been vacant since the resignation last December of L. Judson Morhouse. He quit the political post and two state positions after being summoned as a witness and declining to waive his immunity in the grand jury investigation of the State Liquor Authority.

The 14th game of the 24game match for the world's chess championship in Moscow between the world champion, Mikhail Botvinnik, and Tigran Petrosian, both of the Soviet Union, was adjourned yesterday after 41 moves. Botvinnik sealed his 42d move, holding a slight positional advantage.

FRANKLIN LAKES, N.J., April 24 The New Jersey Audubon Society is stepping up its campaign against spraying with DDT to eradicate gypsy moths, Frank W. McLaughlin, executive director, said today at the society's headquarters here.

A group of five American songs, all given for the first time, was the high point of the debut recital of Alexander Terry, a young countertenor from Indiana, at Judson Hall last night. The three composers of the songs, Ned Rorem, Jonathan Elkus and Richard Gumming, were in attendance; Mr. Gumming, especially so, since he was the accompanist.

ALPINE, N.J., April 24 The Palisades Interstate Park Commission is acquiring the 300acre camp of the North Bergen County Council of the Boy Scouts of America for a public park with facilities for 15,000 persons.

BOTH the 9th and 10th games of the world title match in Moscow between the champion, Mikhail Lotvinnik of the Soviet Union, and his countryman Tigran Petrosian were drawn. Each game, at adjournment, had been whittled down to a rook-andpawns ending, with material uneven.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 24 (UPI) Arrangements were completed today for a return match between the heavyweight champion, Sonny Liston, and Floyd Patterson. The bout will be held in the Las Vegas Convention Center, according to Al Bolan, the promoter of Championship Sports Inc.

A political wrangle that has plagued West Germany for years and had begun to affect its role in world affairs has at last been settled. Over the opposition of Chancellor Adenauer, his Christian Democratic party has nominated Economics Minister Ludwig Erhard as his successor. The end of the "Adenauer era" is approaching.
A decline of 828,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, April 24 Atomic Energy Commission scientists were not greatly im pressed today by the critical factors of confinement time, temperature and particle density reported by the Soviet researchers. But they said the type of device used in the experiments might be significant.

PARIS, April 24 The widow of Julian Grimau Garcia, the Spanish Communist leader who was executed in Madrid Saturday, accused Generalissimo Francisco Franco today of an act of "political vengeance and of hate."
The delicate balance of power in the Middle East is being altered by political developments and modern technology.
The New York Hilton plans to use an I.B.M. 1401 RAMAC data-processing system to compute guest charges immediately as they are incurred.
WASHINGTON, April 24 The House of Representatives approved today a $205,700,000 program of aid to medical education.
With one exception, trading on the European stock markets was indecisive and quiet yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP)--Avery C. Adams said today he will retire May 1 as board chairman and chief executive officer of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth largest steel producer.
THINKING things over thoughtfully--which is the best way of thinking-- Herbert Hoover has just finished a little book about fishing.
FONTANA, Calif. April 25-- Nearly 4,000 workers at the Kaiser Steel plant here received today a month's bonus averaging $75.
A long-range master plan for the development of the Hudson River from the Battery to 72d Street was made public at City Hall yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 25--Odell Lewis of Sarasota, Fla., today drove a 25-foot Bertram to victory in the 159-mile Miami-to-Nassau powerboat race in the record time of 3 hours 20 minutes 21 seconds, finishing 1 minute 32 seconds in front of Johnny Bakos of St. Cloud, Fla.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- Gen. Lucius D. Clay told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today how it could cut $200,000,000 more from President Kennedy's foreign aid request.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 25-- Iran's new Minister of Agriculture said today that he felt the country had passed the critical point in its land-reform revolution.
Franz Hals's "The Merry Lute Player," one of the Dutch painter's best known character pieces, is expected to bring between $700,000 and $800,000 when it is auctioned next Wednesday evening.
The proposed acquisition of the Tennessee Corporation by the Cities Service Company may result in legal proceedings by the Justice Department under the antitrust laws.

WASHINGTON, April 25--A Government steel expert pictured the steel industry today as sore beset by competition from abroad and at home, particularly from sub stituted materials. Louis J. Paradiso of the Commerce Department, a witness before the Joint Economic Committee

RUDOLF NUREYEV gave his first performance here with the Royal Ballet last night, and Dame Margot Fonteyn danced magnificently. Their appearance, at the Metropolitan Opera House, was in "Giselle." Dame Margot was, naturally, in the title role, and Mr. Nureyev was Albrecht.

The nation's newspaper publishers announced yesterday the start of "a series of studies" to seek solutions to labor problems that caused protracted strikes in the last year. They emphasized that their aim was to preserve "free local collective bargaining."

GENEVA, April 25--The United States and the European Common Market remain divided in their approach to the vital international trade negotiations scheduled for next year, a high United States official said today.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Consumer Price Index rose by one-tenth of 1 per cent in March.
AMERICUS, Ga., April 25-- A white voter registration worker reported tonight that he had been attacked and beaten here after accompanying a Negro girl to the Sumter County registrar's office.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- Last fall's quarantine of Cuba was praised and denounced today at a meeting of the American Society of International Law.
SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., April 25--Dr. Samuel Berg, a dentist and civic leader here, died today at the age of 75.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 25--Indian and Pakistani negotiators agreed today to open a sixth round of talks on the Kashmir problem May 15 in New Delhi. Pakistani delegates declared it would be the last round in a series that began in December.
