While the band played "Roses of Picardy" and sentiment and cigar smoke filled the air, 150 waltzing couples locked in embrace recaptured their first scent of romance early yesterday morning at Roseland Dance City.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)--Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, in reply to a challenge from President Kennedy, said today he was not afraid of going to war over Cuba. But he did not advocate an early invasion of the island.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 25 --Two babies burned to death today in a farm workers' camp that has been the scene of at least six fatal fires in recent years.
Roy Hamey is not quite ready to ask that Yankee Stadium be designated a disaster area, but if the Bombers' injury list expand, the general manager may be so tempted.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Administration won a narrow victory tonight as the House passed a farm bill that Democratic leaders hope will influence the important national wheat referendum next month.

SEATTLE, Wash., April 25-- Renewed efforts by aircraft machinists to obtain further contract concessions from the Boeing Company were rejected today. Both sides had reached an agreement in Washington April 15, which was narrowly rejected by the union membership.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 25--The American Association of Advertising Agencies amended its constitution today to clear the way for public ownership of member agencies.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 25--Allan F. Kitchel, former chairman of the Board of Estimate and Taxation here and retired chairman of Binney Smith, Inc., in New York, died this morning at his home on Binney Lane in Old Greenwich. He was 77 years old.

The United States soon will have to adopt every trade-promotion technique used by competing countries in further intensifying its own export expansion, Luther H. Hodges, Secretary of Commerce, declared yesterday.

YONKERS, April 25--The 31,071 customers at Yonkers Raceway tonight saw as exciting a horse race as any honest, upright race-tracker could ask. The horses in the $60,000 United Nations Trot provided a ring-tailed sizzler of a finish.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25-- Of all American rowing coaches, Joe Burk of Pennsylvania has been the most enthusiastic over the visit here of the German Ratzeburg crew, which will race Penn, Princeton and Columbia in the Childs Cup regatta at Princeton Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)--Representative Bob Wilson of California, chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, described President Kennedy's foreign policy tonight as one of "defeat, retreat and deceit."

A 33-year-old Bronx man said to have been involved in a supermarket robbery was arrested yesterday. He was named as an accomplice by Robert Bowerman, who is charged with shooting two detectives in Times Square on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, April 25--New heights of glory were attained by the Mets today when they again defeated the Chicago Cubs, this time by 3--2. With the help of the Reds, who lost to the Dodgers, 7--1, tonight, the Mets moved into eighth place.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- Rail and truck loadings ended April 20 were slightly above the preceding week. However, they were below the similar 1962 week.
FURNISHINGS scaled for small apartments and moderate budgets have been assembled in a new shop that opens today on the second floor of W J Sloane.

The conviction of former Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh of Brooklyn for taking a $22,500 bribe to fix a bankruptcy fraud case in Federal Court was upheld unanimously yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
Dr. George James, the City Health Commissioner, warned yesterday of "ominous signs" that tuberculosis might be "girding for a comeback."

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 25-- --Chateaugay of the Darby Dan Farm rallied after being overtaken in the stretch and won the $30,300 Blue Grass Stakes at the Keeneland Race Course today.
WASHINGTON, April 25--A global weather surveillance network, using satellites, robot ground stations, rockets and balloons, was recommended today in a report by the National Academy of Sciences.

A new production of Verdi's "La Traviata," designed and staged by Luchino Visconti, the Italian director, will be given on June 20 at the opening of the sixth annual Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy.

LONDON, April 25--The British Admiralty and security services were virtually absolved of blame today for the conditions that permitted a civilian Admiralty clerk to work undetected as a spy for the Soviet Union for more than seven years.
The six-story elevator building containing 47 apartments at 818 Fairmount Place, near Marmion Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by George Hanns to a client of the Levites Realty Company, the broker.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- President Kennedy has been asked by a group of his advisers to ban the creation of new military bases, space installations and other Government facilities in areas where discrimination in housing exists.

UTICA, N.Y., April 25--John M. Bailey, the Democratic National Chairman, and William H. McKeon, the state chairman, urged upstate Democrats today to start work at once on the 1964 Presidential campaign.
LONDON, April 25--A British neuropathologist has found that brain damage suffered by boxers is probably caused by the overstretching of nerves and veins by blows to the head.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 25 (AP)--The Studebaker Corporation reported today a loss of $6,400,000 for the first quarter of 1963. This compared with a loss of $2,600,000 a year ago.

MOSCOW, April 25--W. Averell Harriman, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, arrived today to seek Premier Khrushchev's help in restoring peace in Laos. The Presidential envoy received a cool official greeting.

PARIS, April 25--Ambrose Ely Chambers, former United States diplomat and Naval officer and a leader of the American community in Paris, died last night on his 64th birthday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 25--The bacteria that killed two patients in New Rochelle Hospital last weekend after routine surgery and made another patient gravely ill were identified today by pathologists, but intensive investigation failed to trace the source of infection.

Sincere, informed and widespread protests against his tax and budget program have failed to move Mayor Wagner. With a stubbornness worthy of a better cause, he defended the salestax increase to 4 per cent in a television-radio address that completely missed the main point at issue: whether there is a better way to raise the needed revenue.

SPRING vegetables and spring lamb are here in quantity once again. The home cook can produce delectable meals for spring luncheons or dinners by using them in combination. Two recipes that do just this are given below.

SHELAGH DELANEY has run into the sort of trouble that sometimes befalls writers who produce impressive first novels. After an exciting first play, "A Taste of Honey," she has stumbled badly over her second.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 25--Two suspects were being questioned tonight in the slaying of a Baltimore postman who was making a one-man march through the South to protest racial segregation.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 24 --The Plaine des Jarres in northeastern Laos, where an informal cease-fire last Sunday appears to have halted three weeks of fighting between neutralist and pro-Communist troops, has been called the strategic key to Laos.

VIENNA, April 25--Reliable reports of fresh anti-Stalinist ferment throughout the Czechoslovak Communist party and of a possibly nationalist-oriented shake-up in the Slovak party leadership have reached Vienna

Bob Fosse, a leading choreographer-director, said yesterday that he had a show of his own conception for his wife, Gwen Verdon, the dancing star. It's an off-beat idea, dominated by movement and dance, that he has been thinking about for five years.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- Premier Khrushchev's anticipation of retirement was read today as confirmation that he faced mounting political pressure and challenge.

The report of the Presidential Committee on International Air Transport Policy is getting the disappointed notices of an overballyhooed Broadway musical that turns out to have familiar tunes and plot relieved by only an occasional fresh idea. The seven-member group spent two years and more than $300,000....
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 25--A school desegregation crisis drew nearer today in Alabama despite a conference between Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy and Gov. George C. Wallace.
MONTREAL, April 25--Wise management, increased safety and lower fares were urged on the world's airlines today by a leading international aviation official.
CHICAGO, April 25 (UPI) --Soybeans soared more than 5 cents a bushel and led most grains up today on the Board of Trade.
The Treasury's gold stock has held steady for eight consecutive weeks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 25--The bravest man in Washington today is Senator Philip A. Hart of Michigan. He has set himself the task of convincing the Congress that the women of this country want to be told the truth about everything they buy, including all those things they wear under all those things, and all those sweet deceptions they use to make themselves pretty.
ROCKVILLE, Md., April 25-- Concerted opposition to the proposed repeal of an antidiscrimination law in this prosperous Washington suburb seems to have assured the law's staying on the books.

Affectionately, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's flashy 3-year-old dark bay filly with the popular parents, Swaps and Searching, had everything in her favor yesterday and won the 10,000 Douglaston allowance race at Aqueduct with the greatest of ease.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The House Appropriations Committee, reflecting Congressional unrest, recommended today an $18,000,000 cut in the budget request for the National Insti tutes of Health.

The head of United Air Lines offered evidence yesterday that the company's new one-class passenger service was thriving. Th evidence was, in effect, a reply to criticism of the service by a rival airline.

THIS summer will abound in color and fresh fragrance if the cosmetics manufacturers have their way. New summer make-up and skin preparations are streaming into the stores, offering a woman many ways to keep cool and pretty.
STAMFORD, Conn., April 25 --Benny Goodman, long a resident here, will appear with other artists this summer in a series of four concerts for the benefit of the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.
Pilots on American Airlines have deepened their split with the parent Air Line Pilots Association by taking action to form their own independent union.

One of the hardest features of the Latin-American scene for North Americans to understand is the inability of the United States to line up the Organization of American States on our side against the Castro regime. The latest failure-- and it was a failure despite an apparent voting victory--has just occurred over investigating Communist subversion by the Cuban Government.
THE buzzer sounded and Bob Cousy flung the ball skyward in sheer exultation. He was entitled to the gesture. A glorious career on the court had reached a glorious end.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)--The House Appropriations Committee accused the Administration today of "inexcusable procrastination" in attacking the problem of genetic changes.
The New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday voted "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" the best play of the 1962-63 season.

To open its spring season of contemporary opera, the New York City Opera Company last night introduced Benjamin Britten's "A Midsummer Night's Dream" to this city. First given in June of 1960, the Britten opera has made the international rounds, which means performances all over Europe as well as the United States.
MOSCOW, April 25--Premier Khrushchev has told an industrial conference that at the age of 69 he cannot be expected to continue "for all time" in the positions he holds.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 25 (UPI)--The United States scored four more brilliant swimming victories, won eight gold medals in wrestling and took one in tennis tonight in the Pan-American Games.
Faculty salaries at colleges and universities throughout the country increased significantly last year, a survey by the American Association of University Professors indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 25--A group of leading businessmen formally organized today to support substantial tax reduction, but not tax reform, this year.

WASHINGTON, April 25--All people, particularly statesmen, politicians and press oracles, who shift positions when circumstances alter cases, incur the charge of inconsistency. But unless the shift is from what they proclaimed to be fundamental principles, the human majority is disposed to agree with Emerson's comment that "A foolish...
YONKERS, April 25--A cool, confident drive by Billy Haughton brought Duke Rodney home the winner in the $60,000 United Nations Trot tonight before 31,071 fans at Yorkers Raceway.

Television and radio rights to the National Football League's 1963 championship game were purchased yesterday for $926,000 by the National Broadcasting Company. The Columbia Broadcasting System, the only other network to submit a bid, offered $750,000.

PARIS, April 25--A great many Europeans who believe in the Atlantic community, meaning a strong link between the United States and Western Europe, hope that America will do something soon to stop what is termed the rot in Western Europe.
Two counts of a four-count indictment against Jerome J. Robinson, president of the Duncan Parking Meter Company of Chicago, were dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles Marks.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 25--Relations between this country's two great religious bodies--Roman Catholicism and Protestantism--have never been better. Evidence of this new climate of friendly rapprochement crops up almost daily.
The committee planning the 11th annual art sale and exhibition for the American Friends of Hebrew University has announced that 23 pieces of sculpture by Henry Moore have been lent for the event.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 25 (UPI)--Jo Ann Prentice of Birmingham, Ala., shot a one-under-par 71 today and took the first-round lead in the Women's Titleholders golf tournament.

PANAMA, April 25 (AP)-- Panama complained today that the United States seemed to be underrating the joint commission set up nearly a year ago after talks with President Kennedy to settle differences between the two countries.
LISBON, April 25--Portugal's Foreign Minister repeated today an offer to confer with African countries on "matters of common interest."
The small investor, who turned his back on the overthe-counter market almost a year ago, now apparently is taking a fresh look.

LONDON, April 25--Britain, always more optimistic than the United States about negotiations with the Soviet Union, is not ready to write off the British-American approach to Prermier Khrushchev to revive the deadlocked negotiations for a treaty to ban nuclear testing.

In the chapel of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon Mrs. Elizabeth Fiske Hitchcock of Washington, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George C. Hitchcock of St. Louis, was married to John Planten Gaillard. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Dawson Gaillard of New York.
Progress was made yesterday in untangling the affairs of the Continental Vending Machine Corporation of Westbury, L.I., and Miami.
Mayor Wagner released a report yesterday disclosing a crisis in skilled manpower in New York City government.

THE Hunter College Schubert-Janacek-Stravinsky series, which has already given New York two of its most distinguished concerts of chamber and vocal music this season, continued in that vein last night for its third event.
Tentative plans for a city conference on race and religion in November were announced yesterday by the Mayor's Committee of Religious Leaders.
LAGOS, Nigeria, April 25-- President Sekou Toure of Guinea began today a four-day state visit to Nigeria that could mark a turning point in African politics.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) had an estimated consolidated net income of $259,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, M.J. Rathbone, chairman, announced yesterday. This is equal to $1.20 a share. Total revenues were $2,746,000,000.
WASHINGTON, April 25--A major step toward creating a Fire Island National Seashore was taken today.

ATTEMPTS to marry written poetry and the visual image are usually unconsummated or end in quick divorce. By a convenient coincidence there are two attempts on display--one at the Steuben Glass Building, Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, the other, an exhibition by Elise Asher at the East Hampton Gallery, 22 West 56th Street.

Cafe Chauveron, 139 East 53d Street, PL 1-6480. This is one of the most agreeable of the town's high-style restaurants, with one of the best French kitchens. It can be said of the Chauveron, as it can of few of its counterparts, that the entrees are almost consistently first rate. Complete luncheons from $4.50 to $8. Dinners are

THERE is a bounty of beef headed for market during the next few months. According to the United States Department of Agriculture, supplies of meat for the first half of this year will be almost 10 per cent higher than they were for the first six months of 1962. This means that reasonable prices should be in order.

LINDENHURST, L.I., April, 25--Vital financial records of this South Shore village, missing since the newly elected Democratic administration took over from the Republicans April 1, were returned today as mysteriously as they had disappeared.
A Cornell University ecologist urged a more cautious use of chemical pesticides yesterday to avoid destruction of plant and animal life.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 25 (AP)--The defending champion, Billy Joe Patton, today shot one-under-par golf to beat Cobby Ware of Augusta, Ga., 5 and 3, and lead Ray Terry, Bob Allen and John Guenther into the semi-finals of the North and South amateur tournament.
MALVERNE, L.I., April 25-- Oliver H. West, an 83-year-old resident here, is celebrating his 25th year this month as a cooperative weather observer for the United States Weather Bureau.
The national Roman Catholic weekly, America, has come out in support of a "fair Sabbath" law for New York City.

The Martin-Marietta Corporation, which derives half of its profits from defense and half from construction materials, contemplates diversifying within the next few years into another area of business.

THERE were so many courageous ideas, rich in ventions and beautiful performances on stage at the Kaufmann Concert Hall last night that one could only wish for a solo concert soon by most of the eight choreographers represented.

The need for modern teachers who can keep pace with today's highly imaginative and creative youngsters was stressed yesterday at a conference of the National Education Association and the Magazine Publishers Association.

The New York Philharmonic commissioned Paul Hindemith to write a work to celebrate the opening season of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, and last night the composer led the piece in Philharmonic Hall.
ALBANY, April 25--State control over real estate syndicate dividends was authorized in a bill signed today by Governor Rockefeller.

ONE of the deepest and most powerful needs of men is the need to believe and belong. So I will demolish your faith. My

THE Marchese Emilio Pucci, the Florentine couturier who designs everything from yachts to collapsible umbrellas, hurried into New York between political speeches in Italy this week to see the skiwear he created. He was in America only 23 hours.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today that a United States warning, of "overwhelming retaliatory action" caused the Soviet Union to back down in the crisis last fall over Soviet missiles in Cuba.
TRENTON, April 25--Gov. Richard J. Hughes' $750,000,000 bond proposal will be the key issue in the fall campaign in New Jersey.
THE Westchester Contract Bridge Association will conduct its annual Empire State tournament this weekend at the Woman's Club of New Rochelle.
The early-spring romance of two homing pigeons from New Jersey is supposed to reach its conclusion here today.

Dr. Frederic Wolcott Bancroft, a leading surgeon here who retired in 1955, died Wednesday in the Veterans Administration Hospital, at First Avenue and 24th Street. He was 82 years old and lived at 271 Avenue C.

ROME, April 25--Many Italians believe that the general election to be held on Sunday and Monday to elect a Senate of 315 and a Chamber of Deputies of 630 may mark the first decrease in the Communist vote for Parliament since World War II.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has warned Congress against accepting the idea that a "nuclear stalemate" has developed between the United States and the Soviet Union, and that the prospects for war have been removed.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc. reported a decline in earnings yesterday for 1962 despite increased sales. The Gimbel annual report showed net income for the year ended Jan. 31, 1963 at $10,293,880, or $2.42 a share.
BONN, April 25--Chancellor Adenauer pleaded today for quick ratification of the FrenchGerman Treaty of Cooperation as a way to secure peace.

Stock prices followed an irregular course in moderately active trading yesterday. They drifted lower in the first three hours and then recovered most of their losses in the final 90 minutes of trading.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- Treasury officials and Wall Street men agreed today that the breakup of the Government's bond underwriting syndicate should exert a strengthening influence on Government bond prices--though perhaps not in the first few days.

A 30-year-old lawyer who has been spearheading the drive against the proposed Hall of Science at the World's Fair found yesterday that some of the city's top officials admired him even if they could not agree with him.

Rene Clement, in addition to being one of France's most distinguished "old-guard" directors, is conspicuously alert to new film trends. Without shifting the scene of his activities, he is turning increasingly toward American-financed, English-language films.
SPACIOUS "islands" offering instant comforts to boat owners are among the new concepts incorporated in the Flushing Meadow Park Marina, now under development in Flushing Bay, Queens.
Cocoa and sugar futures rose sharply in heavy trading yesterday. Most other commodities traded in New York were higher in quiet dealings.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) --Increasing Federal bank deposit insurance from $10,000 to $25,000 would lessen "public interest in the stability of banks," the House Banking Committee was told today.

CHICAGO, April 25 (UPI) --The National League president, Warren Giles, today asked team managers for their opinions on the major leagues' controversial balk rule. He learned immediately that at least two disapprove of it.

Arthur B. Homer, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said yesterday that the present attitude of the Administration was "much more favorable toward business improvement and expansion" than it was a year ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 (AP)--Orlando Cepeda and Ed Bailey crashed home runs today in leading the San Francisco Giants to an 8-4 victory over St. Louis. The victory gained the Giants a first-place tie in the National League with the Cardinals.
City motorists face an inincrease in parking rates as a result of Mayor Wagner's proposed commercial occupancy tax.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP)-- Aleksandt Pavolovich, the leader of a Soviet delegation of book publishers touring the United States, said today that abstract art was neither understood nor wanted in the Soviet Union.
Governor Rockefeller proposed last night that the Western European nations set up "a combined European nuclear force" that would work in "genuine partnership" with the... United States nuclear force.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he planned to confer with Chief Criminal Court Judge John M. Murtagh on charges that the city's courts had been too lenient with landlords convicted of slum housing violations.

The Gotham Bowl, New York's controversial two-year experiment in post-season college football, came to an end yesterday--not with a bang, but with an adverse ruling by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

DAVID TAYLOR STANLEY told the Women's City Club yesterday that the problem of finding highly qualified employes for the city government reminded him of the story of the six Boy Scouts and the old lady:

With the Geneva disarmament conference deadlocked, the United States and Britain have again presented to Moscow new proposals on a nuclear test ban. This move was initiated by Britain with an eye to promoting a Big Three foreign ministers conference or even a summit meeting and incidentally to aid Prime Minister Macmillan in his impending election battle with the Laborites.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25--The American university that is emerging from the present ferment in the "education industry" will serve as a model for the rest of the world, a California educator said tonight.
A gift of $500,000 from Mrs. Henry L. Moses to establish the Henry and Lucy Moses Chair of Neurology at Columbia University was announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of the university.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 25-- President Joao Goulart of Brazil wound up a three-day visit today and could look back on a triumph in personal and political relations. He came in contact with nearly everyone from President to workers in their new low-cost homes and seemed to have conquered all.

Hair-drying machines, which are beginning to appear in coin laundries for women who want to wash their hair while waiting for their laundry to be washed, are subject to state regulation, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ruled yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 25--The Soviet Union's powerful watchdog agency has reached into the highest levels of Government to censure and humiliate a Deputy Premier of the Byelorussian Republic.

A campaign to increase voter registration in the BedfordStuyvesant area of Brooklyn will be supported by a $10,000 grant from the Concord Baptist Church of Christ, the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Gardner C. Taylor, announced yesterday.
Russian audiences are developing a taste for American serious music, but the development still has to be coddled, an American pianist reported yesterday.
GADSDEN, Ala., April 27 (AP)--Sheriff Dewey Colvard called on the Federal Bureau of Investigation tonight to help solve the slaying of William L. Moore.

PARIS, April 26--Gerard Pipart is reliably reported to be the successor to Jules-Francois Crahay as the designer for Nina Ricci, although the couture house has not yet officially confirmed the appointment, Crahay has announced he will design for the house of Lanvin this fall.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)-- Jack Bradfute, a New York advertising executive, died on the way to a hospital today. His age was 41. Officials at the Sheraton-Blackstone Hotel, where Mr. Bradfute was staying, had called an ambulance when he com plained of being ill.

MEXICO CITY, April 26-- Economic regionalism must not be allowed to become economic nationalism on a large scale, the International Chamber of Commerce declared here today as a statement of policy on common market practices.
After some years in the doldrums, the rail stocks came to life this week and gave the whole market an impetus to move forward. For the rails it was a memorable week.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 26--Surgery was resumed today at New Rochelle Hospital, where two persons died Monday of infections following operations. A third patient was made ill, but recovered.
PARIS, April 26--Responsible French opinion appeared tonight to be hardening against any announcement by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization of the formation of a NATO nuclear force.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., April 26--"Tonight I give in," a young Greenville, S.C., insurance salesman named William Hart McCorkle wrote in the flyleaf of his New Testament one night in May, 1925. "Whatever you want me to do," he wrote, "I'll try." He tried and succeeded.

Dr. William J. McConnell, former associate medical director of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company here, died Wednesday in Miami Beach. He was 74 years old and lived at 125 Northfield Avenue in West Orange, N.J.
SANTA ANA, Calif., April 26 (AP)--Mrs. Dorothy O'Hara Lunney, a California fashion designer, died of a brain tumor today. He age was 51.
The Police Department began a campaign yesterday to reduce drunken driving, the theft of automobiles and the operation of vehicles by youths without licenses.

MIAMI, April 26--The Cuban Government radio said tonight that bombs were dropped by an unidentified plane on oil refineries in Regla across the bay from downtown Havana. According to the broadcast, the bombs did not explode and no one was injured.
ATLANTA, April 26--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy defended today the Administration's appointment of Southern segregationists to the Federal bench.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 26 --Premier Souvanna Phouma of Laos will fly to the Plaine des Jarres tomorrow for new talks with Prince Souphanouvong, his pro-Communist half-brother, in an effort to restore the ceasefire in this disturbed country.

New York City's newest municipal golf course, Douglaston Park will be opened to the public today. The formerly private North Hills Golf Club of Douglaston, Queens, after a dedication ceremony yesterday that was attended by city officials, became the latest layout for the public links devotee.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26--In a heated session today Britain firmly rejected suggestions by the Committee on Colonialism for a visiting commission to study conditions in the Aden colony and the surrounding Federation of South Arabia.
A top-ranking Israeli shipping executive has been rocking the boat back home by steering straight into a hot historical controversy.
Bertram Peacock, Singer and actor who played the role of Franz Schubert the original "Blossom Time," died yesterday in his home at 112-15 72d Road in Forest Hills, Queens. His age was 79.

MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif., April 26--Ethel Shutta, the singer with George Olsen's band during the nineteen-thirties, is taking a short vacation from her Greenwich Village flat. The whe will return to Broadway, after an absence of 20 years.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- No matter what subject is up for debate, all that Farm members of Congress want to talk about these days is next month's national referendum on a new wheat-production control plan.

MOSCOW, April 26--Premier Khrushchev has expressed confidence that writers and artists who have strayed from the party line will "look at life from a new angle" and contribute to the achievement of Communist goals.
CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)-- Home runs by Wes Covington and Johnny Callison and the pitching of Art Mahaffey gave the Philadelphia Phils a 5-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

BOSTON, April 26--The Navy's bathyscaph Trieste arrived today in Boston to help try to find out what happened to the nuclear submarine Thresher, lying in 8,400 feet of water 220 miles east of Massachusetts.
THE Royal Ballet presented "Swan Lake" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the first time during the company's current visit here.
Stock prices closed in a mixed pattern yesterday--more stocks rose than fell, but on average they finished the day with a small loss. Volume dwindled to the lowest level in four weeks.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 26 --The world champion Ratzeburg crew faces the first real test of its American tour here tomorrow.
Top-weighted Crimson Satan, just about the richest "sick" horse of 1962, is likely to go to the post as the favorite in the 20th running of the $75,000 added Grey Lag Handicap today at Aqueduct.

"The more it changes the more it is the same" can certainly be said of the skilled manpower problem in New York City's government, as described and prescribed for by the Brookings Institution personnel report made public with considerable fanfare yesterday. Acting on its findings with consummate dispatch, Mayor Wagner ordered that "highest priority" be given to corrective measures.
BONN, April 26--Vice Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said tonight that he would make no move to revamp the West German Government before he took over from Chancellor Adenauer, presumbly in October.
Jason Robards Jr., one of the theater's major performers, has committed himself to appear in four plays over a two-year period for the Lincoln Center Repertory Company.
A city Health Department plea for a jail sentence for a landlord with 56 convictions was rejected yestercday in the housing part of Criminal Court for the third time this week.
Stockholders of Tower Universal Corporation attacked management yesterday at the annual meeting for recent corporate activities.

The $5 million grant by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for the establishment of a Center of Advanced Engineering Study is significant far beyond the frontiers of one campus. It is a hint of the future pattern of education and man power.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 26 --H.T. Lowe-Porter, a poet and the translator of Thomas Mann's works, died today in Merwick, a nursing home of Princeton Hospital, where she had been for six years. She was 86 years old.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 26--Scores of schoolchildren and adults kicked and trampled their way today through 50,000 books stacked along a 400-foot lane.

MOSCOW, April 26--Premier Khrushchev joined President Kennedy today in reaffirming full support for the Geneva agreements of June 12, 1962, that provided for the creation of a unified Laos under a neutral government.

WASHINGTON, April. 26-- The Senate Government Operations Committee voted today to seek a review of the Nassau County contract to buy 435 acres of the former Mitchel Air Force Base with a view to cutting the cost far below the $13,628,000 the Government asks.
ALONG the banks of streams, on lawns, and in meadows and produce departments, the thin, tubular, green stalks of the chive plant are much in evidence as harbingers of other spring and summer herbs.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 26--Gunmen shot and killed four special palace escorts for President Francois Duvalier's two teen-age children today. The children were on their way to school two blocks from the National Palace.

Dr. George A. Weiss, a senior information analyst for the Free Europe Committee, died Thursday of a coronary occlusion in his office at 2 Park Avenue. He was 64 years old, and lived at 106 Cabrini Bouelvard.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)--Tom Cheney hurled a three-hitter tonight that gave the Washington Senators a 6-0 victory over the Kansas City Athletics, who won the opener of a twilight-night double-header, 12--10, in 13 innings.
CINCINNATI, April 26 (AP) --The spreading controversy over calling balks in the National League today resulted in a temporary halt in the strict interpretation of the rule by umpires.
Sugar and cocoa futures advanced in very active trading yesterday.
The problem of taming the reaction that makes possible hydrogen bombs--and putting it to work for peaceful purposes--has turned into one of the most difficult tasks of modern science.

IN Bill Mauldin's immortal cartoon saga of World War II there is a memorable literary moment. Willie says: "You'll git over it, Joe. Once I wuz gonna write a book exposin' th' Army after th' war, myself."
Half-fare air travel for United Nations personnel on the systems of American Airlines and Trans World Airlines will not be permitted, at least for now, the Civil Aeronautics Board has ruled.

William H. Loughran, administrative chief of the New York County District Attorney's office, died yesterday of a cerebral thrombosis in Bay Ridge Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 7905 10th Avenue, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The United States suggested today 10 ways in which the United Nations could be pro gressively strengthened for peace-keeping operations.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 26 (AP)--South Vietnam's massive American-backed military machine is confused and sluggish in its response to a Communist guerrilla onslought on the Camau peninsula, American military sources charge.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- An agency of the United States Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. authorized negotiations today to buy 10 hospitals in Kentucky, West Virginia and Virginia from the United Mine Workers of America Welfare Fund.

WITH June coming soon, many New Yorkers may be busy gift shopping for brides-to-be. Those who are unfamiliar with the future brides' tastes and needs may have difficulty in selecting appropriate gifts.
United Nations television plans to have its camera crews abroad by summer filming the story of the struggle to close the widening gap between the underdeveloped nations and the rest of the world.
The owner of an East Side nightclub testified yesterday that an employe of the State Liquor Authority had demanded $2,000 as the price for being allowed to keep his liquor license.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The Ford Motor Company has patented equipment to keep its Aeolus on the rails at Speeds from 200 to 500 miles an hour.
PHILADELPHIA, April 26-- Members of the Philadelphia Orchestra have "stunned" their management (in its own words) by demanding the right to dismiss their conductor.

HOUSTON, April 26 (AP)-- Houston's Bob Bruce pitched the first one-hitter in the National League this season, allowing only a first-inning single to right field by Vada Pinson tonight as the Colts defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 2--0.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 26 (UPI)--Cuba jolted the United States hopes for its first baseball gold medal in the four-year history of the Pan--American Games today by scoring a 3-1 victory.
The Department of Sanitation has rescheduled its weekend operations to make men and equipment available to help the Fire Department fight possible brush fires.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)--A realignment of United States air defenses was announced today by the Defense Department.

Stockholders of the Glickman Corporation voted yesterday to change the name of the real estate investment company to the Franchard Corporation. But the financial difficulties of its founder and former top official, Louis J. Glickman, dominated the annual meeting, at which tempers flared.
All that glitters at the special exhibition opening tomorrow at the Brooklyn Museum is truly gold.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 26--American yachtsmen racing in this British colony found today that their cup of tea is a light wind.

Like the whooping crane, individual violin makers are approaching extinction. New York nearly lost another recently when Luthier Rosenthal was forced to vacate the shop he had rented for 30 years in the Rembrandt Building next door to Carnegie Hall.

ROME, April 26--The conclusion of a long-term agreement between the Italian State Oil Agency, E.N.I. and Esso Standard International was described here today as implementing the basic policy of E.N.I. as laid down by its first president, the late Enrico Mattei.
GENEVA, April 26--The World Meteorological Organization approved today a plan for mapping the weather around the globe.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Integration groups asserted today that President Kennedy was not really trying to implement his own order to end discrimination in housing.
Local 1814 of the International Longshoremen's Association, the Brooklyn local, has "found" 700 more jobs for its 8,500 members.
CHICAGO, April 26 (UPI)-- Soybeans and rye futures were mixed and wheat fell today on the Board of Trade.
In the world of professional football, seven playing seasons add up to a lot of bruises, sprains, aches and pains.
A sharp drop in sales and earnings was reported by the American Tobacco Company yesterday in its statement for the first three months of this year.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 26--Devout Thais, who have believed in the spirit world since the dawn of remembered history, are gradually finding compromises with the Machine Age, which has come only recently to this ancient Buddhist kingdom. Everywhere in this capital city one sees "spirit houses."

ALBANY, April 26 (AP)-- Governor Rockefeller's schedule contains no official activities from May 9 through May 31, but his press office maintained its tight "no comment" today on reports that he will marry Mrs. Margaretta Murphy next month.
WASHINGTON, April 26--One of the graver problems confronting this country today is the traffic-sign explosion.
The scheduled sale of $115, 000,000 of Placer County Water Agency, Calif., revenue bonds next Wednesday is the largest issue set for competitive sale next week.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 26 (AP)--Tom O'Hara overcame a 50-yard deficit as anchorman today and carried Loyola of Chicago to a record in the distance medley of the 54th Drake Relays.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)--The Government announced today the settlement of civil damage suits against seven electrical companies for a total of $272,450.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The 1961 death of a Cuban at the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo made news today with a report that he had been killed by a Marine Corps captain who was secretly dismissed from the service for his act.
LONDON, April 26--Prime Minister Macmillan launched one of his bitterest attacks on the opposition Labor party tonight, stirring new speculation that he was getting ready for an election this year.
A geneticist proposed yesterday that male sperm be stored underground in a deep freeze to protect man's descendants from the mutagenic effects of radia tion.
BONN, April 26--Leaders of the West German Parliament reluctantly bowed today to an Allied veto of plans to convene the Bundestag, or lower house, in Berlin next month.

AS the second in a monthly series that Channel 9, in a remarkable burst of selfexamination, has singled out to be entitled "family programs," the station presented a one-hour concert last night by Robert Shaw and the Cleveland Orchestra.

CLARKSBURG, W.Va., April 26--The tragedy at Compass No. 2 mine, where 22 men were killed late last night in a terrific explosion of methane gas and coal dust, entered its inevitable sequel late today when rescue squads began bringing up the bodies of the victims.
A STORY from an old book that doesn't get told very often these days came true at Town Hall last night.

Birny Mason Jr., president of the Union Carbide Corporation, told some 800 stockholders attending its annual meeting here yesterday that the present Federal corporate tax structure is keeping many companies from undertaking business ventures.
LONDON, April 26 (AP)-- United States firmness succeeded today in postponing higher trans-Atlantic air fares.
Mickey Mantle appeared fit to play against Cleveland in the two-game series, beginning today at Yankee Stadium, but Roger Maris's status remains questionable.
The American taxpayer who seems to take a perverse pride in the thought that he pays the world's highest taxes would be surprised to learn that this isn't true.
"Street Scene," the second offering in the New York City Opera's three-week season, opened last night and if there are still people who have not seen the work, the advice is to go.

MACUTO, Venezuela, April 26--The director or the American aid program declared today that Alliance for Progress aid could not be geared to take the place of losses suffered by Latin-American countries because of declines in export prices of their basic commodities.
Dr. Calvin E. Gross, the city's new Superintendent of Schools, called last night for a return to "intellectual development" in the schools.

BALTIMORE, April 26 (UPI) --A wild throw in the 13th inning by the center fielder, Bob Savarine, enabled Lee Thomas to score as the Los Angeles Angels gain a 4-3 victory tonight over the Baltimore Orioles.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 26 (UPI)--Mickey Wright, in quest of her third consecutive Titleholders golf triumph, stormed into the lead in the second round today by shooting an even-par 72.
The Tresury's $300,000,000 issue of 4 1/8 per cent 31-year bonds traded freely in the market yesterday as the managing syndicate dropped price restrictions with less than half of the issue sold.
The Methodist Church is celebrating the 75th anniversary of its deaconess movement, in which women dedicate themselves to full-time religious work.
Dr. Ray E. Trussell, who has been the city's Commissioner of Hospitals since March 1, 1961, will continue to head that department until June, 1964, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 26-- Seventh place, at least for the time being, proved to be a mirage for the Mets tonight. All they had to do to reach this exalted position for the first time in their experience was to beat the Pirates, because the Cubs had already lost an afternoon game in Chicago.
LONDON, April 26--The Archbishop of Canterbury disparaged today the arguments of those in the Church of England who are challenging the traditional concept of the deity.
Two sternwheelers, restored to the gaudiness of old Mississippi River queens, will vie on Tuesday for the title of "dowager" of the Ohio.

VINELAND, N.J., April 26-- Ardah L. Donley, Superintendent of Schools, was found guilty in Municipal Court today of leaving the scene of an accident in the death of Marie Elana Vesper, a 17-year-old junior in Sacred Heart High School.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 --Professional educators assailed today California's proposed teacher requirements giving priority to competence in subject matter over teaching method.
The National Maritime Union served notice on 84 American steamship companies yesterday that it would seek at least 3 per cent more in wages in 1965 to improve its pension program.

In the Italian general elections tomorrow and Monday, the possibility of shift lies in the narrow majority that the democratic parties had in the last elections in 1958--53.5 per cent. In fact, since the present coalition under Premier Fanfani was formed in February, 1962, the Government of Christian Democrats, Social Democrats and Republicans has only been able to get majorities in Parliament through an arrangement whereby Pietro Nenni's left-wing Socialists abstained on crucial votes.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The index of wholesale primary market prices declined onetenth per cent to 99.8 per cent of its 1957-59 base, during the week ended April 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Joey and Lenny Mangiapane, the twin welterweight boxers who nearly caused a riot at Sunnyside Garden, Queens, earlier this month, were penalized yesterday in a hearing before the New York State Athletic Commission.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 (AP)--George Altman drove in the winning run with a two-out single in the ninth inning as St. Louis wiped out an early sixrun Los Angeles lead and defeated the Dodgers, 8--7, tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk will visit Belgrade next week to signal a further improvement in relations with Yugoslavia.
TOKYO, April 22--For almost four weeks, teams of Texas Baptists have been traveling around Japan testing the theory that if Madison Avenue can sell soap it can also help sell religion.
The city's record budget of $3,093,641,582 was attacked yesterday as being both too small and too large.
LOUISVILLE, April 26--Never Bend redeemed himself today in the Stepping Stone Purse.

AS the brilliant opening fig uration of Bach's Organ Prelude and Fugue in C (B.W.V. 545) soared into the vast recesses of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church last night, a historic musical series got under way in this city.

WASHINGTON, April 26--A "substantial number" of savings and loan associations in California will announce cuts soon in the interest rates they pay their depositors, according to a Government official who has been keeping careful tabs on the situation.

OTTWA, April 26--Ambassador Christian A. Herter, President Kennedy's special trade negotiator, met with Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson and other high Canadian officials today to discuss the proposed multilateral tariff negotiations that may be held next year.
YONKERS, April 26--With an impressive late drive in the last quarter, Irvin Paul, the even-money choice, won the $25,000 Alden Pace tonight before a crowd of 27,137 at Yonkers Raceway.
Tighter supervision of the private carting industry in the city was called for yesterday in a report to Mayor Wagner by a three-man citizens' committee.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- Under Secretary of State George W. Ball said today that a nuclear force under the North Atlantic Treaty Oganization would be imperfect but was the only practical solution to a difficult problem.

M.K.M. Murphy, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, died Thursday in Beekman-Downtown Hospital after having suffered a heart attack in the bank building at 165 Broadway. He was 61 years old and lived at 256 Van Winkel Place in Rutherford, N.J.
BONN, April 26--A United States diplomat urged memners of the European Common Market today to act speedily in formulating directives for next year's trade negotiations.
CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)-- Fact-finding hearings by a Presidential emergency board on the work-rules dispute between the nation's railroads and five operating unions will move to New York next week.

PARIS, April 26--Western Europe's current political changes are changes more of personality than of fundamental policy. In this sense, agreement by West Germany's Christian Democratic leaders that Erhard should soon succeed Adenauer does not betoken any dramatic shift in Bonn's intentions.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26-- Fordham and Boston College, running short races over long distances, swept past Villanova today to score stunning victories in the four-mile and distance medley, respectively, as the 69th Penn Relays opened before 5,000 at Franklin Field.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt 3d of Silver Spring Farm in Paoli, Pa., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Roosevelt's sister, Mrs. Blandina Babcock Burns, to Maitland T. Ijams. He is the son of Mrs. J. Horton Ijams of Lawrence, L.I., and New York and the late Mr. Ijams.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- Nearly 2,000 Republican women were here today doing their political spring cleaning. They polished off the New Frontier from one end of Pennsylvania Avenue to the other as they opened the 11th annual national Republican women's conference at the Sheraton Park Hotel.
David Susskind, the television producer, will bring a British comedy to Broadway next season, it was learned yesterday.
The head of the Air Line Dispatchers Association believes the airlines are missing a bet in failing to improve reservations practices.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 --The American Association of University Professors voted today to censure the University of Illinois for dismissing an assistant professor of biology who publicly criticized conventional standards of sexual morality.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The permanent value of a youth project in New York City was questioned today by a House subcommittee.
A management survey has found that serious administrative weaknesses prevent the efficient operation of the city school system.

THIS is the last weekend to to see a number of important exhibitions. The Armory Show, at Lexington Avenue and 25th Street, closes Sunday evening at 11 o'clock. The fine display of Wyeth drawings at the Pierpont Morgan Library closes today.
MOSCOW, Saturday, April 27 --Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba arrived in the Soviet Union early today on Premier Khurshchev's personal invitation.

THE National Industrial Recreation Association will conduct a nationwide parhand bridge tournament today for bridge players in the 800 concerns that are members of the association. About 4,000 persons are expected to enter.

BERLIN, April 26--In a test of nerves a Soviet jet this morning repeatedly flew close to two United States Army helicopters over East and West Berlin, but the United States decided not to protest about the incidents.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation is making an offer to stockholders of the Fordyce Lumber Company of Fordyce, Ark. to purchase their stock at $400 a share, it was disclosed yesterday.
A Swedish industrialist and former diplomat forecast yesterday that compelling economic forces would bring enlargement of the European Common Market during the next two or three years.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., April 26--Four of the top women golfers of Long Island competed for top honors in the opening-day tournament of the Cross County Golf Association, won by Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley.
The London stock market continued yesterday its week-long pattern of wide activity with irregular results.
PORTLAND, Ore., April 26-- The first successful replacement of three of the heart's four valves in a human patient has been achieved by a University of Oregon heart surgical team.

HUNTINGTON, W.Va., April 26--The Rev. William H. McCorkle, newly elected Moderator of the Southern Presbyterian Church, was being hailed here today by the denomination's conservatives. They viewed him as the man to dissipate moves toward liberalism.

ALBANY, April 26--Governor Rockefeller signed a bill today authorizing New York to participate in the creation of a tristate transportation commission to undertake long-range planning for the transportation needs of the New York City metropolitan area.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 26 (UPI)--Billy Joe Patton went a step closer today to winning the North-South amateur golf tournament for the third time by eliminating Ray Terry, 1 up, in a semi-final match.
A weekly car-ferry service between the Italian Adriatic port of Ancona and Haifa, Israel, is scheduled to start next March.
Selective price increases in the steel industry have been followed in the last ten days by a wave of higher prices for metal goods ranging from turbine forgings to aluminum sidings and copper wire.
Turn forward (not backward) those clocks tonight; it's time to save daylight again.

A GRAY-HAIRED Belgian named Gustave De Busschere arrived last weekend "to get the feel of New York" and he hasn't taken his eyes off the ground since. Mr. De Busschere is the designer and sales director of a 345-year-old bootmaking concern in Bruges.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today that he would offer legislation to outlaw contributions by United States citizens on behalf of foreign clients.

WASHINGTON, April 27--India's request for an initial loan of $512,000,000 to build a Government-operated steel mill was seriously questioned today in a report to the Agency for International Development.

IN January the Ford Foundation decided to greatly expand one of its most successful musical experi ments. Not only did it elect to continue financing young composers in the school system, but it decided to work on both the elements between which the young composers have been turning out music.
At least one New York design company is providing correspondence service for design and decoration clients in jobs too small and too far away to warrant personal supervision.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26--The Massachusetts Institute of Technology varsity heavyweight crew fought off a last-minute challenge by Yale and went on to defeat the Elis today on the Housatonic River.
Uniformed chauffeurs doing "bootleg" business in expensive, gleaming limousines are arousing concern among legitimate limousine and taxicab operators and the police.
Alfonso Montecino returned to Town Hall yesterday afternoon for the first time since 1958. The Chilean pianist showed the technical assets that have marked his playing in the past.
New York City's annual expenditures for health and medical services have increased $115,000,000 since 1959, Mayor Wagner was informed yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 27--Local, state and Federal agencies have begun a new study of the Red Tide, a periodic phenomenon in the Gulf of Mexico that kills fish by the millions.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Two California scientists presented evidence here this week that they believe supports the idea that explosions consuming the equivalent of 1,000,000 or more suns occur regularly in the universe.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 --California's population boom is bringing an inexorable byproduct--a steadily increasing danger to agriculture from insect pests and diseased plants in shipments to the state.

WASHINGTON, April 27-- The residents of 36 states and nearly 2,000, cities, towns and counties fish some extra pennies out of their pockets and purses almost every time they buy anything. Those pennies, paid out as sales taxes, add up to more than $6,000,000,000 a year.
Are stockholders asking more intelligent questions at annual meetings this year?
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 27--By capturing the first race of the day, the United Kingdom earned the championship today for international 14-foot dinghies.
A THEODORE DREISER script, reportedly the only screen play written by the novelist appears to be headed toward the movies, at long last. The work, once...

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (AP)--Claude Raymond, a relief pitcher, drove in the winning run with a double in the 12th inning today to give the Milwaukee Braves a 6-5 triumph over the San Francisco Giants. It was Raymond's first hit since he moved up to the majors in 1961.

President Kennedy's slowness in implementing his five-month-old order to abolish racial bias in Federally aided housing is bound to strengthen doubts in the Negro community about the sincerity of those who advocate moderate measures to end discrimination. On no civil rights issue...

LOS ANGELES, April 27 --Ray Washburn pitched a perfect game for 6 2/3 innings and wound up with a threehitter tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3--0. Washburn scored his fourth straight victory.
Although the availability of mortgage funds from conventional sources remains high, opportunities for real-estate loans for small-business investment corporations ware continuing to expand.
BUENOS AIRES, April 23-- Four strong men have emerged from the ranks of Argentina's constantly shuffled generals as a result of the tumultuous events of recent months.

Grace Protestant Episcopal Church was the scene here yesterday afternoon of the marriage of Miss Helen Gail Walker, daughter of Rear Adm. Edward K. Walker, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Walker of Glen Rock, N.J., to Charles Robert Reuning. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. George W. Reuning of Wellsville, N.Y.

THE new contract bridge laws that will become effective Wednesday are realistic, if nothing else. They do not attempt to change the habits of bridge players and they make no provision for rare irregularities.

THE literature about Winston Churchill is so complete, one would have thought there was no room for another book. But here is another, "The War and Colonel Warden" (Colonel Warden was Churchill's wartime code name.) A very good book it is, too.

AMERICANS, especially those urged to give increased support to higher education through either personal gifts or taxes, frequently ask two questions, "Why don't colleges and universities make better use of their resources by operating on a 12-month basis?" and "Why should young people take four years to get a bachelor's degree when most of them could do it in three?"

HAROLD MACMILLAN, 69, a nickname-prone leader who has been called everything from "Supermac" to "Macmiserable," has served notice that he means to stay on at the head of the British Government for a bit, despite some grumbling...

AT 7:45 on a recent Tuesday evening the Eptagynon Club met in the small, comfortable living room of a two-story brick house in Flatbush, Brooklyn. There wasn't a good fellow in the lot and the "certain ...
WASHINGTON, April 27-- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. indicated today that his civil rights truce with the Kennedy Administration had ended.
ALBANY, April 27--Governor Rockefeller announced today that he had signed a compromise version of the controversial Condon-Wadlin antistrike law.

VIENNA, April 26--Seven weeks of discussion produced this week the first broad agreement of the International Community on Consular Rights and Privileges, including contact with arrested foreigners. But it lacked one simple safeguard-- an automatic obligation of the signatories to report such detentions to appropriate consulates.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 27 --Adelphi College announced today that it would assume university status in September, and open a major expansion program.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 26 --When Michael V. DiSalle, a Democrat, moved out of the Governor's office last January, he took with him a deep-piled rug that he had purchased.
THE American GI's during the last World War kicked an idea around until they came up with the phrase: "Going for broke!" Violently, to win or lose.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., April 27--Miss Anita Bleecker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Spann Bleecker of Brewster, was married this afternoon to Thomas Allin Kahrl. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. George Morrow Kahrl of Elmira, N.Y., and Georgetown, Me.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, April 27 (AP)--Government officials here speak of the possibility of "the greatest slaughter in history" if enemies of the regime attempt to overthrow it. And an anti-United States campaign has been started, using a racist appeal.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 27--State Democrats scrapped plans yesterday for an open Constitutional Convention on reapportionment this spring and decided to try to hold it on Dec. 8, 1964, instead.

WASHINGTON. A NOTED American engineer once remarked that he had often thought "how infinitesimally small would have been the chance of any man or group of men, except the one who actually had the idea, planning to invent the common zipper."
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Kennedy faces a fight within the Public Health Service over the management of his mental health program.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)--The Federal Aviation Agency tonight seized a plane owned in part by the freelance photographer Alexander I. Rorke Jr., who said he staged a bombing raid over Havana Thursday.

Southeast Asia is one of the world's strategic crossroads, a jumping-off place for possible Communist advance to the islands to the south, a pivotal area of struggle that will affect the future of non-Communist Asia. The key to this vital area is Laos, the small kingdom that has been a buffer against Communist pressures.
Alexander Pfeiffer, a realestate lawyer here, died yesterday in his home at 7 West 81st Street. His age was 80. He was senior member of Pfeiffer Crames, a law firm at 300 Madison Avenue.
A comprehensive survey of public education in the American Virgin Islands will be conducted by New York University.

WOOD shingles on the outside of a house can be finished with several different kinds of paint--as well as with various types of shingle stain. Since even the "experts" will not always agree as to which type is best under all circumstances, the homeowner is often confused when faced with the task of selecting the best paint (or stain) for use on his shingles.

ESPALIER has been used by gardeners since me dieval times when fruit trees were dwarfed to save space. Although the term applies to any woody vine, shrub or tree trained in an ornamental pattern against a wall, trellis or other support, dwarf fruit trees remain the traditional favorites.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 27--Sportsmen, conservationists and fishermen jammed Town Hall here this week to protest a plan to turn over to the state only a quarter of the town's 10,000 acres of wetlands for conservation.

WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY Jr., publisher of the weekly, The National Review, says that he would rather be governed by the first 2,000 people in the Boston telephone book than by the Harvard faculty. Nor is it merely Harvard. "Academic folk appeared almost in a body," he says, "to accept the hysterical myth that Sena
WASHINGTON, April 27--A Presidential emergency board made a major move today to try to end the deadlock in the long and bitter railroad labor dispute over work rules.

The Bois de Boulogne, the wooded park on the west side of Paris, is the inspiration for this year's edition of the Fete Champetre (outdoor party) series that benefits Fountain House. It will be held indoors in the appropriately decorated Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria on May 8.

JACK SCHAEFER can spin a yarn with the deftness of a cowboy lassoing a steer. In these 10 stories, he ranges from the comic to the tragic--from ranch to town to army post-- exploring the society of the Old West. A reader could not ask for a better guide than Mr. Schaefer, author of "Shane," and that lovely junior novel, "Old Ramon."
WASHINGTON, April 27--President Kennedy's relations with Speaker John W. McCormack of Massachusetts remain one of the mysteries of the Democratic party.

ROCKET CENTER, W. Va., April 27 (UPI)--Three men were killed and 11 others injured today when an explosion tore through the Alleghany Ballistics Laboratory, one of the chief sources of fuel supply for the Polaris Missile.

WASHINGTON, April 27-- Evidence presented here in recent days indicates that bodies orbiting within the solar system have been banging into one another throughout the last billion years and probably longer.

THE most obstreperous creation in Robert Rau schenberg's large retrospective exhibition at the Jewish Museum is something called "Broadcast" (1959), which accompanies the spectator everywhere with cacophonous sounds.

The Spring Festival sponsored by the women of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church will be preceded by the Festival Frolic on May 8. The fete, a buffet dinner dance, will be held in the parish house of the church at Madison Avenue and 71st Street, where the festival will take place on May 9 and May 10.

The Soviet Union Atomic Energy Committee reported last week what is described as "an important step" in the quest for controlled thermonuclear fusion, the harnessing of the vast power of the hydrogen bomb for the production of practically limitless quantities of electricity for peacetime uses.
RONKS, Pa. In this big-barn country of the Pennsylvania Dutch the spring breezes carry the sweet smell of fresh milk--too much milk.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 27--The first anniversary of the start of "a living memorial to Dag Hammarskjold" was observed here this week.

BRIDGETON, N.J., April 27 --Three teen-agers were killed and two critically injured today when the car in which they were riding went out of control, struck a tree and overturned. The gasoline tank burst into flames and started a brush fire.

MADRID, April 27--Spain's nationwide poisened-drink scare spread today, affecting the wine and canning industries. Sales and consumption of hard liquor plummeted earlier this week after some brands were found to be lethal.

A cleanup of Easter apparel stocks has brought a surge of wholesale buyers into the New York Market. A compilation of Buyers Arrivals in The New York Times indicates more buyers here than in any post-Easter period in the last four years.

A new home development on Guinea Woods Road in RoslynEast Hills, L.I., has been opened by Lawrence. J. Mulhauser. Eleven ranch and Colonial dwel lings with as many as five bedrooms and two and a half bathrooms are planned in the colony, called Heathcote Homes.

MY first innpression of Stephen Spender's collec tion of some of his prose since the last war was that it contained a motley assortment of random pieces, several of them on the over-familiar subject of Anglo-American literary relationships, others simply pre sentable reviews, and the rest a scattering of stray subjects any one of which might or might not interest an equally stray reader. The tone, too, is...
A New York school principal has started an unusual campaign to reduce Soviet-American tensions through education.

A letter of despair written by Gen. George Washington on Dec. 10, 1776, as, short of troops, he was retreating before the British was auctioned last week for $17,000, a record at auction for a Washington letter.

ARTHUR GODFREY no longer has a television contract with the Colum bia Broadcasting System, which brings up the question whether he may do some shows for another network. He is still tied to the C.B.S. radio network under a contract that was recently extended for two years.

NOT long ago I returned to the United States from a year at Moscow State University, a year of living with Russians in a dormitory, of eating, drinking and playing basketball with them and of listening to them talk among themselves. I met physicists and poets, provincials and young sophisticates and had discussions with many of them, picking mushrooms or sitting over glasses of tea or vodka long into the night.

Among contemporary world leaders Premier Khrushchev at 69 is by no means the oldest. He is younger than Pope John, Konrad Adenauer, Mao Tse-tung, Chiang Kai-shek, Charles de Gaulle, Jawaharlal Nehru, Harold Macmillan.
OTTAWA, April 27--Canada's new Liberal Government under Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson will be one of conciliation, but not of appeasement, in the domestic as well as the foreign sphere.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 27 (UPI)--Pfc. Wilbert (Skeeter) McClure of Toledo, an unbeaten middleweight contender, scored his 14th consecutive professional victory tonight on a unanimous 10-round decision...

Sociologists have dissected modern man, psychiatrists have split his super ego, and anthropologists have cut out his patterns of culture. None of them however has yet, come to grips with two of New York's loneliest crowds--the one at the Polo Grounds, the other at Yankee Stadium.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- Under the Employment Act of 1946 it is the policy of the United States Government "to promote maximum employment, production, and purchasing power."

Almost-simultaneous publication of two translations of a Soviet military work brings before the American book industry again the problem that copyright protection does not exist for such books. The publishers involved indicate that no solution is likely.
CHESTER, N.J., April 27-- A group of landowners here is protesting the aerial spraying for the Gypsy moth, which is scheduled to begin in North Jersey on Monday.

PORT--AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 27--The United States Embassy warned Americans in Haiti today to take precautions against outbreaks of violence in this Caribbean republic. Armed civilian militiamen patrolled the streets in a Government effort to crush opposition to President Francois Duvalier.

When Philip Landwehr first heard about President Kennedy's plan to offer a 7 per cent credit against taxes for money spent on new machinery, he had already committed himself to invest $370,000 in phonograph record production.

A spokesman for the United States-flag tramp shipping industry said last week that the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service was favoring subsidized, regularly scheduled cargo ships in the carriage of Defense Department cargoes.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- Interest rates on conventional home mortgages vary more from place to place than has generally been thought, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reports.
A drug's unexpected side effects usually get attention because they prove unpleasant or dangerous, but a specialist in Britain has found one that is pleasing to the patient--and to the beholder.

BERLIN, April 27--A man rose at a forum of the Jewish community here to say that a play he had seen in a Berlin theater and the storm that it had stirred had made him decide to settle in Germany once more.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 27--Mrs. William Dana Hooper has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Cook Hooper, to Edwin Bickford Hooper Jr., son of Rear Admiral Hooper U.S.N., and Mrs. Hooper of Chevy Chase, Md. The families are not related.

AT the time when French intellectuals were busiest de nouncing American justice for its "cat-and-mouse" treatment of Caryl Chessman, Marie Besnard had suffered for almost 11 years as mouse to the cat of French justice. She had another two years of purgatory to endure before her vindication.

JUNEAU, Alaska, April 27-- Alaska is formerly inaugurating its state ferry system this weekend. The ferryboat Malaspina went into service over the 490-mile marine highway between Prince Rupert, B.C., and Skagway, Alaska, on Jan. 25 and became a popular vessel by early spring.
Still haggling with stewardesses over a new union contract, American Airlines has grown nostalgic about the start of its hostess service 30 years ago.

LAST week's exhibitions brought one that I have been hoping for ever since Lennart Anderson, a 35-year-old painter, went unnoticed last year in his first one-man show at the now defunct Tanager Gallery.

IT would seem that one of the season's most important books in the news sense may end by being one of its resounding fiascos in the commercial sense. This is, of course, "One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich," by Alexander Solzhenitsyn, and the reason for its odd status is that practically everyone in the book industry has somehow or other gotten into the act.

SANDOWN PARK, England, April 27 (AP)--Gregory Peck's Owen's Sedge died of internal injuries today. The horse fell four fences from home in a steeplechase.

No other group of citizens has the same relationship to our Federal Government as do our Indians. The unique nature of this relationship is based on the treaties and laws that govern the Federal Government's responsibility for the protection of Indians and their resources.

QUEBEC, April 27--The new Liberal Government of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson appears to be headed for political difficulties with the provincial regime of Premier Jean Lesage of Quebec, who is also a Liberal.

Mr. and Mrs. William P. Maloney of Bayside, Queens, formerly of Southampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Denise Marie deLourdes Maloney, to Walter Donald O'Hearn Jr. of New York. He is the son of Mr. O'Hearn of Westmount, Que., and the late Mrs. Mary McGrath O'Hearn of New York.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 --The American Association of University Professors reiterated today an opposition to including church-connected schools in a program of Federal aid to higher education.

PARIS. Increasing interest in prefab ricated housing is being noted in three European countries-- Denmark, West Germany and England. After 15 years, developments in this field appear to herald the coming of a major industry.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 27 (Reuters)--Jordanian and Palestinian students shouting "Death to King Hussein" stormed the Jordanian Embassy in Baghdad today, carrying banners urging the union of Jordan with the United Arab Republic.
The fifteenth anniversary of Israel's establishment as a nation will be observed with special ceremonies and meetings in this city today and tomorrow.
The works of 30 artists who shared hardships and paint at the same Lower East Side school will open Tuesday at a gallery on the Upper East Side.

IN her first collection of short stories Mary Nash, a writer of magazine fiction and juvenile books, deals mainly with the emotional gropings of adolescents and young people hovering on the brink of adulthood. Though she understands their vague longings, self-doubts and make-believe, she is not deceived by their illusions or posturings.

Jackson Matthews, U.A.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Matthews of New York and and Peru, Vt., was married to Richard S. Bacharach. The differences between President Kennedy and Senator Keating about how many Soviet troops are in Cuba could reflect a serious weakness in the elaborate apparatus the nation maintains for collecting and evaluating the data on which policy must be built.
A leading concern of naval architects has advised the United States Government to consider taking a great leap forward into the field of nuclearpowered merchant shipping.

The city is preparing a new attack on slum landlords. The plan was revealed yesterday on the WNBC-TV television program, "The Mayor's Housing Program." The Mayor and six city officials concerned with housing appeared on the half-hour broadcast.
LENORE TAWNEY is more than just a Weaver--she is also an artist. The art form she employs is so new and personal that it does not yet have a name or classification.
For the first time in its nineyear history, the American Shakespeare Festival at Stratford, Conn., will deviate from its policy by putting on a nonShakespearean work.

PITTSBURGH, April 28--It's tough enough to win when the other teams are stronger, and when your own team plays below even its own limited potential. But when fate joins the opposition forces, there's just no chance at all, as the Mets discovered today.
A nationwide study of teacher education made public yesterday said that all "the remaining teachers colleges in the United States should be Shut down, or converted to general purpose institutions."
The Universalist Church of New York City celebrated yesterday the 125th anniversary of its founding.

LONDON, April 28--The British Government has quietly adopted what is, in effect, a new economic policy. It can be described as "steady speed ahead and damn the torpedoes."

Heavy foreign borrowing persists in the United States nearly a year after Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon expressed the hope that Europe would take measures to lessen use of the New York money market by foreigners.

The Port of New York, where 26,000 longshoremen and checkers are registered, saw an increase of 3 per cent last year in the number of hirings, compared with 1961. The Waterfront Commission reported 4,559,500 hirings for 1962, compared with 4,421,856 in the previous year.

Ray Charles, the singer, pianist, saxophonist and rouser of spirits, made his annual appearance with his orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon and evening. The hall was filled to capacity for both performances.

A drastic revision of the personnel practices of the city school system has been proposed by a group of management consultants retained by the Board of Education.

A new concept in jewelry--in which a center stone in a brooch can be replaced by another stone--has been worked out by Ostier, Inc., designer and manufacturer here.
