FELTONVILLE, Pa., April 28 --Ch. Rebel Roc's of Casanova von Kurt, a seven-pound miniature pinscher owned by Mrs. E. W. Tipton of Kingsport, Tenn., gained his 70th best-in-show award today. He topped a field of 714 in the Penn Treaty Kennel Club fixture.

AMERICANS who travel abroad for the first time often wonder why Europeans handle their knives, forks and spoons in ways so contrary to American custom. They may even disapprove, judging it ill mannered.
OTTAWA, April 28--The opening of the shipping season on the Great Lakes has brought a renewal of the union strife that led last year to a twoday blockade of St. Lawrence Seaway traffic.
Edward N. Costikyan, New York County Democratic chairman, said last night that he still regarded Mayor Wagner as the most influential Democrat in the state.

BOSTON, April 28 (AP)-- Carl Yastrzemski broke out of a slump with a six-hit barrage, including a double that settled the 12-inning opener today as the Boston Red Sox swept a double-header from the Chicago White Sox, 4--3, and 6--2.
WEST LOS ANGELES, April 28 (UPI)--Kenneth, Macgowan, professor emeritus of theater arts at the University of California at Los Angeles, died here last night at the age of 74.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28-- James R. Hoffa and his International Brotherhood of Teamsters decisively defeated today the most serious challenge to the union since it was expelled from the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations in 1957.

IF there are any husbands around still worrying about the prospect of a radical fashion change that will cause their wives to scrap their wardrobes and start anew, they can probably put their fears to rest. For another season, at least.

Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts might be $9,000,000 farther from its final fundraising goal of $160,700,000 than appeared to be the case last week. At that time the center announced it had raised $140,100,000 to date, bringing it to within $20,600,000 of its goal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 29--U Thant, the Secretary General said today that he "welcomed any measures" the United States would take to facilitate the recruitment of qualified citizens for the United Nations staff or technical assistance programs.

LONDON, April 29 (UPI)-- The Secretary of the English Football Association, Dennis Follows, said today "it would be wrong for the public to think bribery is rife in British football,"' following the confession of a player who said he had accepted a bribe.
Cotton futures advanced 10 to 40 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

RABAT, Morocco, April 29 --Moroccans were not altogether happy about the start today of direct New YorkRabat air service.

The season for annual meetings is in full swing. Traditionally, today (the last Tuesday in April) is a popular one for annual meetings. In fact 33 New York Stock Exchange companies are doing just that today--holding their annual meetings. It's the busiest day since Tuesday, April 23, when 57 Big Board companies met with their stockholders.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 29--The West African republic of Gabon, roughly the size of Colorado, is one of the few African states to register a consistently favorable balance of trade in the last few years.
Station WNEW-TV replied yesterday to an attack by David Susskind and announced that it would cancel his program, "Open End," after Sunday's telecast.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)--The Supreme Court decided today that capital gains realized by a Connecticut trust, whose beneficiaries are residents of England, are subject to United States taxation.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI)--The House today approved a non-repetitive tax cut of about $181 million for employers throughout the country.
AMMAN, Jordan, April 29-- Jordan declared a state of emergency along all of her borders today and warned that those crossing illegally would be shot.
Madison Square Garden opened its doors yesterday morning, and 14,000 handicapped children trooped in for the annual free performance by the Ringling Bros. Barnum Bailey Circus.
New York paid official tribute yesterday to Israel's 15th anniversary as a nation.

The city school systen could save about $6,265,000 annually by improving its administrative procedures and eliminating unnecessary positions, a report made public by the Board of Education asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29, (AP)--The United States trade negotiator said today the United States would insist that farm goods be included in the next negotiations with the European Common Market for tariff reductions.
A bright young man, 17 years old, who has foresworn football for life was honored yesterday by the local chapter of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame--but not for doing that.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)--Justice John Marshall Harlan protested in a dissent to a Supreme Court decision today that the Court was laying down a rule of its own "which bears little resemblance" to the legislation passed by Congress.

Post positions, always strong factors in a shorter race, mean less at a mile-and-a-half, the distance of Thursday night's $50,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway. Unhesitatingly, therefore, the linemaker at the Westchester harness-racing plant yesterday listed Irvin Paul as the 8-to-5 favorite against the top sidewheelers from this country, New Zealand, Australia and Canada. This, despite the No. 7 slot from which Irwin Paul will start.
Two new tenants have taken space in the new 21-story office building constructed by Samuel Rudin at 1 Whitehall Street.
William Henry Barnum, president of the Park and 46th Street Corporation, owners of the Postum Building at 250 Park Avenue, died on Friday in his home at 150 East 73rd Street. He was 81 years old.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 29 (Reuters)--The Government's bill to permit persons to be held for repeated 90-day periods without trial passed its third reading in the lower house of Parliament today.

Mrs. Ethel Traphagen Leigh, founder and director of the Traphagen School of Fashion, 1680 Broadway, died yesterday in her studio at 200 West 57th Street. Her age was 80. She was the widow of William Robinson Leigh, noted painter of the old West, who died in 1955.
The Sidney Hillman awards in the field of mass communications were given yesterday to a Mississippi editor, two writers and four members of television documentary terms.
SAO PAULO, April 29 (UPI) --Gary Anderson of Axtell, Neb., led the United States to a pair of gold medals in rifle shooting in the Pan-American Games today.

CHICAGO April 29--The White Sox, feeling they had the Yankees slightly on the run with both Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris sidelined, made a determined effort to play their game with the Bombers tonight.
SEOUL, April 29--Premier Kim Hyun Chul said today that he believed elections for the transfer of power to a civil Government would be held by the end of October.
LOS ANGELES, April 29-- Negro foes of the Black Muslims picketed in front of the county courthouse today as testimony began in the trial of 14 Muslim members involved in a riot a year ago.
RECIFE, Brazil, April 27-- A race to organize rural workers into unions is under way here between Roman Catholic and Communist-oriented labor groups.
Mayor Wagner reiterated last night his pledge to fight to maintain tuition-free education at the city colleges.

WASHINGTON, April 29--In the clash between the Eisenhower-Kennedy and Rockefeller concepts of how to Great a NATO war-deterrent nuclear arm, one area of the dispute is thus far in complete obscurity. Neither side has detailed the means whereby it would be decided whether to pull the nuclear trigger or maintain the safety-catch.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Tuesday, April 30--Haiti withdrew her forces from the Dominican Embassy in Port-au-Prince last night in compliance with a Dominican ultimatum to do so or face armed action.

BERLIN, April 29--East German officials expressed concern today over the increasing number of attempts to escape to the West, after four young East Germans crashed an army truck into the Communist-built border wall last night and fled. The four were uninjured, although East German border guards fired several shots.
GENEVA, April 29--The United States protested today the distribution by the United Nations of a Soviet memorandum containing "inacceptable and offensive language."
GENEVA, April 29--In the newspapers of Sweden, England and possibly other places, too, Ingemar Johansson is pictured this week as a man who has begun hearing bells in his ears.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 29 --Dr. Edward S. Corwin, an authority on constitutional law, and the Presidency, died today in Princeton Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 487 Stockton Road.
A $400,000 appropriation to provide fellowships for returning members of the Peace Corps and other Americans with similar overseas experience was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
After years of controversy among its members, the Na tional Basketball Association finally abolished its territorial draft rule at the opening session of its annual meeting yesterday.
Record earnings, exceeding the 1955 high of $2.64 a share, are in sight this year for the Allied Chemical Corporation, Chester M. Brown, president, told the annual meeting yesterday.

BALTIMORE, April 29--A defense attorney described as a hoax today the Government's case against two former members of Congress accused of selling their influence in Washington to impede the criminal proscution of a savings and loan promoter.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- Long Island supporters of a Fire Island National Seashore spent a day lobbying for the project here today and found the results "very encouraging."
CINCINNATI, April 29-- Ohio has given seven native sons to the Presidency, but only one was a Taft.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- Prospects are dim for continued Washington sponsorship of the American Ballet Theater, which moved here as a resident company just five months ago.

"VIVE le Pacificateur, Francois Duvalier," pro claim the neon lights on Portau-Prince's waterfront. The way Haiti's President since 1957 has "pacified" the country has been recounted by Berkeley Rice, a recent American teacher in Haiti, in the current Harper's Magazine.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- A nuclear test-ban treaty with the Soviet Union probably would not have the backing of the United States. Joint Chiefs of Staff.
A grand jury granted immunity yesterday to Milton C. Winkler, a lawyer, in an effort to force him to tell whether he had conspired to bribe an official of the State Liquor Authority.

First-quarter sales and earnings of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., were the highest for any quarter in its 114-year history, John E. McKeen, president, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in Brooklyn.

An operator of an electronic tabulating machine was accused last night of secretly punching new holes in the file cards of city personnel and getting the electronic brain to turn out better jobs for his friends.
Directors of Outboard Marine Corporation reduced the quarterly dividend yesterday to 10 cents from the 20 cents a common share. The declaration is payable May 24 to holders of record of May 10.

Massachusetts Investors Trust, the country's oldest and second largest mutual fund, reported yesterday that asset values advanced in the quarter ended March 31, but still were below the high levels of a year ago.

Optimistic statements about the British economy made by Prime Minister Macmillan and the Chancellor of the Exchequer,, Reginald Maudling, before the weekend produced early gains in industrial isues on the London market yesterday.

Dr. Samuel B. Gould, president of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, which operates television station WNDT, and the National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that no conditions of any kind were attached to the N.B.C. grant of $100,000 to Channel 13.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 29--Secretary of State Dean Rusk arrived tonight for a meeting of the Central Treaty Organization Council at which the most explosive questions will involve Kashmir and arms aid to India.
VIENNA, April 29--Franz Cardinal Konig of Vienna left for Poland today for a five-day visit with Roman Catholic prelates there.

The Senate investigation into the contract award for the TFX fighter has shown that service combat specifications were significantly reduced because of Defense Department insistence that one plane serve the needs of both the Air Force and Navy.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 29 --Power changes in the Middle East, particularly in Iraq, are causing the Turkish Government considerable apprehension about the future of 2,000,000 Kurds, most of whom live in the rough, inhospitable eastern areas of Turkey.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 29--Secretary General U Thant delayed a scheduled European trip today to rush through plans for sending a United Nations observer team Yemen. His action seeks to take advantage of promises by Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Rapublic to cease interference in the Civil War in Yemen, where they have backed the opposing sides.
Broadway may have changed since the young Moss Hart began his climb toward the theatrical heights, but to denizens of Shubert Alley yesterday morning, it might have been 1929 again.

WASHINGTON, April 29-- A second Telstar, designed to extend the lifetime of communications satellites in the radiation of space, will be launched next week.
ALBANY, April 29--The national and state chairmen of the Democratic party sought today to end the dispute over who was the most influential Democrat in the state. They agreed it was Mayor Wagner.
TRENTON, April 29--The State Senate voted unanimously and sent to Gov. Richard J. Hughes today a bill that would raise the minimum salary or school teachers in New Jersey to a record high.
MOSCOW, April 29 (AP) Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba and Premier Khrushchev held a discussion today in the Kremlin.

HAIFA, Israel, April 29-- Twenty-seven Mirage 3-C jet fighter interceptors, symbolic of Israel's growing military power, swept in almost at sea level and then zoomed high into the sky, over this Mediterranean port today.

The Union Oil Company of California's first-quarter earnings were $12,049,630, or $1.32 a share on the 9,158,289 capital shares outstanding, A.C. Rubel, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Los Angeles.

NEW ORLEANS, April 29 (UPI)--Ralph Dupas defeated Denny Moyer on a 15-round split decision tonight, and won the junior middleweight boxing title.

WASHINGTON, W.Va., April 29--The Southern Presbyterian Church intensified its stand to day against racial segregation in churches and church-related institutions.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29-- The union that represents the 106 members of the Philadelphia Orchestra said today it had been misled by its own people into demanding a contract clause that would give the orchestra members the power to oust their conductor.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission will hold a public hearing this morning required in connection with the creation of 36 new jobs in the five Borough Presidents' offices. All but three of the jobs have already been filled for the last four months.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 29 --A regional agreement barring nuclear arms from Latin America was proposed today to Cuba and all other countries of the region in a joint declaration by five Presidents.

The Inter-American Press Association has set up a special subcommittee to undertake a "documented study on Communist infiltration of the press" in the Western Hemisphere and to keep member publications informed.
Successful landings in close to zero-zero weather by a jet Caravelle equipped with an allweather landing system were reported yesterday by Sud Aviation of France.
St. Tropez, a 5-year-old gray gelding who bears a striking resemblance to his sire, Native Dancer, scored his third triumph in a row at Aqueduct yesterday.
BONN, April 29--West Germany was plunged today into its first major labor difficulties in more than a decade.
Senator Jacob K. Javits predicted yesterday that the Senate would soon appropriate the first peacetime Federal funds for day care of children.

ONCE upon a time smart sports operatives followed one well-established the ory: Never bet against the New York Yankees, Notre Dame or Joe Louis. Those who defied that precept went broke fast. But Louis eventually retired and Notre Dame's football forces definitely mislaid their winning touch. Only the Yankees continue to have what might be vaguely described as an aura of invincibility.
ALBANY, April 29--Governor Rockefeller signed a bill today establishing a licensing procedure for chiropractors. His signature ended a 50-year battle for state recognition of the profession.

WASHINGTON, April 29-- The House approved today an Administration bill to promote the coordination and development of effective Federal and State outdoor recreation programs. The movement began during the Eisenhower Administration.

Victory can't taste any sweeter than it did to the Mets and 23,494 paying representatives of the New Breed at the Polo Grounds last night. Sometimes maligned as the Dodger B. Squad, the Mets defeated the Dodger varsity, 4--2, in a game of minimum significance and maximum delight.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)--Assistant Secretary of State Harlan Cleveland said today that legislation to aid the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands would help speed the day when people there "can make a meaningful and informed choice as to their future."
MOSCOW, April 29 (AP)--A Soviet note to the United States published today repeated Moscow's charges than United States warships fired dummy shells at a Russian trawler off Norfolk, Va., last month.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- The Securities and Exchange Commission told Congress today that it needed broad new powers to police the securities industry.
JOHANNESBURG, April 29 (AP)--Some young ministers of South Africa's powerful Dutch Reformed Church are rebelling against an all-white secret society, the Broeder bond (Band of Brothers.)
VATICAN CITY, April 29 (AP)-L'Osservatore Romano said today the Italian soccer riots that killed a man and injured 89 persons yesterday were a throwback to the days of the pagan gladiators.
Former Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, one of "the fighting McCooks," will celebrate his 90th birthday tomorrow.

A six-pointed red star soared high over central Brooklyn yesterday. It represented the farthest-out part of the curriculum at Pratt Institute--the making of kites as a problem in architectural design.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 29-- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors today authorized a $38,000 study of bus service in the county.

ALARMING bulletin from a reader: He reports that although George Washington provided in his will for a national university his wishes have never been fulfilled. If the interest on his endowment gift were compounded at 5 per cent, the reader adds, the principal would be worth more than $50,000,000 today.
LONDON, April 29-- Queen Frederika and her daughter, Princess Irene, were chased by an angry mob of demonstrators here April 20 and took refuge in a stranger's apartment.

First-quarter sales and earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation fell sharply from those a year ago when the heavy inventory buildup by steel consumers preceded the agreement on a new labor contract at the end of the 1962 March quarter.

Leon Pearson, correspondent and entertainment critic for the National Broadcasting Company, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital, where he had been convalescing from a heart attack suffered April 18. He was 63 years old.
DETROIT, April 29 (AP)-- Auto manufacturers are off to a fast start on their program to build more than 2,000,000 cars in this quarter.
Both sides in the Haitian-Dominican conflict must accept the mediation of the Organization of American States.
Sugar and cocoa futures soared yesterday in very active trading. Most other New York commodities were lower in quiet dealings.
The 23 Federal judges in the Southern District of New York honored Senior Judge John Clark Knox yesterday on the 45th anniversary of his appointment to the bench in 1918 by President Woodrow Wilson.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 29 --The Jersey Central Railroad threatened tonight to cut or eliminate its commuter services unless the state enlarged its subsidy in the year beginning June 1.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- Treasury bills rates rose slightly on today's sale of regular weekly issues.
CHICAGO, April 29 (AP)-- Plans to build a 782-foot tall apartment building near Chicago's merchandise mart have been announced by Mayor Richard J. Daley and a syndicate of developers.

The Federal Communications Commission's promised inquiry into the affairs of educational-TV station WNDT will have a salutary influence if it helps clarify the still-obscure policies of Channel 13 on noncommercial broadcasting.
Ignoring appeals for delay, the city administration decided yesterday to pass today the bill in the City Council to raise the sales tax to 4 per cent.
Stimulated by inventory stockpiling, steel production rose last week for the 13th consecutive week.

Governor Rockefeller has adamantly refused to call the Legislature into special session to reconsider the destructive package of taxes authorized for New York City at Mayor Wagner's request. The Republican attitude at Albany during the Legislature's regular session was one of complete abdication of responsibility for these taxes.

LIFE may be a chamber of horrors to the guilt-ridden, the lonely and the love-seekers. But to Nikolai Evreinov, a Russian playwright, the chamber is only an imaginary vortex in which truth fights with truth and the characters are hypnotized by the search for illusion.

Northern Illinois Gas Company reported yesterday that revenues for the year ended March 31 reached $175,569,034, marking the first time the company topped $175,000,000 for any twelve-month period. Operating revenues for the twelve months ended March 31, 1962, were $159,771,625. By comparison, the utility reported $167,000,000 in revenues for the calendar year 1962.
Six men were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to evade income taxes on more than $1,000,000 in profits from the sale of worthless Canadian mining stock.
MOSCOW, April 29--A romance that began five years ago in Red Square led today to the marriage of a New York newspaperman and a Soviet college teacher.

LEXINGTON, Ky,. April 29 (UPI)--Directors of the University of Kentucky Athletics Association today issued a formal statement saying the favored integration of athletics, but within the framework of the school's Southeastern Conference membership and obligations.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)--The Supreme Court upheld today, 6 to 3, an injunction barring a strike threatened by four railroad brotherhoods against the Louisville Nashville Railroad.
TUNICA, Miss., April 29 (AP)--A tornado roared through the Moon Lake area south of here today. Civil defense officials said the known dead totaled three. Twelve persons were injured.

Mrs. Vanderbilt Webb yesterday received the second Sustaining Members Award of the Junior League of the City of New York. She is the founder and board chairman of the American Craftsmen's Council, part of the program of which is the Museum of Contemporary Crafts at 29 West 53d Street.
This is the start of the open season for the acquisition of knickknacks. It is a long season, running from now.

SMALL fashion shops that carry individual dresses, separates and sometimes accessories are not new to New Yorkers. Boutique Monique, 827 Lexington Avenue (63d Street), however, goes one step further. It has a tiny home furnishings section where small decorative items such as coasters and...

James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, has repelled what many observers considered the most serious challenge to his prestige since the union's expulsion from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. for corruption in 1957. Truck drivers in the Philadelphia area voted 2 to 1 to reject a secession movement that was organized by anti-racket forces and was backed by George Meany of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

William David, Motti, Inc., an over-the-counter broker-dealer that filed a voluntary petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act last June, has made arrangements to pay back fully money or stock owed its customers.
GENEVA, April 29--The Soviet Union said today that the 17-nation disarmament conference had become a "waste of time."

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 29 --Pakistani police arrested Ataullah Khan Mengal, champion of autonomy for Baluchistan, here today on a conspiracy charge, in connections with the assassination last week of the man who had succeeded him as chief of the Mengal tribe.

TWO Tchaikovsky winners proved Brahms winners last night at Carnegie Hall. If this sound obscure, it means that the Brahms Double Concerto was very well played there by an American cellist and a Soviet violinist, both of whom reaped high laurels last year at the International Tchaikovsky Contest in Moscow.

ALVIN ROTH, who made both the unconventional (he calls it "tricky") twoheart bid and the unconventional opening lead with the West hand in today's deal, is generally credited with contributing more innovations to standard contract bridge bidding than any other player of this bridge generation.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- Gov. Ross R. Barnett's right to a jury in his trial for criminal contempt will be considered by the Supreme Court next fall.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- The first signs are appearing that the postwar boom in industrial research is coming to an end.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 29--Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover testified today that it was "physically impossible" for the nuclear reactor aboard the submarine Thresher to have exploded.

A GOOD book about real espionage must do two things. First it must tell us that spying is a matter of infinite drudgery seldom adorned by beautifully landscaped Mata Haris. Then it must reveal a fair quantity of astounding actual sleuthery involving the fates of nations.
Truck drivers who violate the ban on their vehicles along the northern part of the Garden State Parkway more than once will face crackdowns beginning tomorrow.

The Ratzeburg eight from Germany and the Columbia varsity that challenged it So closely Saturday and won the Childs Cup for the first time since 1940 were showered with plaudits at the rowing luncheon at Leone's Restaurant yesterday.

Under Secretary of State W. Averell Harriman arrived at Idlewild Airport late yesterday from London. He stopped there on his way home from Moscow, where he discussed the Laos crisis with Premier Khrushchev.

The Mills College of Education, which owns and occupies the eight-story building at 66 Fifth Avenue, between 12th and 13th Streets, has bought the adjacent 12-story Forbes Building at 70 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of 13th Street, and the University Residence Club, an eight-story apartment house at 45 West 11th Street, in the block to the south.

Any jail or hospital can "clean" (detoxify) narcotic addicts in a few days. But what good is "withdrawal" to the addicts, or the effort and expense to the public, when the relapse rate is 75 to 80 per cent? Sometimes within hours after the addict is home again he is back on drugs--which remain strangely available in New York--and the revolving-door process to jail and hospital starts spinning again.
CHICAGO, April 29 (UPI)-- Vigorous buying pushed May wheat sharply up for a short time today on the Board of Trade, while other grain prices dipped in mixed trading.
The immediate public response to the Armory Show of 1913 was ridicule and criticism; its 1963 reconstruction earned applause and reward for its sponsors.

KONTUM, Vietnam, April 29 --Military sources said today that Communist guerrillas had apparently penetrated to the inner positions of a reinforced Government company before at tacking it Saturday. The South Vietnamese Government force was badly torn up in the action.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- The Civil Aeronautics Board has . not given up its fight against higher fares on trans-Atlantic jet economy flights.

KONTUM, Vietnam, April 29 --Military sources said today that Communist guerrillas had apparently penetrated to the inner positions of a reinforced Government company before at tacking it Saturday. The South Vietnamese Government force was badly torn up in the action.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- The Civil Aeronautics Board has . not given up its fight against higher fares on trans-Atlantic jet economy flights.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)--Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Anthony J. Celebrezze, told Senators today that "the condition of education in the United States calls for action" now by the Federal Government.

Advertising men have a peculiar reverence for the power of repetition. Once they develop a successful campaign, they will run it week after week, year after year, until it shows visible signs of wear.

Two leading men will perform opposite Mary Martin in "Jennie," arriving Oct. 17 at the Winter Garden. They are Dennis O'Keefe and Robin Bailey. Both have had ample stage and screen experience but have not acted on Broadway. Each will play a husband of Laurette Taylor, whose early acting career notivates the plot.
Louise Patterson brought an interesting program of songs and arias to Town Hall last night.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- The steel price increase has not budged the Government's wholesale price index.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the case of a Los Angeles bookseller convicted on an obscenity charge for selling Henry Miller's novel "Tropic of Cancer."
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)--A Senate committee was told today that uniformity in Standard and daylight times was needed to halt a "clock chaos enough to confound Fa ther Time himself."
Legislation of key importance to service morale --the military pay bill--will be debated in the House soon.

ROME, Tuesday, April 30-- Premier Amintore Fanfani's Christian Democratic party was clearly, winning Italy's fourth postwar general election when more than two-thirds of the votes for Senate seats had been counted early today.
THERE are indications-- not a few of which are political--that there is going to be a considerable to-do around Hempstead, L.I., before a final resolution is made of the wetlands issue there.

LOUISVILLE, April 29--On a track that was officially described as sloppy following an early thunderstorm, No Robbery contributed a satisfactory workout this morning. The Greentree Stable's winner of the Wood Memorial and currently one of the "big three" of Saturday's 89th Kentucky Derby did a mile in 1:41 2/5.
LONDON, April 29(AP)--A North Sea survey undertaken by three major oil companies may extend to the continental shelf off Norway, one of the Royal Dutch-Shell companies said today.
ATLANTA, April 29--Six whites and six Negroes planned today to leave Chattanooga, Tenn., at dawn Wednesday to finish a slain postman's 400 mile "Freedom Walk" across Alabama to Jackson, Miss.

The commercial building at 89 Steuben Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the American Consumer Industries, Inc., Joseph S. Robinson, president, to an investor. The property, with a lot 100 by 150 feet, is under a net lease that has 15 years to run. It was held at $275,000 and was sold for cash through John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 29--The Jamaican Government has decided to abolish the inheritance tax in an allout bid to attract industrial investment for economic development of the country.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) --The Anti-Communist Liaison Committee said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was questioning participants in the organization's two-day meeting here. A private air raid on Cuba was first reported at one of the organization's meetings.
PARIS, April 29--Enemy cities are the only logical targets for France's nuclear striking force, Defense Minister Pierre Messmer disclosed today.

Presented Distinguished Service Medal to Admiral Robert L. Dennison, retiring chief of the Atlantic Fleet; saw Danny Thomas, the entertainer, who received the Big Brother of the Year award; sent to Congress detailed recommendations for Federal workers' pay raise beginning next January.
The Royal Ballet's performance of "Giselle" last night was distinguished by some particularly interesting dramatic portrayals, in both dance and pantomime.
WASHINGTON, April 30 President Kennedy submitted to Congress again today a bill to encourage political contributions through tax benefits to the contributors.

HOLLYWOOD, April 30 MCA, Inc., has established 15 graduate fellowships or undergraduate scholarships for playwrights and screen writers at leading American universities and is negotiating to establish 11 more. The 26 grants may represent an annual expenditure of $100,000.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 30 Diplomatic sources said tonight that Haiti had agreed to allow 22 political refugees in asylum in the Dominican Embassy here to leave the country.
Some of the top names in fashion are joining with Montgomery Ward Co. to present a collection of suits, coats, dresses, sportswear and accessories to mail-order customers.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 Bonjour won the 36th running of the Derby Trial today. The California-bred colt owned by Patrice Jacobs permitted a pair of rivals to set the pace in the important one-mile test and then, in the final moments, came through with a winning burst at Churchill Downs.

The Eastern Shoe Machinery Corporation, importer and exporter of used shoe machinery, has bought the three five-story buildings on plot 75 by 100 feet at 120, 122 and 124 West 25th Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Prices for farm products increased by 1 per cent during the month ended April 15.

ROME, April 30 Premier Amintore Fanfani's Christian Democratic party, which has dominated Italian politics since World War II, suffered a setback in the election for the Chamber of Deputies Sunday and yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 30 ?The Illinois Senate unseated Arnold H. Maremont today as chairman of the State Public Aid Commission.

Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday he expected labor negotiations in the steel industry to begin within several weeks. He said he hoped there could be serious discussion without a formal reopening of the present contract.
WASHINGTON, April 30 A key Senator moved today to help the Post Office Department solve its deficit problems and stave off a threatened cut in postal services.

ONE of the jobs most avidly sought by young women from all over the world lasts only two years, requires the equivalent of a university degree, offers scanty preparation for a future career and is not a good place to meet a husband. The job's title? United Nations Guide.

AGANA, Guam, April 30 (AP) Half the homes and all the crops on the island of Saipan were destroyed Tuesday by Typhoon Olive, which whipped its fiercest winds over World War II bomber base in the Mariana Islands.

WASHINGTON, April 30 The Federal Communications Commission was ordered by the Court of Appeals today to give closer scrutiny to a protest by radio station WQXR against new stations on nearby frequencies.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Federal agencies joined today in renewed demands that Congress do something to reduce "clock confusion" in this country, especially that created by daylight saving time.

International Business Machines Corporation stockholders, about 3,400 strong, thronged, to the New York Coliseum at noon yesterday to discuss with top management all phases of the business. In general, they were well satisfied.
WASHINGTON, April 30 The White House is approaching the 1964 Presidential campaign with only one major change in prospect for the team that managed John F. Kennedy's narrow victory in 1960.
Another major American company and one of its unions have agreed to establish joint subcommittees to study bargaining problems well in advance of contract negotiations.'

THE fishing for striped bass in the New Jersey Bay waters and surf has been the best in years. The lighttackle fans have been wallowing in a wealth of good fishing, at least when the wind drops enough to get a small boat out.
Directors of the Borden Company yesterday raised the quarterly dividend on the common stock to 45 cents a share.

AS automobile makers introduce new car models every year, manufacturers of paper plates and cups now present annual innovations in styles and patterns that range from the boldly colorful to the austerely elegant.
Mayor Wagner warned yesterday that the city's low-rent public housing program would come to a halt unless further funds were forthcoming from Washington and Albany.

Celeste Holm has decided to star in Turgenev's comedy, "A Month in the Country," a classic, she says, she "always wanted to play." David Ross will present and direct the revival, adapted by his wife, Carmel, from the translation by Constance Garnett.
HARTFORD, April 30 John Hamilton King of Willimantic, an associate justice of the State Supreme Court, was nominated today as chief justice by Governor John Dempsey.
THE uptown New Yorker Theater really has itself a hunk of film in a 1951 Japanese version of the Dostoevski novel "The Idiot." It runs nearly three hours a load of idiocy in anybody's language.
Prices of Government securities were generally firm yester day in moderate trading.
MOSCOW, April 30 An unusual official press correction tending to downgrade Premier Khrushchev's position in the Soviet Union interested diplomatic observers here today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) Senator Barry Goldwater accused the United States Office of Education today of "manufacturing" statistics and turning out "propaganda" designed to show the existence of a classroom shortage.
The Gulf Oil Corporation, the Philadelphia and Reading Corporation, A.C. Nielsen, the Amerada Petroleum Corporation, the United Jewish Appeal and Fairbanks-Whitney, Inc.,

LOS ANGELES, April 30 Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris played their first league game of the season side by side tonight as the Yankees opened a three-game series with the Los Angeles Angels before a crowd of 32,381.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 30 (UPI)--A Navy submarine expert testified today that a tank ruptured on the submarine Thresher 30 days before her ill-fated voyage. However, he said, the mishap was not a factor in the submarine's sinking.
Thomas E. Mullaney will become financial-business news editor of The New York Times on Aug. 1, it was announced yesterday by Turner Catledge, managing editor of The Times.

WASHINGTON, April 30 The Federal Maritime Commission announced today, after fourteen months of study, that it had adopted rules and regulations to govern the business practices of licensed independent ocean freight forwarders.
THE role of the instant experts on Russia and the more leisurely and scholarly analysts of the Soviet Union was discussed last night in a stimulating hour over Channel 13.
WASHINGTON, April 30 Spokesmen for independent banks told Congress today that Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon has demonstrated an "unconcealed zeal for large multi-unit banking systems."

Should the General Motors Corporation, which paid each of its two top executives upward of $725,000 last year, clamp a $200,000 limit on total compensation? Should the General Dynamics Corporation, which builds missiles and submarines, move its annual meeting site from Dover, Del., to New York City?
Radio, which used to put out one of the liveliest daytime shows on the air from City Hall will return there today to place its microphones in the City Council, after an absence of 21 years.
Scandals and corruption brought about the downfall of the last of the state lotteries nearly 70 years ago.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 30 High Dominican officials said today that their consul in the Haitian border town of Veledero was being held "a virtual prisoner."

A former City Councilman charged in court yesterday that Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was trying to "ruin" him because he had information connecting Mr. Lefkowitz with corruption in the State Liquor Authority.
WASHINGTON, April 30 The poetry and music of Elizabethan England echoed in the White House tonight after a dinner for a monarch of a modern era.
THE tournament of the National Industrial Recrea tion Association, which was played throughout the United States last Saturday, may lead to international matches.

WHEN you have said that the Museum of Modern Art is opening a Rodin show today, you have said enough to describe a stellar performance. Everyone knows Rodin by now and everyone knows that the museum always does a fine job of installation, so there you are. The Rodin show, however, has some extra added atractions.
"And in the stretch it's The Ibex," Fred Capossela informed 21,112 fog-bound racegoers at Aqueduct yesterday.

A new round of labor trouble threatens the nuclear ship Savannah. The $53,000,000 combination passenger-cargo liner is scheduled to leave her shipyard base in Galveston, Tex., next Monday for a cruise to Atlantic ports and New York. But her 14 engineers say they will not sail her.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 30 Gerald D. Peet Sr., retired vice president, director and chief engineer of Wallace Tiernan Co., Inc., a chemical and manufacturing company in Belleville, died yesterday at his home. He was 72 years old, and lived at 12 Berkeley Place here.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 30 (UPI) The United States bagged four gold medals in the Pan-American Games today to increase its total to 68 but had to settle for second place behind Cuba in the baseball tournament.

Lucia Chase, co-director of Ballet Theater, said today that she was hopeful that the Washington Ballet Guild would give partial support to Ballet Theater's 1963-64 season, even though it appears likely that the guild will not underwrite another Washington season for the company.
WASHINGTON, April 30 Federal laws may inhibit the operation of the New Hampshire lottery.
The United Jewish Appeal announced yesterday that it was conducting a six-week emergency campaign to raise $39,500,000.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages, unless otherwise noted.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Labor peace in the maritime industry would mean more United States ships at sea and many more jobs, the chairman of the House Merchant Marine Committee said today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 Foy D. Kohler, United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, will not attend tomorrow's May Day ceremonies in Moscow because of the presence there of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.
ALBANY, April 30 The state was authorized today to speed its collections of $132,000,000 in stop-gap revenue to help balance Governor Rockefeller's record budget.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 30 Laotian neutralists and proCommunists agreed today on formation of still another civil and military committee to work out a new cease-fire formula and return the situation in Laos to "normal."
Four thousand butchers voted yesterday to go on strike last midnight against 200 wholesalers in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, April 30 Storm signals of a revolt over the Kennedy Administration's foreign policy in the Middle East flew in Congress today.

LOUISVILLE, April 30 The tulips cringed from the cold. The achyranthes and the dusty millers lay dull and lifeless beneath the pall of scudding gray clouds. No sun shone bright on any old Kentucky home. The setting for today's Derby Trial, the last tune-up for the Big One on Saturday, was downright nasty.
In a glow of cognac and fellowship early yesterday, five Soviet horsemen discussed the lessons they had learned from two losing Soviet horses.

WASHINGTON, April 30 The House approved today a $5,500,000,000 fund bill for the Labor and Health, Education and Welfare Departments. The $309,500,000 in "economy cuts" made by the Appropriations Committee were not restored.

WASHINGTON, April 30 The former chief of the United States military mission to Haiti defended himself today against Marine Corps charges that he had violated regulations in writing an unpublished article about Haiti for Life magazine.
The Curtis Publishing Company is consolidating certain departments and services of its magazines in an effort to improve efficiency and cut costs.
Mayor Wagner was told yesterday that the time was short in which the city could hope to take over Breezy Point in Queens as a "new Jones Beach."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 30 A ten-man Jordanian Revolution Command Council has been formed in exile under Ali Abu Nuwar, former Jordanian Chief of the General Staff, it was reported from Damascus today.

THE Road Racing Drivers Club, a select group that includes many of America's most skillful sports car pilots, will conduct its annual advanced drivers clinic Saturday and Sunday at the Bridgehampton (L.I.) course.

Scores of museum people and other leaders in art education attended the opening meetings yesterday of the 21st annual conference of the Committee on Art Education, sponsored by the Museum of Modern Art.

WESTPORT, Conn., April 30 Do you want a strongbacked boy to mow the lawn and rake the leaves? Or a home economics student to mind the baby and wash the dishes? Or a qualified counselor for a summer camp?
ALBANY, April 30 The Republican State Committee elected Fred A. Young of Lowville as the party's state chairman today to succeed L. Judson Morhouse.
Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange in April scored the largest monthly advance since last November and reached the highest level since March, 1962.
BONN, April 30 West Germany's automobile manufacturers warned today that they might have to shut down in a few days.

BRADFIELD, England, April 29 Eton, the largest and most famous of the ancient English public schools, is in for profound changes, if Anthony ChenevixTrench, the newly appointed headmaster, has his way.

MIAMI, April 30 The United States Government has withdrawn its support of the Cuban Revolutionary Council, which it had previously regarded as the voice of approximately 200,000 Cuban refugees in the United States.

Yesterday's rain clouds seemed full of silver linings for the Mets. Their night game with the Dodgers was called off, giving them plenty of time to savor the victory of the night before and plan for the twogame series with Houston beginning tonight.

The warmth of the Soviet reception for Fidel Castro represents more than an effort to heal the wounds left by Premier Khrushchev's unilateral decision to remove Soviet missiles from Cuba last October. The ramifications of Moscow's relations with Peking also are involved in this process of wooing Castro.

As a reward for finishing with the lowest winning percentage last season, the New York Knickerbockers picked up Art Heyman, the outstanding Duke player, at the National Basketball Association's annual player draft yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Bermuda, April 30 Sixty-three sailboats, competing in one body of water today, made this mid-Atlantic resort island look like a huge American backyard on washday.
Samuel I. Rosenman warned yesterday that a national railroad strike was "a great possibility" unless the public made it clear that it would not stand for one.

One hopeful sign for the railroad industry is the carriers' renewed interest in equipment. Yesterday, for example, Southern Pacific, a prosperous railroad that can afford experimentation, demonstrated a new freight car, almost twice as...
NEWARK, April 30 The Rev. William P. Hayes, pastor emeritus of the Bethany Baptist Church, died Saturday in his home at 272 South Sixth Street. His age was 82.
ST. LOUIS, April 30 (UPI) Curt Simmons scored his fourth victory with a four-hitter to night as the St. Louis Cardinals gained their fourth in a row with a 2-1 decision over the Milwaukee Braves.
The United Gas Corporation reported yesterday that consolidated share earnings rose 21 per cent in the first quarter.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) The Administration has approved a domestic subsiday program for the cotton industry. The program would eliminate the two-price cotton system in mid-1964.
PARIS, April 30 France has raised a new obstacle to the successful conclusion of tariff-cutting negotiations under the Trade Expansion Act between the United States and the European Common Market.

PARIS, April 30 United States nuclear policy toward Europe went wrong when it contradicted the basic philosophy developed under the Marshall Plan. The latter sought to encourage a strong European coalition which, as our ally, might eventually join in some union of its own.
There was enough rain in the New York-New Jersey area yesterday to ease the threat of more forest and brush fires.
With Wagner administration forces in full control, the City Council voted 15 to 6 last night to increase the sales tax to 4 per cent on June 1. There were two abstentions.
A group of 15 banks has demanded the power to co-sign the checks of the Credit Industrial Corporation, 11 West 42d Street.

A management survey of the city's school system, the contents of which were recently revealed in this newspaper, makes one fundamental complaint. It is that the city's schools are saddled with a bureaucracy too cumbersome to be responsive to fast changes and new demands.
The Union Carbide Corporation has named Birny Mason Jr., president, as chief executive officer of the corporation, it was announced yesterday.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 30 A Belgian who was the official spokesman for President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province has been quietly transferred to a job in Leopoldville's art museum.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) George Meany accused Gen. Lucius D. Clay today of having "an absolute antipathy to foreign aid."

The Bethlehem Steel Company announced yesterday the award of contracts totaling about $50,000,000 for major construction and mill facilities at the company's $250,000,000 Burns Harbor, Indiana, plant near Chicago.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan was ordered yesterday to show in Supreme Court why the current phase of the grand jury investigation into corruption in the State Liquor Authority should not be halted because the prosecutor resorted to electronic eavesdropping.

The Heart of America Ball was held at the WaldorfAstoria last night for the benefit of the Heart Fund, which supports the program of research, community services and education of the New York Heart Association.
ST. PETERSBURG BEACH, Fla., April 30 William Chase Gilman, partner in W.C. Gilman Co., consulting engineers of 115 Broadway, New York, died here today in his winter home. He was 66 years old.

LONDON, April 30 The Government and the Opposition dueled with election-fever sharpness in the House of Commons today over Dr. Richard Beeching's proposals to reorganize the British Railways system by closing down 5,000 miles of unprofitable track.
James Baldwin and Harry Belafonte have dropped plans, for the present, to appear on any discussion program produced by either David Susskind or by WNEW-TV.
Cocoa declined and sugar futures were mixed in heavy trading yesterday.
The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday sharply higher sales and earnings in the first three months of 1963 compared with those of a year ago.
The first major international film festival to be organized for New York City will take place in September at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 30 It is fairly definite from Army's spring practice that Coach Paul Dietzel has abandoned the three-platoon system he made famous at Louisiana State University and next fall will field two cadet units trained in both offensive and defensive football.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 30 Israeli concern over Jordan mounted today in the wake of the decision yesterday by King Hussein to declare a state of emergency in his kingdom's frontier areas.

Burl S. Watson, chairman of the Cities Service Company, indicated at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del., that he was optimistic concerning the prospects for the early consummation of the company's plan to acquire the Tennessee Corporation.

THE newest word in theology these days is "ecumenist." There may be some argument over the niceties of definition, but basically an ecumenist is a Christian who accepts as a fact the spiritual union of separated churches while striving for their return to "one flock, one shepherd."

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., April 30 (AP) President James Monroe's great-grandson handed a copy of the Monroe Doctrine to a visiting Soviet consul today and told him to tell Premier Khrushchev that "the document is very much alive."

The results of the Italian general election are dominated by the Communist gains. These are disturbing, even though for the time being they need bring no changes of a drastic nature. The Christian Democrats remain the major political party. The modified "opening to the left" by which the Nenni Socialists support a government coalition of Christian Democrats, Social Democrats and Republicans will continue.
WASHINGTON, April 30 A union of employes of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union received full bargaining rights today in an order published by the National Labor Relations Board.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 30 Gov. J. Millard Tawes signed today a controversial bill that will gradually shut down Maryland's flourishing legal slot machines.

With President Kennedy's blessing, the newly established Business Committee for Tax Reduction in 1963 is calling for prompt Congressional action to cut taxes by at least $10 billion. This is in line with the Administration's own proposal, which calls for gross reductions of $13.5 billion over the next three years, accompanied by reforms that will recoup some $3.3 billion.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 The 106 musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra will meet soon, possibly tomorrow, to decide whether they should remove from current contract negotiations a demand for a provision that would give them the power to oust their conductor.
In a major move toward rehabilitating the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the City Planning Commission approved two housing projects for the area yesterday.

Fort Lauderdale, Fla., sold yesterday two issues that total $16,050,000 of water and sewer revenue bonds due from 1964 to to 1992. A banking syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co.; B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and the Equitable Securities Corporation submitted the best bid for the issues.
Dr. Henry Pitney Van Dusen made public last night his retirement as president of Union Theological Seminary effective June 30.
MONROE, La., April 30 (AP) John Pennel of Northeastern Louisiana State regained the world pole vault record tonight with a leap of 16 feet 6 inches in a track meet against Northwestern (La.) State.

The American Can Company is expanding its capital expenditures program by nearly $70,000,000 this year, William C. Stolk, chairman, and Roy J. Sund, president, told shareholders attending the annual meeting here yesterday. In the last five years, an average of $49,000,000 a year was spent.

ALBANY, April 30 Bessie A. Buchanan, a former member of the Assembly, who bolted the Democratic party last fall to support Governor Rockefeller's re-election, won an appointment from the Governor today to the State Commission for Human Rights.
A Criminal Court judge, sitting as a judge yesterday, reversed a verdict he had returned on Friday while he had been sitting as a jury.

LISBON, April 30 (Reuters) G. Butler Sherwell, a vice president and senior consultant of the International Division of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died today at the Ritz Hotel here, where he was staying. He was 64 years old.

ROBERT GOLDSAND has a fondness for unifying his programs of piano music around a single composer or an idea. He has devoted recital series or single appearances to Beethoven's piano sonatas, Chopin's complete piano literature, Schumann, contemporary music and piano etudes.

Four thousand complaints are made to the police each year about New York's taxi cabs and their drivers, according to a survey made by the Citizens Union. And that figure, the survey says, does not include many persons who grumble only to themselves.
Investors in London and Milan were preoccupied with the topic of elections yesterday.
The Hollywood (N.J.) Club defeated Crestmont, 13 1 yesterday in one of the few matches completed in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team competition.
ANTON GUADAGNO led the Symphony of the Air in an operatic program last night at Carnegie Hall. The concert was a benefit for the Damon Runyon Cancer Fund.
The City Council debated for more than an hour yesterday before giving its final approval for a $3,500,000 Hall of Science that is to be the official New York City exhibit at the 1964 World's Fair.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 (UPI) The Delta Queen, main taining a proud tradition for the Green Line Steamers of Cincinnati, ran away from The Belle of Louisville and won the first Ohio River passenger steamboat race in three decades.
Stock prices edged up slightly as trading quickened yesterday. Chemical, sugar, airline, motor and electronic issues were among the stronger groups. Steels and aircraft stocks tended to be weak.

The Government sought a $1,000 penalty yesterday from a dancer-comedian, charging that his drunkenness aboard an airliner had threatened the safety of 57 other passengers and caused an emergency landing.
The president of the Board of Education charged yesterday that the Legislature had deliberately refused to approve bills that would have enabled the city school system to operate more efficiently.

Undoubtedly troubled over the wisdom of its action, but unable to muster the courage to rebel, a City Council majority has approved an increase of 1 per cent in the retail sales tax. STRANDS of cartoon and satire, fantasy and fury thread "The Blue Boy in Black," which arrived last night at the Masque Theater. There are moments when Edmund White's play seems touched by the charged laughter of Ossie Davis's "Purlie Victorious" and others when it blazes with the outraged passion of Genet's "The Blacks."

WOODBURY, L.I., April 30 Nassau, a county that has been transformed in the last two decades from an area of potato farms and fruit orchards to a community of homes and light industry, will have its first barn theater in June.
CONCORD, N.H., April 30 Gov. John W. King signed today a bill giving New Hampshire the first legal sweepstakes lottery in this country since 1894.
A reverse flow of dollars from Israel into the United States will start today as the first State of Israel bonds are retired here.

By ORVILI ON a warm summer night in September, 1941, an ancient bus ground to a stop at the Marine Corps training camp at Parris Island, S.C. Among the half dozen tired and sleepy volunteers who were passengers and who were welcomed to the base by bellows of ferocious profanity was a tall, blond, blue-eyed boy just past his 21st birthday, named T. Grady Gallant.
BERKELEY, Calif., April 30 ?The creation of a regional council on the arts was proposed today in a study prepared for the University of California.

The Greyhound fleet began operating out of the PortAuthority Bus Terminal at midnight last night. It marked the first time all of the city's major suburban and long-distance lines were concentrated under one roof.
PARIS, April 30 The French Cabinet took several actions today to allay widespread economic discontent.

LONDON, April 30 Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., and Courtaulds, Ltd., the major British man-made fiber concerns, will provide the money for acquisitions designed to reorganize this country's textile industry.

Contrasting views on immigration laws were expressed last night by Representative Francis E. Walter and William J. vanden Heuvel, president of the International Rescue Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) --Republican National Committeeman Carl L. Shipley said today that many Washington voters had told him it would be political suicide for Governor Rockefeller of New York to remarry. "And I am inclined to agree with them," Mr. Shipley said.

WASHINGTON, May 1-- Joseph Campbell, the Controller General of the United States, and an assistant testified today that they could not audit the figures that Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara used to award a contract on a new type of warplane because the Secretary "had the figures in his head."
WASHINGTON, May 1-- The Senate passed today legislation that would pay to the Philippine Government the $73,000,000 Congress appropriated last year to liquidate damage claims from World War II.

ANYONE who thinks about it for a moment or two should realize that those rolypoly, shuffling, lovable, hairy creatures called bears must be treated with respect. They sometimes bite, that's why. But almost always they depart with haste when humans intrude.

Louis Goldfarb, realty investor, has taken title to the sevenstory garage building at 267-69 West 87th Street, between Broadway and West End Avenue. The property, with a plot 50 by 100 feet, was bought for cash over a first mortgage of $200,000 for 16 years. William O. Land was the broker.
TRENTON, May 1--The Legislature's joint appropriations committee today trimmed $4,500,000 from Gov. Richard J. Hughes's $547,479,498 budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

THE 13th game of the 24game world title match between the champion, Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union, and his countryman Tigran Petrosian, was drawn after 54 moves: Botvinnik won the next game in 57 moves, evening the score at 7-7.
LOS ANGELES, May 1--A jarring first-inning grand-slam home run by George Thomas and a four-hit pitching performance by Bo Belinsky gave the Los Angeles Angels a 5-3 triumph tonight over the Yankees.

THOSE who make a living from dogs include bar bers. One of them, Derry Harvey, was visited for some idea of the work and what it cost. Incidental intelligence turned up was that Miss Harvey was also an obedience instructor and an agent for a Spring Valley (N. Y.) boarding kennel. It developed

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1-- An audience that thronged the 3,200-seat War Memorial Opera House and occupied some of the standing room space gave its approval to spring opera last night.

The community of interest that should exist among New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in improving and expanding mass transportation is so obvious that it is rather remarkable that full cooperation toward that end has never been formalized in law. New York has now taken that first long step with Governor Rockefeller's signature on a bill to create an interstate compact agency to be known as the Tri-State Transportation Commission. Mayor Wagner has under consideration the development of a plan for an early-warning system that would enable him to head off strikes over automation.

WASHINGTON, May 1-- James R. Hoffa warned Congress today that the nation's jails were not big enough to hold all the violators of compulsory arbitration settlements in labor disputes if that system became law.

Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon will address the spring dinner of the New York Financial Writers' Association on May 27 at the Americana Hotel, it was announced yesterday by Robert E. Bedingfield of The New York Times, president of the association.

TULSA, Okla., May 1 (AP) --Pan American Petroleum Company, an affiliate of Standard Oil Company of Indiana, denied today that it owed any commission on an Iranian oil concession to two men who have filed a $75,000,000 suit against the company.

The Kratter Corporation, one of the publicly owned real estate concerns that has been plagued by financing problems over the last 12 months, saw its shares dip to a historic low yesterday. Kratter was the most active ...
WASHINGTON, May 1--A Republican attempt to cut $200,000,000 from President Kennedy's request for $450,000,000 for accelerated public works was resoundingly defeated in the Senate today.

Despite slightly decreases revenues, the Southern Pacific Company increased its net income in the first quarter to $15,088,831, from $12,798,370 in the period a year ago, the report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The Republicans failed today to delay Senate consideration of a House-approved feed-grains bill that the Administration hopes will influence the national wheat referendum May 21.
Communists and affiliated leftists staged a quiet celebration of May Day in Union Square yesterday. About 1,500 persons witnessed the rally.
LOS ANGELES, May 1--Four actors played more than 70 roles when the world premiere of a dramatization of "Spoon River Anthology" opened tonight at the University of California at Los Angeles.
A $60,000 study of domestic freight movements, made with the aid of the Federal Bureau of the Census, has found an estimated potential of air freight far in excess of that being carried.
The Central Park Zoo was a sort of nursery for animal babies yesterday.
LONDON, May 1--Sir Winston Churchill announced today that he would not run again for Parliament.
Leonard Bernstein will not conduct the New York Philharmonic the season after next. He is taking a sabbatical to compose another Broadway musical.
DETROIT, May 1--The American Motors Corporation reported today earnings of $10,297,586, or 54 cents a share, in the quarter that ended on March 31.
Stock prices climbed in active trading yesterday, but a late round of profit taking trimmed prices from their highest levels of the day.

The city's first double-feature budget hearings--by the Board of Estimate and the City Council simultaneously--opened to small houses yesterday and the curtain rang down early. Despite its advance billing, the performance was desultory.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 1--Diplomatic and official sources here said today they had received persistent but unconfirmed reports of a massacre of political opponents of President Francois Duvalier.

WILDWOOD, Ga., May 1-- Five white persons and five Negroes completed today the first leg of a 400-mile "Freedom Walk" to Jackson, Miss. They then encamped for the night at a little church in an isolated mountain cove.

FASHION is fun. Fashion is frivolous. Fashion is also big business. Fifteen years after the establishment of the State of Israel, fashion can take credit for giving economic aid to a developing nation.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 1--International One-Design sailors from Long Island Sound were beaten today in both races against the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club. Two victories yesterday and two today gave Bermuda the Amorita Cup, which has been won 15 times by Bermuda and only nine times by the United States. The competition is part of International Race week.
SAO PAULO, May 1 (UPI)-- Pete McArdle, a 34-year-old New Yorker, set a record of 29:52.1 in capturing the 10,000meter run at the Pan-American Games today.
Heavy trading in cotton textile issues provided a springboard for a good day on the London market yesterday.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 1 (UPI)--A controversial bill authorizing an American company to build an oil refinery here, today seemed destined for the shelf at least temporarily-- if not forever.

LONDON, May 1--The most controversial show in British television history has gone off the air for the summer. But the arguments roll on about "That Was the Week That Was," a British Broadcasting Corporation program of satire that changed the Saturday-night habits of nearly a quarter of the British people.

THE excitement of a preschool child's discovery of color, design and texture is immediately apparent to anyone watching a youngster wield a paintbrush. Much of the pleasure appears purely sensuous--the squish and splatter of paints, the squash of clay.

ROME, May 1--Italian workers celebrated May Day today in the calm and peaceful spirit that marked the general election of Sunday and Monday. Often on past May Days there have been riots and disturbances with dead and wounded.

LOUISVILLE, May 1--When life began to stir in the barn area at Churchill Downs before dawn today, it was so cold that a thin glaze of ice could have formed on any water bucket left full. The temperature was just about at freezing.

WASHINGTON, May 1--Officials of the National Association of Securities Dealers voiced objections today to one of the plans put forth by the Securities and Exchange Commission for tighter policing of the securities industry.

Directors of the General Foods Corporation voted yesterday to increase the common stock dividend by 5 cents, to 50 cents a share. The declaration marked the eleventh successive year in which the large food concern had raised its dividend.
A hoodlum connected with "the very heart of organized crime," who was once a power in Cuban gambling activities during the Batista regime, was arrested yesterday on income tax evasion charges.

Two Federal offices have submitted favorable advices to the Federal Reserve Board on the proposed acquisition of the Bank of Rockville Centre Trust Company by the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company.

BETHPAGE, L.I, May 1-- The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, leading Long Island industry in space and advanced military aircraft programs, has appointed three senior vice presidents and three vice presidents.

Dr. Calvin E. Gross has begun his formidable task as the city's Superintendent of Schools on a promising note. He has spent much of his time quietly visiting schools without publicity fanfare and presumably even without advance warning to the schools. These were business trips, not exhibitions of showmanship.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) --Ray Tucker,, former syndicated newspaper columnist and political correspondent, died tonight in the District of Columbia General Hospital of lung cancer. He was 69 years old.

LONDON, May 1--One of Britain's many splendidly titled offices, that of Black Rod, will change hands June 18 with the retirement of Sir Brian Horrocks.

After a tug-of-war between the Puritan ethic and Yankee resistance to high taxes, New Hampshire has decided to ease its fiscal problems by becoming the first state in this century to legalize a sweepstakes lottery. The perils are monumental; yet every state is finding it so hard to balance its budget without sacrificing essential services that the Granite State's experiment commands national attention.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 1-- A former Chinese air officer who organized rescue parties to help the survivors of the Doolittle raid on Tokyo in World War II arrived here today as a refugee.

PARIS, May 1--France will build a nuclear test center in the Tahiti group of islands in the Pacific.
For James Walter Kennedy, election yesterday as the president of the National Basketball Association was the culmination of a lifetime of vicarious participation in sports.

WASHINGTON, May 1-- President Kennedy has been taken off an embarrassing spot by the decision of a former Marine captain, Arthur J. Jackson, not to attend a White House reception for winners of the Medal of Honor.

Opinions differed yesterday on the role of emotional stress in causing heart disease in American males. The forum was a news conference called by the New York Heart Association.

Sales of New York department stores were unchanged last month from the level of April, 1962, according to a special survey by The New York Times.
MOST of the high scorers in the American Contract Bridge League's last nationwide charity contest, which yielded $48,000 for the league's beneficial fund, were from states west of the Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)--The House passed today a bill to authorize a $2,000,000,000 increase in the resources of the Export-Import Bank, a Treasury agency to stimulate United States exports.

Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon was reported last night to have made plans to join a law firm here and to have begun searching for a permanent home in the New York area.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The calendar may, in its own way, tell us as much about a nation's character as the census. Consider what May means in America.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 1 (AP)--The Alabama Senate, trying to agree on new taxes for schools, bogged down today in its second filibuster in a week.

YONKERS, May 1--Now that the top trotters have come and gone from Yonkers Raceway, the harness racing spotlight shifts to the pacers tomorrow night with the presentation of the $50,000 International Pace.
SAN ANTONIO, May 1 (AP) --Brig. Gen. Joseph Merit Tully, U.S.A., retired, whose troops were the first to land in France by sea on D-Day, died here today. His age was 69.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The world's Communist parties spent May Day, their day of "international solidarity," in a state of conflict and confusion.

CINCINNATI, May 1--Builders of machine tools, the complicated and high-priced machinery that makes machines, had only good news to report today.

THE first televising of the budget hearings of the Board of Estimate left no doubt yestetday of the immense contribution that the visual medium can make to an awareness of the needs and problems of local government.
