MANHASSET, L.I., May 2 --Fred W. Kessler, a dealer in air mail stamps with offices at 500 Fifth Avenue in New York, died yesterday of a heart ailment in North Shore Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 24 Castle Ridge Road.

BY a happy coincidence, a survey of popular taste in television viewing, sponsored by a television studio, turns out to confirm the present policies of television producing. Everything is for the best in the best of all possible TV worlds.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 2--The Soviet Union destroyed any remaining hopes today for an early United Nations agreement on space matters with an assertion that it saw no aspect of the subject on which it could agree with the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 2-- President Kennedy Interrupted his busy White House schedule today to praise the sacrifices of Congressional wives.
BERLIN, May 2--West Berlin welcomed a beautiful new theater today the Volksblihne building, which opened its doors to the public for the first time last night.

The New York Blood Center and Research Institute, established through a recent partnership arrangement between the Community Blood Council of Greater New York and the American Red Cross, received the endorsement yesterday of Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner.

WASHINGTON, May 2--At the 1962 Yale commencement, President Kennedy appealed to the American people to "move on from the reassuring repetition of stale phrases to a new, difficult but essential confrontation with reality."
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP)--A single by Brooks Robinson with the bases filled in the ninth inning helped the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-7 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

PIERMONT, N.H., May 2-- A raw, wet, cold, exqui sitely miserable opening day of the spring bear-hunting season has bone into the records. In these mountains the only casualties other than weather-numbed hunters, who don't count, were two bear dogs--a learning pup and a leathery old veteran called Smiley.
THE accent was supposed to have been on spring at last night's concert by the New York Philharmonic. Leonard Bernstein had programed two "Spring" Symphonies--the Schumann and Benjamin Britten's.
The Roman Catholic population of the United States now stands at a record of 43,851,500, the Official Catholic Directory for 1963 announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2-- James R. Hoffa gave Congress a glimpse today of his longrange plan to enlist the support of European labor unions on a reciprocal basis to make his strikes of American trucking concerns more effective.
WASHINGTON, May 2-- The Civil Aeronautics Board gave a further indication today that it was prepared to resist international pressures for a rise in trans-Atlantic fares.
BRIDGEWATER, Conn., May 2 (AP)--Van Wyck Brooks, writer of literary history and biography and noted critic, died today at his home. He was 77 years old.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 21 --Indiana University took the position today that three students indicted un charges of subversive activity were innocent until proved guilty.
Federal Judge Charles M. Metzner said yesterday that he would enter a default judgment against the Hughes Tool Company in the antitrust case brought by Trans World Air lines, Inc.

WASHINGTON., May 2 (AP) --The Commerce Department has estimated that $17,500,000,000 was spent on new construction in the first four months of 1963. This was 5 percent above the corresponding period of 1962.
The use of mass psychology to persuade pedestrians and drivers to behave safely in traffic situations will begin here next month.

The net earnings of the operating companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group in the first quarter were almost 5 per cent higher than in the period last year, the shareholders of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Coma pany and of the Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., were told at their meetings yesterday.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 75 cents a bale down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
NEWARK, May 2--Gov. Richard J. Hughes disclosed plans today to sponsor legislation designed to encourage middle-income housing construction by private developers.
PARIS, May 2--The French Government is considering, among other economic measures, a tax penalty on private industrial concerns that raise wages by more than 4.5, per cent a year.

A PROPHET without sufficient honor in his own country is having an exhibition at the Cordier Warren Gallery, 978 Madison Avenue at 76th Street. The prophet is Man Ray, an original Dadaist, a founder of surrealism, and thus, indirectly, a partial granddaddy of Pop. Now about as French as an American can get, he lives in Paris. America, deserted, is the less.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP)--Ron Fairly's two-run homer with two out in the ninth inning gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 3-2 victory tonight over the Philadelphia Phillies and ended the Dodgers' losing streak at four.

Paradise Inn, 311 West 41st Street, LO 3-2581. This is a colorful, down-to-earth Greek restaurant with a faithful clientele and a fascinating bill of fare. The menu includes such Hellenic specialties as taramasalata, the traditional red caviar...
NORMAN G, DYHRENFURTH, 44 years old, Santa Monica, Calif., a motion picture producer-director and explorer. He is expedition director and will produce the expedition film.
YONKERS, April 30--Henry T. Adios, already the greatest money-earner among active pacers, rallied to capture the $50,000 International Pace as the rich got richer tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

Can strength through merger save jobs? The Chesapeake Ohio Railway believes the answer is a resounding "yes." Railroad unions have been attempting to block any further consolidation of the C. O. and the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, contending that the B O earned almost $2,000,000 last year.

WASHINGTON, May 2-- Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg may look like a fragile reed that would blow away in a strong wind, but she is as vigorous as one of President Kennedy's physical fitness enthusiasts. At 67, she fishes, swims and water skis. She is also good at shaking hands.
WASHINGTON, May 2-- Congressional leaders agreed today that prospects were good for action this year on most elements of President Kennedy's aid-to-education program.

WASHINGTON, May 2--A group of the nation's leading economists agreed today that business activity had turned upward more strongly than either it or the Kennedy Administration had foreseen just a few months ago.
The Waterfront Commission yesterday accused the marine insurance industry of closing its eyes to a "rising tide" of cargo pilferage in the Port of New York.
Continued activity in textile shares and news of a rise in Britain's gold and currency reserves in April spurred another advance on the London stock market yesterday.
When the New York Clearing House Association moved 67 years ago into a marble, three-story Italian Renaissance building at 77 Cedar Street, a plaque was installed.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The president of the Boeing Company denied today that his company's bid on the TFX warplane was unrealistically low. And he challenged defense chiefs to let him build four prototypes to be tested against those of the winning bidder.
WASHINGTON, May 2-- Gov. George Romney of Michigan denied again today that he would be a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination. But his statement was a shade less than final.
LONDON, May 2--A relaxation of pressure on sterling was indicated today in the Treasury's report on British reserves that showed a 12,000,000 ($33,600,000) rise during April.
Two prominent players are making the trek to Off Broadway. The latest are Shelley Winters and Jack Warden. Both will appear June 10 at the York Playhouse in "Cages," written by Lewis John Carlino.
Dr. Samuel B. Gould declared yesterday he was certain of being "vindicated" by a Federal Communications Commission inquiry into the relationship of Channel 13's programing to network contributions.

NORMAN GUNTHER DYHRENFURTH, an aggres sive, dynamic, natural leader, has brought his group to the summit of Mount Everset, the first Americans to do so. Persons who know him well were delighted, though hardly surprised, at the achievement.
MONTREAL, May 2--Two convicts at the maximum-security St. Vincent de Paul Penitentiary, seeking a transfer to another prison, stabbed a guard to death this evening as they held him hostage in a cell.
WASHINGTON, May 2--President Kennedy paid tribute at the White House today to 240 holders of the Medal of Honor, men whom he called "our most distinguished American citizens."
THE Sophisticated Mexican ceramics and folk paint ings that will go on sale Sunday at the annual fair of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church are a far cry from the cake sales of the past.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 2--President Juan Bosch said tonight that he was going to ask all the American states to break with Haiti.

The Federal Reserve System's holdings of Treasury securities rose to a high this week, as the central bank bought heavily to offset a tendency towards tightness in the money market.

GENERATIONS of bridge students have observed that the famous experts, in their published hands, seem to make as many mistakes as the run-of-the-mill home player, and the student has the comforting feeling that "I could do as well myself."
Consolidated net income of the Phelps Dodge Corporation declined in the first quarter to $9,656,096 from $10,554,894 in the 1962 quarter, the report disclosed yesterday.

Stocks prices continued to edge up yesterday as volume slackened sharply from Wednesday's pace. Gains in most major groups were limited to fractions although a few specialty issues were able to add a point or more.

LOUISVILLE, May 2--The entry of Investor this morning established a starting field of nine for the Kentucky Derby, the world's most ballyhooed horse race, which will be run for the 89th time Saturday. The tardy action did not disturb the status quo ante of the classic in any respect.

The head of the American Council for Judaism last night criticized the Zionist movement for what he called an attack on "the fundamental American commitment" of American Jews and an attempt to "weld a national bond among all Jews."
SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 2 (UPI)--Robert Lee Beck, a 26year-old Harvard graduate student from San Diego, led a United States sweep of the modern pentathlon today in the Pan-American Games.
The Hearst publishing Company has confirmed reports that its Sunday newspaper supplement, The American Weekly would cease publication effective Sept. 1.
KATMANDU, Nepal, May 2 --Two climbers of a United States expedition reached they summit of Mount Everest yesterday. The news came in a message today from the expedition's base camp.
LOS ANGELES, May 2 (AP) --Bryant Washburn, a silentscreen star, died Tuesday in the Motion Picture Country Home. He was 79 years old.
Rabbi Elkan Cohen Voorsanger, who was called "the fighting rabbi" of World War I, died yesterday in San Francisco, where he had lived in retirement for the last three years. His age was 74.
The Community Service Society announced yesterday that it opposed two recommendations of the Moreland Commission report on public welfare.

TOKYO, May 2--Japanese maritime officials rejected today the report by crewmen that the Chinese Communist freighter that went down in the East China Sea yesterday had been sunk by torpedoes from a submarine.

"The whole world around us lay spread out like a giant relief map," said Edmund Percival Hillary after reaching the summit of Mount Everest.

In his efforts to develop an early-warning system to head off strikes over automation, Mayor Wagner has turned to a labor-management foundation for guidance in detecting areas of potential conflict before antagonisms have hardened to the battle point.

Although Paul Boepple's musical sympathies range widely, the works of Palestrina recur frequently in his programs. In 1955 he led the Dessoff Choirs in a concert devoted solely to the 16th-century master.
ATLANTA, May 2 (UPI)-- The legality of telephone eavesdropping was challenged in Federal court today in a $10,000,000 libel suit.

WASHINGTON, May 2--A partisan fight over the national debt limit was assured today as the House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill fixing the limit. The ceiling was put at $307,000,000,000 until July 1 and at $309,000,000 for July and August.
WASHINGTON May 2-- John A. O'Donnell, an agent for Philippine war damage claimants, has disputed the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on the extent of his interest in the claims act of 1962.

A 9-year-old boy wrote a note to a juror in a Queens manslaughter trial Wednesday. It led to a motion for a mistrial, an investigation by the District Attorney and an unusual action by a Supreme Court justice.
ALBANY, May 2--Governor Rockefeller today reported the signing of a bill prohibiting discrimination by hospitals against doctors because of race or color.
In Detroit last month, a man was indicted on a charge of illegally leasing a 16-mm. print of the Walt Disney film "The Shaggy Dog."

Business profits in the first quarter retreated slightly from the advanced level reached in the final quarter of last year, the First National City Bank says in its monthly economic letter published today.
HONG KONG, May 2--The United States made its biggest single direct grant to the Hong Kong Government today to help the British crown colony in its refugee-aid program.
KINGSTON, N.Y., May 2-- Two pilots were killed late this afternoon when their jet fighterbombers collided over the Catskill Mountains while on test missions.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)--The International Association of Machinists scheduled today for May 10 a vote by 26,000 aerospace, production workers on a proposed new contract with the Boeing Company.
WASHINGTON, May 2-- Right-wing extremists do "devil's work far better than Communists could do," Thomas H. Kuchel of California, the Senate Republican whip, charged today.
Elisabeth Bergner, the Viennese actress, will make her first New York stage appearance in 15 years tonight at the Barbizon Plaza Theater.

WASHINGTON, May 2-- President Kennedy told two ranking officials of the European Common Market today that the United States wants more substantial European concessions in next year's international tariff negotiations than have been indicated to date.

LOS ANGELES, May 2--Richand M. Nixon's planned move from California to New York will mark the end of the second major chapter in the former. Vice President's public career.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 2 --Hundreds of young Negroes, many of them in their teens or even younger, demonstrated through the streets of Birmingham this afternoon.
Thirteen persons and two defunct brokerage concerns were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of perpetuating a stock fraud in which the public lost $250,000.

With 10 16-millimeter movie projectors and four filmstrip viewers in simultaneous operation, 416 registrants yesterday packed the fifth-floor screening rooms of the Biltmore Hotel as the fifth American Film Festival held its second-day session.
WASHINGTON, May 2--The United States has urged the United Arab Republic, Syria and Iraq to cease propaganda attacks against King Hussein of Jordan.

BERLIN, May. 2--Soviet officials have proposed the establishment of a special committee to study the possibilities of widening trade between West Berlin and the Soviet Union, city authorities said today.

DETROIT, May 2 (AP)-- Larry (Bobo) Osborne hit two home runs against his former teammates as the Washington Senators defeated the Detroit Tigers, 9--4, today. It was the first time this season the lastplace Senators won two games in a row.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) --President Kennedy praised six women in Federal service today for distinguished contributions to the public interest.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., May 2 (UPI)--Twin jets of seawater were shot with explosive force at a model of a control panel today for a Navy court of inquiry investigating the Thresher disaster.
LONDON, May 2--The British Overseas Airways Corporation will reduce its fleet and staff because "there is less expansion and less growth ahead of us than we used to look forward to."

The Weavers gave the first of two Carnegie Hall "family reunion" concerts last night to mark the 15th anniversary of the folk-music quartet. All seven of present and former Weavers held their audience.
A Stockholder of American Metal Climax, Inc., expressed concern at the annual meeting yesterday for the fate of the company's mining investments in Africa.
The chairman of a Presidential emergency board in the railroad work-rules dispute indicated yesterday that the panel might not be ready to submit settlement recommendations by the deadline of May 11.

Robert Moses, former chairman of the State Council of Parks, accused the national Outdoor Recreation Resources Review Commission yesterday of "a monstrous distortion" in its appraisal of local recreational facilities.
WASHINGTON, May 2--Rail and truck loadings for the week ended April 27, were both above the preceding week. However, compared to the corresponding week last year, loadings were about the same.

Cocoa and sugar futures declined yesterday in active trading while most other New York commodities were higher in quiet dealings.

Officials at Aqueduct yesterday found themselves running into a shortage of jockeys-- highly qualified ones--for their $50,000-added Carter Handicap. The seven-furlong contest is scheduled for tomorrow with about a dozen starters expected.
The State Department of Insurance said yesterday that it had seized control of the Dental Insurance Plan, Inc., covering 150,000 subscribers in New York State.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches, postponed from Tuesday because of bad weather, were played yesterday.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 2--Fear that President Francois Duvalier might resume liquidation of his opponents gripped Port-au-Prince today as a commission of the Organization of American States finished its investigation here of Haiti's dispute with the Dominican Republic.
CHICAGO, May 2 (UPI)-- Corn futures edged upward, but old crop May wheat fell more than 2 cents a bushel at one point and led other grains downward today on the Board of Trade.
BONN, May 2--Dr. Ludwig Erhard intervened today in a spreading metal-industry strike that threatens to cripple the economy of highly industrialised West Germany.
A kind of do-it-themselves project to prevent delinquency and crime is under way here among those who know the problem best--the youngsters themselves.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that the need for Federal health insurance for the aged "grows more urgent daily."
Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon announced yesterday that he would move to this city June 1 and practice law here.

LONDON, May 2--There are sharp differences between India on the one hand and the United States and Britain on the other over the question of the longterm military aid that India is seeking from the West.
The entire banking community has been stirred up by James J. Saxon, the Controller of the Currency, who is responsible for supervising nationally chartered banks.

The Long Island Golf Association opens its season formally today with the staging of the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament. It is an amateur event in honor of the late sports writer of The New York Times and will be played at the Seawane Club, Hewlett, L.I.
CINCINNATI, May 2--Most of this country's machine tools--the machines that make machines--are obsolete. That was the word given to some 1,200 industry members ...
The president of Trans World Airlines called for joint industry action yesterday to overcome "some of the more flagrant examples of overscheduling" on certain routes.
MIAMI, May 2--A former Premier of Peru said today that the Soviet Union was using Cuba "as a scalpel to sever North and South America."

YORKTOWN, N,Y., May 2 --A million-dollar hole in the ground at Mohansic State Park that was to have been opened next July 4 as a swimming pool and sun area for 4,000 persons was ordered fenced off indefinitely today.

Despite Mayor Wagner's promises of last year, despite his proposed imposition now of nearly a quarter-billion dollars in new taxation, his executive budget for 1963-64 falls disappointingly short of meeting New York City's vast needs--as was made painfully clear yesterday at hearings before the City Council and the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, May 2--A pickup in jobs underlined generally improving economic conditions today. April figures released by the Department of Labor showed that nonfarm employment had reached its highest point, after allowance for seasonal factors.
Fred A. Young, the new Republican state chairman, said yesterday that he would start at once to build party strength for the state and national elections of 1964.
PARIS, May 2--Signs emerged today of a possible reduction in the huge surplus in France's international balance of payments.
RISING FAWN, Ga., May 2 --Billie Sol Estes paid a visit today to 10 "freedom walkers," but was asked to leave.
LONDON, May 2--Canada's part in an international nuclear force was discussed today by the British and Canadian Defense Ministers.
The Government securities market was firm yesterday in somewhat slower trading. Highgrade corporate bonds were higher ors heavier volume, while municipals were steady in routine business.
Albert Klapper, managing clerk in Martin C. Epstein's law office for 15 years, was indicted yesterday with two other men on charges of bribery and conspiracy in state liquorlicense scandals.
ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP)-- Stan Musial's seventh-inning double with the bases filled to night enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 4--3.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 2--Glen Foster of Larchmont, N.Y., won the Princess Elizabeth Trophy by finishing third today in the last of five International 14-Foot Dinghy races.
WASHINGTON, May 2-- The United States issued an unusually strong warning today that the situation in Haiti remained tense and "potentially explosive" despite an appearance of calm.
LONDON, May 2 (AP)--The morning after he had bought a Frans Hals painting for $600,000 by traps-Atlantic telephone, Edward Speelman flew to Paris to watch one of his many horses race.
WASHINGTON, May 2--Department-store sales in the week ended April 27 were 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year. Five districts, however, showed a decline for the period.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2-- The members of the Philadelphia Orchestra decided today to accept the resignation of Julian Goldberg as their attorney.
WASHINGTON, May 2-- President Kennedy's chief political lieutenants are quietly proposing Representative Samuel S. Stratton as the Democratic candidate for the Senate in New York next year.

A 53-year-old accountant who, the Government said, is one of the biggest bookmakers in Manhattan and the Bronx, was arrested by Internal Revenue Service agents yesterday on a charge of failing to have the Federal gamblers' stamp.

ALTHOUGH meat cutters have gone on strike for a shorter working week, meat supplies have not been seriously affected. Meat buying, on the other hand has been. Retailers, hotel and restaurant buyers have increased the amount of their purchases, and the result is that retail prices of several meats have risen.
Senator Jacob K. Javits last night said a 4 per cent city sales tax would be "a powerful inducement to industry, to business and to people to move out of the city."

The City Planning Commission proposed a two-stage, $547,000,000 program yesterday for extending and improving the rapid-transit system. It asked $70,000,000 in immediate outlays to improve service to Queens.

The First National Real Estate Trust, a Massachusetts business trust formed in 1961, has bought the long-term leasehold on the Squibb Building at 745 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of 58th Street. The sale was arranged by S. Dudley Nostrand, chairman of the Cross Brown Company, brokers, for the Squibb Building Corporation.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 2-- Premier Souvanna Phouma talked today with pro-Communist leaders and returned to Vientiane with the hope that further meetings would lead to a solution of the political-military crisis in Laos.
TRENTON, May 2--William E. Ozzard, president of the State Senate, predicted today that the Senate on May 10 would approve the $750,000,000 bond referendums proposed by Gov. Richard J. Hughes.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) --The airlines have begun an industry-wide survey on what makes their planes late. The 60-day study began April 1 at the request of the Air Transport Association, the trade organization for the nation's scheduled carriers. ...

WASHINGTON, May 2-- The first manned flight in the two-man Gemini capsule has been postponed until late next year.
The unsettled political situation in Haiti has prompted several steamship lines to divert their passenger vessels from Port-au-Prince, the capital.
PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP) --Juan Marichal pitched a five-hitter for San Francisco tonight as the Giants edged the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2-1, on Felipe Alou's two-run homer.

Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., showed increased earnings and sales in the first quarter, Jerome A. Straka, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel yesterday. The results were also the best for any similar period in its history, he added.
During the New York Philharmonic's 1964-65 season, when Leonard Bernstein takes a oneyear sabbatical from his duties as music director, the orchestra will have four guest conductors.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 3 --Indictment of three Indiana University students on charges of subversion has stirred strong reaction here.

The two United States trans-Atlantic passenger airlines, Pan American and Trans World, were caught between the devil and the deep blue sky yesterday in a dispute between governments over international air fares.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 3 (UPI)--Jack Nicklaus, playing near-flawless golf in 90-degree heat, increased his margin to five strokes in the $60,000 Tournament of Champions today. He posted a 12-under-par score of 132 for 36 holes.
WASHINGTON, May 3-- Joseph Zack Kornfeder, a former official of the Communist party in the United States, died of a heart attack Wednesday while checking into a hotel here. His age was 65.
KATMANDU, Nepal, May 3 (AP)--One American and a Sherpa guide made up the first United States team to conquer Mount Everest, it was learned here today.
A spiritual leader in Conservative Judaism deplored yesterday the tendency of American Jews to make Israel "an issue in Jewish life."

WASHINGTON, May 3--The sidewalk cafes are beginning to appear for the season here. They are unhappy places, event the one operated by the button-eyed little Frenchman who wears a flower in his lapel and drifts among the patrons asking judgment on his food.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3-- As the San Francisco Opera Company prepares for the longest fall season in its 41-year history, Kurt Herbert Adler, the general director, voiced a complaint today over programing conflicts with the Metropolitan Opera Company in New York.
GLEN COVE, L.I., May 3-- William VanAnden Hester of Red Spring Lane, former treasurer of The Brooklyn Eagle, died tonight at Glen Cove Hospital. His age was 62.
A pocketful of small pennies, worth $1.82 when they were minted between 1856 and 1958, brought $15,879 at auction yesterday.
The Board of Education halted the construction of a $2,161,713 elementary school in Brooklyn yesterday after its inspectors had found defects in the concrete.

AN unopened bottle of wine seems capable of inspir ing more conversational claptrap than any alcoholic excess. A wine's origin, production, selection and service are frequently surrounded with so much snobbish nonsense that it is hard to separate the taste from the pedigree.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) --A jukebox industry spokesman said today that a $25 license fee on the coin-operated machines would put a lot of operators out of business.
An agreement in principle for the purchase of the Joe Lowe Corporation, maker and distributor of bakery supplies, by the Consolidated Foods Corporation, was announced yesterday.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., reported yesterday net earnings of $440,000 in March, paring the company's net loss for the first quarter of this year to $3,530,000. In the 1962 quarter the airline had reported net earnings of $660,000.

NEW DELHI, May 3--An authoritative American source indicated today that the United States and Britain had reached an impasse in their efforts to persuade India and Pakistan to settle the Kashmir dispute.

Contrary to the best laid plans of sentimentalists and promotion men, a young man named Jack Fisher and an older one named Duke Snider turned out to be the heroes of Willie Mays night at the Polo Grounds last night.
SAVANNAH, Ga., May 3 (AP)--A mass withdrawal of Negro students at Savannah State College was threatened today to protest the dismissal of a professor who had sought to integrate his classes.

ALBANY, May 3--Governor Rockefeller's office reported today the signing of a bill setting up a new state agency to take over the building program for mental hospitals and schools for the mentally retarded.
The sixth and last of the season's concerts given by Carnegie Hall in cooperation with the International Society for Contemporary Music was presented in Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
The State Liquor Authority is ready to begin its own investigation of an alleged attempt by one of its employes to shake down a nightclub owner for $2,000.

CINCINNATI, May 3--The space industry and the perforated tape that can replace a human operator in directing a machine are revolutionizing the metalworking industry and the making of machinery.
Stock prices staged a mild retreat yesterday as volume picked up slightly.
We love Willie; we love Mets." Fans sitting behind home plate at the Polo Grounds exposed their split loyalties with these words on a big sign last night.

WASHINGTON, May 3--A teacher in an American Army school in Munich discovered that three fifth-grade boys who hated to study were interested in airplanes. This week he got patent 3,087,257 for the electrically controlled model aircraft that he built for them.

TRENTON, May 3--Eleven hundred acres of woodland in northern Morris County and a small adjoining section of Sussex County were sprayed today for gypsy moths, tent caterpillars and inch worms, all leafeating insects.
A group of private individuals in the insurance industry is trying to salvage the Dental Insurance Plan, Inc. The state seized the plan two days ago because of financial deficiencies.
Astronauts who ultimately land on the moon and the planets may be able to eat part of their spacecraft.

WASHINGTON, May, 3-- Senator John L. McClellan fired a sharp letter at the Pentagon today. It called for documents and information that, he said, defense officials "have either refused, or, so far, failed to provide."

THE heroine of "The Pumpkin Eater," an unusual novel by Penelope Mortimer, is an eloquently tragic victim of a great modern worldwide concern: the population explosion. She wants more children. Her husband does not agree.
BUENOS AIRES, May 3-- Argentina's political future remains far from clear despite President Jose Maria Guido's reluctant signing of a decree postponing the nation-wide elections scheduled for July 7.

Gerold Frank's book "The Deed" glorifies the assassination of a high British official in Cairo on Nov. 2, 1944, by two young members of the Stern Gang. They "gave their lives for an ideal," the author tells us, the ideal being Zionism.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 3--The curious notion that lefthanded pitching can hobble the Yankees, who still can't use ailing Mickey Mantle against southpaws, may be due for a sharp revision.
A mistrial was declared yesterday in a Queens manslaughter trial because a 9-year-old boy had passed a note to a juror saying that the defendant was innocent.

If in asking the City Planning Commission to review the Transit Authority's program for improving service to Queens, Mayor Wagner thought he would receive a rubber-stamp endorsement of it, he was in for a surprise.

Credit Industrial Corporation, 11 West 42d Street, was accused yesterday of having paid $1,400,000 since Oct. 1, 1962, to two concerns described as partnerships of two of the corporation's officers.

GLENVILLE, Conn., May 3--Karen Ann McGuire, the girl who tried to buy the champion race horse Nashua in 1955--but was outbid by $1,251,175.97--is just as pleased she never got him.
There is a pressing need for increased patronage of the creative arts, John H. MacFayden, executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts, said yesterday.

The Polaroid Corporation dropped 3 points yesterday to 123 , a low for 1963, while Bell Howell shares climbed 1 , to 25 7/8, a new high for the year, as the fourth most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 3-- Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon told Congress today that his most active critics are motivated by a desire to protect "dormant banks" from "prospective enterprising rivals."
MOSCOW, Saturday, May 4-- The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party confirmed early today that Frol R. Kozlov, the 54-year-old Party Secretary, was suffering from an illness.

George T. (Ted) Baker, airline pioneer who sold his conAirlines last spring to Lewis B. Maytag Jr., is suing Mr. Maytag in an effort to regain a voice in the management of the highly profitable carrier.

Once a Mayor of New York makes up his mind on a new tax, public opposition rarely stops him. The last time that happened was in 1954, when Mayor Wagner proposed to extend the city sales tax to commercial services. He said: "I hate this tax." So, apparently, did the taxpayers--so many stormed Board of Estimate budget hearings that the Mayor finally relented and dropped the tax.

LONDON, May 5--After 18 months of negotiations, the Soviet Union has agreed to the first sale of contemporary Soviet oil paintings and watercolors to the West.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., May 5-- The 23d American Assembly of Columbia University ended its four-day conference today with sweeping recommendations for United States governmental and private action to help reduce the world birth rate.
LONDON, May 5--Sir Howard Robertson, the architect, died here, yesterday at the age of 74.
Transactions in the foreign exchange market were limited during the past week. British pound sterling opened strong then turned soft. Canadian dollar continued listless.

Frank DeVerna was elected president yesterday of Theatrical Protective Union, Local 1. The stagehands' union with a membership of 1,487, exercises jurisdiction in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island.

A Federal agency has contended that the city's proposed shift in site for the projected Federal Office Building would cause an unnecessary two-year delay and would increase costs by $9,000,000 to $15,000,000.
PITTSBURGH, May 5 (UPI) --Lee Walls smashed a threerun pinch-homer in the ninth inning today to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
WASHINGTON, May 4--The ceiling on the national debt is everything but, and the new scheme pending in Congress won't change it.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 (UPI)--A liberal group favoring the admission of Communist China to the United Nations and the abolition of the House Committee on Un-American Activities retained control today of the California Federation of Young Democrats.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 5--The Government hinted today that a political conspiracy might have been behind the mutiny of the Leopoldville police force Friday.
Senator Kenneth B. Keating reported yesterday that Governor Rockefeller said "rather recently" that he had not decided whether to seek the Republican nomination for President next year.

Herman C. Kupper, Inc., china and glassware concern, has leased a floor at 11 East 26th Street for showrooms, offices and shipping. Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., was the broker. The lease involves 11,000 square feet of space. The tenants have moved from 39 West 23d Street where they have been for more than 35 years.

LONDON, May 5 (AP)-- France, Yugoslavia, Austria, Rumania, the Soviet Union and Chile scored 5--0 sweeps and advanced to the second round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition today along with Brazil, Denmark, Belgium, Norway and Rhodesia.

The New York Pro Musica, the American ensemble formed to play music from before the time of Bach, has received a $465,000 grant from the Ford Foundation to enable it to reach the status of self-support within the next 10 years. The ensemble was founded in 1952 by Noah Greenberg.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith urged President Kennedy yesterday to "act with all strength" to protect Southern Negroes.

A three-year experiment permitting persons involved in negligence cases to choose either trial by a judge under a "rule of comparative negligence" or trial by jury was urged yesterday by the New York Chamber of Commerce.

PARIS BRITAIN may not be a mem ber of the Common Market, but its fashion spans the Channel with ease. The Paris ready-towear collections that opened last week began with an unprecedented salute to London--first a group show, then a solo by Mary Quant.
Lecture, Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York, 450 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, 4 P.M. "The Evolution of a Protein," Dr. Vernon M. Ingram.

LOUISVILLE, May 5--"He's dead fit. All he needs is rest and exercise," was what Jim Conway had to say of Chateaugay this morning. Chateaugay was the surprising winner of the 89th Kentucky Derby yesterday. Conway is the trainer of the colt.

The director of the Family Life Bureau of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday denounced Dr. John Rock, Boston gynecologist, as "a man who capitalizes on his Catholicism, yet speaks not at all out of a Catholic conscience."

ALBANY, May 5--Governor Rockefeller's office announced today that he had approved a new state law that eliminates the automatic death penalty for persons found guilty of premeditated murder or kidnapping.
Preliminary calculations that the Government will release in a few days are expected to estimate the first-quarter balance of payments deficit at about $700,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 5--Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. warned today that unless steps were taken, Washington hight have "one of the worst race riots" in history.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 5--The Dominican Republic stood today on the threshold of an armed invasion of Haiti.

There is a relatively littleknown group of mutual funds that can at once raise the ire of most industry men and draw skeptical interest from investors. They are the so-called "no-load" funds, which sell their shares at net asset value with no sales or commission charge.
Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, called last night for the establishment of a health corps, similar to the Peace Corps, to help new nations achieve high health standards.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 5 --Several hundred Negroes carried out a peaceful march and a demonstration today at a small park near the Southside jail.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 5-- Douglas H. MacNeil of Cherry Valley Road, chief of the Bureau of Social Research of the New Jersey State Department of Institutions and Agencies, died here yesterday. He was 61 years old.

PARIS, May 5--Although the possibility of enlarging the European Common Market to include Britain and other European countries is practically certain to remain in the deep freeze for several years at least, there is one exception. It is the small but vigorous country of Austria.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 5--Ambassador Walter P. McConaughy of the United States and the British High Commissioner, Sir Morrice James, had urgent consultations with President Mohammad Ayub Khan here today about the sixth round of Indian-Pakistani talks on Kashmir, scheduled to open May 15.
Despite the best efforts of the Kennedy Administration and the tax law specialists, who, like the public, want simpler laws, there is a decided trend in the opposite direction.
MOSCOW, May 5--Jan Peerce, the Metropolitan Opera, tenor, won the admiration and affection of a Moscow audience here tonight in the opening concert of a month-long Soviet tour.

Unregulated waterway carriers performed 395,800,000,000 ton-miles of service in 1961, providing 85.1 per cent of the total service in the nation's waterborne commerce, according to a report published by the United States Army Corps of Engineers.

In a thoughtful as well as courageous speech, Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, has publicly challenged the advocates of "total victory" against Communism. He points out that the "total" victories actually won in World Wars I and II raised more problems than they solved and certainly did not create perfect worlds.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 5 (UPI)--The United States won both the individual and team gold medals today in the Grand Prix, the equestrian event which closed the sports competition of the Pan-American Games.
An hour-long dramatization of "One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich," the Soviet novel about Stalin's labor camps, will be televised next fall by the National Broadcasting Company.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 5-- Parachutes found on the ground in a Communist-held mountain region have provided the strongest evidence yet that the Communist guerrillas have been receiving supplies by airdrop from Laos, reliable sources said today.

Miss Alice Clarisse Pepper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Pepper of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Leon Cooper. He is a son of Maurice D. Cooper of Newton Centre, Mass., and the late Mrs. Cooper.
Merchant seamen will have something "loud and clear" to say about Federal shipping policies at a convention of the Seafarers International Union of North America this week.
ALGIERS, May 5--Algeria's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Khemisti, died today, three weeks after he was wounded by a Moslem assassin's bullet.
PARIS, May 5--Former Premier Michel Debre made a strong political comeback today with his overwhelming election to the National Assembly as a representative of the Indian Ocean island of Reunion.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 5 (UPI)--Jack Nicklaus fired a closing round of 69 for a 72hole total of 273 to win the $60,000 Tournament of Champions today on the 36, 36--72 Desert Inn Country Club course.
MEXICO CITY, May 5--The first of several planned auctions of the works of Jose Clemente Orozco brought a total of nearly $62,000 here last night.

LOME, Togo, May 5--The provisional regime of President Nicholas Grunitzky was virtually certain of victory today as Togo held its first election since the assassination of President Sylvanus Olympio last January.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 5--The Billou Farm's gray mare Silver Lady, from Commack, scored 18 points today and won the working hunter championship. Althea Knickerbocker rode Silver Lady in the Rice Farms spring horse show on the Melody Farms course.

The turbulent Middle East is in the midst of a double crisis that threatens to break up the new federation of Egypt, Syria and Iraq and to endanger peace in this vital area. The man in the middle of both crises is President Nasser.
The construction of 475 apartments in a series of fivestory structures on vacant land in Greenwich Village was proposed yesterday to test new theories in urban housing.
Many Republicans said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's marriage to the former Mrs. Margaretta Murphy would not affect his chances for the Presidential nomination next year.
AFTER losing his grand slam on this deal the South player asked his partner, "Could I have made it?"
Governor Rockefeller and his bride flew to Venezuela yesterday on a two-week wedding trip.

MOSCOW, May 5--Official concerns such as the illness of Frol R. Kozlov seemed remote today as Muscovites took advantage of sunny skies and 70degree temperature to flock to parks of "culture and rest."
PITTSBURGH, May 5--The pressure on steel supply was increasing last week.
The possibility that the Wagner administration might abandon its request for extension of the 4 per cent sales tax to outof-city deliveries within the state appeared yesterday to be increasing.
Weaving throungh a shifting maze of Sunday morning drivers, baby carriages, strolling couples and dogs too serene to bite hard, 38 men in undershirts walked twice around Central Park yesterday.
Three of the theater's first ladies took the stage last night at the Majestic and proved once again that there is no business like show business.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli sector), May 5 (Reuters)--The Israeli Cabinet expressed approval today of a suggestion by Premier David Ben-Gurion that the Soviet Union and the United States jointly guarantee Israel's borders against attack.
LOS ANGELES, May 5--More than 10,000 persons attended the first folk-music festival to be held at the University of California at Los Angeles.
QUEBEC, May 5--One American and two Canadian steel companies are presently in the middle of a potentially bitter dispute between two of Canada's eastern provinces.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5-- A strong plea for Federal financial help for Roman Catholic colleges is made in a Catholic magazine by Seymour E. Harris, economist at Harvard. But he opposes Federal aid for parochial schools.

LOUISVILLE, May 5--Jimmy Conway gave Chateaugay a pat on the flank and sent his chestnut colt off on his mission, yesterday's 89th running of the Kentucky Derby. The trainer was not buoyed up by any overwhelming surges of optimism.

The Brooklyn Opera Company is now well into its spring season at the Brooklyn Academy. On Saturday night the troupe put on the time-honored double bill of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" before a capacity and warmhearted audience. Both operas were solidly conducted by Anton Coppola.

MILAN, Italy, May 5 (UPI) --Sandro Mazzinghi of Italy scored a technical knockout in the eighth round today over Don Fullmer, younger brother of the former middleweight champion, Gene Fullmer. A crowd of 6,000 fans saw the bout at Vigorelli Velodrome.

WASHINGTON, May 5-- President Kennedy, somewhat to his surprise, has received a ballot on which he is asked to cast his vote for a new member of the Yale Corporation--the ruling body of Yale University.
WASHINGTON, May 5--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara has asked the Navy to restudy its proposal for a nuclear-powered surface fleet.
A new tide of controversy over baseball's balk rule began rising yesterday and promised to enliven tomorrow's showdown meeting on the topic.

The investigating committee of the Organization of American States has completed the first stage of its mission to Haiti and the Dominican Republic. While two members remain, the others will report to the O.A.S. council. This council meeting offers an opportunity, perhaps the last, to work out calmly and under hemispheric auspices, a program to meet the Haitian crisis.
While Governor Rockefeller honeymoons in Venezuela, his new state chairman will be trying to soothe an outbreak of chapped feelings and windburn among New York Republicans.

A new nonpartisan Citizens Committee for a Free Cuba has brought together prominent Americans, including Adm. Arleigh A. Burke, former Chief of Naval Operations; Edward Teller, the physicist, and union executives and educators.
WASHINGTON, May 5--All emergency meeting of the Council of the Organization of American States was called for tomorrow morning as the Dominican Republic again threatened to invade Haiti.

The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, stated clerk of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., expressed outrage "and disgust" yesterday at the racial situation in Birmingham, Ala. He gave the 25th anniversary sermon of the Church of the Master at 360 West 122d Street.
KANSAS CITY, May 5 (UPI) --Frank Malzone and Chuck Schilling hit home runs today to pace the Boston Red Sox to a 3-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
The Rev. Margaret Barr said yesterday that there are many paths to God.
VISCHER FERRY, N. Y., May 5--Miss Suellen Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Vischer Smith of Vischer Ferry and Bradenton, Fla., will be married here on June 29 to William Thomas Wiggins Mader.

WASHINGTON, May 5-- Medical investigators in Connecticut have traced an uncommon fungus infection in eight or nine persons to the salt hay used as winter covering on the tennis courts at a country club in Fairfield County.

All that the State Attorney General's office, Brentano's bookstore and the REA Express know about Charles D. Lyon is that he is an art lover and lives at Kalakaket Creek, Alaska.
ROME, May 5--A delay in some plans or policies in which the United States is particularly interested is forseen here as a consequence of the situation brought about by last week's general elections.

A procession of clergymen from nine church bodies entered the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine yesterday as a demonstration of the growing spirit of unity among Christians.

WASHINGTON, May 5--The election returns from Italy have now been thoroughly studied in Washington and the conclusions spell trouble. Washington foresees not crisis, but uncertainty, delay and long argument in Rome over the policies that are of greatest interest to the United States.

Sachs Equities, Inc., David Sachs, president, has sold the 20-story and penthouse apartment building at 161 West 16th Street, northeast corner of Seventh Avenue. The building is a landmark of the Chelsea area because the ground floor is occupied by Barney's, a clothing store.

FORT WORTH, May 5 (UPI)--William Fleming, who made a fortune in oil in the classic Texas tradition and devoted much of his wealth to the Baptist Church, died last night in a hospital of a heart attack.

Reproductions of priceless laces of 15th century France and Belgium, many of them museum pieces, are appearing on 20th century dining room tables these days. They are in the form of white, gold and silver paper doilies, made through engraving skills rare in this country.
WASHINGTON, May 5--Every day now, with the high-school tourist wave at floodtide, thousands and thousands of glowing youths flow into the Great Rotunda and sign on for the guided tour of the Capitol.

RUDOLF NUREYEV made his first New York ap pearance in the "Blue Bird" pas de deux last night in the performance of "The Sleeping Beauty" given by the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House. He was the partner of Vyvyan Lorrayne.

By any standard, what happened at the Polo Grounds yesterday qualifies as one of the most remarkable events in baseball history. Through the turnstiles came 53,880 paying customers; some 5,000 more were turned away.

The Volkswagen, the redoubtable little roadster that has sold so well in the United States, is now vastly expanding its advertising in Europe. In doing so, however, the company and its agency, Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., have found it necessary to make some sharp changes in advertising strategy.
Now that Wall Street has had ample opportunity to digest the first portion of the Securities and Exchange Commission's special study on the markets, it has found nothing to become really upset about.
Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon was reported last night considering the purchase of a spacious cooperative apartment in the same building where Governor Rockefeller has a floor.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 5-- Laotian neutralists and procommunists fired on each other's positions in the mountains east of the Plaine des Jarres today. The political war was quiet.
LONDON, May 5--Per Jacobsson, managing director of the International Monetary Fund since 1956, died in a hospital here today following a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 5--Baseball being a most unpredictable game, it almost follows that the New York Yankees, after deftly hurdling two sharp left-handers in the first two games with the Minnesota Twins, should stumble over a right-hander in the third one.
WASHINGTON, May 5-- President Kennedy praised the labor movement tonight as a "powerful force for progress."

TRENTON, May 5--An apricot miniature poodle, Ch. Pixiecroft Sunbeam, owned by Mrs. Garner Cassatt of Bryn Mawr, Pa., outperformed 1,997 other dogs today to win best-in-show at the annual Trenton Kennel Club show.

BURBANK, Calif., May 5-- Walt Disney Productions showed a net income of $2,576,556, or $1.49 a share, on 1,725,049 common shares outstanding for the half year ended March 30, Roy O. Disney, president, said in an interim report to stockholders today.

The Mohole Project, one of the nation's most important basic research efforts, appears to be in serious trouble. To the enormously difficult technological problems which were apparent from the beginning, there have been added serious managerial and political squabbles.
"Heavens Above," a British comedy on a religious theme, starring Peter Sellers, will have its premiere May 20 at the Sutton Theater, Third Avenue and 57th Street.

DOUALA, Cameroon, May 5 (Reuters)--At least one person--believed to be an American--survived the crash of a DC-6 airliner with 55 persons aboard on a jungle-clad mountainside near here yesterday, search parties reported today. All the others were feared dead.
A new approach to the teaching of high school biology will be available to school systems this fall in the form of three different courses.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (UPI)--The Houston Colts beat the Philadelphia Phils, 6-2, in the second game of a doubleheader today behind the sevenhit pitching of a former Phil, Dick Farrell. The Phils won the opener, 6-5, with a two-run rally in the ninth aided by an error that let the winning run score.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 5--After narrowly escaping defeat in the semi-final round, Charles Slicklen Jr. of the North Hempstead Country Club won the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, May 5-- The annual spring battle over the national debt limit gets under way in Congress this week with Republicans seeking to make political capital out of the need for another increase.

Two Gian Carlo Menotti operas reflected new light on each other last night when the New York City Opera paired them for the first time.
"A Rainy Day in Newark," written by Howard Teichmann, co-author, of "The Solid Gold Cadillac," has been acquired for Broadway production in October by Roger L. Stevens and Elaine Perry.

Beaten in a close game Friday, completely humiliated Saturday and quickly put in their place by a 6-3 defeat in the first game of yesterday's double-header, the New York Mets finally turned on the San Francisco Giants in the second game.

NEW DELHI, May 6 The Indian Government had indicated it will agree to "low key mediation" or "good offices" by an American or a Briton in the Kashmir dispute if Pakistan proposes such participation by a third party.

WHITE PLAINS, May 6 An antiques show that dealers are proud to be part of opened here today at the Westchester County Center. It was an event of the kind that seldom, in recent years, has won such unanimous and wholehearted approval.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The Alliance for Progress, hailed as a dream plan to cure Latin America's ills, has become a painful process, but Teodoro Moscoso says that in spite of everything it is pushing ahead.

WASHINGTON, May 6 Racial clashes and the use of police dogs against Negro marchers moved Senator John Sherman Cooper today to accuse both major political parties of paying "lip service to the cause of civil right."
How slow-witted is the typical consumer? The United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that he was not quite as slow as the Federal Trade Commission seemed to believe.
A patrolman walking his beat in the Bronx was attacked last evening by a thug who grabbed the patrolman's revolver and shot him twice.

Kermit Bloomgarden confirmed reports yesterday that he is preparing Loring Mandel's drama, "Project: Immortality," for a Broadway premiere in October. This is the play that Mr. Bloomgarden was to have opened here last Jan. 23 under the title "The Doner Program."
PITTSBURGH, May 6 (UPI) Johnny Logan's bases-filled pinch single capped a four-run rally in the sixth inning today to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 7 4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

The Wagner Administration, under heavy fire from all quarters, has scrapped one of the worst of its new tax proposals the plan to extend the 4 per cent sales tax to out-of-city deliveries within New York State. Since the plain effect of this tax would have been to accelerate the flight of shopping to the suburbs, with serious hurt to many businesses and their workers; its abandonment is welcome.
HARTFORD, May 6 The John P. Kelly Company, agent of record for state insurance, produced its files for inspection today in response to a subpoena.
Mortgage bankers in convention here yesterday heard the Kennedy Administration's program for tax reduction and increased spending described as a gamble.

LONDON, May 6 The United States and Britain have run into trouble on their plan to create a joint nuclear force. The plan had been to use, at the start, British bombers, three United States submarines and fighter-bombers contributed by other allies.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 6 In the antiseptic air of the north woods, business is bustling and culture is bursting into bloom. The Eastern notion that this is merely the home of "Ole Olson, the big dumb Swede," and Paul Bunyan lumberjacks is as hackneyed as the...

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 6 Eight children from the 98 per cent Negro Lincoln School staged a sit-in this morning in the virtually all-white Cleveland School. Seven others picketed the building for about 40 minutes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 6 The United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America has urged the Central American Common Market Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemale, Honduras and Nicaragua to strengthen its productivity as a Starting point for maintaining its growth rate.
A 40-year-old woman bookkeeper for a publishing house was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of embezzling $3,000 from the company union of which she was formerly president.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 A conservation group said today that the Pacific Gas and Electric Company had falsified testimony in an attempt to win permits to build a $61,000,000 nuclear power reactor on Bodega Head, north of San Francisco ...
Some strange things are happening in the Pentagon these days.

SHERIDAN, Wyo., May 6 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dean Sage of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alida Douglas Sage, to Kennett Thorin Richardson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew K. Richardson of Clark, N.J.
HOLLYWOOD, May 6 Three of the biggest movie companies in Hollywood are "exploring the possibilities" of building one studio that could be used by all three for movie and television production.
WASHINGTON, May 6 Dr. Frances O. Kelsey surveyed a 20-by-15-foot storeroom today in a temporary Government building off Independence Avenue.
World sugar futures gained moderately and cocoa was mixed in active dealings yesterday.
ALBANY, May 6 Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill denying tax relief to the New Haven Railroad on real property used for commuter service.

MILWAUKEE, May 6 (UPI) Bobby Bragan, the manager of the Milwaukee Braves, told his pitchers today it would be to their advantage, artistically and financially, to comply with the controversial balk rule being enforced in the National League.
J. Raymond Jones, a Harlem Democratic district leader, struck a snag yesterday in his effort to gain election to the City Council.
WASHINGTON, May 6 Archbischop Patrick A. O'Boyle of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Washington outlined tonight a "minimum program" that he said would lead to improved race relations in this city.
PARIS, May 6 Throughout this year, France will celebrate the centenary of Eugene Delacroix, her greatest romantic painter, who died in Paris in 1863.
RYE, N.Y., May 6 Golfers and golf course superintendents in Westchester County expressed the hope today that warm weather would soon cure their ailing putting greens.

STONY BROOK, L.I., May 6 Frump is the name given to a hypothetical organism in biology examinations at the State University at Stony Brook. It has also been selected by students as the name for the school's new marine biology research vessel.
MOSCOW, May 6 George London, the Metropolitan Opera bass-baritone, became the first American today to record the title role of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" with the Bolshoi Theater Company.

Per Jacobsson's death removes a dynamic innovator from the international financial scene. His task as head of the International Monetary Fund was not completed, though he left the fund in its strongest condition. Bold and imaginative leadership will be required to continue its rapid evolution as the key factor in maintaining the financial stability of the free world.
The long end of the Treasury securities list continued its upward movement yesterday. High-grade corporate debt issues also advanced, while state and municipal obligations remained dull.
WASHINGTON, May 6 President Kennedy appointed Adm. David L. McDonald today as Chief of Naval Operations. The appointment put a surprising end to Adm. George W. Anderson's one-term tenure.
WASHINGTON, May 6 An Illinois Republican today called Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman an "unreliable source of information" on the cost of farm programs.
The Military Air Transport Service has awarded contracts totaling $96,872,000 to 11 airlines for international services.
WASHINGTON, May 6 A House subcommittee reported out late today a $1,195,000,000 higher-education bill limited to construction grants and loans.

In the wake of record sales and earnings for 1962 and the first quarter of this year, directors of General Motors Corporation voted yesterday a special dividend of 50 cents a common share. The directors also approved the regular quarterly payments of 50 cents.
SKEPTICS assume that the Soviet Government closed the Fernand Leger exhibition in Leningrad because abstract paintings offend official dogma.
MIAMI BEACH, May 6 The American Institute of Architects opened a four-day annual convention at the Americana Hotel today. Some 800 delegates are attending.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 The Right Rev. James A. Pike of California shared with other Protestant Episcopal Bishops of the Far West today a pastoral letter in which he admonished clergymen against participating in the growing practice of glossolalia, or "speaking with tongues."
The British pound declined in dealings on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday under pressure from European currencies.
WASHINGTON, May 6 The $53,000,000 nuclear liner Savannah is enmeshed in a labor tangle again and will not sail from Galveston tomorrow as scheduled.
ST. LOUIS, May 6 The American Psychiatric Association opened its 119th annual meeting here today in what was regarded as a good atmosphere for mental-health programs.
George T. Eastment, one of the nation's leading track coaches for the past 35 years, will retire as head coach of the Manhattan College track and cross-country teams on June 30.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 6 The United States is leaning toward a compromise British proposal to meet the cost of the United Nations peace-keeping operations in the Congo and the Middle East.

When Prime Minister Pearson meets President Kennedy at Hyannis Port this weekend he will be well along on the "sixty days of dynamic action," through which he hopes to give Canada a new image in world affairs. His is a minority Government that will meet its first test when Parliament assembles May 16, yet it has already generated a new air of action and decision in Ottawa.
The trial of Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re, his son, Gerard F. Re, and five other persons began in Federal Court yesterday.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 6 About 1,000 Negroes were arrested today as wave after wave of marchers chanted challenges to segregation.
Operating revenues of Dow Jones Co., Inc., have increased from $16,399,427 to $59,335,066 over the last decade, the company disclosed yesterday in releasing a preliminary prospectus.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 6 Peggyann Murphy will be confirmed tomorrow night by the Town Council as West Orange's first planning director.

"Adlai Stevenson Reports," which recently won a Peabody television award for its "contribution to international understanding," will be discontinued next fall by the American Broadcasting Company.

LOS ANGELES, May 6 Indians' consumption of the vision-producing cactus peyote is not comparable to polygamy as a religious practice subject to a legal ban, the American Civil Liberties Union contends.
HOBOKEN, N.J., May 6 Roger M. Blough, chairman of United States Steel Corporation, told stockholders of the company today that officers' salaries and directors' fees had been cut this year.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 6 Motorists crossing the Sava River Bridge to the new section of Belgrade last weekend were brought up short by a sight never seen before in the Yugoslav capital.
City school officials are investigating the possibility that a principal or teacher may have leaked the topic of a test given to some candidates for promotion in the school system.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 8 (AP) Governor Rockefeller and his bride spent the first full day of their honeymoon on Mr. Rockefeller's Monte Sacro ranch today horseback riding, pruning fruit trees and touring in a Jeep.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon is being criticized by people who think banking should be "a closed industry," according to some bankers who came to his support today.
WASHINGTON, May 6 The Air Force announced today that another attempt would be made "in the near future" to girdle the earth with a 2,000-mile-high belt of copper "needles."
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 6 The prospects for an immediate Dominican invasion of Haiti seemed to recede tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 6 The complaint of eight major steel companies against low-price imports from Japan was rejected today by the Treasury.
