The first real test last night of Telstar II, the transmission of a video tape from a ground station at Andover; Me. to Britain, France and Italy, was only partly successful. However officials of the Bell Laboratories and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said there was nothing wrong with the satellite.

MOSCOW, May 7 Lieut. Vladimir P. Sviridov, the former Soviet commander in Hungary who supervised the Communist takeover of that country after World War II, died last week in Leningrad. He was 65 years old.
BONN, May 7 Foreign Minister Gerhard Schroeder will fly to Brussels tomorrow to press a West German program for liberal development of the European Common Market.
The Government introduced its first five witnesses yesterday in the United States District Court trial of Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re and his son, Gerard F., on charges of stock fraud conspiracy.
Ten Bowery derelicts have died of wood alcohol poisoning in the last week and the toll is expected to rise, the Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, took issue yesterday with political leaders who for "the first time" are applying pressure for a cutback in expenditures for education.
A special grand jury was sworn in yesterday in the Bronx to act on evidence of fraud in highway projects in the borough.

LOS ANGELES, May 7 (UPI) Theodore Payne, internationally known horticulturist who has both a wilderness park and wildlife sanctuary in California named in his honor, died yesterday. He was 90 years old.

BURBANK, Calif., May 7 (UPI) The directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation declared today an extra cash dividend, approved a stock split and announced a dividend policy that calls for an increase in the quarterly cash dividend rate.
A few minutes before the market opened yesterday the stock ticker announced:
Baseball's top brass moved yesterday to reduce the number of balks called against National League pitchers.

Progress is the motto of the 1963 Mets. They overpowered the Phillies with first-inning homers by Charlie Neal and Frank Thomas at the Polo Grounds last night and went on to a 3-1 victory behind Alvin Jackson.
Common stock of the General Motors Corporation, gaining momentum against a generally trendless market, moved ahead yesterday to a record high of 71 1/8, gaining 1 7/8 on turnover of 81,000 shares.
"MARY was tested and she's in the 99th percentile," a young Manhattan mother told a friend recently. Hearing this news about 5-year-old Mary, her friend asked, "Are you happy or scared?"
A little bit of everything went into the Composers Concert at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The theme was music and literature, with texts from...
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing had an increase in sales and earnings in the first three months this year over those of a year ago, according to the report released today.

WASHINGTON, May 7 Gen. William H. Draper Jr., retired, who headed a study of foreign aid programs in the Eisenhower Administration, said tonight that underdeveloped nations would not be "off our backs" until their uncontrolled population growth was curbed.
Lower sales, higher unit costs and increased taxes in Chile produced lower first-quarter earnings for the Kennecott Copper Corporation than in the same period a year ago.
DETROIT, May 7 Manager Ralph Houk of the Yankees proved to be something of a prophet tonight. But it was a role in which he took no great pleasure.
School districts in the New York suburban area began their annual elections last night to determine school budgets and school board members. The elections will end tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, May 7 Miss Kate Adair Halsey and Simon Peter Marsh will be married here on the evening of June 29 in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church.
CHICAGO, May 7 (UPI) Wheat led a strong grain market advance today on the Board of Trade.
The 1964-65 World's Fair has given a Los Angeles company the concession to build a monorail, the company announced yesterday.
A 7,547-ton British freighter and a 500-ton-Dutch motorship collided one minute after sundown yesterday five miles east of Elberon, N.J., just south of Long Branch and 35 miles south of the Battery.
The Best Foods division of the Corn Products Company has named Guild, Bascom Bonfigli, Inc., to handle advertising for Bosco Milk Amplifier. Donahue Coe, Inc., had the $1,500,000 account.
Thousands of Greenwich Village residents watched last night as firemen fought a threealarm blaze that almost destroyed a seven-story loft building and damaged two adjoining buildings.
GREENFIELD PARK, N.Y., May 7 Twenty Conservative rabbis left tonight for Birmingham, Ala., in a "testimony in behalf of the human rights and dignity" of Negroes in that city.

Two legitimate playhouses will be built one on top of the other in Los Angeles by Zev Bufman and Stanley Seiden, a team of coast producers and theater operators, at a cost of $700,000. This was disclosed here yesterday by Mr. Seiden.
The Canadian dollar eased in trading on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday, following the Bank of Canada's announcement of a cut in its rediscount rate to 3 per cent from 4 per cent.
MONTEREY, Calif., May 7 (AP) Brig. Gen. Thomas Bayne Wilson of the Army Reserve died today at his home in Carmel Valley. He was 70 years old.
THE four young performers who appear in "The Un common Denominator," which is presented by the Uncommon Company, have two things in common talent and a desperate need for some uncommon material.

The burning question in Jack Cooper's office at Aqueduct yesterday was not whether Candy Spots could take Chateaugay in the Preakness but whether Royal Dale would have to run barefoot in the third race.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 Stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad were told today that the carrier would show a profit in the second quarter, but "probably not enough to entirely wipe out the first quarter deficit" of $7,900,000.
Marshaling a United States Davis Cup team is posing a problem for Capt. Robert J. Kelleher.

The decision of the House Education subcommittee to take President Kennedy's National Education Improvement Act apart and deal with its provisions piecemeal comes as no surprise. When the President first submitted his comprehensive package of school aid legislation in February, we noted that the intent of his impressive legislative blueprint may well have been that of a White Paper.
Recreation services in New York City are poorly distributed, with those most in need of facilities being the least served, according to a survey made public yesterday.
CHIRGUA, Venezuela, May 7 (UPI) Governor Rockefeller of New York and his bride opened their hilltop house to newsmen today and later rode on horseback for photographers.

WASHINGTON, May 7 The United States ordered today that dependents of its personnel in Haiti leave that country. It also offered to assist in the evacuation of other United States citizens from the island.
UNITED NATIONS, May 7 The threat of war between Haiti and the Dominican Republic will be put before the Secu rity Council tomorrow at Haiti's request.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 7 (UPI) Birmingham's city jail was so jammed with Negro racial demonstrators today it took more than four hours to serve breakfast grits and gravy, applesauce and bacon.
WASHINGTON, May 7 President Kennedy spent a pleasant half hour in the midday sunshine of the White House grounds today.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) The House Rules Committee approved today a bill to provide another series of increases in the national debt ceiling through Aug. 31.

The grand jury investigating corruption in the State Liquor Authority filed another sealed indictment yesterday. The identity of the defendant will become public when he is taken into custody, probably today.

WASHINGTON, May 8 The Organization of American States decided today to send a special mission back to Haiti with broadened instructions for averting a threatened clash between Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
TOKYO, May 8 (UPI) Communist China and the Soviet Union signed today what was called a "cooperation plan" for 1963 in an outward show of friendship between the two Communist giants.

YONKERS, May 8 There is no coughing epizootic among standardbred horses stabled at Yankers Raceway. However, Irish Napoleon, who was to have started in tomorrow night's Good Time Pace, today was scratched from the mileand-a-quarter stakes race because of a virus infection.

ROME, May 8 Leaders of the Democratic Socialist party unanimously approved tonight the "validity" of continuation of the center-left coalition government supported from outside by the Left-wing Socialists.

Convinced that he can preach more effectively as a novelist than as a clergyman because "religion is basically out of touch with people," Rabbi Herbert Tarr announced yesterday that he would leave his Long Island synagogue in July and devote himself to writing.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 8 The Project Friendship experiment at Knoxville has turned out "very well," one of its leaders reported today.
WASHINGTON, May 8 There will be no wheat legislation this year if farmers reject a tight production-control plan in a national referendum May 21, President Kennedy predicted today.

WASHINGTON, May 8 General Dynamics said today it was unwilling to build prototypes of the TFX to compete with Boeing Company prototypes, because two, or four, prototypes were not enough to make adquate tests.

The city must find ways to subsidize the "rent indigent," the person who can't pay his rent although he is otherwise self-supporting, the City Rent and Rehabilitation Administrator declared yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 8 (UPI) The enrollment of Roman Catholic students in public schools took on new life today, with demonstrations in the metropolitan areas of Kansas City and St. Louis.
A former toy company president plunged to his death yesterday morning from a window in his 15th-floor apartment at 1056 Fifth Avenue at 87th Street.
An elderly hardware clerk was arrested last night on a homicide charge as the apparent death toll from wood alcohol poisoning among Bowery derelicts rose to 31.

Pickets calling for a "General Strike for Peace" held a silent one-hour vigil in Times Square yesterday. After the vigils some of the group joined members of the War Resisters League at Columbus Circle for another demonstration shortly after noon. There were no disturbances.

Colorama Features, Inc., a film distributor, has merged with Telac, Inc., a recntly formed, international producing organization headed by Richard Arlen, the former actor, as a major film outlet in the United States.

LONDON, May 8 One of the longest, costliest and most sensational divorce actions in British legal history ended today when the 59-year-old Duke of Argyll was granted a decree against the 49-year-old Duchess.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 8 White and Negro negotiators reached a tentative agreement today on most major issues in this city's racial crisis. But serious obstacles remain to its implementation.
PALISADES PARK, N.J., May 8 The mutilated body of a 7-year-old boy who had been missing since about noon yesterday, when he left his home for school, was found today in a wooded section in Leonia.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission said today that "in fairness to the general taxpayer" it will start charging between $2 and $100 for filing broadcasting applications after Jan. 1.
A year ago Ed Kranepool was slamming long home runs at a record clip for James Monroe High School in the Bronx. Anyone remember?

ST.LOUIS, May 8 Radical and dramatic changes in the hospitalization of the mentally ill were supported today in a study showing that acutely psychotic patients could be treated on a day-hospital basis.

WASHINGTON, May 8 President Kennedy said today that Adm. George W. Anderson had agreed to accept another high post. There have been reports that the admiral was dropped as Chief of Naval Operations in a dispute with Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara.
SAVANNAH, Ga., May 8 (AP) Student leaders at Savannah State College for Negroes said today they would continue boycotting classes, despite an ultimatum from the State Board of Regents.
Good afternoon. I'm gratified to note the progress in the efforts by white and Negro citizens to end an ugly situation in Birmingham, Ala.

What may be the opening gun for new Soviet intervention in the Middle East has just been fired by the Russian Communist party. It has openly thrown its support behind the Kurds in their struggle for "autonomy," thus far confined to Iraq. It has even embraced as a potential ally the Kurd's most militant anti-Communist leader, Mullah Mustafa al-Barzani.
Record first-quarter sales and earnings were attained by Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., the report of William S. Paley, chairman, and Frank Stanton, president, disclosed yesterday.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 8 The evacuation of about 300 dependents of United States officials in Haiti began this morning in a calm atmosphere.
Mayor Wagner called last night for "a crusade" against all attempts to change the freetuition system at the City University of New York.
WASHINGTON, May 8 Several small manufacturers of steel-wire products testified today that they had to use lowpriced wire rod from abroad in order to compete with the big United States producers.

Marubeni-Iida America, Inc., a leading Japanese import and export concern, has leased the 42d floor in the new 59-story Pan Am Building, 200 Park Avenue. The lease was negotiated by Daniel L. Dayton Jr., vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the building. It involves 35,000
WASHINGTON, May 8 Several welfare myths were ex ploded today in a nationwide survey of aid to dependent children.
DREW MIDDLETON'S "The Supreme Choice: Britain and Europe,"* is a searching and exhilarant guide to the uncommon complexities of the European Economic Community.

THE nuances of logic can take beguiling twists and turns in the bizarre realm of television, but for the moment Elizabeth C. Smith, an examiner for the Federal Communications Commission, appears to have made a particularly distinctive contribution to the enticing rationalization of contemporary morality.
Plans to contest the denial of a license to a Danish movie called "A Stranger Knocks" have been announced by the Trans-Lux Film Corporation.

Investors Diversified Services, Inc., a mutual fund complex controlling more than $4,000,000,000 in assets, revealed yesterday a long-awaited plan of recapitalization. Strong opposition to the terms appeared likely.

BRUSSELS, May 8 The key decision-making body of the European Economic Community began a two-day conference here this afternoon that could have important consequences both for the future of United States foreign trade and the Common Market itself.
WHEN the wicked witch of beauty looks into her mirror, she will probably sleep easier after it tells her that Ruth McDevitt and Margaret Hamilton are the fairest of them all.

A public protest against the wages, conditions and hiring policies of the Mobilization for Youth was staged yesterday by young men it is trying to help. They picketed outside the agency's office at 214 East Second Street.
Eric J. Treulich, majority leader of the City Council, said yesterday that he did not believe that more than $20,000,000 could be cut from the city's $3,093,641,582 budget for 19631964.
Mayor Wagner and other Democratic leaders are seeking to solve some intriducate political problems to avoid primary contests in Manhattan next fall.
NEW DELHI, May 8 India has told the United States for mally through diplomatic channels that she will accept mediation or good offices by a third party in the Kashmir dispute if Pakistan also agrees.

WASHINGTON, May 8 Senator J.W. Fulbright and his supporters sought to recover the offensive today in the battle over whether $73,000,000 for Phillipine war damage should be paid to individual claimants or directly to the Philippine Government.
WASHINGTON, May 8 President Kennedy once again expressed hope today that Premier Khrushchev would use his influence to restore order in Laos.
RECENTLY some campers left a state camping site piqued after the park ranger had confessed there were no outlets on the trees they could use for their electric charcoal fire starter.

A spokesman for the Fuji Iron and Steel Company, a major Japanese steel producer, flatly denied yesterday charges by Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, that Japanese steel companies were engaged in cartel operations in this country.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 8 Southern Baptists were asked here today to empress their concern for the "2,400 of our brethren in Christ" jailed in the Birmingham, Ala., racial demonstrations.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 8 (AP) An antique dealer here said today she had sold a statue she bought for $65 to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York for $18,000.
CHICAGO, May 8 (UPI) Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg today asked lawyers to follow the lead of doctors in providing free professional services to the needy.
A MAGICAL ritual, a mirror hung before man, a gold mine for those who seek the poetical, the fanciful, the unusual this is the meaning of theater to William Tyrone Guthrie.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) The Justice Department told the Supreme Court today that the responsibility of Gov. Ross B. Barnett of Mississippi for his actions in the James H. Meredith case was the same whether he was in office or out.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 8 The National Association of Security Dealers had decided that it cannot commit itself in advance to support the proposals of the Securities and Exchange Commission to tighten policing of the securities industry.
GREENFIELD PARK, N.Y., May 8 An expert in constitutional law and two Jewish Conservative spiritual leaders sharply differed today on Federal aid to Jewish education and church-state relations.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 8 (UPI) A three-judge Federal court panel ruled today that Iowa's present legislative apportionment resulted in "invidious discrimination" and violated the equal-protection clause of the United States Constitution.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 8 Fifteen thousand Southern Baptists sang a revivalist version of "Happy Birthday" here today for one of their most illustrious brethren, former President Harry S. Truman, on his 79th birthday.
Prices of Government securities retreated yesterday in sluggish trading. Corporate issues turned dull and municipals continued in the doldrums.
A near-record performance by Mrs. Harris B. Massey's Dark King in the Youthful at Aqueduct resulted in a new pay-off record yesterday for the local thoroughbred racing season.

The New York Racing Association indicated strongly yesterday that it had every intention of putting Belmont Park back into operation within the next two years. And when it is restored to the New York racing circuit, the track will retain all of its old beauty and charm.
WASHINGTON, May 8 The Senate passed tonight a $6,069,000,000 money bill carrying extra funds its sponsors said would prevent cuts in postal service in the coming year.
A new $5,000,000 outpatient building at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center was dedicated yesterday to a woman physician, Dr. Connie M. Guion, who is still practicing at the age of 80.
Suburban school districts in the New York area held the second round of their annual elections yesterday.

"High Spirits," a musical version of Noel Coward's longrun farce, "Blithe Spirit," will bring Beatrice Lillie back to Broadway. She will return March 31, 1964, after having been absent since 1958, when she followed Greer Garson in "Auntie Mame."

A new prize, to be known as the Crock o' Cheese Trophy, will be presented to the winning coach in the triangular track and field meet on May 18 involving Fordham, New York University and St. Johns at St. John's field in Jamaica, Queens.

JACKSON, Miss., May 8 (AP) Legislative, investigators today linked the University of Mississippi desegregation riots with Kennedy political ambitions and blamed Federal planning errors and tactical blunders for the violence.
ROME, May 8 Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Primate of Poland, arrived today as reports spread that the Vatican and the Soviet Union were negotiating to improve relations

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (UPI) Willie Davis hit two home runs and a triple as the Los Angeles Dodgers clubbed St. Louis Cardinal relief pitching for six runs in the last two innings to take an 11-5 victory tonight.
Stock prices surged yesterday as volume accelerated sharply.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) President Kennedy said today that paramilitary forces the kind used to combat guerrillas might be needed in the Western Hemisphere.

BOSTON, May 8 One thing was made clear to Francis Ouimet today on his 70th birthday he is still one of the most celebrated of golf champions. Fifty years ago this summer he scored his historic victory in the United States Open at the Country Club in suburban Brookline.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) President Kennedy said today that he was confident "there will soon be a careful Congressional review of the civil defense problem."

BONN, May 8 The entrance gates to more than 1,100 metalproducing plants in BadenWurttemberg reopened today, signaling the end of a weeklong lockout in the state and possible labor peace for the rest of West Germany.
BALTIMORE, May 8 (AP) Capping a five-winner day for Wayne Chambers, Leonard P. Sasso's Serenade Menow got up in the final strides to capture the Mahubah Purse at Pimlico today.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8 Princeton undergraduates today generally supported Dr. Robert F. Goheen's strong condemnation of a riot by 1,500 students more than a third of the un dergraduate enrollment late Monday and early Tuesday.
GLASGOW, Scotland, May 8 (AP) An international soccer game between Scotland and Austria was abandoned by the referee tonight after two Austrian players had been ordered off the field.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 8 (AP) Here, in a juvenile court judge's office, many sides of the Birmingham story emerged today.

CHICAGO, May 8 Emergency food centers were opened in 32 neighborhood settlement houses here today. They will serve about 4,000 Chicago families whose relief checks have been delayed because of a state legislative deadlock on relief appropriations.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 8 Mayor Harold S. Osborne said today that the voters' 2-to-1 rejection of a proposal to fluoridate the town's water supply "very definitely settles the issue for Montclair for a good long time."

CHICAGO, May 8 (UPI) The Chicago Cubs scored four runs in the eighth inning today and defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9 5. The victory extended the Cubs' winning streak to five games, their longest since 1961.
Operating revenues and net income of the Western Union Telegraph Company rose in the quarter ended March 31, the utility reported yesterday.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes listed below in share holdings by officers, directors and controlling stockholders. These reports are based on filings made by the insiders with the Securities and Exchange Commission as required by law.

The House of Representatives has now taken a welcome step toward restricting abuses of Congressional overseas travel privileges. The institution of the "junket," with the unlimited use of Government funds and Air Force transportation, has long been a national disgrace.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., May 8 Thomas F. Patton, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, said today that further increases in labor costs could deal "a telling blow" to the steel industry's hopes of improving its competitive position through cost reduction.
Two gunmen beat and robbed a 36-year-old widow of $800 in cash and jewelry she valued at $50,000 early yesterday morning in her apartment at 40 Park Avenue.
LONDON, May 8 A Texan has scooped $1,500,000 worth of rough diamonds, mostly gems, from the coastal waters of South-West Africa in the last eight months.
WASHINGTON, May 8 President Kennedy said today that business leaders in Birmingham had pledged "substantial steps" to begin to meet "the justifiable needs of the Negro community."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 8 Young Indonesians living near the border of Sarawak have been told by the chief of staff of Indonesia's armed forces to give all possible support to rebel groups attempting to prevent the formation of Malaysia.
WASHINGTON, May 8 Officers on the strikebound nuclear ship Savannah have rejected a proposal to arbitrate their dispute.

WASHINGTON, May 8 The chairman and three members of the Federal Reserve Board took four different viewpoints today on one member's proposal to merge the Federal regulation of banks into a single new agency.

Toots Shor, the normally jovial restaurateur, was in a grim mood the other day. "The state of the restaurant business is very depressing,"' he said. "The three-drink customer is taking only two drinks and the two-drink customer is taking only one."
PARIS, May 8 A quiet but decisive change has taken place in the thinking of leaders in the movement to build a united Europe.

Manuel Veiga, a pianist born in Bahia, Brazil, came to New York in 1957 to study at the Juilliard School of Music and remained there as a teacher after having received his master's degree two years ago.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's report on the Presidency, "The White House Years," will begin with publication by Doubleday of a first volumes in November. Called "Mandate for Change," it will cover 1953-56. A concluding volume will appear in the fall of 1964.
BOSTON, Mass, May 8 The International Telephone Telegraph Corporation reported here today that the company had completed its best first quarter ever.
WASHINGTON, May 8 The President of the United States said today he cut his finger slicing bread.

WASHINGTON, May 8 Once again an Administration has put itself on the defensive, and incurred resentment in Congress, by the manner in which it transmitted a tough decision to the loser. The latest instance of a kind of Byzantine method of supplanting high...
DETROIT, May 8 The Yankees and Tigers sprayed each other with four homers apiece tonight, but it was the Bengals who got in the final word.

LONDON, May 8 The Soviet and British Governments have resumed discussions on Laos, but the outlook for effective Soviet help in restoring peaceful conditions in the Southeast Asian kingdom remains dim.

Mrs. Edmund Johnstone and Mrs. H. Donald Sills have arranged a cruise up the Hudson River the evening of May 23 to raise funds for Comeback, Inc., a national voluntary organization devoted to the social rehabilitation of the agin ailing and handicapped.
BY winning the 15th game of the 24-game world title match in Moscow in 58 moves, the challenger, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, regained the lead from his countryman Mikhail Botvinnik.

MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, May 8 The United States cited some Latin-American development failures but offered hope of wider markets for Latin-American products at an inter-American economic conference here today.
PARIS, May 8 The French attitude toward the establishment of a nuclear force in the North Atlantic Alliance will lepend on how the project is presented, responsible sources said today.

MOSCOW, May 8 Lieut. Col. Yuri A. Gagarin, the Soviet cosmonaut, has joined the chorus of critics denouncing the popular nonconformist writers Yevgeny Yevtushenko, Vasily Aksyonov and Andrei Voznesensky.
WASHINGTON, May 8 A compromise bill to create an Oregon Dunes National Seashore was advocated by the Administration today.

Educational station WNDT plans ao televise a weekly series of half-hour music programs in cooperation with the Lincoln Center for Performing Arts next fall. It also will initiate a series of hour-long experimental dramas to be presented every two or three weeks.
WASHINGTON, May 8 President Kennedy warned today against any aggression in the Middle East. He said the United States supported the security of both Israel and her Arab neighbors.

ALGIERS, May 8 President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic left today after a five-day visit. Although he had received a warm welcome, he achieved no shift in Algeria's cautious attitude toward membership in his new Arab union.

ROME, May 8 (UPI) Judy Alvarez of Tampa, Fla., the 10th-ranked United States women's tennis player, sprang the first major upset of the Italian international championships today by defeating seventh-seeded Renee Schuurman of South Africa, 1 6, 10 8, 6 2, in the second round.

HE WALKED in off the street in 1948 to apply for a job, uninvited and unknown. It was to become the start of a warmly sentimental relationship between Emlen Tunnell and the New York Football Giants. This love affair reached a new plateau the other day. The Giants embraced their one-time-defensive wizard with another display of affection by naming him as assistant coach.
The Bureau of Customs announced yesterday that it had switched from wholesale value to full retail value minus 40 per cent in assessing duty on tourist purchases made abroad.
A surprise bid from a "maverick" investment house apparently won the $122,000,000 Washington Public Power Supply System bond issue yesterday.
A concert of contemporary Israeli and Latin-American music was presented at Judson Hall last night under the sponsorship of the Israel-Iberoamerica Institute.
EXPERT bridge players get tired of bridge occasionally, as almost anyone would who plays the game so often, and periodically they turn to other diversions in their bridge clubs.
WASHINGTON, May 8 The muddled international air-fare situation drew a sharp comment today on the Senate floor by Warren G. Magnuson, Washington Democrat.
Mayor Wagner was asked yesterday to kill a Park Department plan to allow the construction of a commercial golfdriving range in Kissena Park.
The director general of the International Air Transport Association offered yesterday to call a conference on the fare situation.
LOS ANGELES, May 8 Miss Helen S. Coman and John Clark Gower will be married Aug. 31 in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) William J. Tobin, vice president of the Chicago Black Hawks National Hockey League club, died today. He would have been 68 years old on May 20.

City Hall was the focal point of a number of rallies and meetings here yesterday to protest the actions of officials in Birm ingham, Ala., in dealing with desegregation demonstrations by Negroes.

Sugar and cocoa futures advanced yesterday in active trading. Most other New York commodities rose in quiet dealings. The other advances were registered by copper, lead, zinc, hides, coffee, wool (uncombed) and wool tops. Rubber, potatoes and cottonseed oil declined.
Stanley Osserman, former board chairman of Dictograph Products, Inc., died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 180 East End Avenue and in East Hampton, L.I.

As the Governor of Alabama and on behalf of the citizens of Birmingham, I reject President Kennedy's statement which in substance says the people of Birmingham have inflicted abuses on the Nebroes and that this should come to a stop.

LISBON, May 8 Progress reportedly was made here today in talks by Britain and several of her partners in the European Free Traffic Association on issues, that could deeply affect the fate of the association.
MIAMI BEACH, May 8 Quality in architecture was described here today as an expression of a society's material wealth as well as its spiritual, social, technical and moral aspects.
Judge Jed Johnson of the United States Customs Court died of a heart attack yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital. He lived at 2 Fifth Avenue, and was 74 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) Republican after Republican rose in the Senate today to charge that President Kennedy's policies had caused "a great leap backward" in United States prestige abroad.
