Supporters of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children will meet at the Astor May 18 for the 14th annual dinner dance in behalf of its New York Chapter.
A decline of 2,724,000, barrels in the country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 8 Anita Woods said today: "My mother told, me I had to serve my time."
The Presbyterian minister who officiated at the marriage of Governor Rockefeller last Saturday was criticized yesterday by an official of his church and now faces disciplinary action.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 8 What a delightful variation on the popular American theme of civic boosting! The Minneapolis Chamber of Commerce invites you to share its pride in "Hamlet."

The Maritime Administration's chief promised the depressed steamship industry yesterday that the agency would shortly begin a nationwide drive to generate more business for United States-flag cargo and passenger ships.
A 38-year-old father of five children was hailed yesterday as the nation's most heroic taxicab driver of 1962.
The Presbyterian minister who officiated at the marriage of Governor Rockefeller last Saturday was criticized yesterday by an official of his church and now faces disciplinary action.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 8 What a delightful variation on the popular American theme of civic boosting! The Minneapolis Chamber of Commerce invites you to share its pride in "Hamlet."

The Maritime Administration's chief promised the depressed steamship industry yesterday that the agency would shortly begin a nationwide drive to generate more business for United States-flag cargo and passenger ships.

WASHINGTON, May 8 The House passed a $1,200,000,000 military pay raise bill today. It would grant the nation's servicemen their first salary increases in five years. The average raise would be 12.6 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8 Students from 16 New Jersey secondary schools opened the second annual high school performing arts festival in McCarter Theater today with a program that included excerpts from plays and musicals and choir singing.
MILWAUKEE, May 8 (AP) The San Francisco Giants capitalized on five hits and a sloppy Milwaukee defense for seven runs in the fourth inning tonight and breezed to a 12-5 victory over the Braves.

Gen. Lauris Norstad proposed last night that control of nuclear forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization be entrusted to a majority vote of the heads of government of the United States, Britain and France.
The loss of newsprint tonnage resulting from the New York and Cleveland newspaper strikes was one of the factors that adversely affected first-quarter earnings of the International Paper Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 8 Haiti accused the Dominican Republic before the Security Council today of threatening the peace of the Caribbean.

The weakness of the telemetry signals from the second communications satellite, Telstar II, was corrected yesterday. Last night video tapes in color and in black and white were transmitted to Europe with good results.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8 (AP) A young music teacher was found strangled tonight in her apartment just off Harvard Square, confronting the police of the Boston metropolitan area with the ninth such unsolved slaying in the last 11 months.

WASHINGTON, May 8 What ever happened in Laos? Oh, the answer is here somewhere, all right, in these mounds of back newspapers and magazines, but who dares pause to look it up? The world is moving on to fresh crises in new jungles, and he who lingers over Pathet Lao today will be in the dark about Tonton Macoutes tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 8 There are signs of improved relations between Roman Catholics and some leaders of the Planned Parenthood Federation.
A 38-year-old father of five children was hailed yesterday as the nation's most heroic taxicab driver of 1962.
WASHINGTON, May 8 Nearly 50 years ago, a little boy asked his mother plaintively, "Doesn't a Cabinet lady ever have a day off?"
The 1,000-deadweight-ton Dutch freighter Pinta is lying in 78 feet of water 6 miles northeast of Asbury Park, N.J., and is not a hazard to navigation, the Coast Guard said here yesterday.

The 18th game of the 24game match for the world's chess title in Moscow between the champion, Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union, and his countryman Tigran Petrosian was adjourned yesterday after 40 moves, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 8 The tempo of the Negro pupils' sit-ins at the nearly allwhite Cleveland School increased today when 26 Negro children went to classes there.
WASHINGTON, May 8 President Kennedy enthusiastically endorsed today India's request for $512,000,000 to help build a steel mill at Bokaro.
Roger M. Blough, chairman of the board of trustees of the United States Steel Foundation, announced a $2,480,000 program of aid to education yesterday.

MOSCOW, May 8 Oleg V. Penkovsky, a former Soviet science official who is the central figure in a spy trial here, was portrayed today as an aggressive agents who had been friendly with members of the Soviet Government.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) Don Lock's grand-slam home run capped a five-run uprising in the last of the 13th inning that gave the Washington Senators a 6-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
The original manuscipt of Joseph Conrad's novel "Victory" has been auctioned for $21,000, a record for a modern manuscript at a public sale.
Mayor Wagner was honored last night fore his "major role in restoring newspaper publication to New York City in 1963 and for his efforts to keep alive the kind of dialogues that make democracy work."

There are extraordinary implications in the current Moscow spy trial. The arrest of Oleg Penkovsky last October seems to have marked the end of one of the most successful coups in the history of Western intelligence activities. If Mr. Penkovsky's confession is credited, the United States and Great Britain were able...
CHICAGO, May 8 (UPI) Near May wheat led other wheat contracts down today and most other grain futures ended mixed on the Board of Trade.

NEW YORKERS, in all probability, consume more corned beef than the residents of any other city. Lean or fat, cold or hot, garlic-tinged or naturally mild, corned beef is a dish that seems to appeal, on occasion, to almost all strata of the city's population.

A professor, professing more "political realism" than the politicians in Washington, predicted yesterday that the Administration's tax and spending programs "would more or less normalize a yearly deficit" of $10,000,000,000 in the Federal budget.

How healthy is the market? One way to find out is to measure the price-earnings ratios. Wright Investors Service reports that the ratio for all Big Board common stocks now averages 18 to 1, compared with 22 to 1 a year ago, a few weeks before the sharp break.
MOSCOW, May 8 The current espionage trial in Moscow points up again the secrecyshrouded character of Soviet society.

A witness testified yesterday in United States District Court that Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re had both offered and demanded bribe payments in common stock. Mr. Re, 66 years old, and his son, Gerard F., 40, are being tried on an eight-count grand jury indictment of stock fraud conspiracy in the 1954-60 period.

Major league clubs began paring their rosters yesterday to get down to the 25-player limit required by noon today. Normally, the cutdown deadline would have been midnight yesterday, but because of baseball's expansion to the West Coast and the various time zones across the nation, Commissioner Ford C. Frick extend the deadline 12 hours.

WASHINGTON, May 8 Foreign Aid Administrator David E. Bell took issue today with Gen. Lucius D. Clay's estimate that no more than $4,000,000,000, was needed for foreign assistance programs in the year ahead.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 8--The special committee on South Africa's apartheid policies has called on the Security Council to re-examine the situation and "take immediate and effective steps to halt the dangerous drift of events in South Africa."

GREENS FARMS, Conn., May 8 Frederick T. Bedford, chairman of Penick Ford, Ltd., Inc., of New York, and a yachtsman for many years, died yesterday at his home here following a brief illness. He was 85 years old.

First-quarter net income of the operating companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group rose to 50,154,000 or the equivalent of $140,431,000, it was announced here yesterday. This is an increase of 4.7 per cent over the 47,917,000, or $134,168,000, earned in the 1962 period.
PARIS, May 9 Edouard Corniglion-Molinier, a military and political leader in France, died here today of a heart ailment. He was 63 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 9 President Kennedy was challenged publicly today by one of his predecessor's economic advisers to explain why Government spending could not be held to present levels.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 9 (AP) The Jaclyn Stable's Ahoy was injured today and trainer J. Bowes Bond said the 3-year-old colt would not run either in Saturday's $50,000 Withers at Aqueduct or the $150,000 Preakness May 18.
In any other neighborhood in New York, the death of more than 30 residents from drinking poison would have aroused tension and grief, but there were no mourners on the Bowery yesterday.
POOLE, England, May 9 (AP) W.L. Stephenson, former chairman of the Woolworth organization in Britain, died today. He was 83 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 9 Haiti and the Dominican Republic agreed today in the Security Council to let the Organization of American States continue to deal with their dispute.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 9 President Kennedy's statement yesterday of United States policy on the Middle East was welcomed here today as a step in the right direction toward assuring stability in the region.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 9 (AP) A prediction of rising business activity, carrying 1963 production to a record total of about $585,000,000,000, was brought today to the spring meeting of the Business Council.
MOSCOW, May 9 The Soviet Union adopted a sharper tone today in propaganda attacks on the United States.
MOORED on the west coast of beautiful Lake Como in Italy, a houseboat that was formerly an old sand barge serves as a weekend, holiday and vacation home.
Theodore C. Sorensen. special counsel to President Kennedy, gave his version last night of the "inside story" of the Administration's handling of the Cuban crisis last October.

ST. LOUIS, May 9 (UPI) Roman Catholic parents and children, 500 strong and joking and singing along the way, marched to public schools in the suburb of Florissant today in protest against Missouri's school bus laws.
WASHINGTON, May 9 James R. Hoffa, president of the teamsters union, was charged today with trying corruptly to influence a jury that tried him last fall. He was
Julia Richman High School, one of the city's largest girl's schools, whose alumnae include actresses, poets, lawyers and just plain housewives, celebrated its 50th anniversary last night.

Gil Hodges, the Mets' elder statesman, and Marvelous Marv Throneberry, their symbol of haplessness, figured in complicated transactions yesterday as the New York club along with the other 19 major league teams cut their roster to the legal limit of 25 players.

SHOPPERS will have no difficulty finding a roast, steak or chops for this weekend's menus despite the strike of wholesale meat cutters now in its second week. Retail shops have not been markedly affected by the strike and offer a wide variety of cuts, especially of beef, at attractive prices.

CHICAGO, May 9?The Yankees made a snappy detour tonight on their way from Detroit to Baltimore to engage the White Sox in the playoff of an earlier postponement. But in almost no time at all they were fervently wishing they had lost themselves en route.
More than 100 cases of a Spanish brandy containing poisonous wood alcohol have arrived in the New York area, the Federal Food and Drug Administration said last night.

Bowery deaths from wood alcohol poisoning mounted to 35 yesterday, 29 other derelicts were in hospitals most of them in critical condition and last night five more suspected cases were found at the Men's Shelter, 8 East Third Street.
WASHINGTON, May 9 "You have to be a free man to be a great artist," President Kennedy said today at the dedication of a marker at the grave of Ignace Jan Paderewski, the pianist and statesman.
A membership on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $199,000 and this price level reflects the professional Wall Streeter's current sentiment on the stock market.

The Kennedy Administration was urged yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers to take prompt action to limit wool textile imports. The association represents mills producing about 70 per cent of the textiles made in the United States.

Stockholder dissatisfaction with the $100,000-a-year salary paid A. M. Sonnabend, the 66year-old president of the Hotel Corporation of America, enlivened the company's annual meeting yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

BALTIMORE, May 9 (UPI) Stu Miller relieved in the eighth inning tonight after John Tillman had opened with a double, and turned back the Boston Red Sox to preserve a three-hit, 4-1 victory for Chuck Estrada and the Baltimore Orioles.

FORT WORTH, May 9 (UPI) Doug Sanders, chipping almost to perfection and making the most of a new club he calls "the monster," shot a threeunder-par 34, 33 67 today for the first-round lead in the $60,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, May 9 The South Vietnamese Government has agreed to budget and pay the cost of operating its strategic-hamlet program, the backbone of its war against the Communist Vietcong guerrillas.

SOME of this country's greatest gamblers are not, as one might think, in Reno or on Wall Street. According to Bernard Roshco, they are concentrated in an 18-block area bounded on the east by the Avenue of the Americas, on the west by Eighth Avenue, and on the south and north by, roughly, 35th and 40th Streets.
CHICAGO, May 9 (UPI) Grain futures rallied sharply in late buying today on the Board of Trade, and new crop soybeans and corn established seasonal highs.
ROME, May 9 (AP) Reports that Pope John XXIII has cancer revived today as his health continued to cause concern at the Vatican.
LONDON, May 9 (UPI) The Communist press throughout Europe attacked the United States today for racial troubles in Birmingham, Ala.
A 45-foot column swung into place in a deep excavation at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts yesterday morning, signaling the start of steel construction on the new Metropolitan Opera House.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, May 9 The British Navy frigate Whirlwind with about 200 officers and men arrived here today to assist in maintaining essential services as a 20-day general strike continued.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 9 Negotiators reached full agreement tonight on terms for settling this city's racial crisis after Negroes had scaled down their demands.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 9 American business and industry has forgotten that they are partners in the country's Merchant Marine, and the Maritime Administration has embarked on a memoryjogging campaign.
WASHINGTON, May 9 The House voted today to let the Secretary of Defense dismiss employes of the National Security Agency without explanation or appeal if he decides they are security risks.
MOSCOW, May 9 The first full account of the capture of the Reichstag by Soviet forces in embattled Berlin 18 years ago was published here today.

LEONARD BERNSTEIN and the New York Phil harmonic saluted spring for the second successive week last night at Philharmonic Hall. This time the conductor's three assistants got a chance to join in the salute.
WASHINGTON, May 9 Seamen who lost out in the Supreme Court's "flags of convenience" decision earlier this year are using the court's ruling as ammunition against the National Labor Relations Board.
CHICAGO, May 9 Julius Monk's elegant cabaret, rich with red Edwardian decor, formally opened tonight with, a sparkling 26-skit, 2-act musical, "Struts and Frets."
WASHINGTON, May 9 The Senate Preparedness subcommittee reported today that at least 17,500 Russians, including 5,000 combat troops, were still in Cuba.
LONDON, May 9 (UPI) M.E. Clifton, James, an actor whose greatest role was the impersonation of Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery in world War II, died here yesterday. He was 65 years old.

Greenwich Village will have two more cozy playhouses, one on top of the other, at 152 Bleecker Street. They are being constructed by Dan Stampler, proprietor of the nearby Steak Joint, a restaurant at 58 Greenwich Avenue, and the landlord of 150, 152 and 154 Bleecker Street.
BUDAPEST, May 9 (AP) A United States diplomat and a medical adviser met today with Foreign Ministry officials for talks believed to deal with Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty.

WASHINGTON, May 9 The Government of Haiti was understood to have notified the Organization of American States today that it would bar the return of an O.A.S. factfinding commission to Port-auPrince, the Haitian capital.
TRENTON, May 9 Gov. Richard J. Hughes and Senator Clifford P. Case called on the Legislature today to reject two controversial proposed amendments to the Federal Constitution.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) A demand for Federal intervention in Birmingham and statements that President Kennedy has the power now to end racial disturbances there were expressed at civil rights hearings today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 The law firm to which Roswell Gilpatric belonged before he became Deputy Defense Secretary received $126,000 in fees from the General Dynamics Corporation between 1958 and 1961, the Senate committee investigating the TFX plane contract has been told.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 9 State Assemblyman Perry B. Duryea Jr. of Montauk is to be named the new president of the Long Island State Park Commission early next week, it was learned today.
The Insurance Company of North-America has leased five floors in the 29-story office building being erected by Sam Minskoff Sons at 250 Broadway, facing City Hall Park.

YONKERS, May 9--Little George Sholty was tall in the sulky behind Royal Rick to- night. The 5-foot-2-inch reinsman from Logansport, Ind., made nary a mistake as he guided the 7-year-old to a 1 -length victory over Henry T. Adios in the Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway before 26,100 fans.
WASHINGTON, May 9 President Kennedy and Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson will fly tomorrow to Hyannis Port, Mass., for two days of talks that are expected to ease United States-Canadian relations.
WASHINGTON May 9 Seagoing engineers, caught in a strange labor dispute on the nuclear ship Savannah, believe she should be taken out of commercial hands and operated by the Government.

MIAMI BEACH, May 9 The architects of the United States cannot escape responsibility for the "sheer ugliness of our country," according to J. Roy Carroll Jr. of Philadelphia who was elected president of the American Institute of Architects today.

FIFTY-SEVEN years ago a spinster loved her mother so much that she started a nationwide campaign of affection. She lived to regret it. When Anna Jarvis died in 1948, she recognized, bitterly, that Mother's Day had become an outstanding example of a sentimental idea exploited for purely commercial objectives.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 9 On a hot summer day, a distressed United Nations diplomat complained that his sleep was disturbed by a loose manhole cover, On another occasion, a newly arrived African delegate appealed for help in settling his 10 French-speaking youngsters in public schools.

The book publishing industry has been trying to avoid serious disruption in spring and fall lists by changing plans to cope with a strike of almost two months at Kingsport Press. The Tennessee book manufacturing plant is one of the largest in the United States.

THE three greatest Florentines, according to Marchese Roberto Ridolfi, were Dante, Michelangelo and Machiavelli. Probably few scholars would seriously dispute this verdict; but for several hundred years many scholars have furiously disputed the meaning of Machiavelli's writings and the nature of the motives that inspired them.
CHICAGO, May 9 (UPI) Dick Ellsworth held the Pitts burgh Pirates to two hits today in hurling the Chicago Cubs to a 3-1 victory to run their winning streak to six games.
PARIS, May 9 Tennessee Williams is the only one billed in the current Paris production of "The Glass Menagerie." No mention is made of actors or director. No one is credited with sets or costumes.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 9 (UPI) Dick Gregory, Negro comedian, was released from jail on bond today and immediately charged that he had been "whipped by five policemen using billy clubs, hammers and sawed-off pool sticks."
The city's Labor Department has called on the academic community to help it solve problems of poverty and unemployment.
Until recently a person with Less than five years of schooling was considered a functional illiterate, but the level has been raised to eight years, a Federal official said yesterday.

THE Bankers Bridge League, the largest and one of the oldest of the commercial leagues in New York, ended its season last month with a victory for the Jersey Standard Club the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Humble Oil and Refining Company.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 9 Thirty-two Negro children entered the nearly all-white Cleveland School today as "unauthorized visitors." This was an increase of six over yesterday's total.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 9 The chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission said here today that his agency was ready to consider any "adequate" international means for the regulation of common carriers in international trade.

WASHINGTON, May 9 President Kennedy has adopted a cautious strategy in the Birmingham conflict. He has rejected the provocations of the extremists there and here and bet everything on arousing the moderates in Alabama.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 9 Finance Minister Francisco San Tiago Dantas predicted today that an International Monetary Fund mission would be favorably impressed by Brazil's anti-inflation program.

WASHINGTON, May 9 For the last week the burden of preventing more serious violence in Birmingham and of starting long-term improvement in race relations there has rested largely on the slim shoulders of the Justice Department's Civil rights chief, Burke Marshall.

ST. LOUIS, May 9 Organized right-wing attacks against the mental health movement and psychiatry are jeopardizing the gains made in public understanding in recent years, a psychiatrist warned here today.
After nine weeks of stability, the Treasury's gold stock declined this week by $50,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

A New York broker received a kickback of $12,315 from Lowell M. Birrell, fugitive financier, for selling 22,000 common shares of the Swan-Finch Oil Corporation in 1956, according to testimony yesterday in Federal District Court.
ALBANY, May 9 The Court of Appeals held in a 6-to-1 decision today that a Rye city ordinance curbing the indiscriminate use of clotheslines was a valid exercise of police power.

Aluminium, Ltd., international, aluminum concern, reported yesterday a drop in consolidated net income for the first quarter to $7,300,000, or 23 cents a share, from $8,100,000, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier.

Serge Ughet, the last financial attache and charge d'affaires in Washington of the Russian Imperial and Provisional Governments, died yesterday at a nursing home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 78 years old and lived at 48 Little Worth Lane in Sea Cliff, L.I.
Twenty-one suburban school districts in the New York metropolitan area rejected proposed school budgets in two days of voting that ended early yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 9 After the rigors of an opening night "Hamlet" that ran for more than four hours, the Tyrone Guthrie Theater unbent last night with a broadly stylized production of "The Miser."

Another dazzling chapter in the joyful saga of the miraculous Mets was written at the Polo Grounds yesterday. They scored three runs in the ninth inning for a 3-2 victory that completed a three-game sweep of the unbelieving Phils and gave them their second fourgame winning streak of the season.

B0B PURKEY stepped on the mound for the cincinnati Reds the other night and pitched a strong game for five and a fraction innings. Since the crafty right hander had been the leading percentage pitcher in the league last year with a 23-and-5 record, this stint may not seem to have any striking significance. But it has.
CHICAGO, May 9 Adlai E. Stevenson declared here tonight that spurious patriots were striving to silence responsible criticism in this country by equating it with treachery and treason.
Sugar futures soared yesterday leading most commodities higher in New York in active trading.
Youngsters who have passed full high-school driver education courses have fewer accidents and traffic violations than untrained young drivers, the Motor Vehicle Department reported yesterday.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.; May 9 (UPI) Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. went through a fullscale review today of Tuesday's space flight that is to take him 22 times around the world.

In the face of rising clamor for more forceful American intervention in the Middle East, President Kennedy is pursuing a course that comports with peace and therefore with the true interests of all concerned, including the United States.

Few state-operated pension funds have turned attention to common stock. Instead, they concentrate on municipal bonds and Government issues. About two years ago, New Jersey's Public Employes Retirement System became an inconoclast when it began to acquire common stocks after passage of a more liberal state investment law.

Tax Commissioner Mortimer M. Caplin dined Wednesday evening at the Roosevelt Hotel here and his comment that the meal was neither "lavish nor extravagant" undoubtedly pleased the management even if it may have slighted the chef. The tab (with drinks) totaled $12.50.
GREENFIELD PARK, N.Y., May 9 A rabbi described today a project that he hopes will stimulate "greater acts of righteous behavior."
WASHINGTON, May 9 The Senate Agriculture Committee approved without change today a House-approved feed-grain bill. The vote was 11 to 6.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Friday, May l0 A crowd of unruly students from Brown University invaded the downtown area last night, but were forced back to their campus early today by the police.

CANNES, France, May 9 The noncompetitive gala showing of an American film, Alfred Hitchcock's "The Birds" and the social events related to it got the 16th Cannes Film Festival off to a lively start tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 9 White House officials expressed concern, today that Congress had not provided penalties to back up its ban against the payment of fees to agents of Philippine war damage claimants.

Mounting evidence that cancer is linked to the hereditary material of the cell was said yesterday to contraindicate the possibility of curing the disease with drugs or by manipulating the body's immunological mechanisms.
Federal Judge Alexander Bicks of the Southern District of New York died yesterday in University Hospital at the age of 62. He lived at 965 Fifth Avenue.
LIKE good wine, Federal dredging projects can't be rushed.
The Tri-State Transportation Committee announced yesterday that it was seeking Federal funds to test a coordinated train-bus service for speeding travel between Manhattan and Idlewild Airport.

The deeper implications of the racial conflict in Birmingham must be faced. An episode of this nature cannot be isolated. It is the result of historic forces and social conflicts that are uniquely American and that demand solution.

Net loss of Pan American World Airways, Inc. was reduced to $2,218,000 after tax credits in the first three months this year from $4,651,000 a year ago, reflecting improved earnings in its Pacific and Latin American areas.
A theatrical agent to whom a grand jury had granted immunity in order to get his testimony about bribery in the State Liquor Authority was arrested yesterday on a charge of having lied to the jurors.
Mayor Wagner will proclaim "Armed Forces Week" at noon today at City Hall, inaugurating the 14th annual celebration honoring men and women in the military services.
Many European stock exchanges reacted favorably yesterday to Wednesday's rally on Wall Street.
Jack Nicklaus is among 2,410 golfers whose entires were accepted yesterday for the 1963 United States Open golf championship, which will be played... June 20-22 at The Country Club, Brookline, Mass.
LONDON, May 9 An English rector startled the Convocation of Canterbury today by asking that he not be required to read "spiritual junk" and "poison" from the Old Testament to his congration.
Demonstrators demanded here yesterday that the Federal Government and the United Nations intervene in the racial crisis in Birmingham, Ala.

With Ray Woolfe riding competently, Kantikoy won the Spring steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday in record time. Remaining in second place through the early stages of the two-mile event, Kantioy showed excellent closing power to score by 1 lengths over Exhibit A.
Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, the chief executive officer of the United Presbyterian Church, yesterday deplored the "excitement" of clergymen over Governor Rockefeller's remarriage.

TEANECK, N.J., May 9 The Board of Education last night adopted a new open-enrollment plan aimed at offsetting a racial imbalance that is developing in the Bryant Elementary School, which is 46 per cent Negro.
The Government securities market eased further yesterday in quiet trading. Municipals and high-grade corporates were steady in inactive sessions.
HOLLYWOOD, May 9 A major Hollywood studio has taken an important step to stimulate local movie production.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 8 The Government is intensifying its efforts to catch Clement Barbot, the elusive would-be assassin and one-time bodyguard of President Francois Duvalier.
WASHINGTON, May 9 Malcolm X arrived today to take over the leadership of the Black Muslim movement in the capital, where race relations have been causing anxiety.

The majority leader of the City Council said yesterday that he would ask an inquiry into Consolidated Edison's proposal to build a nuclear-powered electric generating plant in Long Island City, Queens.
WHITE PLAINS, May 9 The annual charity ball for the benefit of the building fund of the White Plains Hospital, will be held at Schrafft's Country Restaurant in Eastchester May 18.

LISBON, May 9 The seven Countries of the European Free Trade: Association plowed through a long series of diffi cult technical, problems today in an effort to reach agreement on achieving internal free trade by 1966, four years ahead of their original schedule.

WASHINGTON, May 9 In his temperate comments at his news conference yesterday on the coercive mass anti-segregation protests in the streets of Birmingham, the President said that "the best remedy in this case and other cases...is to, in time, take steps to provide equal treatment to all our citizens."

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Dr. Harold F. Dorn, whose studies in 1959 led to the Public Health Service's search for links between lung cancer and smoking, died at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. He was 56 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Dr. Harold F. Dorn, whose studies in 1959 led to the Public Health Service's search for links between lung cancer and smoking, died at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. He was 56 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

There is a growing debate on Madison Avenue about the pirating of advertising campaigns. Two major agencies, for example, are exchanging charges that each is stealing the other's ideas. One agency president recently threatened to bring suit against another agency on piratine charges.

ONE index to the mounting numbers of new converts to fishing is the number of telephone calls and letters that come in asking for advice. Giving directions is a tricky business. If the angler follows them and catches nothing his next communique is likely to be plaintive at the least and colorful at the most.

If the "All Flags Flying" fair next Wednesday is a success, and there is no reason to believe it will not be, there will be quite a few teen-agers in private schools around town entitled to take bows.
LONDON, May 9 Sir Charles Brooke, the Raja of Sarawak from 1917 to 1946, died here today after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

WEBSTER, N.Y., May 9 Manufacturers of dry office copying equipment were put on notice here today that the Xerox Corporation's licensing agreement with the American Photocopy Equipment Company was considered a precedent.
WASHINGTON, May 9 Rail loadings increased six-tenths of 1 per cent last week from the level in the comparable 1962 period, while truck loadings fell 1 per cent.
A place of meditation for 1964-65 World's Fair visitors is likely to be provided, Robert Moses, president of the fair, indicated yesterday.

LONDON, May 9--A basic shift in United States planning to deal with any outbreak of hostilities in Europe is in prospect following recent conversations here between Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and British leaders.
MILWAUKEE, May 9 (UPI) Ed Bailey and Felipe Alou droye in three runs each to spark the San Francisco Giants to an 8-2 victory today over the Milwaukee Braves.

A $10,000 Cadillac belonging to Roy M. Cohn was seized by the city sheriff for auction last Monday. The former counsel to the late Senator Joseph, R. McCarthy's investigations said he didn't miss the car until yesterday.
Stock prices churned upward yesterday in one of the most active trading sessions of the year.

Approximately 30 international airlines will begin an emergency meeting in Bermuda next Thursday in an effort to resolve the fares impasse on North Atlantic and Pacific routes, reliable informants said yesterday.
VAN WYCK BROOKS died in his home in Bridge water, Conn., May 2, 1963, at. the age of 77.
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute announced yesterday a major revision in its engineering program.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Republicans whooped it up tonight for Senator Barry Goldwater and attacked the Kennedy Administration as a slowpoke regime.

Approximately 30 international airlines will begin an emergency meeting in Bermuda next Thursday in an effort to resolve the fares impasse on North Atlantic and Pacific routes, reliable informants said yesterday.
VAN WYCK BROOKS died in his home in Bridge water, Conn., May 2, 1963, at. the age of 77.

HONG KONG, Friday, May 10 Communist China has notified the Soviet Union that a high-level party delegation will be sent to Moscow to discuss the deep-seated ideological differences between the two Governments.
MOSCOW, May 9 The Soviet Union's drive against private investock holdings was given new impetus today with the adoption of two decrees.
LONDON, May 9 "Changes have taken place in the last 10 years, changes are now taking place and changes will continue to take place which would never have been dreamt of by our predecessors."

Decision was reserved yesterday by the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in the appeal of the Securities and Exchange Commission against a District Court decision to permit Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., to remain under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 9 (AP) Prince Souvanna Phouma, the neutralist Premier of Laos, said today an international peace team would remain on the Plaine des Jarres despite a leftist demand that it be withdrawn.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., May 10--President Kennedy and Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson of Canada discussed joint defense problems today and there were strong indications that an understanding had been reached on the touchy question of nuclear weapons on Canadian soil.
BALTIMORE, May 10--Gene "Big Daddy" Lipscomb, the National Football League star, died today, apparently after an overdose of drugs.
THE deal shown today, played at rubber bridge at the Cavendish Club last week, may have produced the year's highest score resulting from a contract that was not redoubled. The total was 2,900 points.

THOSE who have yet to find an appropriate gift for Mother's Day might take a look at the Mexican accessories that have just arrived at Pampered Kitchens, on the 18th floor at 220 Fifth Avenue (26th Street). Particularly charming is the tin basket that has a simple hammered floral and
AMITYVILLE, L.I., May 10 --The Long Island Rail Road plans to initiate a 91-mile bus service along the South Shore between Amityville and Montauk early next month.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., received a patent this week for an improved system for controlling the attitude, or orientation, of satellies.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., May 10 --The state forester came down from Hartford today to try to settle a dispute over 13 shade trees.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 10 --As shifting and gusty winds sent scores soaring, two golfers tied for the medal in the 53d Walter J. Travis memorial tournament today.
ROME, May 10 (AP)--Topseeded Roy Emerson of Australia breezed into the quarterfinals of the men's singles in the Italian tennis tournament today but four other seeded players were eliminated.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 10 --Tensions mounted in Laos today as both neutralists and proCommunists refused to take steps to break the impasse that halted their cease-fire talks a week ago.
MOSCOW, May 10--The Soviet Union's leading geologist suggested today that Soviet claims that it leads the world in many strategic raw materials were exaggerated.

WIENER NEUSTADT, Austria, May 10--Franziskus Cardinal Konig, Archbishop of Vienna, took up a busy vigil here today to see whether his first personal mission to Communist East Europe had led to a settlement of the Mindszenty case.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)--Under Congressional prodding, the Pentagon has eased restrictions on information about Soviet satellite launchings. But it has virtually ruled out release to the public of the story of Soviet space failures.
A plan initially favored by the Controller of the Currency, to form an association of national banks, appears to be dead, at least temporarily if not permanently.

MANY a business partnership is formed over the luncheon table, but not as many are likely to be made in elevators. Two young designers, who are in business together today, formed their original business pact in this unorthodox manner.
BALTIMORE, May 10--Not even the inspiring presence of Whitey Ford could check the astounding descent of the Yankees tonight as Ralph Houk's Bombers plunged to their fourth straight defeat.
Four unusual species of warblers have been reported sighted in the city, three in the Ramble in Central Park and a fourth in the New York Botanical Garden, the Bronx.
The Medical Examiner's office yesterday attributed the deaths of four more derelicts to wood alcohol poisoning. The total in the current outbreak thus rose to 39.

LONDON, May 10--Britain charged tonight that the Geneva agreements on Laos were being "persistently and plainly frustrated" by the pro-Communists there. The charge was made by the Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)--Adm. George W. Anderson, Chief of Naval Operations, asked all hands in the Navy today to stop speculating about why he had not been appointed to a second term.

A race that is older than they Kentucky Derby will be run today at Aqueduct with a field of 16 horses contesting in the Withers Stakes. First held in 1874, the Withers will be contested for the 88th time. The Derby had its first running in 1875.
Cardinal Spellman will ordain a young Indian seminarian to the Roman Catholic priesthood at 9 A.M. today in the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and 60th Street.
A relatively light calendar of competitive sales of fixed-interest securities faces the capital market next week.

HONG KONG May 10--A day after announcing that a highlevel mission would go to the Soviet Union, Communist China issued today another scathing attack on policies in Moscow that have split the two biggest Communist states.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- A $1,195,000,000 college-aid bill moved toward the House floor today with bipartisan support. It was approved, 25 to 5, by the Education and Labor Committee.
The Broadway debut of "The Beast in Me," the revue based on James Thurber's "Fables for Our Time," has been delayed from next Tuesday to Thursday at the Plymouth Theater.

Young people looking for jobs this summer will be fighting a powerful array of obstructions --automation, the population increase, a greater demand for skills and the relatively new practice of encouraging winter vacations for regular employes.
MOSCOW, May 10--The Soviet prosecution demanded today the death sentence for Oleg V. Penkovsky, the Russian scientific official on trial for espionage on behalf of Britain and the United States.

Salling sentiment on the London market, generated by the heavy losses takenby the Conservative party in local elections, was partly offset yesterday by an optimistic economic forecast by the National Institute of Economic and Social Research and by the end of a railload strike threat.

Awards for outstanding work by students in the film departments of New York University, City College and Columbia University will be presented on May 27 in the auditorium of the Casa Italiana on the Columbia campus. The program,

LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP)--Don Drysdale, who hadn't won in nearly a month, pitched a six-hitter tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the San Francisco Giants, 2--1, in the first meeting of the clubs since the National League playoff last year.

PARIS, May 10--Crowds thronged up the big stair case of the Louvre today, past the statue of "Winged Victory" into the Grande Galerie for the greatest event of this year's Paris art season. The occasion is the retrospective exhibition of paintings, drawing and watercolors by Eugene Delacroix, who died here 100 years ago this summer.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- The Republicans put on a party for Senator Barry Goldwater last night, but Gov. George Romney almost stole the show.
Frankie Howerd, the British music-hall and pantomime artist, has been the unwitting cause of some uncomfortable moments on stage at the Alvin Theater.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 (AP) --George Altman hit his first home run of the year with two out in the ninth inning last night. It broke up a brilliant pitching duel between Curt Simmons and Bob Friend and enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to score a 1-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
LONDON, May 10--Conservative party strategists began working overtime today following yesterday's thumping victories by the Labor party in local elections.
The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company reported yesterday gains in gross and net income and gas volume for the first quarter.
Prices of Government securities were mixed yesterday in a sleepy session, Municipals and high-grade corporates also were traded in listless markets.
The battle for the presidency of the powerful 60,000-member International Longshoremen's Association is still in the preliminary stages, waterfront sources said yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 10 (UPI)-- Juan Pizarro combined his first American League homer and a run-scoring single with 3-hit pitching to give the first place Chicago White Sox a 2--0 victory tonight over the Los An geles Angels. It was Chicago's fifth straight victory.
"MY hardest job," said one of the attorneys de fending Negro demonstrators in Birmingham," is to keep Fred Shuttlesworth from talking."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10-- The Baath, the ruling party in Iraq, has assured Syrian Baathists of its full backing in their power struggle with Nasserites.
BRUSSELS, May 10--The conflicting tariff-cutting proposals of France and the United States are expected to raise a storm of controversy during the trade talks that begin in Geneva Thursday.
The investigation here into graft in the administration of the state's liquor laws has caused repercussions in the nearby suburbs and in a few upstate cities and rural counties.
A Negro-owned financial institution, the Carver Federal Savings and Loan Association, has received Federal approval to open a branch in the Penn Station South urban-renewal project.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 10--Christopher J. Devine, one of the nation's leading dealers in United States Government bonds, died of a heart attack last night while being driven by taxi from New York to his home here in Oak Bend, Llewellyn Park. He was 58 years old.

GEORGETOWN. British Guiana, May 10 (AP)--Prime Minister Cheddi B. Jagan charged tonight that a plot was in the making to overthrow his Government by force. He said he would take every step necessary to thwart it.

NEW HAVEN, May 10-- Seventeen Yale University students were arrested early today after a student demonstration that spilled from the campus toward the downtown business district. All were released on bond of $100 each for appearance later in Circuit Court.
Legislation increasing the city's retail sales tax from 3 to 4 per cent, effective June 1, was signed last night by Mayor Wagner. The estimated yield of the increase is $106,100,000 a year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 10 --Gustav V. Karlson, former development engineer for the Elizabeth, N.J., division of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, died of a heart ailment yesterday in Mount Auburn Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Belmont, Mass.

A 71--YEAR--OLD grandmother whose benign smile and gentle manner conceal one of the most uncompromising minds in the child care field has stepped down from a post that was created for her during World War II. She is Cornelia Goldsmith, and for nearly 20 years she has been director of the Division of Day Care, Day Camps and Institutions of the New York City Department of Health.
CUMBERLAND, Md., May 10--The vanguard of 266 entries for Cumberland's 11th annual national championship sports car races checked in and practiced today on the 1.6-mile airport course.
LISBON, May 10--The seven countries of the European Free Trade Association agreed today to achieve complete free trade in non-farm products at the end of 1966.
More history, more noise, more signs and more success were made last night by the Mets and their uninhibited supporters at the Polo Grounds.

The International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots is batting 500 in its dispute with the Association of Maritime Officers over officer personnel representation on two dry cargo ships. The association is an affiliate of the National Marine Engineers Beneficial Association.

FRENCH opera, something of a moribund creature in these parts, looked very much alive last night at the Manhattan School of Music. Gounod's "Mireille" was produced by the school's opera theater in what was probably the work's first performance in New York for many decades.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)--The Army announced today that its reorganization of the National Guard and Reserve had been completed May 1, a month ahead of schedule.

BOSTON, May 10--W.R. Grace Co. held its annual meeting here today for the first time because of its many New England stockholders. Its Dewey and Almy Chemical division operates seven plants with more than 1,600 employes in Massachusetts.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- Justice Department officials hailed the settlement of the Birmingham racial dispute as "a tremendous step forward for Birmingham, for Alabama and for the South generally."
WHITE PLAINS, May 10-- A suit to prevent the construction of Interstate Highway 87 along a controversial route through northeastern Westchester was on file in State Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- Rene Chalmers, Foreign Minister of Haiti, assured Secretary of State Dean Rusk today that his Government would not oppose the return to Port-auPrince of a fact-finding commission of the Organization of American States.
The battle over trans-Atlantic air fares presented a picture of confusion yesterday, with the day of decision set for tomorrow.

Both Peking and Moscow have provided new evidence of the strained relations between their ruling Communist parties. Peking was almost insulting in the casual way it replied to the long and closely reasoned Soviet note of last March 30.

FORT WORTH, May 10 (AP) --Julius Boros, the former National Open golf champion whose last tournament victory came here in 1960, putted brilliantly today for a 4-under par 66 and took the lead after 36 holes in the $60,000 Colonial National Invitation tournament.
LAKE EYRE, Australia, May 10 (Reuters)--Donald Campbell has selected a surrealist landscape of whitened camel bones, parched land and dust for his latest attempt on the world land speed record.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- State Department prose, like a garden, "is a lovesome thing, God wot," and the noon briefing for reporters today produced a rare bloom.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 10 --The police clashed repeatedly with Negro students today in the third sucessive day of demonstrations against segregation at two Nashville restaurants.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 10 --Zalman Shazar of the Mapai party and Dr. Peretz Bernstein of the Liberals were formally entered today as candidates for election as Israel's third President. The election of Mr. Shazar, a member of the World Zionist Executive in Jerusalem, is assured.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 10 --Howard L. Davis, a vocational counselor, died yesterday in his home at 194 Inwood Avenue in Upper Montclair. He was 85 years old.
CHICAGO, May 10 (UPI)-- Old May wheat closed weak and other grain futures were narrowly mixed today on the Board of Trade, Soybeans were firm.
BALTIMORE, May 10--The unit-rule in elections was banished today from Maryland the last state to retain the system.

MOUNT TABOR, N.J., May 10--Robert Allen Hickerson, who supervised production for the Silk Branch Agency of the United States Occupation Forces in Japan, died yesterday at Passavant Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 44 years old.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 10--For the second morning in a row there was no disturbance today as 28-unregistered Negro children attended class in the virtually all-white Cleveland School. The few parents who took their children to the school did not linger, and only one policeman was in sight.
MOSCOW, May 10--The Chinese Communist offer to send a high-level delegation to Moscow for ideological talks in mid-June instead of this month appears to have caught the Soviet leadership by surprise.

BARCELON A, Spain, May 9 --This bustling Mediterra nean city has a complex. Its complex is Madrid. But Barcelona, the once turbulent and now thriving capital of Catalonia, also has a hope. Its hope is Europe.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 10 --Harbor improvements on Westchester's coast costing $921,000 were proposed to Federal officials today by Larchmont, Mamaroneck Village, Mamaroneck Town, Rye City and Port Chester.
The Columbia Broadcasting System's policy on color television was spelled out yesterday for the network's affiliates.
PARIS, May 10--Tonight's opening of "A Man for All Seasons" at the Theatre National Populaire ends an important phase in the history of the French theater.
SILVERSTONE, England, May 10--The first important auto grand prix of the season will be raced here tomorrow, and as usual, no one is really ready.
At least a dozen nations will participate in a program exchange that will be seen on the Columbia Broadcasting System in this country and on 208 stations abroad.
Stock prices showed small gains at the close yesterday after a late rally erased morning losses.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) --President Kennedy, a seafarer of long standing, proudly showed off his collection of ship models today to a group organizing a 1964 rendezvous of old-time sailing vessels.
Charles F. Kraft, a vice president of the United States Lines, died of cancer yesterday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 55 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

THE sign over the window reads "Lola's French Sweets." It is the only indication that in the basement store at 167 West 74th Street some of the finest chocolates and unusual glazed nuts in town are made and sold.

BUENOS AIRES, May l0-- President Jose Maria Guido's civilian rule was challenged by the military again today when Gen. Enrique Rauch, the Interior Minister, demanded the dismissal of four civilians in the Cabinet.

PARIS, May 10--The United States is pressing its European allies for general cooperation, not simply West German cooperation, in the building of a nuclear force for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

The German mark improved again in trading on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday, following heavy buying of marks in Germany. Sub stantial investment activity in the German stock exchanges probably was an important factor in the demand for the Ger man currency.

This week marked the 150th anniversary of City Hall, one of the precious gems of our architectural heritage. But leading architects in the city and state wished that, apart from the appropriate ceremonial flourishes, concern had been voiced for its future as a great esthetic landmark.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 10 --Greater Birmingham's retail sales, which ordinarily total $1,000,000,000 a year have been sharply reduced as a result of a long Negro boycott.
A Federal Bankruptcy Court referee yesterday granted a sixth adjournment in hearings on the reorganization of the American-flag shipping empire of Manuel E. Kulukundis.

The proposed "decapitation" of the fourth floor of Washington Heights Branch Library was protested yesterday by a neighborhood group that has been trying to obtain use of the floor as a teen-age center.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- Malcolm X, the Eastern leader of the Black Muslim movement, denounced today the use of Negro children in the Birmingham demonstrations.
Sharply higher sugar futures led the advance of most New York commodities yesterday.

KOTABARU, West Irian May 5--Indonesia's hopes of bringing more than 400,000 Papuans of West Irian from the Stone Age to the 20th century will continue to depend in large measure on the efforts of Christian missionaries.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10--Secretary General U Thant has asked the General Assembly for authority to continue the United Nations force in the Congo through 1963 at a strength tapering off to 6,700 men by Oct. 1.
Foreign competitors are taking business away from North Americans in Mexico without really trying, according to a consensus of trade-mission views presented yesterday.
Cotton futures were unchanged to $1.40 a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
NEWTON, Mass., May 10 (AP)--A Yale University professor said today that much American theater was "commonplace, nervous and jerrybuilt."

The argument that "a moderate degree of inflation," like a small dose of medicine, is a good thing holds no allure for Dr. Marcus Nadler, the economist.

YONKERS, May 10--Virus Infection among horses stabled at Yonkers raceway continued to mount today and tonight. No actual count of the number of standardbreds affected was available, but one source said that at least a dozen had developed coughing spells.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 10 --Southern Baptists drew their annual convention to a close here today with their ranks ruffled but not rent.

Three compositions, spanning three decades of modern dance, were presented last night at the Juilliard Concert Hall for the benefit of the Dance Scholarship Fund of the Juilliard School of Music. I have listened to the arguments on the pending local law increasing the sales tax from 3 per cent to 4 per cent. I had studied all these arguments even before I proposed the sales tax increase as part of the tax program for which we asked authorization from the State Legislature in March.

Great American Industries, Inc., showed a loss of $3,119,772 last year, in contrast to a profit of $366,397 or 6 cents a share earned in 1961, the company's annual report disclosed yesterday.
Judging by the current theatrical season, musical impresarios are saying that now is the time for all good women lyricists and composers to come to the aid of Broadway.
Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba believes that the United States has "taken some steps in the way of peace" in its relations with Cuba and that these might be the basis of better relations.
GENEVA, May 10--The United States rejected today the Soviet view that the 17-nation disarmament conference here was a "waste of time."

WASHINGTON, May 10--Unemployment among the nation's youth is already critical and if it continues to be neglected it could develop into one of the most explosive social problems in United States history, a, high Labor Department official said today.

IT is a pity the Royal Ballet waited so long in its season here to introduce "The Invitation" by Kenneth MacMillan, which was given its first New York performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It is not only better than any of the novelties the company has presented thus far; it is a good work by any standard.

A reorganization and salary changes to enable the City Commission on Human Rights "to attract and keep top-quality professionals" were announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Commission Chairman Stanley H. Lowell.

As Prime Minister Pearson meets with President Kennedy in a cordial atmosphere at Hyannis Port to discuss major problems between Canada and the United States, he could point to evidence of his country's economic and political resurgence. One such indication is the Bank of Canada's reduction in its discount rate from 4 per cent to 3.5 per cent.
ST. LOUIS, May 10--A neurosurgeon from Utah reported today that he had successfully treated patients with serious mental illnesses by using an ultrasonic beam to perform brain "surgery."
BOISE, Idaho, May 10--The Acting Governor of Idaho has signed the controversial loyalty oath that is binding on all state employes.

LISA HOWARD'S exclusive interview with Dr. Fidel Castro, Premier of Cuba, was an enterprising accomplishment on the part of the distaff member of the American Broadcasting Company's news department. If on past occasions some of her journalistic energies have taxed the patience of both her professional colleagues and viewers, in this instance, Miss Howard was becomingly businesslike and straightforward.

The Adams and Carnegie Cup races command chief interest among five regattas that will furnish final tests today for heavyweight crews preparatory to next week's sprint championships of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges.

The Murchison-dominated board of the Allegheny Corporation has called a meeting for May 20 to act upon a recapitalization plan for Investors Diversified Services despite the indicataed opposition of Allan P. Kirby, Alleghany's largest stockholder.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- A top-level review of the balance-of-payments problem has resulted in a decision by the Government not to take major new measures now.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)--Executives of the General Dynamics Corporation have sworn they had no advance knowledge that they would win the disputed TFX warplane contract.
Ernest Katz, who retired in 1943 as controller of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., died yesterday in the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was 80 years old and lived at 305 West End Avenue.

PARIS, May 10--Europe's most interesting and most ironic current development is the journey of certain Gaullist strategic ideas across the Channel, where they seem to be taking root despite the persisting Anglo-French diplomatic quarrel.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- The Senate Republican Policy Committee questioned today the high priority now given to the program to put Americans on the moon.
A sampling of audits made in Albany over the last two years has disclosed that 274 municipal officials or employes violated conflict-of--interest statutes.
WASHINGTON, May 10--Retail store sales got a minus sign on the economic report card for April.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 10 --A full agreement on a limited desegregation package plan apparently brought an end today to this city's five-week racial crisis.
MONTREAL, May 10 (AP) --Gordie Howe added another National Hockey League record to his collection today when he was named the league's most valuable player for a sixth time.

TRENTON, May 10--Gov. Richard J. Hughes's $34,700,000 tax package became bogged down in the State Senate tonight. Final action was put off to Monday after the upper house had offered amendments to reduce the package by $13,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- The new Republican National Committeewoman from New York State is scheduled to be Mrs. Dorothy McHugh of New York City. She is the wife of Keith S. McHugh, New York State Commissioner of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- President Kennedy and Canadian Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson agreed today to have their labor secretaries try to settle a bitter interunion controversy that has threatened to tie up much Great Lakes shipping.

THE entry for the Long Island Kennel Club dog show at the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L. I., next Sunday, is 1,138, which is 155 dogs more than last year.

THE Garden Club of America in session last week for its 50th Anniversary Meeting honored eight distinguished horticultural leaders with medals, A special Citation was presented to Miss Rachel Carson, author of "Silent Spring" for service in the cause of conservation.

WASHINGTON, May 12-- The best way to get on a committee these days is to strike up an acquaintanceship with Henry H. Fowler, Under Secretary of the Treasury. Mr. Fowler qualifies as the town's leading inspirer of committees.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 12 --Extraordinary putting helped Jim Tingley win the 53d Walter J. Travis Memorial golf final today. Tingley beat Ken Gordon of the Montclair Golf Club, 2 and 1, after sinking four putts of 30 feet or more on the Garden City Golf Club course.

The virus epidemic among harness horses that raged through Buffalo, closed Brandywine and recently hit Yonkers has slowed down the normal inter-track traffic in the East.

Joseph H. Cohen, a retired textile manufacturer, who for the last 20 years worked with young people through the National Jewish Welfare Board, died yesterday in his home at 25 East 77th Street. His age was 73.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 12--Gov. George C. Wallace told President Kennedy tonight that "we have sufficient state and local forces" to handle the situation in Birmingham and asked him to leave the entire matter to the state and local governments.

QUITE the smash hit of London's television season has been the Saturday-evening program "That was the Week That Was," the first TV presentation anywhere to offer sharp political satire as a regular diet.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 12--Several hundred townsfolk turned out today for an open house at the new New Canaan Nature Center. The 40-acre property on Oneoke Ridge was for many years the summer home of Miss Susan D. Bliss. She gave it to the town three years ago with a stipulation that it be used as a park for "passive recreation."

WATERBURY, Conn., May 12--Temple Beth-El was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Diane Cassel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Cassel, to Howard Weinreich. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Weinreich of Jamaica, Queens.

AKRON, Ohio, May 12 (AP) --Members of the big United Rubber Workers Local 2 voted today to call a meeting to reconsider a contract with the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. The contract had been voted down previously.

Lawrence B. Karter, realty investor, has sold the two fivestory buildings at 643-45 Ninth Avenue, northwest corner of 45th Street, to the Eastview Realty Corporation. ROME, May 12--Aldo Moro, Secretary General of the Christian Democratic party, is emerging as a strong candidate to succeed Amintore Fanfani as Premier of Italy.

Hostility between the White House and the business community has faded, along with doubts about the business outlook. Yet the new look in the economy has not brought any change in their conflicting views.

Major changes will take place today in the top management of the McCrory Corporation, parent comgany of the McCroryMcLellan-Green Stores, which operates variety stores throughout the country.

Edward Steuermann was honored last night by the Juilliard School of Music. The school, where he has taught the piano since 1952, presented him as both a performer and a composer.

James G. Bellows has been appointed editor of The New York Herald Tribune John Hay Whitney, editor in chief and publisher, announced yesterday.
Wilhelmine S. Oetjen, an elementary school teacher here for half a century, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Wickersham Hospital. She was 76 years old.
LONDON, May 14--Prime Minister Macmillan declared today that Britain was opposed to the use or threat of force in the Middle East.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Wednesday, May 15--The attempt to launch Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. on a 22-orbit, dayand-a-half space flight was rescheduled last night for this morning after a radar breakdown in Bermuda had been corrected.
The election of James E. Dingman as a director of the Empire Trust Company was announced yesterday. He is executive vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Though an error in editing, Rudolf Nureyev was described in The New York Times yesterday as a former dancer of the Bolshoi Ballet. Mr. Nureyev was a member of the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad until his defection in Paris on June 16, 1961.

SEOUL, Korea, May 14--The Civil Rule party, a major civilian opposition group, was inaugurated today at a convention here. It is the first political party organized by former politicians in opposition to the present military regime.
The Life Office Management Association has leased most of the 14th floor in the new 27story ofice building nearing completion at 757 Third Avenue, ...
Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon stole the show at the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company's annual meeting here yesterday, and he wasn't even there.

ABERDEEN, Scotland, May 14 (AP)--Barbara Cummings finally presented her carpenter husband with a boy today--and added three more daughters. Her quadruplets were born five weeks prematurely by Caesarean section and put into incubators. The family has two sets of twins, all girls.
Two industrial giants announced changes yesterday in top management positions.

ALBANY, May 14 (AP)-- The commander of the New York National Guard denied today charges by a member of Congress and a veterans organization that there was a pattern of segregation in the New York Guard.

The Transit Authority placed 2,000 men's and women's umbrellas on the auction block yesterday. They were sold for an average of 35 cents each.
In a forthcoming ad campaign, the United Fruit Company recommends that packers bottle-feed their bananas.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)--Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said today the nuclear ship Savannah would be immobilized for four to six months because of a labor dispute that will make it necessary to train new engineers.

Everything was propitious for Faith 7, America's most ambitious venture for orbiting a man into space. The weather was perfect over the vast stretches of the Atlantic and the Pacific. Astronaut Cooper, the Air Force officer who ...

OTTAWA, May 14 (Canadian Press)--George J. McIlraith, Minister of Transport, is expected to head a team of aviation experts in a new bid to get a better deal for Canada on air routes into the United States, a reliable source said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 14-- United Arab Republic troops have been moved into as well as out of Yemen in the last two weeks despite Cairo's promise to reduce its involvement in Yemen's civil war.

A defense of language laboratories in the public secondary schools was made yesterday in reply to criticism of the laboratories in a report by the Institute of Administrative Research at Teachers College, Columbia University.
The Transit Authority served notice yesterday that motorists occupying exclusive bus lanes to be established on Monday in Brooklyn and Staten Island would be summarily dealt with.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 14 (UPI)--The officers of the United States aircraft carrier Coral Sea denied today reports that 250 to 300 men had missed the ship when it sailed from Sydney yesterday.
The 1963 camp appeal of the Salvation Army for $75,000 began Monday and will continue until July 1, the organization announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 14--A Presidential emergency board made public today its recommendations for settling the long, bitter dispute over railroad work rules.
A "super-hot oven" for testing metals that may be used in the heat shields for future spacecraft has been designed and built by the MartinMarietta Corporation, Baltimore.
A Federal Communications Commission official warned the New York Board of Regents yesterday that if it did not soon use 10 ultra-high-frequency television channels assigned to it, it might lose them.
LOS ANGELES, May 14-- Jim Beatty, America's premiere distance runner, threatened today to boycott Friday night's Los Angeles Coliseum Relays, America's premiere outdoor invitation track meet.
Col. and Mrs. Marcus H. Ray of Chicago have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adine Victoria Ray, to Samuel C. Usher Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Usher of Atlanta.

LONDON, May 14--Trade ministers from the Commonwealth wound up a two-day meeting here today declaring that a solution to the economic problems of developing countries was vital to the expansion of world trade.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 14 --Mr. and Mrs. Colby M. Chester 3d have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clare Chester, to Alexander Gortchacow. He is the son of Prince and Princess Michel Gortchacow of Buenos Aires.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 14 --An attempt to solve problems of discrimination here has been started by a newly formed committee of seven clergymen.
The Organization of American States is now having to take the type of abuse that the United Nations sometimes gets.

TORONTO (Canadian Press) May 14--The Toronto Stock Exchange and one of its governors were accused today of a conspiracy that was intended to remove the governor's main competittion from put and call brokerage.
MOSCOW, May 14--Premier Khrushchev failed to break the impasse in the negotiations for a nuclear test ban treaty in his latest message to President Kennedy, a well-informed source said today.
POMPTON LAKES, N.J., May 14 (AP)--Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Epstein have a surprise awaiting them when they get back from Israel: they've just won a trip to Israel.

Lake Underwood's return to racing after a four-year absence, Bob Johnson's clearcut victory in an AC Cobra and Roger Penske's continuing success with his ZerexClimax Special marked the 11th annual national sports car meeting at Cumberland, Md., last weekend.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 14--Industrial production in Eastern Europe, including the Soviet Union, more than tripled from 1950 through 1961, the United

NEW DELHI, India, May 14 --Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the Pakistani Foreign Minister, took a lukewarm position here tonight on a proposal by the United States and Britain that his country and India resort to mediation by a third party in their dispute over Kashmir.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 14 --Thirteen Princeton University students were found guilty in Magistrate's Court today on charges arising out of the riot of students May 6.
Irving Davis of 75 East 21st Street, Brooklyn, head of the advertising agency bearing his name at 151 West 51st Street, died yesterday at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. His age was 61.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 14--Chattanooga will become the 75th among the 104 municipal distributors of Tennessee Valley Authority power to reduce retail rates below the basic level, T.V.A. officials announced today. Seven rural cooperatives have also reduced rates.

An executive of the Advertising Research Foundation urged advertisers yesterday to set specific profit goals for their ad campaignsand to step up efforts to measure the impact of advertising on corporate earnings.
MILWAUKEE, May 14 (AP) --The Milwaukee Braves defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4--3, tonight as Warren Spahn gained his 332d National League victory.
The United States and Great Britain, who made polo history in competition for the famed Westchester Cup from 1886 through 1939, will renew their rivalry here this year after a lapse of 24 years.
The Sonotone Corporation announced yesterday development of a new phonograph needle that is said to be virtually unbreakable.

Rear Adm. James W. Davis, U.S.N., commander of the United States Naval Base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, and Mrs. Davis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nina Elizabeth Davis, to Wayne Edgar King.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J. May 14, --The Negro sit-in at the nearly all-white Cleveland School moved quietly through its seventh day today.
The Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Company is offering 200,000 new shares at $27 each through a group headed by Hornblower Weeks and Robert W. Baird Co.
Seven four-story apartment buildings at 1522 to 1532 Charlotte Street, between Jennings Street and Vyse Avenue, in the Bronx, have been sold by the Tove Management Corporation ...
J.J. Newberry Company, variety and department-store chain, omitted yesterday the dividend on the common stock usually declared at this time for payment on July 1.
Wall Street brokers said yesterday they detected some quickening of customer interest in over-the-counter stocks, but that buying was concentrated in quality issues that pay dividends.
The church is one of the "most segregated careers in our society," a committee on clergy placement reported yesterday to the annual meeting of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

ROCHESTER, May 14 (AP) --The director of the Monroe County public safety laboratory said today he had discovered lethal amounts of lead in blue dishware known to have been purchased in Juarez, Mexico.
DIAMONDS are not a girl's best friend. This proposition--heresy to some--has been advanced by a tall, Swedish woman with light brown hair and slanting eyes the color of the Baltic sea.
JACKSON, Miss., May 14 (UPI)--A clergyman who served as a Freedom Rider testified today that the Protestant Episcopal Church supported eight of nine Communist party recommendations on race relations.
Documentary evidence allegedly implicating Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re and his son, Gerard F., in a stock fraud conspiracy was introduced at their trial yesterday in Federal Court.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 14 (UPI)--Officials at Saratoga Raceway said tonight that at least 100 horses have come down with a "mysterious virus," which appears to be spreading throughout eastern tracks.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 --The National League for Nursing announced today the election of Lois M. Austin, acting chairman of the department of nursing education at the University of Pittsburgh, as president.
ALBANY, May 14--New York residents 65 years old or older will have another opportunity to obtain hospital and medical insurance without an examination from June 1 to 15.
A master contract covering 5,000 nonmedical workers in 100 nursing homes was signed yesterday in Mayor Wagner's office at City Hall.
Two new champions, representing Long Island and New Jersey were installed as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches were concluded yesterday.
The radio and television networks will carry out their original plans for covering the launching of Maj. L. Gordon Cooper's orbital flight today.
The presidents of the two leading stock exchanges voiced over-all support for President Kennedy's tax reduction and reform program yesterday with ...

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) --Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, made a new appeal today for legislation to overcome what he termed the deplorable lack of uniformity in the use of daylight time.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)--Officials of the movie industry conferred today with Government representatives in what was described as exploratory talks about economic problems plaguing Hollywood.
